column10: literally the most shittiest game I've ever played. This game was running fine a few months ago. Then you decide to screw it up and make the game even buggier than it ever was. Frame drops EVERYWHERE . Literally the most unplayable game ever. CONGRATULATIONS EA

Getting towards the end of the story as of writing, and I'm very satisfied with it. Gameplay is mostly good, with some issues better shown through clips or the many videos available online. the major sticking point is the performance - however, i have managed to run this on 1600x900 using an RX570. It crashes mostly on Koboh, the largest of the explorable areas, but my GPU does not meet the minimum requirements to run the game. Will try and remember to come back and amend this review after upgrading the GPU within the next few months. 

Story: 8/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Performance: 5/10 (didn't expect to be able to run it at all until after upgrading gpu so my opinion is skewed here)

This game was phenomenal bar the random performance issues after the most recent patch. The game ran seamlessly on my gaming laptop for the first 40 hrs but after a recent patch started playing extremely laggy in the open world sections of the game. Regardless of that, the narrative told was amazing, the combat was fun, and expanded on the combat from the first game in a few nice ways. There was a bit of a lull near the start of the game in my opinion, but once you reach midway through the game, it is incredibly engaging and hard to put down. I 100%d it in 46hrs.

I originally criticized this game for performance and optimization issues (as did everyone). It's gotten better, but regrettably not to the point that it should. Still though, excellent story, characters, worlds, and about 50 hours of gameplay if you're a completionist. Plus NG+, which I've come back to after a long hiatus. I hope game 3 in the saga is optimized from the start so we can focus on the game and not whether it will run properly.

This is one of the best games I have played in a while. I heard about issues on release so I waited to play it and had no difficulties and encountered few bugs. They actually outdid themselves, which is saying a lot because the original game, Fallen Order, was a great experience. I was expecting more of the same, which I'd welcome, but there were many moments where I was just in awe. Beautiful art and music and story. I play games almost every evening and found the combat very challenging on the normal setting, and I can't imagine most kids completing a lot of the puzzles unaided. I have played 34 hours and am considering exploring further. I keep finding impressive puzzles and new bounty hunters.

Game is pretty great over all and if you like the fallen order you will like this. It is an improvement over past game in almost everything except maybe performance. 

The game is no where near the disaster state many claim it to be but there are issues and considering my pc is not the best but quite alright, I can see how people will less powerful rigs can have problems. My game mostly runs fine with some very smaller stutter from time to time but it to so brief and rare that it legit don't even matter. 

The game does have odd blurr to it though and that is my only complaint. When you trying to change Cal's looks and whole thing is just looking like it got bloom and perma motion blurr cranked to 11 even on epic graphic settings. 

Besides all that, combat, story, acting, exploration, customization are some of the best we ever had in Star Wars games.

I'm ultimately going to recommend this as a half price or less purchase.

I remember when random aliens in Star Wars didn't speak English. It's things like that slipping from the Star Wars galaxy that best illustrate the problems with this game. It stutters and every once in a while it throws a big white polygon onto the screen which I think is because of not loading in a bit of graphic when it should have. It's cheap with the combat and doesn't feel like a an accomplishment so much as just the game is input reading, and cheating player skill. Most everything in the game just seems a little off the mark. Ignoring the stuttering, and glitching from time to time this would otherwise be a visual tour-de-force with an amazingly detailed world to explore. You can do a lot worse for $30-$40.

The gameplay was buggy, even a year following release they still haven't fixed the stuttering issues.  

The story was terrible.  I loved the first game and the story, but the changes to the characters and their stories is just terrible.

Great game. But I spent untold hours trying to get the game to recognize my ps4 controller, which just stopped being recognized by the game after many hours of play. I tried everything. Very disappointed in EA. Won't buy from them again.
The combat, the story, the exploration, are all great. it is a great game, it is fun and challenging,

I have literately the most capable gaming computer the money could buy, yet the game kept crashing because of bad memory management and overloading the my RTX-4090 GPU with horrible ray tracing. Also, the saving sucks because every time the game crashed I lost all my progress since the last checkpoint! The map could be much better in terms of navigation. For a game that is this expensive IT SHOULD have been tested and fixed so much more! Sometimes levels would just load badly and would lag so bad I had to kill the game and reopen it which every time reopening the app takes a few minutes! This was an amazing game, story, design, graphics, everything was great! Yet I would not recommend it unless these issues are resolved.

"Star Wars Jedi: Survivor" is a fantastic follow-up to "Fallen Order," taking the best parts of the first game and making them even better. 

It's a big step up from "Fallen Order," offering a much larger world to explore.
The fighting, moving around, and graphics have all gotten better.
The story is deep and emotional, adding new depth to the Star Wars stories we know.

Because the game is bigger, sometimes it feels a bit slow or dragged out, also ray tracing had to be turned off to stop game crashing every 5 min.

The story picks up five years after "Jedi: Fallen Order." Cal Kestis, the main character, has grown from his previous adventures, making him stronger and more confident. This growth shows in his fighting skills and the use of Force powers right from the start, making battles more exciting.

The game's world feels more alive than ever, with stunning places to see and lots of details that make it feel real. An interesting new area is Koboh, a planet that reminds you of the Wild West, filled with unique characters and challenges.

However, the game's large size can be a bit much at times, with so many places to explore that it sometimes feels overwhelming. Despite this, the mix of characters and their stories keep you hooked, showing different sides of the galaxy during a tough time.

Fighting in the game is more fun, with new ways to use your lightsaber and Force powers. This makes each battle feel fresh and exciting. Moving around the game world is also better, with Cal feeling more agile and able to do more from the very beginning.

Even with its few issues, "Star Wars Jedi: Survivor" does a great job of building on what made "Fallen Order" good. It offers a deep and engaging story, better gameplay, and a rich world that feels new and exciting. Cal Kestis' journey continues to impress, making this one of the best Star Wars games out there.

I really wanted to fully enjoy this game, but I cannot recommend it on PC.

To discuss the game, regardless of console, I was not a huge fan of the side quests, or "rumors". They did not feel like they added anything important to the game, and the exploration felt similarly. Most of the loot you can find of the beaten path are cosmetics, which I personally do not find much fulfillment in. I'm also not sure if I was too fond of the metroidvania world, which sees you returning to various planets over and over again with the option to revisit and explore previously locked areas. I really feel as though this would have been more effective as a right linear game with some puzzles and platforming elements. Furthermore, the shortcuts you unlock along the way definitely feel forced, rather than clever, and make the previous obstacles feel like they were put there to squeeze more time out of the game.

The combat was also disappointing. The parry system, while very satisfying when it worked, does not really prepare you for the challenges thrown at you, and thus does not go far in making you feel like a badass jedi. I never really felt excited to spend the skill points I unlocked because the skills are very underwhelming, with basic force pushes and pulls, and various minor new combat moves. Additionally, the enemies vary VASTLY in difficulty, which leads to some incredibly frustrating encounters. For example, one mini-boss I found about halfway through the game was easily the most difficult fight in the whole game, though only because its moveset and attacks were extremely difficult to dodge and could one-hit kill you if they landed. This leads into the overarching problem with the game's combat. As this is commonly referred to as a 'Soulslike', you can easily reminisce about memorable fights FromSoft's various difficult games, where tight controls and responsive feedback means that when you die, it's on you. In Jedi Survivor, however, many fights can feel incredibly frustrating, like you're constantly fighting the controls to overcome an obstacle rather than finding harmony with them. For context, I have played many incredibly difficult action RPGs like Sekiro, Elden Ring, and Dark Souls 3 to completion, so I am very conscious of what good controls feel like.

The performance is also ABYSMAL. I went into this game with low expectations due to reading many reviews, but nothing could prepare me for the absolutely embarrassing optimization. My rig is as follows:

Monitor: 3440 x 1440p
GPU: RTX 4080 16GB VRAM
CPU: i7-14700KF ~3.4Ghz
RAM: 32GB

Even though I'm running a high-end rig, I was expecting to be unable to run this with raytracing enabled, but many moments made me wonder if I should have turned the settings down. Constant stuttering and frame hitching absolutely marred the experience, constantly dragging me out and preventing me from suspending disbelief. Performance decreased the longer the game ran, to the point where restarting the game would restore a decent framerate. Unfortunately, not mods or fixes exist as the issue is purely with development. These development issues bled out into the gameplay as well, with many cutscenes having graphical bugs and some execution animations occurring 15 feet off the ground. 

Finally, having to launch this through the EA app topped off the horrible experience. To get my Dualsense Edge controller working, I had to add the EA app as a non-steam game, and then launch the EA app through Steam. Otherwise, controller input was not detected. I tried many different controller configurations but was unable to get any working other than this. 

To summarize, this port is a complete embarrassment for EA, and a huge detractor for Respawn, developers of the incredible TitanFall and TitanFall 2. Yes, there were some awesome moments, and yes I did enjoy parts of the gameplay, but the consistent gameplay and performance issues made fully exploring and realizing the open-world utterly unenjoyable. I would not recommend this for anyone on PC, regardless of specs. I would also not really recommend this game period. The pacing, side quests, and gameplay were a huge turnoff that added a lot of filler, and not enough memorable content. 

NOTE: I do not typically write reviews for games, even ones that I don't enjoy, but this is beyond unbelievable for the $70 price tag. If I had not gotten this on sale at 50% off, I would be incredibly upset with my purchase, more so than I am now. EA can afford to produce something better, and it's sickening that this is how they treat their consumers.

Man, I really want to love this game. In fact, I do kind of love this game. I love the world, the music, the ambience, the gameplay, the customization, literally every new thing this game brought about is amazing and every aspect they refined from the first one is, in fact, refined. There's just one major issue: the game runs like dogsh i t. It's unstable and lowering graphics settings seems to have minimal effect on the frame rate. The game is just poorly optimized for PC and it's such a damn shame. I have a ryzen 9 5th gen, an RTX 3070, and 16 gigs of RAM. The game's minimum is 8 gigs with recommended 16 gigs, but when I play it never gets to 7 gigs of RAM usage, so that's not my bottleneck. I play on an SSD, my thermals are good, my machine should be MORE THAN CAPABLE of running this game. But it just simply cannot. That also rules out the steamdeck.

Poorly optimized. Game drops frames even in the desert section when you'd think a barren level with a few enemies off in the distance wouldn't take much to render. Even the holomap on the ship drops to 5fps at 1080p with a 4060 and 32 GB of ram. My CPU is a Ryzen 5 3600. It is old but it can handle cyberpunk at 1080p on ultra settings. Search the web and you'll see people with beefy CPUs and top of the line GPUs are still getting frame drops. EA has made it known they don't care about making this game optimized. I got this on a sale and the story is good but for full price I can't recommend this. Get it on a deep sale.

6/10 at current state
+ 
Nice story, not a huge epic but a cool addition to the Star Wars lore in times of the galactic empire. Variety of worlds with beautiful sceneries and immersive environment. Entertaining new challenges over the open worlds as Cal unlocks new skills and scaling enemy difficulty make most of the locations interesting even in late game. This made me enjoy the game overall and finish all the worlds to 95-100 %.
- 
Graphics: Terrible optimisation, EA should be really ashamed. Optimisation sequence at every game start seems really unnecesary to me. Being in menu while AFK stressed my GPU to 100 % due to unlocked FPS - like really EA? Tons of useless graphic settings but no FPS lock? Did anyone even test the game menu? Best visuals achieved with FSR but character faces are still blurry and ugly in close shots for some reason. Playing with DLSS or without upscaling made the graphics look like a 2010 game even on the highest grahics settings.
Game mechanics: Clunky combat system, little pauses between combat actions make it literally impossible to avoid hits, no matter how skilled and fast you are. Unnecessary cosmetic content - is it a Star Wars RPG or a hairstyle/gardening simulator? Wouldn't the manhours invested in all this useless boring junk be better spent on development of Cal/BD-1/Mantis/mounts upgrades with an actual impact on gameplay?
Story: [spoiler]Is Darth Vader going to be a part of every Star Wars game no matter how unnecesarry it is? Felt suprising but realistic in Fallen Order in an inquisitor training centre, but here it felt too forced. The end was just pathetic. A child being fine around its fathers' killer? Is Kata a psychopat or what?[/spoiler]

This is probably the best Star Wars game I've played since Disney took over Lucasarts. The characters are well written and relatable making you want to finish the story. I found myself watching cut-scenes with a desire to see what's going to happen to the characters. The story was well written, picking up where Jedi Fallen Order left off. It truly rounded out the main character Cal, adding to his story rather than just having him exist for players to play as. I think one of my favorite parts was how this game kept all the powers Cal learned from the first game, having the player start with them. It was a nice change of pace rather than having the writers try and explain that Cal lost his powers. Without spoiling the game, I will just say the entire game brings Cal through a terrific character arc that very few of the new Star Wars movies and shows have achieved. 

Now that the story is out of the way, on to the game play. As I stated prior, it was nice to play a sequel in a series where the main character did not need to start a square one as far as abilities go. It was fun finding new powers and abilities that built on the old ones and using those to solve new puzzles. The new light saber stances were a welcomed addition and I found myself wanting to try each one to get the full experience; however, I did find one that I enjoyed more than the others and I ended up using that stance the majority of the time. The combat was enjoyable for the vast majority of the game with a few exceptions being legendary enemies that you could encounter early in the game. Luckily those enemies are not necessary to defeat in order to progress the game and a  player can return to them later once they are more powerful. 

The puzzles themselves, while solvable, are challenging this time around. I found many locked paths that had no clear way of how they open. In the end, some of those inaccessible areas were only able to be unlocked when I explored and forgot the area existed. It should be noted, the difficult puzzles are not all necessary to complete the game. In the end I found myself trying to complete all the puzzles, which ended up making me gather every item in the game, making this one of the few games I have ever completed to 100% with all the collectibles. 

On to the bad. This game is not without its faults and most of the issues I have with this game are in the form of glitches and bugs. For example, there is currently a glitch with the sound where dialogue is next to impossible to hear. When I first started the game I saw text on the screen and did not understand why; it wasn't until I saw the characters lips moving that I understood there was actual dialogue taking place. I was able to solve the issue by changing a lot of the sound settings in the game and tweaking settings on my machine. Another glitch came in the form of doors that would not re-open and required exiting the game to solve. Despite these issues I still found the game to be very enjoyable. 

I bought this game and Jedi Fallen Order at the same time when they were both on sale, and I had very little expectation for them both. I was happy to be surprised.

Graphics ‚Äì 8/10
Sound ‚Äì9/10
Gameplay ‚Äì 8/10
Story ‚Äì 8/10
Replayability ‚Äì 7/10

Overall ‚Äì Star Wars Jedi: Survivor has a lot of great upgrades going for it from the previous game Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order. The traversal mechanics feel awesome! The different ways you can grapple, wall run, wall jump, and slide down walls are great, also the Merrin teleport sequences are insanely fun! The additional stances are a welcomed upgrade. I personally went with Crossguard for bosses and rare mobs to make easy work of them and blaster stance for everyone else. This allowed me to experience two very different styles of combat on the fly, the slower/souls style of gameplay and something a bit faster with some mixed in, powerful, ranged stuff. An improvement in the combat all around. The storyline was also very well done, and the exploration felt rewarding and didn‚Äôt drag the game down. Very much looking forward to seeing what they continue to do with this franchise.   Highly Recommended.

You would think that a game that entirely focuses on lightsaber combat, lightsaber combat would be fluid, smooth, and makes you feel like a badass right? Well, that's not really the case here in this game. 

First off, there is no arcade mode. That was the best part of its predecessor, Fallen Order. We can no longer just go into an area and just kill things or face challenges in an arena. This severely cuts down on replayability.

Combat feels so janky, it doesn't make you feel like a jedi at all. There are few boss fights that pose fun challenges, but everything else feels either too easy or annoyingly a little too difficult for fun common enemies. Too many common enemies are unaffected by a lightsaber swing and too many more die from one hit. At least let the lightsaber interrupt their combo if their scrap staff is going to interrupt mine. 

Additionally, the frames do occasionally become an issue, but it's to a point where I can still try to enjoy my janky lightsaber fights. There's also frequent crashes, these issues I would overlook normally if this was in alpha development, but for $60 from EA, this is just disappointing. 

Don't buy this game until they fix the issues.

An overall ok game that, just like the previous iteration, is overshadowed by major flaws. (See my earlier review on SWJ:FO).

First and foremost, the movement and traversal have not changed in the slightest.  Cal still feels floaty and unattached to the ground.  His running and movement are still awkward looking and don't feel natural.  Momentum during traversal gimmicks is still completely unpredictable, and most terrain design makes no sense.  Cal can Jackie Chan his way up only specific surfaces and sprint up 60 degree slopes. However if there's some water on a 45 degree slope it becomes an impassable slip'n'slide.  Enemies continue to appear from rooms with no doors, or in places they have no reason to be, isolated on a platform with no way to have gotten there.  After meeting up with Merrin again, enemies literally burst through a stone wall to come fight you leaving behind a completely otherwise enclosed hollow in the rock.

Combat has been diversified with new stances, which are incredibly satisfying and straight up well designed. But overall combat has become worse.  Every enemy except the basic stormtroopers and B1s are just a spam-fest of attacks and massive damage sponges, even on the easier difficulties.  A B2 battledroid should not take 7+ strikes from a lightsaber to take down.   A major complaint I have of the previous game was Cal's lack of forward motion during lightsaber attacks, allowing enemies to slowly backpedal while you swing at the air.  I'm happy to say I I don't feel this way at all anymore.  However, a new, far worse issue has been programmed in.  The developers have taken the pathetic, lazy design route of implementing "difficulty" by making all but the weakest enemies unreactive to your saber strikes, and arming them with a plethora of unblockable attacks and one hit kills.  That's literally it.  This is 100% of the game's difficulty.  It's that basic and that dumb.  Zero effort to design thoughtful challenge, just enemies with varying immunity to your abilities, playing by a completely different set of rules beyond what's reasonable.

The game is equal parts excellent and frustrating.  I've still stuck around to play it to 100% completion.  I really like the characters and voice acting.  Cal himself has really grown on me and I believe his voice actor did a particularly amazing job.  Sad characters can be very transparent, but Cal is completely natural and believable.   The music is exactly what you'd expect from a Star Wars game.  The style is consistent and there are a few pointed drops of classic song bits.  There's a lot to love, but much of the game still just feels like trash to play.  I still find myself struggling against the game rather than against the enemies and it does not currently leave me with the impression that player feedback was considered on a reasonable scale.   However the implementation of fast travel via meditation points is extremely welcome.  We should have had it in the first game, but at least it's here now.

There are still fundamental flaws in too great a number so i can't leave a positive review once again.  

Here's an example of what I mean when I'm talking about textbook, objective bad game design.  The double Oggdo boss fight.  That's right folks.  The logic of "How do we make the game harder?  Oh, I know, just re-use an old boss and make it a gank!"  Oggdo Bogdo and Spawn of Oggdo do nothing but trade relentless unblockable attacks back and forth in a rhythm which removes the punishment window where you can even hit them back.  They have a grand total of 7 attacks... only 2 of which are blockable.  The aggro'd one attacks while the other tries to constantly one-shot you with the old frog tongue attack.  They have now removed the ability to cut the tongue off because fuck you that's why.  The fight has a timer though it means nothing.  Giving the impression that you need to beat it quickly.  And worst of all, there's no "retry" option, forcing you to endure the death animation, the force tear exit animation, then load back into the world, listen to call say something inane like "Oops that wasn't right", then re enter the force tear with another animation, then load back into the boss fight just to try again.  For a lot of people, that process will be longer than the boss fight attempt.  I struggle to understand the lack of basic game design concept implementation.  Keep the player engaged, limit the time needed to get back into the action after a failure.  The double Oggdo is a tiny diorama/arena battle in a skybox, there's no reason this shouldn't be able to quickly reset without needing to re-load the entire game twice.  Especially after dying because the invisible ceiling around the edge of the arena has again stopped you from jumping out of the way of an attack. 

Oh and all you get is a single kill point for winning. As if the injury necessitated insult.

My overall experience with bugs an general malfunctions was minimal.  No game breaking or long lasting issues occurred.  Cal mysteriously lost the use of the X (square) or Y (triangle) button on one stance from time to time, requiring a complete relaunch of the game, but I believe that was related to my hardware and not the game.

It was a real love/hate with SWJS, just as it was with SWJFO.  I'm sure when the next one comes out I'll dive in again.  I still really want what this series has to offer, I just want it less frustrating.  I still hold the hope that the next instalment will get a positive review from me.

What a great game, story, characters, environment, music score, and everything about the game. I think this is an amazing sequel to a set of games that are truly a blast for Star Wars fans to enjoy an amazing world building experience. I loved all the emotions this game made me feel, besides the frustration of playing on a really hard difficulty. I think the combat is fun and rewarding when you conquer a level, or group of people. Again the story is incredible, I almost cried during some parts and my emotions were a roller coaster., especially towards the end. As of writing this I plan on completing all achievements, but there are so many collectables and things I need to do/explore, I am not looking forward to it. I love all the customization that can be done, one of my favorite things being the opportunity to select different lightsaber stances that promote different play styles. Once I discovered the blaster option, I practically used it all the way until the end of the main story.
I'm so glad I got to play this game, because I had a blast. However, I was not impressed with the frame rates, sometimes it was like I was watching a slideshow. For a game that costs $70 dollars, it's embarrassing that this game hasn't been optimized to run on a gaming PC like the one I own. I can't imagine playing this on a console, my condolences to anyone who has to play it on one. I tried to change my settings to account for the horrible frames at times, but no matter what I did they always would drag. There was also a couple times when my game would crash, despite the fact it was the only thing running on my computer. I also glitched out of the ship once when it was trying to leave for a different planet, so I had to save and exit. Thankfully I didn't lose any progress because of this, but still was a bit worrying.
If there was a way to avoid these crashes or avoid the horrible frames at times, this would be game of the year 2023 for me, but that holds it back. Recommend if you're confident you can avoid lag and horrible frames, and you want an even better Fallen Order.

One of the greatest games of all time. The performance is an issue, but if you turn off ray tracing and put your settings down it can make it manageable. For reference I have a 3080 OC, 5900x OC, 32 gm ram and resizeable bar for vram. I had to put my settings to HIGH and draw distance to medium to get something acceptable that also wouldn't crash my game. The game did crash on me once and stuttered like crazy. Real damn shame

If're a fan of the Star Wars franchise you'll like this. Has more of the feel of the "original trilogy" in my opinion. Cal's journey is really engrossing, the puzzles are fun but challenging. Haven't finished it yet, but not encountered any bugs yet (even though I read a lot about them and it turned me off the game for a while).

Might be the fact that I have a pretty decent rig though.

Highly recommend the game (and of course, they The Fallen Order first!).

I couldn't get my dualshock 4 to work for this game, so i settled for an xbox controller, which was still incredibly broken to use. I don't mind using mouse and keys, but the default controls are quite miserable and the remapping interface is absolutely infuriating to navigate. but once i got that over with, the story is good so far, and the gameplay is a lot of fun. the game could still be optimized quite a bit further, and the process of launching the game takes forever. but if you can get past that, its a pretty solid game otherwise, but i wouldn't pay $70 for it.

I have never been so dissatisfied with a game in my life. Worst money I have ever spent on a game. This game is a technical disaster. Full of bugs and glitches, game mechanics were faulty most of the time. 
The story seemed more like a DLC instead of a sequel. 
It's a shame for Respawn, we all know EA don't care.
With some fixes, this is a wonderful, and beautiful game. Definitely pick it up if you're a Souls and Star Wars fan. It'll scratch the itch.
It is a really good story, very entertaining. game runs well and with great graphics. I recommend to play in hard level as it gives more challenge. I would definitely play it again!

As many of you are aware, this game had major optimization issues on PC. However, as of the recent update, these issues seem to have been resolved, as I only encountered one hard crash and very infrequent stuttering in my entire playthrough. That being said, currently, there is a problem where the PlayStation controllers aren't working - if that concerns you, wait to buy till it gets patched.

Overall the story was excellent, immersive, and entertaining throughout the run. Although some story beats are predictable, there are also multiple unexpected developments. In addition, there are opportunities to further develop relationships with your crew on the Mantis, and meet new interactable NPCs on the various planets. I remember laughing many times during the playthrough.

Gameplay-wise, it's pretty much the same as Jedi Fallen Order. Although mobility is improved, and there are more customization options for combat, if you did not enjoy the previous game, I doubt you'll opinion will change. 

All in all, I recommend this game, especially for a Star Wars fan.
Everything we loved aboutthe first and more!  EA finally getting SW games right!
An improvement in almost every way to the previous game
I got maybe 20 hours into the game, now I get an infinite loading screen and cant do anything. why?
Most performance issues have been fixed (I have a rtx 2070 super, played the game on max settings at 1440p with DLSS and had around 60 FPS constantly). It's one of the best Star Wars games in years.

Needs more polish for smooth frames. Needs better load times, sometimes it just freezes. Worse of all I purchased the deluxe edition and can't access the customization items that come with it. If you charge someone extra for something, then they need to be able to access that something! (2024 update)- old problems fixed and good casual fun now

I completed the game in about 100 hours (story, collecting, achievements, etc). Personally I liked the plot with the twist they included. It follows Star Wars lore. As for gameplay, it takes place over multiple worlds so there is various environments to explore. They give a short recap of the previous game using a video, so overall you don't need to know the prior game plot. To honor the plot, Cal does have access to single and double lightsaber stance at the start with additional stances to be unlocked throughout the game. As for collecting everything, later in the story you can unlock maps that show the specific locations so its a mix of collect as you go and handle on later. 

At this point in time, the game is very demanding in regards to performance. The graphics are beautiful and detailed, but you need a mid to high-end GPU for a decent framerate. The recommended requirements should be the minimal requirements. Eventually it will become the norm as time pass, but it may be awhile.

I'm somewhere mid game. 
Okay, I don't see why this game is at 'mixed reviews' other than it being an EA title. 
-performance, bugginess far and above better than the first game, though still not perfect. Running this game on a two year old laptop with an A3000 workstation graphics card, which is kind of mid range, and it's fine, in my opinion. It hasn't crashed on me once. I don't have ray tracing enabled and it's still beautiful. 
TIP: They were lazy setting up the control scheme for keyboard + mouse. I made only one change, swap Tab and Ctrl so you your hand doesn't instantly cramp up. I've found that's all I needed.
-graphics are great, improving on what was in the first in the series
-art is great, lots of beautiful locations and great star wars frontier/ ancient ruins art
-combat + platforming action are all there from the first game with some new additions and improvements
-open world, suffers from the same confusion about when it's okay to chill and when you need to stay on mission that all open world games do, but I think that's maybe part of the point of this game after the first one
-the world of people you can not kill and things other than combat that you can do is larger, which again goes back to the theme of this episode which is Cal wrestling with whether he should be "a weapon" or stop and try to live [if he even can].



-mullet + lightsaber

In my opinion, the performance issues are nowhere near as bad as people are saying. 

I'm here to say that the game is a bit rough, but it is by no means unplayable, and it is by no means deserving of a "mixed" review status. This is a really, really good game. Plenty of systems can play it at a solid 60+ fps if you are willing to compromise on certain settings. And the game will still look great. I've had no problem getting very high frame rates that are stable.

I'm tellin yall right now, I have no issues getting a solid 170fps with ray tracing off. With ray tracing on, I get a solid 90 fps most of the time. But that's RT for ya. All settings are on Epic, AMD FSR is set to quality, and AMD Fluid Frames activated via the AMD Adrenaline Overlay.

Specs:
Resolution: 1440p
GPU: AMD RX 7800 XT (16gb VRAM)
CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 7700x
RAM: 32gb DDR5

Obviously those are solid specs. But they're upper mid-range; not top of the line. I'm noticing that a lot of people reporting lousy performance happen to be using NVIDIA GPUs. I'm wondering if the game is just better optimized for AMD GPUs because game consoles run AMD. My other theory (without deep diving into specs/benchmarks) is CPU bottlenecking.

Obviously EA sucks. I hate them as much as everyone else does. But since they basically have a monopoly on Star Wars games, we may as well vote with our dollar and show EA that people still want great single player games like Jedi Fallen Order and Jedi Survivor. Respawn is doing the lord's work and this series is imo the best thing to happen to Star Wars since the original trilogy.

Star Wars Jedi: Survivor -
I almost gave it a 10/10!

Unlike its predecessor, Star wars Jedi: Survivor focused more on a grounded story rather than a grand scale like the Empire and the Fate of the Universe. Jedi Survivor almost, ALMOST, has the perfect blend of classic Star Wars action like the original trilogy, and a really immersive and grounded narrative, unlike the sequel trilogy.

Playing this on PC was not the best experience but it was fine given the condition it was released in. Leaving all the technical issues behind, I felt like Jedi Survivor shows the universe of Star Wars in the best way possible. The dim and saturated streets of Coruscant, the vivid and lush lands of Koboh, and the grainy deserts of jedah; the game looks fantastic.

The story was way more interpersonal compared to the first Jedi game, as this one focused more on Cal's growth not only as a Jedi knight but also as a friend, a pupil and a lover. Survivor made me care for Cal which inadvertently made me care for Bode, Cere and all the other characters involved. 

The characterisation of Dagan was a personification of how order can slowly become a dictatorial power without compassion, which is what exactly happened with the Jedi order. Dagan served his purpose..but the story writers had me in shambles with Bode Akuna. Oh Bode....

While Survivor does not have the perfect narrative (some parts of the 2nd half felt a bit bloated and rushed), it certainly is a way superior product compared to what Star Wars has become lately (Fuck Disney, really). The 
gameplay, on the other hand, felt like a more polished version of Jedi Fallen Order instead of being a generational leap. Considering how great the gameplay of Jedi Fallen Order was in the first place, I honestly have no big complaints.

Overall? i would say Survivor is¬†a¬†good¬†8.5/10.

Here the problems show right from the first start-up. It is absolutely unacceptable to release a game in such state, let alone leave it like this almost a year after the release. Some of the worst performance and poorest optimization I have experienced recently, and the competition is tough.

High to Ultra without RT. And the game looks gorgeous at those settings. I also had 3-4 crashes throughout my 25 hours, a couple of which were very inconvenient and caused me to have to redo some things.

Performance aside, this game is fantastic.

If you have played [i]Fallen Order[/i], you should know what to expect for gameplay. If not, I like to describe it as [i]Elden Ring[/i] meets [i]Uncharted[/i], or open world-ish souls-like combat with lots of platforming and traversal.

To me, this game series is undoubtedly the best ongoing Star Wars narrative, aside from maybe Andor. But if you come to Star Wars for the lightsabers and Jedi, this is it. It is mature and impactful in its storytelling. I cannot wait for a third entry.

Another positive note, there are a lot of cool fighting styles (stances) that you can spec out, equipping two at a time. I found myself geeking out every time I unlocked a new one. There are the ones from Fallen Order of course, but my personal favorite new one was, [spoiler]and I am not a sequel fan, the CROSSGUARD stance, inspired by Kylo Ren's fighting style (and saber). It uses those big heavy swings and its tree has a lot of really cool, powerful-feeling abilities.[/spoiler] The game uses these different stances to switch up your gameplay in a interesting ways, and you are only ever required to use one right when you acquire it for tutorial purposes. For the rest of the game, you are free to use whichever stances you prefer.

Performance aside, kudos to Respawn for developing such massive Game in 3 years. Everything is so detailed, characters are loveable and the gameplay itself is a blast.

Respawn is not to blame. EA and Investors however, for pushing short deadlines.

Edit: After the release of the first performance patch, Jedi Survivor runs smoothly for me. I love the game more and more while playing. Almost a 10/10 for me.

I played with everything set to low and even lowered the resolution so the optimization issue of the game won't affect my experience. I didn't mind the grungy textures as long as I was able to get 30 fps. [b]BUT[/b] for me, the game is still worthy to play since the game's content more than makes up for it.

[b]EVERYTHING[/b] and I mean everything from the first game has been improved upon along with tons of new stuff. Stances, traversing the world, new force powers, new collectibles, you name it. And with new traversal methods comes new planets to explore that are [b]VASTLY[/b] wider compared to the ones from the first game. Albeit, the ones from the first game are more visually aesthetic. 

The characters and the story are much more exciting too this time around, although it didn't had the same amount of [b][i]memorable and inspirational lines fallen order had.[/i][/b] But still, an exciting journey nonetheless. 

I can't wait for Cal's next journey on Jedi 3. But for now, I'm off to hunt all the achievements.

My feelings towards this game after my first hour are lukewarm at best. The dodge/parry timing is off, not by too small but by being too long before the actual hit. At least on "Jedi Knight" difficulty, you will miss the dodge/parry if you actually time it right before the hit. Additionally, whose idea was it to add a tutorial item mid-combat (hold F to block with dual blades) and then have it immediately NOT WORK and kill the player? Was that on purpose? The story thus far is a retread of the first game. We get new side characters and before we learn their names they die. Oh no, not what's his name! Just like that "friend/mentor" in the first game, they really tried to make a moment out of nothing and failed. The gameplay is roughly the same, the graphics are fine but not astounding. This entire thing is a C- at best, but I really hope to come back and adjust this review later on because the potential is clearly there.

Edit: Over 10 hours in and my opinion stands. It's playable for a Star Wars fan but performance is bad, gameplay is mid, and the story is the only thing keeping me going. Related note, why do we use the lightsaber like it's a goddamn baseball bat? So uncivilized.

Performance is still not 100% but it was mostly fine for me, had 0 crashes and played the majority of the game at good frames. Great sequel which does everything better than the original and is a really good Star Wars game.

I didn't want to buy the game on release thinking that maybe Respawn would of just made a 1.5 version but they proved me wrong and its a totally different experience the moment you enter the first episode on Coruscant. The exploration and traversal challenges that Fallen Order brought is dwarfed by what you can do in Survivor because the opened world aspect is some more vast and I have to applaud Respawn for referencing old school games like Mega Man X and Super Metroid for their traversal mechanics and Devil May Cry for the secret challenges portions. The puzzles  are mostly tied to the story like in Fallen Order but this time they are more intricate and needs your full concentration. The combat is as intricate as the first one but there are so many new things Cal can do and it feels like full gameplay evolution and in my opinion it strays away from the Souls like formula and is more akin to a Devil May Cry game. 

The story is a great departure from the previous game making Cal and his friends have a more fleshed out personality, the game also introduce you to a lot more characters since now you have a central hub with optional side quests you can get from some of the people roaming around the main planet, they all have a back story to tell and they feel like they belong in the lore as you progress more and more through the story making them have a sense of connection to the main characters. To me this franchise grew to almost feel like a ''what if'' Anakin Skywalker didn't turn to the dark side and instead fought in the shadows against the Empire, every references from the original movies that you may understand or remember have their moments and it feels like this franchise is great at making them more meaningful to give Cal a good back story to tell each time he gets into a situation similar to other main movie characters which is great for his development.

There aren't many grips that I have against the game but there's one thing I really think Respawn should address and its the power scaling that Cal is heading to for his arsenal, I think if he is going to to carry most of what he learned in this game to the next, like they did from Fallen Order they should improve to what he already acquired instead of giving him another set, that way it makes them more iconic and unique to him and makes him feel less over powered like Star Killer in The Force Unleashed for example, It makes it more believable since Lord Sidious and Darth Vader are suppose to be the strongest force wielder and even they don't really feel that over powered lore wise. So that way if they build the next world around the new arsenal, it could make solving puzzle and traversal not only about what you unlock as movement and tools extension during the story or what BD can do to help Cal solve puzzles.

Speaking of BD I don't know if it was a bit lazy but lore wise one of his perk seemed off and made using it in puzzles a bit convoluted but that's just me so whats stays in Star Wars stays in Star Wars huh!?

Playing Jedi Fallen Order back in 2019 was the first time in more than 10 years I was playing a Star Wars game (or an Electronic Arts game for that matter!).
This wasn't perfect game at all. But it was good enough that it got me back playing something from that universe.

Jedi Survivor goes beyond that and brings back not only that which I liked from 2019's Fallen Order but also something that was lost since the old days of Lucas Arts games. 

One thing that comes to mind when thinking about this game are all the great characters that you meet while playing it. Not only the main characters which are returning from the first game, but also the great cast of supporting characters that you will meet along the way. 

There are many great lines of dialogue to be found if you go fully exploring all that the game has to offer far beyond the main story. I would say it's even better than the main story, which is very exciting as well, but in the end didn't exactly stick the landing for me. Still, I very much loved the journey and the places you get to go there. 

The thing that comes to mind about the supporting characters in Jedi Survivor is that this game has a sense humor... Jedi Survivor can actually be funny at times. Cal has even one liners!!! Many of these lines of dialogue are depending on your actions and how you choose to engage certain enemies.
In brief, this game has good writing, and excellent world building, something that I think must be told.

The levels in Jedi Survivor are excellent. There are many layers to them. When you first explore most of them, they offer you a clear path, with some optionals here and there. Some paths are obviously blocked to be later unlocked. But... when you start advancing on the main story and gaining certain powers, and even more so if you care to explore past the main mission and unlock more abilities... you will find there is more than one way to explore each level, and some abilities could even change completely the way you move on each level.... there are even whole sections absolutely hidden from the main story. Excellent level design all the way.

The music is very good, not because it sounds like Star wars but because it tries to do the impossible (And forbidden) which is to separate itself from the Universe it comes from, keeping the spark alive.... and it very much succeeds in doing that.

Playing Jedi Survivor was one of the few times I still was able to enjoy playing a Star Wars game and sincerely I wouldn't mind going back at it again one more time in the future.

But there better be a Poncho!

Ignoring glitches, some frame rate issues and the long ass loading screen just to get to the main menu screen-
I had an absolute blast with this game. The combat is a significant improvement over Fallen Order. Finally the game lets you wield dual sabers and even adds a lightsaber/blaster stance as well as the crossguard saber which were welcome additions. The force combat was greatly improved. Now you can use the force to influence various creatures. This may include friendly creatures that you can ride on and help dismantle enemies easier or you can mindtrick enemy creatures to help you kill a squadron of stormtroopers.  This added some nice variety to the gameplay that was missing in Fallen Order. I thought the story overall was a step down from Fallen Order and a bit predictable. For example there was a twist that occurs towards the end of the game but there were so many hints and foreshadowing of this moment happening that it didn't surprise me much.  I also felt the game's plot had so much going on and there were some intriguing characters in it that never really got as much development or screen time as I would've liked.

gameplay and story-wise: 9/10.

And would be a 10 had Respawn, likely forced to do so by EA, not implemented all these open world Inquisition-type bs and instead focused on developing the main story more. I would rather see the main plot prolonged with some additional planets, characters, and so on (not sure where to put them, though, because the plot is actually amazing) instead of some nonsense bounty hunter missions or some other rubbish collectibles. Fine, it's cool customising Cal, but this game, as much as Fallen Order, is a story-driven game. And in particular in Jedi Survivor, the story is mostly based on the relations between main characters. I am not stupid to think that it will happen, but I still have some vague hope that for the sequel, the devs will be more focused on the story aspect of the game and not some post-game things, because nobody does them anyway. We already have ME Andromeda for all the looters.

Technical issues can be persistent, but on better hardware, virtually no location other than Koboh is affected.

Overall, an amazing game with (unfortunately) poor optimisation (which will vanish over time, as better and better hardware is developed, anyway). Very high hopes for the sequel.

The game is amazing. It's in almost every way a perfect sequel to Fallen Order, from game mechanics to the character evolution, the story progression, the music... It was incredible fun the entire way through, not to mention an emotional roller coaster. 

That said, it has it's issues, the main of which and the one that almost ruined it for me being the performance of the game itself. At the time of writing, I'm playing this on a 7800x3d, an RTX 3090 and 32gb of ram. The best gaming cpu on the market and a slightly older but still flagship grade gpu atm and the game still manages to stutter and lag at many points.

It's horribly blurry on anything below 1440p, ideally 4k even as for some reason they apparently have it set to 50% resolution scale by default and the TAA is just god awful. FSR and DLSS help in sharpening it up a bit but still...
Ray tracing is a complete no go as well, the moment I turn it on it becomes an unplayable crash ridden mess. Thankfully, at least most of the bug's have been fixed and once ray tracing was off the game no longer had any crashes or freezing issues.

It's really a shame because I truly believe that underneath all of the problems it has, is an amazing gem Respawn just need to polish up and allow to shine. But even so, I simply don't have the willpower to leave a negative review. It gave me exactly what I hoped it would after Fallen Order and then some, with some of the scenes just breaking me completely. 
So one day, once they finish fixing all of the issues, when the average components are strong enough to run it at it's best and you find it sitting on a nice little steam sale like I did, feeling that Star Wars itch? ABSOLUTELY give this game a try.

Recommended. A solid follow up from Fallen Order. Great story and game play. I do feel though as the story never finish. Either another game is coming along or (to me) not complete. 
Still some update to do regarding bugs and optimisation but this is a recent game so I truly hope the the devs will continue their hard work to give us the best experience. Worth the price for Star Wars fans.

I was a huge fan of the first game and was super excited for the sequel. Unfortunately with how bad the launch was, I decided to wait for the game to be on sale to go ahead and purchase it/hope some of the issues would be resolved.

The state this game is in is downright appalling. I have a 4070 super, playing on 1440p and I get 30 FPS in this game, and changing the settings does not change it. DLSS does nothing, frame gen is absolutely not usable because it adds the weirdest artifacts/visual glitches and insane amount of input lag, more than I've seen in any other game using the same tech. Controller support is absolutely busted, the menus are super bugged, the game crashed 4 times at the intro cinematic before finally letting me into the game.

I got this game on sale for $30 and I honestly can't recommend it for that price. For $10, maybe, but currently ti's unacceptable. This is the first game i've actually left a review for because the performance issues are *that* bad that i'm probably going to look for a refund. Not even going to mention that this turd takes up nearly 150 gb of storage. Devs should be ashamed of this one.

WARNING: DO NOT BUY. I wish I would have listened to the bad reviews before I bought this dud. The graphical problems in the game make it unplayable. No matter what graphic settings I use, all I see is flickering light when I go to the start screen. I thought if I start a game, it would be better, but no, it got worse. I've never seen a mainstream game be this buggy. EA should be embarrassed. They would have been better just releasing this as a DLC for Fallen Order--a game that actually works. Bottom line: only buy this game if you like throwing your money away.

I'm prefacing this review with the fact that I bought the game on sale for 35 bucks. I don't think it's worth the base price of 70, but it's definitely worth 35.

This game is more of the same stuff you got out of Fallen Order. Personally, I think the spark of starwarsy joy is lesser, but still present. If you liked Fallen Order, you'll probably like this.

No doubt you're expecting me to mention the bugs and performance issues. The latter was far more my experience than the former; I experienced screen tearing, occasional framerate drops, and a single crash in my 32 hours of play. I will note however, that according to Steam's statistics, 45% of all players complete the story. That's actually a really good percentage, which indicates the performance problems *probably* aren't as widespread as people report.

Now, some thoughts:
There's a lot of stuff to do; this is a bigger game than Fallen Order and contains a ton of secrets and discoverable stuff. In 32 hours I'm nowhere near a 100%, that was my time to clear the main story (although I did spend a good amount of time wandering, hunting down secrets, and fighting bonus bosses). You start the game with most of the stuff you had in Fallen Order, none of the "the protagonist inexplicably doesn't remember how to do things" nonsense.

Story is a bit different; while the Empire is still an ever-present looming threat, they're not the main baddies this time around, but saying more would be spoilers. You'll spend most of your time exploring the planet Koboh, which serves as a hub, and occasionally venturing out to other worlds. Characters from the first game reappear, of course, but there are some new faces as well.

All in all, I think it's a good game, *on sale*. I would not pay 70 bucks for it, that's just too much even for AAA talent.

This game is a master piece. Fallen Order was one of my favourite single player games of all time and this one was a complete upgrade to the first. The story was amazing and the gameplay was  great . In regards to the issues people have been facing I was expecting a lot worse than I experienced. I did have to run of lowest setting but the game still looked fine and my PC is not very high end. I have a gtx 1660 super, 32gb ddr4, and i5 9600k. I waited until December 2023 to buy this game and waited for sale but i would've payed full price. Whole time it took to 100% achievement only crashed 3 times and experienced lag very few times in certain areas. I am honestly suprised that many reviews from people with way better pc hardware than me are experiencing so many issues. Overall 10/10.

This game is awesome. 

A solid sequel to the first one, although I still find the first a little bit better. The maps are much bigger than FO and that for me is a disadvantage as I felt FO more diverse, since the planets were quite distinct from each other. In survivor you get 2 large planets and a few very minor ones (which btw are not very nice looking). The planets are very well crafted with lots of distinct environments but I still lacked the feeling of exploring that galaxy far far away.

Other than that: a solid plot, a (extremely challenging) fight with Darth Vader and new challenges being added till the very end.

The game is very competent in reinventing itself as you progress, with new abilities being added gradually till the very end, which for me is very appealing as it feels refreshing all the way.

Regarding the technical issues, I decided to wait a few months to buy the game as I was concerned about the reviews, but now most issues seem to have been addressed. I luckily got away with very occasional CTD and lags, but other than that it ran fine. So I cannot complain about that. Hope EA learned their lesson though, and in the future avoid releasing such a good game with so many issues. It's a shame.

Bought on sale as a combo deal with Fallen order, roughly $35 bux.  Highly recommend at that price point.  The early reviews turned me off, and the second time I noticed a price drop to the $30 range, I finally had enough confidence to take the risk on an EA game, despite past bad experiences.

That said, I do recommend picking this game up at some point, if you are a star wars fan generally, or want to know the continuation of Cal Kestis's journey as a survivor.  This game is absolutely worth the $35 price point, but I would not pay full price due to that being encouragement to EA that their intolerable management of games is anything north of acceptable, as it clearly isnt.

That said, after about 15 hours playtime it is a good/enjoyable game.  Graphics and controls are universally an improvement over the 1st game, and the story so far is decentlyl written, though weak in a few places (Deus ex machina and other weak plot devices apparent).  

Buy this at half price.  DO not buy at full price unless you have stupid people money, in which case you probably already did and are not reading this review in the first place.  May the force be with you.

UPDATE FEB 16, 2024:

Purchased it again almost a year after release. The game is still unplayable to me. Sure, I was getting 20-40 FPS before and now I'm getting 40-70 FPS. But i'm still getting less than 50% CPU and GPU utilization and having textures constantly downsample and microstutter everytime I turn around.

To people who are happy to play a game at 30FPS, it's probably worth it to buy on 50% discount. MAYBE even people who are happy to play at around 60 FPS. You'll probably be there 50% of the time.

But if you are "spoiled" like me, who is used to being able to run every game at 120+ FPS, it gives me a headache to play this to the point that it might as well be outputting 15 FPS. 

Also, the fact that STILL, almost a year later, the menu is not navigable with a keyboard, is testament to the fact that EA just does not care to make this game function properly on PC. 

Very disappointing.

Original Review April 30, 2023:

I have been counting down the days for this games release. Fallen Order is literally in my top 5 games ever. And I am very unhappy to say that I have returned it after 2 hours of game time. 

I have a 5800X, 3080, and I'm getting ~30 FPS regarding of settings or resolution (1440p or 1440p 32:9, doesn't matter). My CPU and GPU utilization are below 50% so it's clearly just not utilizing the resources available.

I hope they finish the game soon, so I can rebuy it, as the gameplay and story are on par with the first game thus far.

I updated this review after over 100 hours of play. It keeps getting better and better, and ultimately eclipses Fallen Order in many ways. Best not to compare them, and simply to consider them one game.

Star Wars Jedi Survivor is a fantastic game and follow-up to Fallen Order. You play once again as Cal Kestis, keeping all of the previous game's story progression skills, with the wall running and double jump being made far stronger. The game improves on the first in every aspect except performance. While that could be expected to a minor degree with it being an intended jump for console hardware generations, the performance issues are worse than that. The game was borderline unplayable on release as far as I heard. In its current condition; I was able to play the game with maxed out graphical settings but ray tracing turned off with my 3070 graphics card. The primary issue I encountered were occasional loading issues, particularly with one of the game's main hub locations: Pyloon's Saloon.

One other annoyance, while not game ruining, is Respawn Entertainment doubling down on bad boss design for the animal bosses. particularly Spawn of Oggdo. Instead of taking in the feedback of Oggdo being horribly designed with Dark Souls 2 boss level tracking and outright broken hitboxes on some of his moves; they doubled down and memed about it with the reward you get. Which sure that part is funny. But it sets a bad precedent to double down on a boss design despised almost universally. Really hope the trend doesn't continue with the next game.

An overall solid sequel to Fallen Order. They improved upon a lot of things from the first game such as combat, customization, and lightsaber stances. This made it feel like a more refined and sharper version of Fallen Order. The game also looks absolutely stunning and reminded me how far games have come in terms of graphics. 

With that being said I do have some complaints. The story felt a bit underwhelming. In this game, Cal struggles to continue following the Jedi Order and begins to question if he‚Äôs even making a difference. This was interesting but they kind of just put it off and introduced some new villains that felt kinda flat. There is not much in terms of the variety of planets to visit which is a shame being how beautiful the game looks. The game featured a sort of ‚Äúhub planet‚Äù that offered side quests that didn't feel all that important or worth doing. In terms of performance, I didn‚Äôt have any huge issues other than annoying frame drops in certain locations. (Nothing game-breaking)

Final Take: I‚Äôd give it a 7/10. If you enjoyed Fallen Order or Star Wars in general, it's worth buying. That being said I would wait for a sale. I wouldn‚Äôt buy it at full price.

An honest review after all those *coughs* minutes I played the game, or what I was able to. Hardware exceeds the recommended requirements yet I can‚Äôt even get past the prologue without a crash saying "out of video memory trying to allocate a rendering resource" either after 3 minutes or after 5. After checking several threats this seems to be the norm for most people which is an absolute shame for a game that expensive and 10 months after release, let alone that some patches prior this was apparently solved for the time. I won‚Äôt refund though, I still hope this gets fixed. Either that or it will stay in my library as a reminder how far EA has fallen. Don‚Äôt buy it rn guys!

Going to try and keep it simple with this one. 

The story is amazing, voice acting is great, open world is actually quite fun, cut scenes are great. Lots of new skills and traversal. Awesome blade stance options. Lightsaber customisation could be a bit better, didnt like most of the styles same for BD1. Outfit styles could be better as well. Picks off well from the previous story, expanding nicely on the already built story. Graphics are great. Fighting is even more satisfying with the new stances. 

The bad? like everyone says, the performance and bugs. Why why why would they repeat the same mistake as the last? idk. recommend to limit the game to 60 fps with something like nvidia control panel. turn on gsync/freesync if you have it. this helped the most with stutters. This is simply a game engine problem no matter what you will have performance problems. I had few bugs where i needed to restart checkpoints. 

Overall if youre a star wars fan or liked the first game this is good successor with some unfortunate game engine issues. Definitely play the first game before this.

The game does not support a Switch Pro controller. Most games recognize the pro controller as an Xbox controller, but not this game. Most of the time I can use Steam's controller recognition to change the controls around, but not with this game. When I try to change it in the settings, the game just freezes. I just spent 4 hours downloading the game, and another hour trying to mess around with the settings to try to enjoy my night, but instead, my time was wasted. You couldn't pay me to play this game, with issues like this. I shouldn't have to buy a completely new controller to have a good experience on a game with a 70 dollar price tag.

Game is alright, the port isn't great, somehow is an unoptimized mess despite taking up so much hardware space.  Its mostly playable if you have a good pc but dont expect to see any of the higher settings.

[h1]Great Game, [i]BUT[/i][/h1]

[code]If you're reading this and suffering controller problems, here's the closest thing to a workaround I've found:

Outside of a physical problem, there was a recent EA App update that screwed up controller support for a lot of people that play through Steam, including me. The workaround for that is to [b]kill any running EA app processes, open Steam and add the EADesktop.exe as a new game. Now launch the EA App through Steam and then Jedi Survivor through the EA app.[/b][/code]

Star Wars: Jedi:  Survivor (henceforth just Survivor, I'm not dealing with that many colons) is the sequel to Jedi: Fallen Order (Henceforth Fallen Order).  In this game, you take control of Cal Kestis as you attempt to find a safe home from the Imperial Empire, whose grip on the galaxy at large has never felt so ironclad.  This journey will take you places, meeting (and subsequently lightsabering) interesting people, and whereas the first game's stakes were potentially galaxy-spanning, this one is far smaller, far more personal, and more character-focused.  It's all the better for it's tighter packaging than the original, especially given Disney's, shall we say, recent handling of the franchise.

Gameplay-wise, everything about Fallen Order's style of [i]'Baby's First Soulsborne Ring: Shadows Die A Lot'[/i] was already working, so Survivor's focus is taking that foundation and piling on [u]MORE.[/u]

More stances, more moves, more ways to play and engage with the combat system, as well as far, far more ways to customize Cal, your lightsaber, BD-1, and a blaster you acquire for one of your stances.  Respawn did not have to do this, especially not with how hectic combat gets, or the fact that said blaster is only used in one stance.  But they did, and I'm rejoicing all the more for it.

In fact, and much like last go around, exploration might yield small upgrades to your health and Force meters, and more stims, this series' Estus-alike - But a good chunk of your exploration rewards come down to customization rewards instead, and these always feel good, even if you never plan on using them.  Almost none of the customization is real-world cash locked, with the few bits that are being upfront in the Deluxe Edition, and if other games can do this avenue, I'd be down for it.

Graphically (when everything works), this game looks good.  Yes, to be expected considering we're up to the PS5/Xbox Series X as standard now, but I don't mean just 'oh haha look at all dem PIXELS'.  I mean this game looks and feels like a Star Wars movie, from the used future of Coruscant to Koboh's more 'Western IN SPACE' feel, from the Empire's sterile, distinctly hostile halls, to the High Republic's distinct style of futurism.  Respawn came at this game with a clear love for the source material, and it shows across the board.

Musically, it's also a home run - Again, Respawn clearly went at this after binging the first three films and chasing that binge with the prequels, because the music manages to pay homage to various themes in Star Wars history while also managing to be it's own thing, sampling the series while never ripping any music one-to-one from it, or only doing so for especially high-profile moments.

I played on a PS5 controller the entire way through, and aside from EA's updates actually breaking controller support, requiring me to download DSX to fix it, I had a decent time.  But this does bring me to my criticisms of Survivor, and unfortunately there are quite a few.

For starters, the PC port is a joke.  While consoles absolutely had it rough with this one too, the PC port stood out at launch for just how insanely awful it was, and while I mostly only ran into stutters outside of combat or funny graphical errors, I cannot and will not overlook that this game's technical state was and still is a mess that should've been left to cook longer.  I don't know if Respawn's QA just didn't have the manpower they needed, or if EA rushed this game out the door.  I can't name names and point fingers.  What I can do is lambaste the state of the game and say that it absolutely needs more fixes then it's getting, and that EA needs to stop breaking their products in half.

The price point only makes these technical issues more readily apparent - 70$ is nothing to scoff at and implies a premium product for the money spent.  To pay 70$ and have [b]this[/b] be what your hard-earned money gets you is disappointing, and while I had fun with this game and walked away enjoying myself, I also got this on sale for 50% off - I went in with reduced expectations and months of bug fixes, and this still wound up sometimes struggling on my computer - Small stutters, especially on launch, a need to compile files every single time I launched the game, and the odd moment where I clipped through geometry and had to quit to the title to fix it.

On less technical matters, the fact that the base gameplay is 'Fallen Order with extra stuff' can be hit or miss.  On the one hand, like I said, everything about Fallen Order was already working, don't fix what ain't broke.  On the other hand, however, the baseline combat system is in need of a bit of zing, and I played on Jedi Knight, the 'normal' difficulty, and found my best way to play was simply to use the basic combos for every stance, parrying when enemies tried to attack.  This is fine, it works, but hopefully the next game manages to find ways to spice up the combat system.

Additionally, the 'Metroidvania' approach taken, mostly on Koboh, your primary planet of sorts, means you'll be doing quite a bit of backtracking if you're out for 100% completion - and even if you aren't, you're still going to want the upgrades and extra stims exploration provides you - which, while the game does throw new enemies and make encounters a little trickier, to it's credit, the act of backtracking in and of itself can get repetitive fast, especially when it comes to treasure hunting, which can feel damn near like a pixel hunt.  Yes, the game does hand you upgrades that mark collectibles, but it felt like those were needed considering just how large these worlds are.

The final question is, 'Did I enjoy Jedi: Survivor?' and the answer is 'Yes, but...'.  I'm happy with my time spent here, and I admit to feeling like the 35$ spent wasn't wasted money.  However, I cannot emphasize this enough - [b]PLEASE, ONLY BUY THIS IS YOU'RE CRAVING MORE FALLEN ORDER, AND ONLY ON A SALE FOR AT LEAST HALF OFF.[/b]

The game's technical state is still sub-par, EA's app is still managing to find new and exciting ways of breaking the game, and honestly, much as this is going to suck for Respawn, I'd argue this game really isn't worth 70$, not for the bugs it's still dealing with across the board.  Honestly, if Steam had a 'Mixed Feelings' option, I'd pick that for this review.  It's kinda terrible that we only have 'yes' and 'no' for options, because at the end of the day, I enjoyed my time with Survivor, but I can understand if a lot of other people didn't enjoy their time with this game, or are frustrated with all the bugs.  I get it.  It's natural to expect a game that's charging 70$ to live up to that expectation, and seeing this game fall so far below par really does not do it any favors.

End of the day, buy this game on a steep discount - The story is great, the gameplay's good if you enjoyed the last game, it looks and sounds like Star Wars damn well should, but the technical side of things are a mess, and will likely remain a mess 'till the day Respawn has to stop patching.

I just hope this is a nadir, tech-wise, rather then the beginning of a trend.

I desperately want to enjoy this game. The gameplay and story seemed off to a good start in my first 30 minutes. I bought this after getting a 4080 Super thinking surely I could now just brute force my way through any optimization issues. In those first 30 minutes, I came to understand just how wrong I was. 

At 1440p on this 4080 Super, I cannot play this game with RTX effects enabled. I can barely get acceptable framerates with RTX off. DLSS does nothing to alleviate this problem. Frame Gen on the 40 series does, but within seconds you'll see the ghosting and artifacts on absolutely anything that moves, down to Cal's hair when moving and his head when turning the camera. You can actively see the generated frames being spliced in because you see whatever is behind moving objects. The thoroughly terrible optimization on full display, getting so few frames that you can see the generated ones without even trying. 

Again, all of this on a GPU second only to the 4090. Despite how much I loved the first game, and how much I'm sure I would love this one, I cannot recommend it. The fact that my GPU can run Cyberpunk with path-tracing on at full resolution, but not this game, is the only reason I need to tell you to avoid it.

Revision explanation: 
I decided to rate the game positively as I watch the end credits.
Despite all the technical shortcomings, constant crashes, framerate issues, etc. I have to give the writing staff and game designers huge kudos. The story is so rich, charged and at moments really funny, that I was absolutely immersed in the universe. I am at a loss for words explaining how beautiful this game looks too, leveraging all the power of Unreal Engine. The spirit of the Star Wars Saga really shines here. After the disaster that has been the Skywalker Saga, this is just so refreshing to experience. Not a single moment has been felt by me like it has been wasted. Grinding has been kept at a minimum, if you just want to enjoy a rich and beautiful story in a galaxy far, far away. (If you want to 100% it like I did, there is some grind, but still worth it...) A must for any Star Wars fan. That is why I implore the devs to make it technically more polished for the next installment, if one will ever surface. Thank you for a massive game, content-wise totally worth the asking price (especially on sale)

I have to say, great game, feels nice has so much more content than the last installment. It obviously runs great UNTIL the VRAM gets filled. I am almost 100% positive it is an oversight in "garbage collection" of the VRAM. I have ~130 fps on epic settings, until I see the VRAM being full on mangohud (Linux gamer here, hi), that is when the stutters happen, assets are obviously not being unloaded regularly and it is a major oversight. I know memory management and optimization is a hassle, but you will have to handle it eventually, or this is the last game I am purchasing from EA. It is not logical to me that there has to be 15 GB of VRAM used in an area where none of the previous assets, where the 15 GB got filled is visible to the player. Fix ya s**t !!!! Why I know it is an oversight on your part? Changing the visual settings to the lowest possible one does not change the VRAM utilized.
