While I did have fun playing this game. The performance really pulls you out the immersion, even when lowering setting I was still getting stuttering and random frame drops.

There are some fun things about this game, but the overall lack of polish effectively ruins most of the good parts of the game. I got the game on sale for $35, and at that price point it's kind of worth it, I guess. Paying the $70 full price would definitely be a rip-off.

The Good: 
 - The visual design is spectacular. The scenery, combat effects, flora and fauna, etc are really pretty. It feels wonderful walking around exploring these places. 
 - The combat system is interesting, visually appealing, and gratifying. The skill required to study your opponent, time your strikes, parries, and special actions makes it a fun challenge (I'm playing through on "Jedi Master" difficulty and it feels about right)
 - I enjoyed the mix of combat, exploration, and puzzle game play. It's not just running around killing everything in sight - there are interesting things to investigate, problems to solve, and places to explore. 

The Bad: 
 - The UI was clearly designed with a controller in mind, and very little effort was made to support mouse and keyboard. I refuse to spend even more money on a controller just to make this poorly built game a little more playable. If you're going to port the game to PC, you should support the default control scheme for a PC. 
 - Lots of graphics glitches. While the graphical design is spectacular, as described in "The Good", the implementation of that design leaves something to be desired. 
 - The game clearly has memory leaks. The frame rate is awesome for the first 20-30 minutes of game play, after which things get progressively more stuttery as we run out of memory (I have a RTX3060TI and 32G of ram). These issues should have been resolved in any of the recent patches, but nope.
 - The story line has potential, but falls flat in some areas. There appear to be some weird plot holes, but it's hard to tell because the story is hard to follow. Also, when you get story line information, it gets saved to a kind of database, but that database is really hard to navigate, so it's hard to look things up later.
 - In combat you lose the ability to look around. Your view is locked onto whoever the computer thinks is your primary opponent at the time. The greatly reduces your ability to move tactically. You pretty much just have to lock into combat with one particular opponent until they are dead and the game releases you to look around again. This gets especially annoying in battles with multiple opponents. 

The Ridicules: 
The rewards system of this game is chock full of intentionally silly nonsense that cheapens the experience and makes it feel more like a time waster mobile game than a AAA Title. While I'm happy to have moved on from Jedi Fallen Poncho, I'm still left deeply unsatisfied with this iteration. 

Loot that you find in the environment should make some reasonable amount of sense. For example: wandering around a bandit base and finding medical equipment (stims) or blaster parts absolutely fits within the setting. But hacking into a crate and finding a haircut or a beard is absurd. Unlocking character customization is fine, but a token amount of effort to make it less immersion breaking would really help. For example, there are shops all over the place. Add some barber shops that have different styles to choose from that you can unlock. 

Parts of the rewards system is based around doing things that seem very counter to the Jedi way. Looting scrolls from ancient archaeological sites and selling them for personal gain, for example, doesn't seem very Jedi to me. 

Conclusion: 
If you buy this game, I won't judge. You'll probably have some fun and enjoy the ride through some fun Star Wars content. However, technically, it is an absolute disgrace. As a software developer, I would get promptly fired if I pushed software of this caliber to production. This is clearly an example of a studio deciding to release something subpar out of greed and laziness, knowing that fans will buy it anyway because Star Wars.

I loved Fallen Order and had a mixed feelings after reading all the negative reviews at launch of Jedi Survivor, decided to wait to buy this on sale.
Just finished and overall I don't like this game. It is such a waste of potential, seems to be rushed production, messy and unpolished.

Game itself wants to be a mix of Tomb Raider - collecting meaningless (literally, mostly cosmetics) items on map and souls-like (respawning enemies, boss fights) and I believe it could be good if execution was not so damn poor.
Fights that are supposed to be hard are not because of some clever boss routine but because they are scripted to be unfair - for example very vague boss attack that kills you instantly (big frog, rancor) or series of unblockable attacks from multiple enemies overwhelming the player - it is simply not fun, but frustrating; lowering difficulty makes game no challenge at all. This aspect kills a lot of joy from Jedi Survivor.

The story is just meh, I mean I have seen it 1000 times already, feels like nobody cared much to make it interesting. Previous instalment felt like real SW movie, this is more an EA game.
Characters are mostly boring (with exception of Greeze) and had no real meaning, you may skip non cinematic dialogues and you loose nothing.

Tech issues are still there - stuttering, especially at new areas, memory leaks causing game to crash 2 times after long sessions (I have Ryzen 5700x + rx 6900 xt with 16Gb, I consider this a decent config), but they were not bothering me as much as poor gameplay.

Ive played it 2 Hours than i slept away cause i was tired af but this game is awesome. The Fighting movement and all things together are funny, u can cut limbs of ur enemies. its just beautiful and im enjoying the gameplay!

Obi-Wan once said: "Only a Sith deals in absolutes". That makes us all, the PC players of this game, Siths, since this is absolutely a piss-poor port from [strike]peasant calculator[/strike] console.

Overall it's a great game with an engaging story, neatly building up and expanding on its predecessor, however the performance on PC is simply outrageous. In order to speed it up you can try the following:

1. Lock the game to 60 FPS directly in the Nvidia settings by selecting the .exe file in [i]Binaries/Win64[/i] folder
2. Disable Ray Tracing and/or DLSS
3. If you have a SSD + HDD setup, disable the paging on the HDD. To do so:
- Go to Settings -> System -> About -> Advanced system settings
- On the Advanced tab, look for the Performance section and click Settings
- On the Advanced tab, look for Virtual Memory and click Change
- Look for your HDD on the list and select it by clicking on it
- Choose "No Paging File" and click the Set button next to it
- Select your SSD and make it System managed and click Set again
- Reboot your PC to make the changes active and try starting the game again
(thanks, [b]rootshaper[/b]!)

That did it for me, allowing to play on Epic in 1440p relatively smoothly (on 3070). 
Still, the number of adjustments you have to make despite meeting the minimal and recommended requirements is unacceptable, don't buy this unless it's heavily discounted.
Still buggy & stutter on Planet Koboh, but in other Planet it run perfectly. I hope Cal Kestis stories still continue...

While there are certain redeeming qualities to the game, most of it is worst than the first. not to mention the entire EA Jedi series just makes me yearn for the force unleashed games instead. This game is a mess of cutscenes and action you wish you could be part of, companion characters forcing a set pacing and killing off bosses without player input, and certain waypoints create ungodly beacons which reach into the heavens - i managed to get 4 into a single camera angle on koboh and that was the very moment I knew for certain I would dislike the game. This is without even going into the collectible hellscape that this game is: hairstyles, beard styles, shirts, jackets, pants, colours for the clothing, lightsaber parts, lightsaber materials, bd-1 parts, bd-1 materials, MUSIC FOR THE GODSFORSAKEN BAR. Around every corner you will without a doubt see at least one collectible be it customisation options, force echoes, force/health upgrades, or seeds/ore/scrolls to sell to  vendors to get more freaking collectibles/customisation. Frankly, it gives the vibes that EA wanted players to spend a lot more real life money but then reeled it back at the last moment.
Too many bugs, crashes and poor optimization to recommend. If the game wasn't this buggy it wouldve been a great experience.

This game would have been AMAZING in 2004. But the limitations of this type of game are painful in 2024. Seriously, i can use the force to blow apart boulders, and run across vertical platforms, but i still can't more than 10 feet? And my lightsaber can slash enemies in half, but disappears into a rock, or leaves a slash on a door that disappears moments later? And what is with the "optimizing game files" on every startup? Do i need to write my own himem and autoexec.bat files too? Games like Cyberpunk have shown that this one-dimensional story telling format is old and outdated. The next Star Wars game needs something more than "better graphics".

Honestly, I liked it. It took some time to set up controller support, and a crashed a couple of times, but I still liked it. The game is good, visuals are great, the poncho is back, and the story took some risks that I think paid off. Now, get the game on sale, I will say that. And make sure you have a BEAST of a computer. This will not run on your standard, every-day laptop, you'll need something much more powerful.
Great game and great story.

Played the game before the patches on an RTX 3060ti when it first came out.
Other than some glitches like improper lightsaber stance animations I had a pretty fluid and fun time with it.

The combat is undoubtedly the best out of any Star Wars game. Flashy, varied, makes you feel like a god but is still challenging and rewarding. Literally Dark Souls with Light-sabers, and the new force abilities are amazing too. Lifting an entire stormtroopers squadron only to slam them intro the ground and then spinning my double-bladed saber around like a pinwheel through them killing them near instantly is so fucking gratifying. the Dual weidling lightsaber stance is quite possibly the best one in the game, do yourself a favor and try the game out with that stance alone. 

The story is definitely a lot less gratifying. Without getting into much spoilers it does weaken the overall experience for me personally close to the ending of the game. Especially with a certain reveal.

Otherwise, this is still a goated star wars game. Pick it up on sale and if you have a monster PC.

*spoilers*
Good:
On a technical level, this is what a sequel should be. I loved that it didn't do a skill-reset like I see a lot in games. Powers-wise, it picked up where the first game left off. It expanded gameplay by adding new stances and companions. The telekinesis and confusion were great additions. 
The movement had some upgrades, namely the dash and the grapple shot thing. 
The story was pretty good. I loved playing as Cere, and fighting Vader felt really fun. I could feel my heart hammering in my ears as I finished it. 
I really liked the holo-tactics minigame and the process of recruiting people to the outpost.
The voice acting was pretty good, still hoping to see Cal in live action at some point. 

Middle: The game felt much smaller than Fallen Order. There were 7 planets with pretty sizeable maps in the first one and only 5 in this one, not including Tanalorr because just getting to Bode explores the entirety of the map. 
The maps we do have are either Desert Planet 1, Desert Planet 2, or Imperial Base I, Imperial Base 2, or Coruscant (Imperial base city). Having a map like Kashyyyk would have been great. In fairness, Desert Planet 1 (Koboh) had some cool and nicely colored areas. 
The maps were also very linearly designed, with only one real way to get to where you need to go. There was no room for thinking outside the box or navigating your own way, like the game tells you to when it introduces the lift and slam force moves. 
The movement, besides the dash and grapple, stayed pretty much the exact same. No fault for it, but it could definitely could see some improvement. 3rd game could maybe have a movement skill that adds triple jump or higher jumps or longer dashes or something. But this would really only be good if they didn't keep adding invisible walls to keep you from traversing any path but the ones the devs want you to take. 
While good, the story was incredibly short. It felt like maybe 2 or 3 missions with Bode before he betrayed Cal. No real time to make any emotional connections- just "I have a daughter. raah I'm evil now" 

Bad: It ran really poorly. I don't have a super beefy computer, but a 3070 and 16GB of RAM should've been able to run this pretty consistently. It did not. Even on medium settings, it still ran at ~40 FPS with a good deal of stuttering. 
Some of the bosses had moves that felt dumb. The hammer and axe droids come to mind with the spin-up attack that tracks you farther than your 2 dashes take you so you just kinda take damage no matter what you do. Maybe it was the stuttery performance, but that was far from the only enemy that felt like there was no counter once it started that move. The flip side to this is other enemies like Dagan were just too easy. I think I lost to Dagan once the entire game but after that he was too easy. It was more insulting since there was a time I beat Dagan without him landing a hit, and then it cut to a scene of him kicking me around. Just felt wrong to flip like that. I remember having to struggle against most of the bosses in the first game, but not here. The bosses were usually really easy, but the animals were much harder. I'd rather do the Cere-Vader fight again than fight a Sand-Wampa. 

All in all, this game sits at a 4.9 out of 10. Just on the edge of where I would recommend it. I had fun playing it, but the performance was sub-par for a game that's been out this long. The movement was linear and uninspiring, but the combat was great with new stances so it became a game of getting through traversal to fight. The story was too short, the planets too few, and the maps too small, so I would recommend buying it on sale like I did. Even having paid $35, the price seems a tad too high IMO. If you can get this for maybe $25 or $30 max, that would be about worth it.

I played this game for about 13.5 hours previously, and I really enjoyed it. Great visuals, fluid combat and amazing customization.

Recently, however, I've run into a HUGE issue... Controller support.
This game is quite literally built around the use of a controller, it even brings up a prompt that to have the best and most enjoyable play-through, you should use a controller.

Previously, I used my Xbox Series controller with absolutely ZERO issue, but after picking the game back up, it straight just doesn't work anymore. Pressing the left thumb-stick brings up a giant on-screen keyboard and I cant even pause the game without hitting ESC on my keyboard. None of the other buttons work at all and it seems the camera is stuck in "fastasfuckboi" mode. It's only "playable" with MaKB and I really don't want to play the game like that, because, at time of review, I JUST beat, at a nearly 100%, Fallen Order, using the same exact controller.

I might update the review if this issue gets fixed by the Devs before I figure it out myself but I spent a solid 2 hours online searching for a solution and nothing seems to work.


EDIT: I FIXED IT. for anyone having this issue, add the EA launcher as a non-steam game to your library and launch it from steam, this completely fixed my issue
Disappointed that the game still has so many crashes and issues after the game has been out for so long

It's so unfortunate that the game has this poor of performance - I did crank the game down to minimum quality settings and Performance FSR (using a 1070) and managed to get a stable 45fps. The reason I say it's unfortunate because is because this game is far and beyond anything the first attempted to do.

The story is so much more interesting and you can clearly tell the dev. team spent the time between releases thinking deeply on how they could make a rich and satisfying story about grief. I would say more but going into this knowing nothing made me enjoy it a lot more (it would also be very spoilery). 

The gameplay is also much deeper than the first and I love the different additions to the styles of combat. Cal must have the most advanced lightsaber in history at this point with how customisable it is.


TLDR: If you liked Jedi: Fallen Order, you'll love this game (as long as you can look past the performance issues).

Story: 8/10 - Cal's story is great, the antagonists are alright, and the overall story is decent
Gameplay: 6/10 - The new stances are awesome, but the actual core gameplay is much worse than JFO, as it feels like the game discourages parrying a lot more with incredibly harsh parry windows (playing on Jedi Grand Master) and enemies almost always spamming unblockables.
Visuals: 9/10 - Most levels look beautiful but some are quite bland and empty, graphics are superb, lighting is great
Performance: 5/10 - frame rate is quite inconsistent, and almost never goes above 50 fps (playing on an RTX 3060) and never reaches 60+ frames other than cutscenes on the mantis.

Only buy if you really enjoyed JFO or if it's on sale, or if they optimise performance a bit more and tweak enemy AI in a patch

An improvement on Fallen Order on pretty much every front. It does away with most of the jank that rubbed me wrong in that original game, combat feels tighter and deeper with the fun addition of upgradeable stances, and traversal is made much more engaging from the start as Cal thankfully already has most abilities unlocked by the start of the game this time around. 
Maps are larger, but thankfully fast travel is here so as to not make returning to places as a chore as it was before. The overall structure of the game is pretty similar still, though some meatier side content lets you spread out the main story missions and explore the planets a bit more. I‚Äôm still uninterested in collectibles here, cosmetics are simply not worth the time investment of solving puzzles and re-exploring areas, but force tears are a welcome addition to the exploration side of the adventure.
Some of the new things added do feel underbaked, especially the perks system. At least while playing in normal, I didn‚Äôt need to pay attention to it, and when I did, I was fairly frustrated by the limitations imposed on equipping them.
It still is a pretty standard AAA action adventure game, with big set pieces and an entertaining story that aside from some standout moments wont linger in your mind for long after rolling credits. Still, I really enjoyed that it narratively involves the High Republic era and that it doesn‚Äôt just stick to the familiar tropes like Fallen Order did. There are a few surprises, new and interesting characters, and compelling developments to the existing cast. It felt rather fresh in comparison to the major Star Wars media we‚Äôve been getting in the last couple of years.
Performance is pretty solid for most of the game, though it takes a real dip in the last couple of missions. Clearly the team prioritized optimizing the first chapter, which ran nearly flawlessly, to the detriment of the rest of the game. It‚Äôs playable, it didn‚Äôt affect my experience all that much, but It‚Äôs a clear stain on a pretty damn solid game that I hope the devs fix up.

I picked this game up skeptically, having hesitated for months due to performance issues on release. I reminded myself to keep my eyes on the clock as I opened the game so I didn't exceed the 2 hour window. 

Thankfully, that time never came. I loved the first Jedi game, and if you also did, you'll likely love this even more. In terms of the story and actual gameplay so far, it gives you more of the good stuff laid out in fallen order (plus extra) and the increased open feeling of the game compared to the first makes it even more fun to explore.

It was worth buying, but i'm glad I waited. Releasing this game underdone had unfortunately marked it's reputation for what could've been a no asterisk celebration of a great sequel. It's always frustrating seeing time and time again AAA publishers push something out too soon, leaving devs to scramble months after fixing the game under public scrutiny.

Any disruptive performance issues I had went away by adjusting just a few settings to fit my PC, but your mileage may vary. If the game looks interesting, pick it up (often on sale), and hopefully you'll be able to enjoy as much as I have... maybe set a timer for 2 hours just in case.

So I waited a whole year for EA to fix this garbage port and got it just recently on a sale for 50% off. And yet.. it is still the most terrible pc port I've been playing since Dark Souls 1. My 4070 ti is running Cyberpunk Ultra Pathtracing as smooth as a 8 bit game but Jedi Survivor manages to stutter and crash like a Disney Stock Cosplay.

Wow where to even begin. Combat seems fun enough, feels less floaty than Fallen Order. They added some quality of life improvements to the platforming so you can actually drop down a ledge without having to do some wild acrobatics, but that is unfortunately where the positives end.

I wanted to like this game, but 9 months since launch and the game remains in an unplayable state due to a memory leak that everyone knows about, and has known about since launch, yet EA has made no attempt to fix. I can't get out of the opening area without the game running out of VRAM and crashing during an autosave effectively corrupting my save file and forcing me to start over.

 It's unacceptable to me that EA can sell a game that doesn't run even when you are well beyond the recommended system requirements, and for that reason alone I not only won't be recommending this game, but I won't be buying a product from EA for the foreseeable future.

This game improves upon the original despite it feels a bit rushed towards the end imo, I heard it got some cut content too so that'd make sense. Gameplay and story-wise it's great, good boss fights, bounty hunting, much more customizations and world to explore. Downside is the performance, I WOULD NOT recommend this on PC even if you've beefy PC this will have stutter issue making your experience awful all around. I tolerated it as I loved the game itself, but not everyone can be as tolerating as me with these kind of issues especially if you have spent good penny on your PC. Get it on console instead if you have (I don't have it so I played here). There's some texture ghosting aswell, visual bugs which idk if they exist on console. Ppl to this day label this as worst PC port, and there's good reasons for it even after so many patches. I got this game so late and it's still in this condition which says a lot about EA, they don't give a shit, they literally said in a post that they can't do anything about it which should give you enough idea. Hell even in Fallen Order which came out 2019, they never fixed stutters, forget about this one. It won't happen. I shouldn't have bought this game myself, don't make my mistake.

The game has to "optimize files" every time it starts up. This seems completely unnecessary, and is a total waste of time. You don't need to optimize files for a menu, and you don't need to load game level files while you're in the main menu. You can do that when the level loads like every other game.

The game lags on my very strong and new PC. This is the only game that lags out of my entire Steam library. I'm being completely honest. There isn't a single game I own that lags, other than Jedi Survivor. It's as if the game is completely unoptimized. Look through all of my other reviews, and you won't find a single mention of lag in any of them.

Some of the audio clips are loud and staticy, as if the sound file is clipping. Either the files are actually clipping, or something is causing them to be played way too loud.

The stamina bar on some of the taller bosses is always near the top of the screen. When you finally drain their stamina bar and break their stance, their stamina bar can go high up off-screen, which causes you to miss out on a visual queue for your small attack window. I don't understand why your wouldn't have the enemy stamina bar height limit set to the top of the screen.

The bosses' projectile weapon throw can go through walls and buildings. This is bad game development. At least have it bounce off or hug the wall. Removing collision is lazy, and looks terrible, and isn't fair to the player.

The game stops when you have the boss at 5% health, to tell you that you can use a new or changed ability, as if that isn't one of the worst times to stop the game and tell you information that you didn't need to beat the boss. They even force you to hold a button to auto-kill the the boss that's at 5% health. Senseless.

This game crashed during the middle of a cut-scene. I don't think this has happened to me since I played a game on xbox 360. Even then I don't know if those crashes were ever during a cut-scene.

I paid around $35.00 for this game. Given my experience, I would say it's worth around $10.00.

Star Wars: Jedi Survivor is a great game. I got it bundled with Fallen Order, which I had played on console, during a Steam sale for a little less than $40 with tax and I'm super happy I snagged the deal.

While Jedi: Survivor improves on many things from the original, the lack of planet variety after finishing the game was disappointing because while each planet is exponentially larger than the ones in Fallen Order, the scenery doesn't vary nearly as much. The game play is great albeit slow and cumbersome at times but overall leaves you satisfied and thirsting to explore for more. Jedi: Survivor's story has me really conflicted. Without going in to any spoilers, I'll just say that after a certain point the plot was easily predictable and could've been handled differently to create a more satisfying and interesting ending.

With these criticisms aside however, Jedi: Survivor is definitely worth playing if you enjoyed Fallen Order. It does a really good job with the open-world and the level of customization is awesome--both cosmetically and in terms of game play styles with the new stances. I recommend using a controller while playing.

The artbook for Jedi: Survivor is coming out soon too so if you like the game you might want to check it out. I preordered it but judging on the Fallen Order artbook you might want to wait to read it until after completing the game to avoid spoilers.

Game bloat.  They've doubled down on the 'dense map you can't fully explore' trope.  The issue is that in order to make this work, you have to either learn brand new skills, or as is the case in this game, mysteriously forget how to use the Force.....again.  For force skills, pushing is one skill, pulling is another skill, but to push or pull things up or down, instead of forward or backwards? Well that is an entirely DIFFERENT skill than pushing or pulling, and you don't remember how to do this until 2/3s of the way through the game. Game bloat!
 Can't land at a base cause of reasons,  so you land at a distance and you go on foot through some crazy back trails and platforming hellscape, but a storm stops you, so you wait overnight and end up at the base just as your ship is landing at the base as well, making your entire prior level utterly worthless.
 For the entire Jedi order being wiped out, everyone is suspiciously well-equipped against lightsabers, including raiders and regular imperial troops.
  All of this is to make your time more difficult, but it is so glaringly obvious that it just feels like game bloat.
 Instead of dealing with the forms for lightsaber combat, they just did it stupid-like.  Hit the enemy with the blade, thats a skill!  Now, hit them HARDER, thats another skill!  Hit them HARDER and FURTHER, thats an entirely new skill!  Now dual-wielding, double-ended, and extra-long sabers are all different skill trees, and each one iterates just like this.  Game bloat.  The Vader fight is truly one of the lamest battles I've ever seen in a video game.  I just quit after that, it was so.....STUPID.  Lame-ass overpowered enemy you know you can't kill, unblockable attacks that track and slide across the map to grab you, being pushed, pulled and knocked down at will.  And he kills you at the end.  Just rage quit after that.

Worst port I've ever seen. the story is great but the port it horrific
The Good: Story, Graphics, continuation on original game
- There are new skill trees that compliment what you already know from the first game. 
- You start game with double jump and force push/pull etc so you're not starting over.
- They really add to the skills you learned in the first game with new skills like jump dash and ascension cable but your really want to have played the first game and learned those skills or this will be a challenge
The Bad: 
- Most garbage PC port ever made. They just didn't care. 
- Mouse is wonky and doesn't work well in the menus. 
- It's nearly impossible just to key bind because the mouse and controls are so bad
- Some of the keys are unbound and you have to end task and restart the game and bind them. 
- If you change the jump key you can't jump off of walls when running and also later when climbing. You then get stuck unless you use default key binds.
- The port was done so poorly that you get a reminder every time you load that you should get a controller and not use a keyboard and mouse
- Nothing is optimized. and the game optimizes files for 5 to 10 minutes every time it's loaded

Okay so i bought this on sale because I loved the first part. I heard it had problems at launch on PC and hoped they would be solved by now. It is not though. I am having technical issues left and right and it made me return the game. I am really sad about that as I love Star Wars and Star Wars games but it is literally impossible to play. I have stutters like many others, the controls do not work (I use an XBox Controller). I started with the recommended controller thing from steam and turned it off as well to see if it works better but it doesnt. Sometimes i do not block but he only lifts his hand without the lightsaber. Sometimes a keyboard randomly opens and i have to click to focus on the game again. The B button to go back does not work most of the times. It just does nothing. Overall a complete technical mess even after multiple months. I cannot recommend it in this state at all.
Game is is full of crashes . 10 time in less than 2 hours.

All the reviews talking about bugs and crashes aren't lying. played it fine for about half an hour then it started crashing. There's a massive 20+ page thread at the top of the official forum filled with people having this issue. I tried to play for about two hours, and it would crash consistently after about 20 minutes of gameplay... and I couldn't even make enough progress to get to the next save point. And then, every single time I loaded the game, it would take about 10 minutes to reconfigure files to supposedly improve to game or something.  It's unplayable in it's current state. 

I liked the first one a lot, really wanted to play this one.

The issues that were there on launch have been patched out (I haven't had any game-breaking bugs or crashes) and the ray-tracing is still broken in some places but I feel like that's an Unreal Engine problem that will be worked out in time, technical issues aside it is a major improvement in every aspect from Fallen Order and I'd say it's worth picking it up for $20 to $40

I pre-ordered the game a while back but only really started playing it this year.
The story and gameplay are phenomenal and rich, however thats basically where the good ends.
This game is very poorly optimized (even tho it takes 2 minutes "optimizing for your pc" on every start up) that you'll be immersed in the game when suddenly the game stutters and just dies.
This one major issue is the reason I cannot honestly recommend this game at full price. Get it on a major discount.

Are the story and gameplay fun? Yeah. Am I three hours in on Steam Deck with multiple crashes and significant performance issues? Also yeah. Shame such an otherwise fun game is a bad experience when played for more than an hour on the deck.

Having played Fallen Order a few years ago and then delving into Survivor, I had heard that this was an improvement over the original. However, the beginning was rather slow, taking me close to 10 hours into the game before I truly became invested in the story. This might be attributed to my tendency to explore nearly every nook and cranny of each location I visited before advancing the story, which consumed a significant amount of time without directly progressing it. Nonetheless, once the stakes became visibly higher and the urgency increased, the game became engaging. Several unexpected events occurred that genuinely shocked me, particularly "that one part" (iykyk). Based on my playtime, hours 16-19 stand out as peak Star Wars. Despite the sluggish start and the game's performance issues, as well as a minor gripe about the lack of planet diversity, the overall experience is incredibly solid, especially for die-hard Star Wars fans. This game and Fallen Order combined are probably the best thing to come out of Star Wars since Disney bought it.

Yes the PC port is very stuttery as of this writing (though much more stable than it used to be), and the writing is not as good as Fallen Order's with features like gleefully tying in with the wretched High Republic series of books. But there's no denying that from a gameplay, atmospheric, and graphical perspective, Star Wars Jedi: Survivor improves and refines on its predecessor to a high degree. 

Beginning with the single best opening to a Star Wars game since the Darth Vader prologue from The Force Unleashed, Survivor sets out to deliver an exhilarating action-adventure title with improved combat and customisation, and it succeeds: You can perform Force Mind Tricks which can allow enemies to temporarily fight on your side, you're given not one, not two, but FIVE different combat stances to master and upgrade, you're given an AI partner in some sections and you can make use of special attacks through this partner character, and of course the combat still f---ing ROCKS: You get all the powers you gained in Fallen Order right off the bat, new force attacks to wield and master, and you're given more challenging enemies to use these skills on, and the loop of pulling an enemy in and stabbing them, swapping to the other stance for crowd control or fast damage, engaging two other enemies with said lightsaber stance and then swapping to good ol' single-bladed to block, parry, and eliminate the elite feels so bloody satisfying.

So overall, though the console versions are a better choice due to their better optimisation, now is a perfectly good time to buy Jedi: Survivor on PC. It's a bigger, badder iteration of what came before, and once again it's the best thing to come out of Disney Star Wars not named "Rogue One".

As of Feb '24 and 6 hours into the game, not a single bug has broken my immersion yet. Leaving that aside, the game is just phenomenal, and it's just like the first one, but everything feels more grand, I suppose.

Edit: 2-9-24. Now that they've patched this game numerous times, it's actually pretty fun to play. I do get some frame drops here and there, but they are nothing like they used to be. I really was excited for this game to release last year but I held off on buying it because of all the reports about the game being unplayable. Bought the game because it was on sale, and the game ran great on medium graphics on my pc. I got through the first mission with no problems, but soon ran into crash city on the second mission to find Greez. Can't play more than a few minutes without the game crashing. I tried some troubleshooting options, made sure my system and game were completely up to date, cleaned up my pc and closed all other programs while running the game, changed the game to high priority in task manager, and tinkered with some of the game properties that helped other users with the crashing problem but nothing has worked. I now think that maybe I need to upgrade some of my system components, if I want to play this game. I currently am running Ryzen 5 3600X processor with GTX1660 Super graphics and 16 GB ram. The system is a little dated, but runs most games great on average graphic modes. I got through the first game FALLEN ORDER with only a couple crashes throughout the entire play through. Anybody think there are some other troubleshooting options I can try, or just need to upgrade my pc?

This game deserves more credit. Sure, there are bugs here and there, sure they are annoying... but compare it to its predecessor, Survivor absolutely kills it. Sure now you got an actual hub and ditch the linear campaign for a more open-world style... but that's exactly the point. If you want the  story only, you go for it. If you feel like Jedi-ing a bit more, you're absolutely welcome to do that. I think this game is as close as it gets to the old-school Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy games... You know, the ones you wouldn't play anymore on your new rig if your life depended on it.

Gameplay was great, performance was alright, but the crashes make it almost unplayable. Already had 3 crashes and I haven't even gotten past the first stage.

From the bit I was able to play it seems like a fun sequel. The problem is that ea put out a patch that completely breaks big picture mode to the point it won't display the game. Until they fix it I can't recommend.

Edit:
Looking into it more this seems to still be a pattern with EA especially for pc ports. Here are some more details on my experience. The game had issues with big picture mode (I could hear the audio for the overlay but it wouldn't show and the controller lighting kept changing to the default every few minutes unless I hit the button for the overlay) the first time I launched but it did work eventually. After that however I can hear the game but not see it. On top of that the performance is pathetic even on reduced settings. To top it all off despite me buying the game ON STEAM they forced me to install their garbage platform for a SINGLE PLAYER only game. 

Come on EA this game could have made you a fortune if it just worked. The previous game was a smash hit and this could have been too if you just put a little more care into making a quality product. Its been around a year since release and its still unplayable for a lot of people. Get your garbage out of a single player game that has no use for it and make a decent product. Thats all you had to do and I would have bought this on day one at full price happily (I had even booked vacation time to play that I cancelled when I saw the state of it). Now here I am absolutely loving the previous game (I bought it in ps4 and pc and played it multiple times on both) reluctantly returning the game because its just not where it should be. The day you get your act together I will happily buy this, but unfortunately you seem to get a kick out of trashing your best products.

I was worried about the reported stuttering issues but 17 hours in and returning to Coruscant story-wise, I've not had a single noticeable frame drop or crash. The game set itself to high settings with FSR on quality, ray tracing disabled, and it's been rock solid.

Ok, if this was 50 dollars cheaper, or 50 gigabytes smaller, or 50 times less buggy, it would be great. However, it is 70 dollars, 128 gigabytes, and overwhelmingly buggy, so as it stands, I can't recommend this. The story's good (by videogame standards), the gameplay is fun (when it works), and there's quite a bit of playtime, but it has some issues.

This game is a lot like an oatmeal raisin cookie. On the surface, it looks like a great product, because it takes the appearance and branding of a better item. You go in expecting a pleasureful experience but are soon disappointed. Technically, it has a lot of substance, but all that substance is dry and tasteless.

For the record, I don't mind oatmeal raisin cookies, I just felt like being clever. This game isn't really worth it.

This port is utter garbage. We need to hold AAA developers to higher standards. The menus don't even work properly with a controller. And for some reason it would never save my invert Y axis setting. And the framerate drops are heinous. I thought it was worth checking out at 50% off for $35 but I wouldn't even pay $3.50 for this game, much less 10x that amount. 

Publishers: do better
Players: demand better

And FWIW, I am a very technical PC gamer. I keep a very clean Win10 installation for gaming and have decent hardware: Ryzen 5950x, RTX 3070Ti, 32 GB G.Skill 3600 CL14 RAM, Samsung 980 Pro, X570...and it still runs like a potato. 

I'm also a software developer myself so I understand the technical hurdles. But they're not THAT difficult. This is just corporate greed. I'm sure EA didn't give the developers enough time or resources to properly port this to PC -- I've played it on PS5 and it was pretty great (after the first few patches). I would have gladly bought this game again on PC if it worked properly. But the port is so terrible that now I kinda feel bad for giving EA any of my money in the first place when I bought it for PS5. 

</rant>

Crashing on Jedha. Missing all the cut scenes due to constantly crashing every 5 minutes. Game was working fine with only one crash before Jedha.

--Jumped back in a year later. Game works but this is one of those games I don't like hitting reset on. Game is everything I love and want more, but disappointed in the experience due to release state.

I'll cut right to the chase. Is the performance fantastic? No. Is it bearable? For me, yes. Generally, I was getting 60 frames (my setup is a 3070, 32gb ram, and Ryzen 5 5600x) with DLSS, but there were definitely frame drops where it would chug down to 20 or so. In my experience, this usually happened during exploration/traversal, not combat. So it was bearable. Most frustrating part was 2 hard crashes, one of which wiped away 90 minutes of progress. 
But, putting aside performance, the game itself is fantastic. In my opinion, an improvement over the first game. In particular, the ability to choose your own playstyle with the 6 stances on offer made for a lot of fun deciding what I liked best. I also quite liked the story, with the new and returning characters all making for interesting dynamics and memorable beats. 
My advice would be to pick it up and give it a shot. If the performance in the first hour is bad, request the refund. If you can tolerate it, though, it's worth seeing through to the end.

So. I've bought this in a Steam sale. It was somewhere in the range of 60%-80% discounted. So the choice was easy.

After 8-9 patches the game is still lagging sometimes. See Digital Foundry's review after 6 months. The latest patch from around 17-01 completely ignores my controllers.

For me it presents as such: The game thinks I am using mouse and keyboard while I'm using a controller. So the in-game prompts change from X/Y/A/B to "enter" or different symbols/prompts. The controller input for entering into the menu translates to a backwards dash. When I press "B" to go back in the menu it trips up/flips out. It wants to translate multiple inputs at the same time. The audio signals as much, giving me at least 3, maybe 4 or more "clicks".

Here's what I tried:

    Unplugging keyboard and mouse and other peripherals, just to check if these were causing it. No solution, 
    the issue persists.
    Different controllers, checking if the controller is faulty. No solution, the issue persists.
    Tried the same controller on different games. No issue. So this proves it is not the controller.
    Checking file integrity through the Steam app. No solution, the issue persists.
    Uninstalling the game and reinstalling through Steam. No solution, the issue persists.
    Checking for Windows updates and GPU updates. No solution, the issue persists.
    Raising a Help-desk ticket with EA. No solution, "we do not support your peripherals".

I've had a friend confirm this. Through Steam, they downloaded both Jedi: Fallen Order and Survivor. Their controllers (DS4 and DS5) both work fine on Fallen Order. But Survivor provides the same issues as I am experiencing. So this seems to be the work of the new patch.

I really want to undo the latest patch, but EA support is no help. The game has become unplayable.

The only way I've been able to get it back in working order now has been to "add a game" to my Steam library. That "game" is the EA app. Now I have to start the EA app through Steam, then start the game. And the graphics have been downgraded in this way.

So I'll try to finish the story after which I'll uninstall and never look back

So even that is just preventing me from loading the game a large portion of the time. Even when I finally get into the game, even with settings on the lowest, the frame rate is so low for so often that it is truly unplayable especially for a souls-like where 5 second of buffering will just leave you dead after it finally catches up and loads. The game play seems pretty good when the frame rate is passing, still some jank but fun enough to enjoy. I was excited about the story but it seems as though I will have to wait even longer for the game to actually be in a working state and I may give up altogether and just ask for a refund because in my opinion, it is not in a working state especially considering they are asking 70$ for a game that does not work many months post launch. Very disappointed but not honestly something I should have expected with EA

Really good game. Loved playing through it. Actually got me into Star Wars itself (somewhere at the middle of the game I started to watch everything Star Wars I could find and became a huge fan). Saw the trailer on Steam and was already hooked, gameplay looked so fun and awesome, I just had to play it. I started with Fallen Order and loved the gameplay, the story and the characters. Continued with Survivor and was absolutely stunned by the world building, even better gameplay, character depth and storytelling. Such an awesome game and Cal is just amazing (also Geez, damn I wanted to hug him throughout the entire game, probably my favourite character besides Cal himself) 

Somewhere after the middle of the game I experienced a few crashes. Not to many to be bothered but still, they seem to be present. Was a bit unnerving in the beginning but I just started to save more often, so I wouldn't lose to much progress but really it didn't happen a lot so it was fine. 

So I full heartedly recommend this game, because it just really is that amazing. No crashes could have stooped me to play through it (and again for me there weren't that many)  because I wanted to no how the story unfolds and what would happen to those lovely characters and oh boy the end, have to say it didn't got me outright cold but almost. Really great spin and storytelling. Can't wait to see, what's comming next for Cal and the others and until then I will play through Fallen Order and Survivor again.

I ran into some issues with the framerate of the game causing some crashes, but these were ultimately fixed by setting my fps to 60 in my GPU driver settings for the game. There is no fps setting in game. Following setting a limit on the fps, I still experienced a few crashes, but they were limited to one very spoiler-y area near the end of the game.

All I can really say about the game is "WOW!" If this game would've released in the current state at launch, we would've been looking at a GOTY contender. The story is great and the game play is fun. When the game hits its peaks in the action and the story, it is hard to top. Some gripes about the platforming controls aside, this game nails what a modern Star Wars game should be. I am very interested in what the team at Respawn can do for a final chapter to the Jedi trilogy.

Jedi Survivor is a third person action game set in the Star Wars universe, where Cal Kestis returns for the sequel to Fallen Order, in search for a home safe from the Empire.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

‚Ä¢	Combat is mostly enjoyable as you‚Äôll use Cal‚Äôs lightsaber and force powers to defeat various enemies including stormtroopers, bounty hunters, large and small wildlife, and various types of droids (some recognisable from episode 1).

‚Ä¢	Lightsaber has five stances to choose from, including single or dual wield, double blade, Kylo Ren style 2 handed, and single blade combined with a blaster. Each stance can be upgraded with special moves. I mostly used the double blade as it features fast attacks and long reach, which helped me to evade enemy attacks.

‚Ä¢	Many enemies will try to shoot you from long range, but if you time blocks correctly, your lightsaber will deflect the blaster bolts back to damage or kill the enemy.

‚Ä¢	I regularly used force push to knock weaker enemies off ledges for instant kills. One time I even managed to do this to a miniboss who still had about 80% of their health bar remaining. You can also use the force to pull enemies, throw your lightsaber, and use mind trick to make enemies attack each other.

‚Ä¢	Most of the game takes place on the planets Koboh and Jedah, in addition to a couple of smaller planets and a brief visit to Coruscant.

‚Ä¢	Playing on Jedi Knight difficulty (the middle of five options), combat is challenging but mostly fair. I really struggled with the final boss [spoiler]who for some reason is significantly more powerful than Darth Vader[/spoiler], and because I wasn‚Äôt enjoying the game for reasons that I‚Äôm about to get to, eventually I just dropped down to story mode so I could be done with it.

‚Ä¢	Much of the action takes place miles above ground level, and you have to navigate terribly designed maps which are full of huge gaps where you can fall to an instant death. You‚Äôll need to jump, double jump, air dash, wall run, grapple and rope swing. The further you progress in the game, and the more force powers you unlock, the longer and more annoying these sequences become, regularly requiring the player to chain together 15-20 moves, and if you slightly miss time anything, you‚Äôll have to go all the way back to the start of the sequence and do it all again. And there were a number of occasions where I was confused about where I needed to go next, or how to actually get there, which frequently interrupted the pace of the combat.

‚Ä¢	Sure, Fallen Order had some sections like this, but while those were relatively short, Jedi Survivor‚Äôs maps are entirely built around it. Maybe some players like this kind of gameplay, but I don‚Äôt. It reminds me of the difference between Doom 2016 (which I loved) and Doom Eternal (which I hated, and yes I know I‚Äôm in the minority there too).

[h1]Story[/h1]

‚Ä¢	Story is nothing special, I think it suffers from the villains not being interesting characters, but its at least better than some of the recent Disney+ TV shows (Boba Fett, Obi-Wan, Ahsoka).

‚Ä¢	Cal‚Äôs struggle with the dark side, and his relationships with the companions who previously appeared in Jedi Order, especially Merrin, did at least provide some excitement.

‚Ä¢	Voice acting is good.

[h1]Technical[/h1]

‚Ä¢	It took me 25 hours to complete the main story and a few side quests.

‚Ä¢	While I didn‚Äôt notice any significant framerate drops, the performance doesn‚Äôt feel smooth, like there are frequent small stutters (i7-12700K, 32GB DDR4, RTX 3080, 1440p). The first few hours seemed mostly fine, but it got worse the further I progressed. Koboh has the worst problems, but as its also the biggest planet, this is where you‚Äôll spend the most time.

‚Ä¢	I also regularly noticed white flashes at the edge of the screen while panning the camera sideways inside buildings. I can‚Äôt remember seeing this before in other games so I don‚Äôt know what is causing it, perhaps the game was loading textures slightly slowly, even though its installed on my SSD.

‚Ä¢	The game optimises some files (I‚Äôm assuming shaders) every time you start it up, it doesn‚Äôt take long, but considering the above issues, I‚Äôm not sure if this actually does anything.

‚Ä¢	The game crashed twice with no error message. By itself its not the end of the world (I can live with 2 crashes in 25 hours), but it still deserves to be added to this list of shame.

‚Ä¢	Level up menu doesn‚Äôt tell you what the abilities further up the tree actually do until you acquire the ability immediately below it. I‚Äôve never seen a game do this, usually you can see the whole skill tree to plan your character build in advance, so this is a really dumb design decision.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Jedi Survivor isn‚Äôt a terrible game, and if Steam‚Äôs review system allowed a neutral option I would have picked that, but overall my feelings are more negative than positive.

While my dislike for the aerial gymnastics is a personal preference which other players might not have a problem with, you‚Äôll still have to deal with unacceptable technical performance which gets in the way of the otherwise enjoyable combat and story.

Only recommended for hardcore Star Wars fans, on a deep sale.

I enjoyed Fallen Order and this game is quite similar but builds off of. I wrote a more in depth review of that game but I will give my spoiler-free takeaways from this game here briefly then get into some mild spoilers (same as the last review I will not spoil the best part)

What I liked: 
- The atmosphere of this game
- The skill progression
- The story

What I didn't like
- The number of planets
- The polish
- The graphics/performance

[h2] Atmosphere [/h2]
This was by far the best part of the game. The Jedi series does a great job at linking episodes 3 and 4 well, as this is probably the coolest time period in Star Wars, and this game expands upon Fallen Order. I'll spoiler flare this, but the coolest faction you fight in this game are the Bedlam raiders and it may be just because I am a [spoiler] prequel fan [/spoiler] but I thought it was cool and logical how they used [spoiler] battle droids [/spoiler] in their armies. Fighting them at the same time as stormtroopers is so mind blowing to me. The wild west was done well with my favorite part of the game Koboh. The planet has so much to explore and feels like a home base which I think the franchise desperately needed. Some of my favorite moments in the game was just getting lost and exploring Koboh. I also enjoyed the customization in this game a lot more than Fallen Order. I got to pick all of my favorite colors, outfits, hairstyle, lightsaber, etc very early on due to my exploration and am very satisfied with how I made Cal look. 

[h2] Progression [/h2]
I thought this game did progression in a similar way to Fallen Order but better. I enjoyed trying out all of the different lightsaber configurations you can do - however I stuck to [spoiler] dual sabers + cross-guard [/spoiler] for most of the game. I also enjoyed the progression with regard to mobility, of which I think Survivor did better than Fallen Order. I would get lost exploring Koboh, and for example see a [spoiler] balloon [/spoiler] and be confused why I cannot progress through the map but realized I just needed to progress through the story to unlock that mobility. It feels more arbitrary than in Fallen Order, where you would learn double jump or something, but in Fallen Order I found the mobility upgrades specifically more fun with regards to exploring Koboh. 

[h2] Story [/h2]
I won't get into much about the story, however I very much enjoyed it from start to finish. At the end of Fallen Order we assembled a cool cast of characters and when I picked up this game I was expecting us to pick up right back where we left off. However, to my initial dismay we did not get that and instead got a time jump. However, I would argue that this payed off when I consider the course of the narrative and especially the ending. Yes, you are in a sense re-assembling the same cast of characters however to me it adds to the atmosphere. How the characters changed and how the exist at the end of the story. I very much enjoyed the story's conclusion. If I were to criticize the story, I'd say that the game could have handled the Villains better. There were a few main Villains and I would argue that two of the three were handled okay and one was handled masterfully. 

[h2] Planets [/h2]
I have basically stated that my main enjoyment in this game has been Koboh. That is true, but honestly it is the only planet in this game that was interesting to explore. The other planets feel half baked and visually boring especially when you compare this game to Fallen Order. We do get a fan favorite map Coruscant which a Star Wars game has desperately needed for a while. However, I would say that the only map with any replay value is Koboh. Most everything else you can fully explore while progressing through the story. One of my favorite parts of these two Jedi games were back tracking and exploring new things you've unlocked but only one planet does this. You could argue that value and quality of Koboh is worth multiple planets, but if that is the case they need to make the other planets visually distinct from Koboh. Which they weren't. The overall color pallet of the games planets is very monochromatic. For example, in Fallen Order when you visit Kashyyk this disrupts the color pallet with a very green planet. But when you go from a desert to the wild west to a grey moon rock the colors don't change that much and it can look boring visually. 

[h2] Polish [/h2]
This game is very unpolished. Sure, there's a big map to explore but so many things you walk on you feel like you're about to phase through the map. For example, lets say there's an X wing on the map if you jump onto it nine times out of ten you would phase right through it, slide off, or be standing on an invisible box feet above the structure. Only one of ten times would you jump on something that isn't the standard pathways you would traverse and actually stand on it like you would if this was real life. It gets frustrating when you go to explore around the map but the map would decieve you and actually the developers didn't bother coding collision physics. The game also just generally feels clunky. With regards to bugs, I only ever experienced one bug that was basically the EA launcher and steam launcher disagreeing with my controller inputs which was solved by launching the EA launcher through steam. 

[h2] Graphics [/h2]
Biggest complaint right here. I have lower to medium computer PC specs when you consider what is needed to play this game. And I had to run the graphics at the lowest possible setting and would barely get an average 30-45 fps. And that's with the game looking straight up worse than a Ps2 game. I would rather just be playing an other ps2 or ps3 game from a visual standpoint, as it would look and run better. Which is crazy, this is a huge trend in the modern gaming sphere where games are vomited out horribly optimized meaning people have to buy crazy expensive GPUs when the devs could just optimize their games or just make games with "worse" graphics but run better performance wise. You could even stylize it to make up for the "worse" graphics and by "worse" I mean not photo realistic which I don't even want anyways I just want decent performance. There were times where Cal looked like a lego figure which was crazy but luckily everything else about the game made it worth playing.

Unfortunately, I wrote a bad review about this game before, thinking it was because of it, after trying for months and not being able to open it. The PC was restarting itself every time I tried to start it. Turns out the problem was only in my ten-year-old power supply. When I replaced my 750 watt power supply with a 1300 watt monster, everything went perfect. With the latest 24.1.1 adrenaline, Ryzen 5 3600 and 32 GB DDR4 RAM and RX 6800xt, the game currently gives 100+ fps in 4K epic settings with FSR balance.
As for the game; I've played Fallen Order before and liked it very much. I thought it truly reflected the unique atmosphere of the Star Wars world, even though it had its shortcomings. In the first episode, we met our young character named Cal Kestis, who took his first step towards becoming a magnificent Jedi, and of course his companions. As for Jedi Surviver, I'm only on the planet Koboh at the end of the 10th hour, and even now I can easily say that they have surpassed the first game in every aspect. Brand new mechanics added to the game, the richness of storytelling, graphics that have improved with the development of technology, tons of different creatures from the depths of the Star Wars universe... In short, the game is truly magnificent. However, in a way that I cannot understand at all, EA managed to turn this game, which could be a candidate for one of the best games of 2023, into a technical disaster and not even be a candidate for anything, or let's say it was a candidate for the disaster of the year award. For now, without further ado, I'll end this review by saying that it's a game that definitely deserves its full price, with not much possibility that it will change. 9/10

Star Wars jedi: survivor is one of if not the best open world PvE Star Wars games. graphics are amazing if you have the correct specs to run it on the high settings. but i do wish it would automatically save once you completed things instead of having to return to a way-point to save your progress. i have left the game countless times and forgot to save only to come back and see that 30 minutes of grinding out force echos and items to be reversed and have to start all over again. the story line is also insane and filled with love, grief and very unpredictable turns that made me want to play the story over multiple times.

The game is fun.  There are story elements that are a bit foolish, but for the most part it is fantastic and enjoyable.

     There is simply a bug that randomly occurs (seemingly) that makes it unplayable if you use a controller.

     63 hours in, after enjoying quite a bit of the game, my controller simply - one moment - became remapped to randomized inputs.  I tried everything I could on the game - remapping the buttons, resetting the control scheme, disabling STEAM mapping.  Tried the controller in other games - worked perfectly fine.  There were times in the initial stages of the issue becoming present where it would occur, then go away, so I tried reboots, restarts, and a variety of 'turn it off and turn it back on again' type solutions for both hard and software.  Nothing worked.  Cal just continued to randomly jerk around and I couldn't even get to the settings menu with my controller - it had suddenly become a block - wait no a force power - wait no a block button.  Frustration, sadness, and shock.

     Sadly, after a series of several days of attempting to find a solution, I realized that the issue had replaced my enjoyment of the game with a constant fear that even if fixed this issue would sneak back up and randomly eliminate my ability to progress further into the game with a controller.  This has now - after consideration and reflection - completely removed my desire to continue what I would consider a potential waste of time and effort.

   If you use a controller, be aware of potential issues.
   If you use a controller, have had this issue, and are willing to share how you fixed it, please let me know.  I am open to revisiting this if a root cause and solve is available.

Cheers,
   TP

First off, I want to say that I loved this game. The game really was amazing and lived up to Jedi: Fallen Order. Below I am going to list some pros and cons of the game and you can decide if you want to play it. I did end up 100%ing the game in the end which took awhile so I will also be factoring those factors in replayability, gameplay, and such. 

Pros:

‚ö™ The Story. The story for Jedi: Survivor was amazing in every way and it truly made this game feel like a Star Wars game while exploring such an unknown area of the lore and mixed it with amazing moments and a great plot-twist.

‚ö™ The Gameplay. The gameplay for this game was unique, there was variety, and it was VERY smooth. The variety of the different lightsaber stances that Cal obtained gave you SO much variety. Fighting enemies and bosses with different abilities and moves felt so unique to your specific playstyle and I absolutely loved that. Even when 100%ing I still had fun because I was able to try out two lightsaber stances that I really hadn't touched. 

‚ö™The World. The world of each planet in this game was so expansive. Even for smaller planets like Coruscant, it still felt like there was so much to do there because of the constant movement of the world around. And as for the biggest planets Koboh and Jedha, it was fantastic. It was everything I could've asked for in a Star Wars game when exploring and everything was always kept fresh even when going for 100%.

‚ö™The Characters. Now this is something that drastically improved from Jedi: Fallen Order. Characters like Merrin have been brought up from basically nothing into fan-favorites. Other more side-characters like Cordova really had you make more of an attachment even though you hadn't seen them in Jedi: Fallen Order (in person). Caij, Doma, Turgle, Zee, and even Skoova are all characters I'd love to see return because of the way that they were represented and the personality that they had. 

Cons:

‚ö™The Optimization. Optimization and graphic issues for this game have been extremely common unfortunately. Frame drops, crashes, bugs, grainy areas, and more have been evident in players' play sessions and it really has brought the game's hype down. With future patches I am hoping this will go away and if it does completely, I will update this review as needed but for now, expect bad optimization.

‚ö™Character Movement and Quality of Life. This is more of a small scale thing but I was always annoyed by the character movements in some in-game cutscenes and in other areas. Whether they were walking or speaking, it just felt robotic at times. Once again this is small and for the most part it looks fine but I'd thought I'd add it in.

Overall, Jedi: Survivor is an absolute must-play for any Star Wars fan and an encouraging play for non Star Wars fans. With some bad optimization and bugs, the game has received backlash but that is and will be fixed (I hope at least). The pros in this game do really outweigh the cons here and I want you if you're reading this to play and try this game. You won't regret it. 

My Final Rating (Currently): 92/100
(for note Jedi: Fallen Order for me was a solid 88/100)
And yes I am a massive Star Wars fan so expect a little bias here but I tried to keep it unbiased.

So about 8 months later, I will change my review because the game is definitely worth it now.

When I finished this game for the first time I thought, This is the best Star Wars sequel since KOTOR 2. But, then I couldn't actually remember much about KOTOR 2 so I went back and played through it immediately after Jedi Survivor. Then I started watching the movies, all of the originals and then the prequels. And I replayed Fallen Order. And then I watched a few shows, started reading the books and am now back to Jedi Survivor doing my new game plus run. Really, what this game is is a joyous romp through the galaxy so many of us have grown up with. It is the best that galaxy has ever looked and sounded (my god, the music in this game is *perfect Star Wars) and it is just reveling in the characters this series has given us. Cal, Greez, Merrin and Cere are all woven into the fabric of Star Wars in ways that develop them much more than the meandering plot of the game. And that's fine. The plot of Star Wars has rarely been the point-- it's always about the characters. And what this game reminded me is that no matter how you feel about the current state of Star Wars it is still fantastic to get lost in all the stories told over the last 50 years. This game brought me back to Star Wars in a way I haven't been as exuberant about since I was a child.

Going back to KOTOR 2 made me realize how similar these two games are. Both are strange stories, fragmented and a little unfocused but both are pushing against the boundaries of typical Star Wars narratives. Both explore the meaning of Jedi and what forms the force can take. And both games are fundamentally busted. KOTOR 2 needs a mod to fix its rushed conclusion and unbalanced gameplay. Jedi Survivor needs serious compromises to be made to enjoy it on a technical level. Both games feel like these patched together, barely functioning experiences with directive vision that outpaced the technical foundations of the games. They barely work. But, wow when they do, there's a magic to these games that is the promise delivered by the very notes of the iconic music that's been echoing around since before many of us were born. 

I appreciate this game for so many things. The art direction is stunning at all times. Coruscant has never looked better and Koboh is FILLED with secrets. There are so many gestures and hints at the wider galaxy that on a second playthrough I am grinning at the references to Manaan, and Nar Shaddaa and giddy at the cameos hinted at. I forgive the game when it freezes, or stutters, or I get mauled from the often clumsy combat. I slow down and poke around the planets and sometimes just rush to the next story beat because I want to know where these characters will end up. And now that I've seen where it all goes, I just want to go back and spend more time with them in this delightful world Respawn has made. Hopefully, the game will be uncompromised by technical issues sometime soon (or in five years when new technology can brute force through the problems) but until then it is still the second best Star Wars game ever made. 

My tips for good performance: Drop the resolution, use DLSS/FSR, and absolutely cap the framerate using your Control Panel. It will still stutter and at worst freeze for a few seconds but it's not terrible now and at least for me, I hardly notice it anymore.

Is it ideal, no. Does it detract from the game. Absolutely. I still really, really enjoy this game.

It's fine. The main issues I had were the characters going to the same 2 planets repeatedly(Fallen Order had a bit more biome variety) and performance. I have the most average PC on Earth(at least according to the Steam hardware surveys), and I got a decent amount of frame drops in the more dense areas, especially on the second planet that you spend 65% of the game in. It was never unplayable by any means, but it was definitely annoying when it happened. The ending was pretty anticlimactic, too, didn't blow muh socks off like the first one. The boss fight before the final boss is way more interesting. Exploration's a bit more fun than the first one, but it's still the worst part of the experience, the combat is really where it's at. Other than that, I feel like they improved on almost every mechanic from the first game. There's also a lot more to do than Fallen Order as well, so if you're a broke nerd who can't afford to buy many games, you'll get your money's worth out of this one.

The story is annoying too, and dialogue and writing is boring, you just skip all the blah blah....

For me, it's not a great game, it's just average because of those flaws.

The story and the setting is nice as usual. But the game got infected with consolitis, so you can have the joy of navigating thru 10001 submenus. Bossfights are utterly broken, I just skipped them by setting it to story mode, so my keyboard and monitor and mental health could stay intact (and yeah, I played Elden Ring, it was super easy compared to this bossfight-garbage). Basically, there're you... there are the bosses... and you die... randomly... by unblockable insta-animated-death moves... enjoy. Loading point is about 2mins away to spice things up.

Jedi: Survivor is an amazing game. It improves on basically everything that Fallen Order started with new powers, more lightsaber stances, better combat and so much more customization. You can play the game the way you like, with whatever playstyle you prefer. 

The story is also great with some old friends coming back and new faces showing up. It's clear that Cal evolved so much since the first game and his entire arc shows it. He's a great protagonist and the game makes sure that you feel as close to him as possible.

I could go on but I'm gonna get to the point, because you're probably wondering "if this guy loves the game so much, then why the hell is this review negative?", and that is because of one simple thing that sours the whole experience and makes it really hard to enjoy the game as a whole: performance.

The game just doesn't seem to work properly whenever you get to a slightly larger area, which composes basically 60% of the entire game. You can be playing the story normally but as soon as you try exploring or going to a different area, there's a pretty good chance your frames will drop to 20 with constant stutters and just general instability. And that's universal, no matter if you upgrade your PC every two months with the latest parts, there's a pretty good chance that you'll be having headaches from the constant drops and frame instability.

The worst part is the game is absolutely amazing, it's everything I expected from a Fallen Order sequel and more but I can't even walk on the main hub without having my frames jumping up and down with unpredictable drops every 10 seconds. It's completely unacceptable that a game can be launched like this on PC while the console versions of the game have basically no issue running it. Because that's the main problem here, if you even interact with the game's UI for a few minutes you'll see that this was made to be played with a controller, on a console. Some of the UIs literally have no mouse support forcing you to use WASD. It's not unusable, but you can see that they (EA/Respawn) weren't giving half a shit about the PC community and forgot to optimize the game for PC users.

I hope that one day they'll fix the performance issues and make the game run smoothly as a whole. When that happens, I'll be the first to change my review to reflect how the game REALLY plays and how good it really can be. Until then, I can't recommend this to anyone. Wait until the issues are actually fixed and then think of getting the game.

Experienced no issues with stuttering or crashing on all ultra setting, the game itself is great a perfect continuation of Jedi Fallen Order and the lightsaber and force abilities are better than ever 8/10

I could not give a high rating, here are my opinion about this game:

Pros:
1. Nearly perfect story and ending.
2. Immersive Star Wars gaming experience.
3. Exquisite design of most scenes.

Cons:
1. Extremely poor optimization. My PC is with i9-13900 and RTX4090, I often experience stuttering at UWQHD (3440x1440), with very poor 1% low frame rate performance.
2. Frequent crashes due to some unknown reasons.
3. Only small improvements in graphics quality compared to the previous Jedi the fallen order, with mediocre outdoor scene, inside building is comparative good.
4. Terrible combat system, nauseating boss fights, greatly affecting the continuity of the story, make me wanna throw up sometimes.
5. As a purely single-player game, aside from the commendable storyline, the gaming experience is even inferior to Star Wars Battlefront 2 from years ago, a game which I actually really liked for its storyline and graphics.

EA has now made it impossible to use a controller due to their new update to the EA app.

Fun experience overall. Game play is smooth and enjoyable, boss fights are good, story is interesting enough (so far). One boss fight was so funny I actually applauded afterwards. Incredible haha. Enjoyed the new stances, the new crossguard stance, despite making me puke every time I look at that monstrosity of a lightsaber, was very satisfying. Not much else to add, nice customisation, interesting puzzles, great dismemberment and finishing blows; very solid game.

A few areas to be improved:
-Cut down on those 'unlock this ability to access this area for a cosmetic' backtracking places. it's fine if it leads to an interesting area or a boss fight, but having to go through the same areas 3+ times because of it is tedious and unrewarding. The first game did this as well and it does nothing but artificially add game time. Instead reward the players who go out of their way to explore (because they'll do it regardless) instead of punishing them with a duller experience for a cosmetic they're probably not going to use anyway.
-Go all out on customisation. Maybe one day we'll get a game like this where we get to customise our jedi from head to toe. For the time being however, atleast let us have more control over outfit colours. There's so many interesting outfits that I never put on because I didn't like the colour scheme options I was given. Also I appreciate the different blades having different sounds, but giving us some shader options for the colour would feel so amazing and would make the lightsaber feel more personable.
-A realism mode. I know it would be gimmicky, but playing through the game with realistic damage both to and from the enemies would allow a more immersive and tactical experience. It would add replayability to the game which could be a substitute for the backtrack exploring. It adds a more healthy, satisfying and enjoyable dynamic to the gameplay.

Like I said, very enjoyable experience. Cannot express how happy and appreciative that we get to play these single player story based games as a Jedi. I hope this is just the beginning for these games, There is so much of this universe (past and future) ready to be created and explored. I look forward to every second of it.
