Another solid entry to continue the series. I loved the first game, and this one has everything from Fallen Order and expands on a lot of the things that made it great. The story was very compelling, and I'll more than likely do a New Game + to enjoy it a second time. Combat can at times feel spammy, but it seems like there is plenty of depth in the moves if you want to play at a higher level, or you can learn one or two moves for a stance you like and stick with it. Customization is much deeper than the first game and very fun if you are interested in that. Overall, a great game if you are a Star Wars fan, and even more so if you were a fan of Fallen Order.

This game is a waste of your money.  I should have heeded the reviews that said it was broken. It's been over 3 months and it is still entirely unplayable on my system. I played it for about 6-10 hours and then the game started crashing once I got to this sand slide to get to "Cere's" base. There have been 6.5 patches and none of them have fixed this on the PC. I will never buy an EA game at launch if there's even a hint of instability on PC. It was a complete waste of my money. I tried so many different solutions and none of them work. I would not recommend you buy this on a PC. My specs: 4090,  Intel I910900k, 64 gigs of RAM. 

UPDATE: For anyone who has had this game crash going to Cere's base on the sand planet with the slide and scorpion that comes up out of sand, if you take a different route and ride that tall camel things which then walk up and over the giant stone hand thing, it seems to  circumvent t he crashing that occurs as you slide down the the ramp to get to the stone hand. It's just a different route and it worked so I can finally enjoy the game and the story.

*Update*
I'm much further now and i really really like the game. All new implementations are fun. I love the crossguard, for example.
Also, the character-writing is very good. You connect with the good Guys. I love Merrin's jokes and Skoova always has me laughing with his fisherman's stories.
But as it was with Fallen Order, when it comes to the bad guys (except maybe the Ninth Sister, which simply IS a stupid brute) - the Second Sister was a masterpiece -, Survivor shines in that category.
In Survivor, digging deeper in the story you come to realize, that they all are haunted and broken. Be it a code of honor that simply turned to an unbearable burden of being instrumentalized, or be it overcommitment and ambition turning into obsession leading to the point of no return. 

For me, it's a must-play.

I have NEVER had a major studio release fail this hard with me and I'm a big Star Wars fan. I played Cyberpunk 2077 all the way thru on dated PC hardware on launch and it ran miles and miles better than this does on much more modern hardware (3070ti), which should be, all things considered, an easy game to port and play on PC. It has great gameplay fundamentals, what DOOM Eternal was to DOOM 2016, but the performance takes out any and all enjoyment. I'm at a mission where Bode and Cal traverse a large vertical section in the later half of the game and I cannot cross 25 fps in just traversal, no combat. If anyone has suggestions, hit me up!

Constantly reminds me it's a console game. Further exploration just reminds me how clunky the interface is and how many of the "rewards" are just more stupid cosmetics. If you like paper dolls in space, this game is for you.

Great game. Awesome gameplay. Engaging story.
It's a bit hard to run the game even on my 2070s, but its a fun game with a good story so far!

Update after finishing the main story:

The final boss fight and the end to the story are really special. It hurts me that this is buried under so much other trash. This could have been a masterpiece if EA/Respawn had more vision and focus. A real shame...

Update after 45 hours:

Most issues aren't game breaking. It's playable now, even with constant stuttering and other weird glitches. But I still don't recommend this game. It lacks polish and feels half baked. I wish EA had cut half the features in this bloated mess and focused on refining/balancing combat. Some encounters are really fun to learn and overcome, while others boil down to throwing as many enemies at the player as possible without concern for balance. And the story... utter nonsense, even by modern Star Wars standards. Fallen Order wasn't perfect, but it had heart. Survivor is corporate garbage that only exists to tick a box on an earnings report.

Original review at 7 hours: 

An (ostensibly) strong game ruined for a massive PC player base because of a terrible port. Stuttering is constant, graphical artifacts like shimmering and culling errors mar otherwise lovely detail, and general performance is wildly inconsistent. Average frame rate with everything cranked (including RT) at 1440p is 70-80 without FSR, but that will drop to SINGLE DIGITS for no apparent reason in certain sections of the game. No settings changes affect these drops, even dropping to the low preset and enabling FSR at extreme performance mode. It is totally baffling. Just terrible software.

I am going to push through because I'm playing in parallel with a friend, but it pains me greatly to have paid EA and Respawn for this shameful, low effort port. I went into 2023 thinking Jedi: Survivor and Starfield would be my favorite games, but it a game about Pinocchio somehow ended up having more polish and heart. A TOTAL SHAME. Don't buy this unless you are willing to be furious.

Horrible PC port for a game. Frame rate is okay at best and often times stutters or drops right when you enter combat. I played with a plugged in PS4 controller and here are some of the many issues i encountered- 
1- the settings/menu button doesn't actually do anything 
2- To get to the menu/Settings page i had to open the holomap, THEN hit the settings/menu button to get there
3- During tutorials, or even just a button prompt to get up there, it Defaults to PC keybinds
4- The PS4 button prompt only shows up when you are interacting in some way with the controller, and only when you are, as soon as you stop it goes back to showing PC keybinds.
5- the "Sprint" Button (L3) pulls up the on screen keyboard for some reason??? and there is no way to turn it off. But yes you do start sprinting. only to hit the "back" button to get rid of the keyboard, taking you out of a sprint. 
6- Controls switching between buttons for no reason,Two i experienced were- holomap button turning into precision evade button, Big rectangle button bringing up the mouse on the screen.

All this with long loading screen times, opening graphic animation (Respawn, ea logos when booting up the game) running at LESS than 10 frames a second for some reason, Constant frame drops, etc.

I can very much tell that this IS a GOOD GAME. or it would be if they actually put effort into making the game playable. if its playable, the sound design, the combat, the story and voice acting i guarantee are great.  as what i could play WAS great. poor player support is Killing this game, and its play ability.

It's definitely a masterpiece. I loved the game through and through: the enemies & combat, the story & voice acting, the characters & humour, the planets & exploring. The game is built on the shoulders of the first chapter and immensely improved in every direction.
Brilliant game.

The game so far is amazing, the story is incredible and it's beautiful as always. For me it ran smoothly, thanks to the PC optimization files that run every time I load up the game. Would highly recommend if you loved Fallen Order.

Man, I really love this game. The combat is fluid and fun, the customization options are amazing, the fact that dismemberment has been turned up since the last game is awesome, and there's nothing better than getting to have another adventure with Cal and BD-1.

It sure would be great if I could actually, y'know, [b]play the game![/b] :D

Seriously, the prologue chapter went flawlessly, but ever since I arrived on the first planet I've had constant crashes, both during cutscenes and during gameplay. It's literally gotten to the point where I can't advance in the game because a required cutscene keeps freezing halfway through, requiring me to force quit the game and relaunch it. I finally managed to get through that cutscene and beat the boss, only for the game to immediately freeze on the next cutscene!

And now I can't even play the game, because it crashes roughly 10 seconds after loading the level. I can't walk more than a few steps from the meditation point without it freezing, meaning that in its current state, this game is [b]literally[/b] unplayable.

If they manage to fix these issues, I'll update my review, but for right now this is absolutely unacceptable.

Avoid at all costs until they fix this problem. EA doesn't deserve your time or money.

UPDATE: I finally revisited this game and, thankfully, it had been patched to the point of being able to play it. That's not to say that the game is without issues still, though; I was only able to play roughly 3 hours each time before another crash, and the crashes got more frequent as I neared the end. The game still stutters pretty horribly, even on current graphics cards, so it's far from optimized.

Overall, I would recommend the game to someone who's already a big fan of Cal and Star Wars, but I wouldn't go out of your way to play it if frequent crashes irritate you.

I beat the game and my experience with it has been mostly positive. I've been running the game at a 2560x1440 resolution at fullscreen with all visual graphics settings set to high with ray tracing off. I get about 40 FPS in the big areas like Koboh and around 70 FPS in smaller areas. I'm sure the performance would be better if I played at a smaller resolution but for me, these frames were fine enough that I enjoyed playing the game. Ray tracing makes it extremely laggy though with my specs which I believe was the cause on why my game crashed once. I turned it off though and it was fine from then on. 

As for the game itself, I really liked the movement, enemy mechanics, and combat in Fallen Order and I think they improved upon that in Survivor which was the main reason I bought this game. I didn't really care for the story to be honest. It was like watching a blockbuster film, story was not great but not terrible either.

I do recommend that if you decide you want to play this game, you should get it at a discount if you can.

After this long, and this many updates, this game runs like garbage. Ge Force Experience has been my way of optimizing my games for 4 years. It optimizes this game to full quality settings in 2560x1440p. RTX on or off doesn't matter. Ive turned the optimization settings all the way down to performance, still crap, better but crap. Never had an issue running a game like i have this one. Very disappointing to no be able to play this purely or effectively at all even. At first i let it be  and played with what we had at the time, hoping it would get fixed. CPU: i7-9700k GPU: Aorus 2070 Super RAM: Corsair Vengeance DDR-4 32gb

I was immersed in the story and was motivated to complete the game faster to see how it turned out. The map locations were detailed and beautifully made, character backgrounds were well-explained and overall I enjoyed the game.

Something I disliked is the game's performance - as described by other reviewers, the game lagged at some locations, Koboh for instance. My laptop specs are DDR4 64gb, AMD Ryzen 7 5800H, NVIDIA RTX3060 and it still struggled to provide a smooth experience, despite having the graphics set to Medium.

Some other downsides are bugs that appear occasionally - an example I can give is that when clicking on the button to open a chest and you are attacked at the same time, you never get to open the chest and receive your reward as this action gets interrupted. You can't seem to open the chest afterward too, as the option to open it does not appear when nearby. Another common bug I found is AI enemies spawning/dying at weird angles, sometimes in the air.

I think the gameplay can also be enhanced as I barely used any of the lightsaber skills that I obtained and mostly maxed out the Force and Survival ones as I found them easiest to use in combat. Another thing I can recommend is to add more maps, as returning to the same one for the main mission multiple times can become boring and I wanted to explore new locations.

A final recommendation I can make is to include the Inquisitor outfit for Cal (I was looking for it at one point, but found it only as a mod and adding it didn't work) and I think other players would greatly appreciate it if in the future it is added to the game.

For the most part, this is running fine now. Do get frame dips on Koboh, the occasional bug, doesn't run as well as it does on PS5 with my RTX 2060 Super, but it does run at 60fps about 80% of the time, depending on my location in the game. I do not have ray-tracing on, everything else on high, game still looks good. If you have a mid-range machine, it'll probably run well.
Really great game! The only problem is that it doesn't run as well as it should. Hoping they eventually can fix it with patches. Looking forward to the next game in the series.
I am literally a jedi

8/10 (it would be a 9/10 if not for the performance issues I'll explain below)

Jedi Survivor is an amazing story-driven action adventure. If you liked the new god of war games, or horizon games, uncharted games and even the new tomb raider games, Jedi Survivor is right up your alley.

It has some of the best graphics I've seen in a video game. Ray tracing is beautiful here and adds a lot to the final image quality. The parkour is  JOY! Cal's ability pick up from those of the previous game and are vastly improved. Combat is fun and exciting. The enemies are hard, as usual and boss battles can get a little difficult if you're not used to this type of game.

The story is also pretty good, although a little inconsistent at times. The villain is not what I expected and although I enjoyed the final moments with him, it felt a little out of place. I don't think his motivations were well fleshed out, but the story isn't really where this game shines the most.

It's the incredibly fun mix of crazy combat with crazy parkour moves that make this game INCREDIBLY fun.

I thoroughly enjoyed my 30 hours of gameplay and I barely did any side quests. I don't think I will go back to those anyway.

Now the performance is still broken as I type this review.  Especially in the real open world maps, the game will stutter constantly, even when my GPU was 70-80% usage and the stutters were crazy. The more enclose areas were usually fine and stutter free, but overall, this game still needs a lot of polish performance wise. 

Hhad the performance been better and the story a little more consistent, I'd say this is a masterpiece, but as is, it's just a great action-adventure game.
Too bad this game released in a utterly broken state, now it's playable and it's fantastic, think fallen order on crack

Btwn the sad story line, janky controls and camera angles and shitty abilities....AVOID this game.   The ONLY reason it is selling, or sold so well was FOMO (fear of missing out), trust me, keep your cash, the only thing you're missing out on is a rage fest.  If I could give this a game a send off to the deepest trenches of the ocean I would, along w/the EA exec's who peddled this fucking slap in the face to one of the greatest movie franchises ever.  FUCK EA.

Performance issues aside, this game is a master piece! Great story and great story telling, got me invested in the characters and made the galaxy feel much bigger than most of Star Wars. The story is much better than 99% of Star Wars media. 

In terms of gameplay it's a metroidvania souls-like, pretty much Zelda in Space with some sprinkles of Dark Souls. Coming from other Souls-like some of the bosses could be more fun/challenging like the ones late in the game, but overall pretty solid game!

Improves on its already quite good predecessor in every way. The story and characters are far more engaging, the combat is better, the platforming is better, the worlds feel more alive--it's as if Respawn read my review of Fallen Order and addressed each critique for Survivor (In case anyone's doing that now, the only thing left on my wishlist for game #3 is more destructible/force-interactive environments! Otherwise no notes).

All in all, it's the best Star Wars game since Knights of the Old Republic 2 (Which turns 20 this year!)... but unfortunately, just like KotOR 2, I have to include the caveat that there is some definite jank. Playing this almost a year after release I never had a crash or game-breaking bug, and the performance was [i]generally[/i] good, but seemingly-random FPS drops and pop-in were common.

Honest review of Jedi: Survivor...

Welcome to JEDI NOT SURVIVING. You reprise the role of COW TESTES, the ORANGE KNIGHT. This time you're older and wiser and slightly more manly, which isn't really saying much, but at least you've learned the poncho is not the HEIGHT OF FASHION, and you can grow FACIAL HAIR. You still can't pronounce your OWN NAME. Your BLACK MOM isn't around to cut your hair anymore so you can get a MOHAWK if you WANT. The quest hub is PLANET TEXAS. You can disguise yourself as a COWBOY with a MULLET and CHAPS and BANDANNA and HORSESHOE MUSTACHE and a GUN. Yeehaw. All you need is WINDSWEPT HAIR and SHORT BEARD and you'll be ORANJI-WON KENOBI. Yeah there's CHOCOBOS on Planet Texas, what're you gonna do about it Squeenix, SUE THE MOUSE? Ride your horsebird into the sunset. Bring peace and order to your one-town empire of dirt, ranchers, and miners. Shoot bandits. Kill rattlesnakes. Buy a drink in the saloon. Of course there's a farming mini-game. Invader Zim is a little green frog.

I sure hope you played the first game 'cause the devs start you off with all the powers you had at the end of it and expect you to know how to use them or die. No tutorial just "git gud, scrub." Don't know which buttons do what? Check the settings, the game won't tell you! Then the devs introduce new abilities you gotta figure out or die, all in the first level. The first boss is a boss from the first game, but she's back with a robot arm, all her old moves, all the moves of the final boss of the first game, plus new mechanics you've never seen before, and you've gotta just figure it out. I died. This is significant because I got hundreds of hours on JEDI FALLING OVER for PS4. I bought it twice, for PS4 and for Steam. It's not just a favorite game, it's my comfort game I fire up when bad things happen in my life. I accidentally did a deathless Master Difficulty run on Jedi: Fallen Order and I died to the first boss in Jedi: Survivor on Knight Difficulty, who mostly had abilities I already knew how to handle. The game is hard. You are the Jedi who is not Surviving.

There are Jedi who are Surviving in this game. Lots. You're just not one of them. There's so many Jedi Survivors revealed throughout the Disney canon that at this point we must conclude almost no one died in the Purge. Order 66 was just a court-ordered eviction served by sheriffs so the Emperor could move in and sh!t in Yoda's bed probably. So many Jedi Survivors appear in this game you even get one from the High Republic who is still surviving "somehow" (actual in-game quote, making fun of Episode IX, love to see it). So basically every Jedi in the galaxy is surviving but you. You die all the time, and for stupid reasons, for instance chickens, like a Zelda game. The first yeehaw you meet (named Mosey lmao) tells you nothing in the Valley is that dangerous and then you die a dozen times to lizards and apes trying to find Muppet Dad's saloon. The game is hard.

Remember that frog on Bogano who killed you 30 fkng times? He was one of the hardest bosses in that game; the devs thought "what if we made him harder?" Spawn of Oggdo has a OHKO with a huge hitbox and he will spam it over and over. If he hippity-hops while you're near a wall he will stunlock. Then you fight him and his dad at the same time. You get to fight a rancor, which is cool, then you get to fight two at the same time. You thought it was rough dodging the frog's OHKO? At least the frog is only the size of a car, the rancors are the size of a building.

Like Cow, the devs are older and wiser, too. They listened to some fan advice. You actually do get to fight Darth Vader (as BLACK MOM of course, who is more badass than before, and deserves her own game). You can turn off damage from FALLING OVER, which you will do, even more, since the platforming is still janky, and even worse with the new mobility mechanics. AND YOU CAN PET THE CATRABBITS! Remember the one you tamed in the first game, who got into the ductwork of Muppet Dad's ship, the MAN-TITS? Apparently it brought a girlfriend and got loose on Planet Texas and became an invasive species of semi-feral pokemon, and you can pet all of them! Remember your goth girlfriend MERLIN who is a WIZARD? She DOES touch your d!ck this time! Cow has no game, because he's a virgin from a monastery, his pick-up line is "the Order wasn't right about everything," but Merl doesn't care, she wants her babies to be orange and psychic! Your droid BD-SM is a perv who watches you two go at it! Tired of your lightsaber working like a wiffle bat that glows? There's a perk that massively increases everyone's damage to be more like the movies! It's only available on New Game+ but at least it's there! You have a lot of fashion choices, other than Scrapper and Poncho! The starting outfit is hideous so grab more outfits hidden across the land, and buy them in shops you pay for with stuff you find hidden across the land! Pallette swap colors! The battledroids are back and are hilarious! They will distract you with their funny and you will die of laughter! EA sucks but this game doesn't! The story is Good Actually, remarkable for Mouse Wars, and I can't wait to see what happens to Cow and Merlin and their baby on Planet Barbie in the third game!
Spent more time finding workarounds for bugs than actually playing the game. If you want to relax and play a game after a long day, unfortunately this is not the game for you.

Not only did it take me around an hour to actually play the game after it dowloaded due to EA requiring you to have an account with them to play a single player game, but on top of that despite having low graphics and everything centered around performance my game played like stop motion and at times freezing in place completely. I also had times when the camera would randomly get stuck not only halting me from interacting with save points but also with continuing the story. I loved the story of the first game and I love what they've been doing to build upon it but they need to actually make a game you can play on systems other than the newest PlayStation or PC.

Jank, jank, jank!

In so many ways this is a worthy successor to the original, but it fails hard in key areas. The story is great, and it has a lot of the same great combat style as the first one, with very cool additions. There are some superb souls-like fights (ya Rayvis!). The world is rich and interesting, with lots to explore and discover. Customization is also super fun -- way better than the first.

But where the game falls down is on the technical side. When you have precision fights and challenge levels  that require intense focus and perfect timing, things like random framerate drops, unresponsive controls, and weird hitboxes are infuriating beyond belief. There are several fights in the game that are completely unbalanced (Spawn of Oggdo ones especially), and at times it ends up feeling like playing QWOP instead of a AAA game. In almost every cutscene there is bizarre twitching fabric and frame drops, and honestly if I was the actors and writers I'd sue. They put on such a good performance but everything they did was marred by the janky jank platform. In the end, the whole thing comes off as amateurish and unpolished.

The other vexing thing is that the devs have just ignored this, even with all of the ongoing comments about these issues. It feels like they just took the money and ran. They did an underwhelming optimization patch at one point from what I gather, but it still clearly hasn't added the polish this game deserves. As a result, they've probably killed what imo promised to be one of the most amazing series out there. Damn shame this one.

~ Jedi Survivor Review ~

[SPOILER FREE]

When I first played Jedi: Fallen Order in 2021, I fell in love with its flashy yet strategic combat, lovely story with likeable characters and gorgeous world design. And I have to say, Jedi Survivor delivers on all of these fronts and more. Now, I first have to put a disclaimer in that all of my playtime was on a modded version. I mostly used cosmetic mods like Outfit Manager and May the Performance be with You, but I did dabble in some game altering mods like the mod that allows you to use all lightsaber stances instead of being limited to two at a time.

However, when most people think of Jedi Survivor, they think of its terrible launch. I am in no way defending it, but I personally bought it a few months after release when most of the issues were fixed. But the game's not perfect and neither was Fallen Order at launch. It crashes very often and I had to get in the rhythm of compulsively resting at meditation points to not lose my progress. Frame drops do still occur, but they are much rarer than before. Over all, I believe that this game, in its current state, is still amazing and here's why:

- Combat -

The combat in Jedi Survivor is a step up from Fallen Order in almost every way. The new skill trees for every lightsaber stance, force ability and the survivability tree include tons of unique moves that, once unlocked, help to spice up combat in meaningful ways. The new stances and reworked double-bladed stance are also all incredibly unique. The single blade is your reliable standard stance, seems boring at first but when I tell you you'll use it way more in NG+, I mean it. The double-bladed saber is amazing at clearing out groups of enemies. The new wider swings and acrobatic leaps make you feel like the Darth Maul you were always meant to be. The dual wielding stance on the other hand makes you play insanely aggressively because it not only allows you to cancel attacks by blocking but also has super fast attacks and an auto-parry attack. The absolute best stances though are the next two, starting with the blaster stance. Not only is it insanely fun to play like a swashbuckling pirate and combine saber combos with blaster shots, but also you can PARRY with your GUN, which is one of the coolest moves to master that feels amazing whenever you use it. The blaster sound effects are also gorgeous. The last stance, the Crossguard is also insanely fun. This is your claymore, so to speak. Slow but powerful. Knowing when you can attack and when you should stay back will win you most of your fights with this thing. I will not spoil what happens in the story, but I will just say there is a secret 6th stance that will be an amazing shock to anyone that experiences it.

Force abilities feel better than ever too. The addition of B1 droids that will crumble if force pushed into eachother or a wall is an awesome move. Also, the infamous flame troopers from Fallen Order can now be countered by force slamming them into the floor, causing their gas tanks to combust. When I figured this out, it was one of the coolest moments of my time playing. And don't think I can talk about the combat without talking about the execution animations that are absolutely the most satisfying part of the game. Combined with the light enemy dismemberment, it makes for an insanely cinematic experience. Enemies are also unique and fun to fight (unless it's those goddamn chickens). In fact, the bosses in this game are so fun that I installed the enemy spawner mod in order to re-fight a ton of my favorite bosses like the lightsaber raiders or "The Mastiff", an elite magnaguard. The major bosses are also massive spectacles and feel as epic as the first game, in some cases maybe even more so. But the game does recycle a lot of basic enemies as bosses later on, but I see it as an Elden Ring situation where that just means more game to play.

- Progression & Story -

The story of Survivor in general takes itself less seriously than Fallen Order, but it has its heavy moments. Dealing with themes of love, loss and settling down, the story is multi-faceted and the characters are three-dimensional. And yes, the overall quality of the story may not be as high as the previous game, it still is an amazing time. Survivor also adds so-called "Rumors" which act as side quests. Every rumor either gives you something new, shows you a new area you'd have never found if you were to just do the main quest or it could even lead you to secret bosses. Also, no little dotted line or obnoxious quest marker is needed and these quests can be completed mostly just by exploring the open world. Also, a lot of progression is tied to exploration. Exploring rewards you not only with cosmetic items to bling out Cal, BD-1, your lightsaber or your blaster (all of which have been vastly improved from the recolors and endless ponchos of the first game), but you also get health and force upgrades and extra STIM canisters as well as trinkets to exchange for more cosmetic items in the game's shops.

The planets, now more than ever, feel like actual planets. God bless Fallen Order's heart, but most of the planets consisted of you being high up on mountains that conveniently were shaped like a video game level. Survivor's main two worlds, Koboh and Jedha feel way more like actual real planets that could exist. And the more linear video game level-like areas are just sub-areas found in these massive planets. Exploration has also been massively improved with an actual useful holomap and upgrades that can show you hidden chests, upgrades, scans, plants and relics that you haven't gotten yet. And of course, the game's graphics are absolutely gorgeous, as to be expected from a game following up to Jedi: Fallen Order, one of the best looking games of the previous generation.

- Movement -

Fuck you, movement is getting it's own section. While yes, Fallen Order had some parkour, it felt more like a chore to get to the next combat encounter than an actual fun part of gameplay. On the other hand, like 30-60 minutes into your first playthrough, you will get a grappling hook that will instantly make platforming way more fun. Luckily, all of the upgrades from the previous game are available from the start in Jedi Survivor. Later on, you also get an airdash and get introduced to green portals that, when dashed through, reset your dash and double jump. This, combined with the even later floating grapple balloons turns a merely passable movement system into flat out a movement masterpiece. And the developers know this. After defeating a certain major boss at the Observatory, for instance, a wall opens up, revealing an obstacle course of floating walls to wallrun off of, bars to swing from and balloons to grapple onto to get back to a save point to fast travel to the Mantis. The developers could have easily given the player a save point and told them to just warp back, but they knew this would be more fun. Also, more room for error allows players to make a few mistakes while platforming and the end-game parkour force tears will straight up turn this game into a kaizo platformer. Prepare to rage at the game if you decide to try one of these.

- Conclusion -

Over all, Jedi Survivor builds off of all aspects of the previous game and turns a great game into an amazing one. Don't think about the more negative reviews, as most of the technical issues have been ironed out and the game is now in an actual playable state. Objectively, it's about a 8/10 game, but it's an 11/10 Star Wars game. The ability to LARP as a jedi is not only insanely fun, but truly getting good at the game's mechanics is one of the most rewarding things I have ever seen. Take it from me, a person who has had 3 playthroughs of the game and a ton of hours just spawning enemies with a mod to enjoy the combat system more. If you are still doubting if it's a good game, just grab it when it next goes on sale. It'll be well worth it.

epic game

I was very hopeful for this game. The first entry in the series was a fantastic metrodvania paired with smooth combat and great enemy types. This game, while it improved on some things, most aspects got worse. While i gave this game a thumbs up it comes with alot of asterisks.

First the good:
Graphics 9/10: The game looks and feels amazing. The new combat animations look super cool as well as the new Cal/BD/ customization allow for some great cosmetic combinations. 

Maps 7/10: The new maps (mainly Koboh) are greatly expanded upon. Its large and feels perfectly dense with things to do and explore. I do think some sequences had to much platforming that left me bored in some areas. Also the map, while having great star wars aesthetics can be hard to read in the denser regions.

Story 5/10: The story is serviceable. Nothing amazing but kept me interested enough to keep playing along. Not much to say here.

Stats/progression 7/10: The new stances are great. They feel well thought out and are fun to play. The skill trees for the stances and other abilities are nice as well. The perk system didn't feel like it belonged in the game at all. I couldn't tell many of the perks having much of an effect and overall it felt like an afterthought.


The Bad:
Difficulty 3/10: I played the first game on Jedi Grand-master and eagerly jumped into this game on the same difficulty. It is clearly not balanced on this level and instead of providing engaging challenge is just overly frustrating. I ended switching to Jedi knight after the save corruption issue around 3/4th into the game. 

Enemies/combat 2/10: Combat in this game has high highs and very low lows. The game feels best when fighting many grunt level enemies or 1 elite level enemy. Unfortunately most of the game is fighting 2-3 medium tier enemies with supporting grunts and leads to very frustrating combat. Almost all enemies including the majority of grunt level enemies have red unblockable attacks which feels very out of place and a cop out for creating meaningful difficulty and combat. This creates situations where you are being spammed with unblockable attacks from multiple enemies which can be hard to avoid while surrounded or locked in a animation. The vast amount of enemy types does not help. Each Star wars faction has 10+ enemy types that instead of having a variety of good attacks has just 1 or 2 spammy and annoying attacks. Cal's attacks also have a lot of inconstancy. While breaking the enemies block bar forces a stagger many of your attacks seems to be decided at the flip of a coin on if the interrupt the enemy or not. This leads you diving into enemy combos where you had previously and successfully interrupted the enemy and launched your own counter attack into randomly getting punished for seemingly no reason.

Performance 4/10:  Playing in 2024 performance was actually pretty good, getting over 100 frames on max settings and didn't experience many frame hitches. Many achievements can be very difficult to get to activate and can be a real chore to get them to pop. The only major issue I experienced was losing around 5 hours of play time including 2 boss defeats from a save corruption and is the only reason I didn't rate it higher.

Bosses 4/10: Many of the mainline story boss fights are very annoying to fight. Once again instead of having a variety of moves to keep you guessing the bosses rely on a short list of annoying and powerful moves that are difficult to play around and are capable of spamming red attacks back to back leading to many portions of there fight were you just have to dodge not being able to get any hits in.

Side missions 3/10: The side missions or "Rumors" seem to be another afterthought and were added just to be filler or simply to check the box off its RPG checklist. None of them were memorable or provided little if any lore/world building. 


Overall 5/10: I wouldn't recommend playing this game above Jedi Master and if I could start again would stick with Jedi Knight. A lot of the game felt a little scattered. From the rumors and many currencies to the elements of outpost upgrading and perks the game felt like it was trying to accomplish and implement to many new systems and failed at making them cohesive. The game overall had good moments and was fun to play. Its worth the time but would wait until its on sale to pick it up. I'm hoping that this game is the low point in the series and that a potential 3rd game can really dial in the combat and a few other aspects more.

Even after being out for almost a year, the game has many many bugs and issues that will prevent gameplay. I've had frame rate drops, bugged shortcuts, CTDs, etc. 

If you do somehow get it to work, its filled with very extremely frustrating puzzles and path traversals, combined with broken enemies and a very dull plot. I hope you are great at memorizing every single step of every single level, because the game forces you to backtrack a ton with a new ability or item, and unless you have the entire level memorized you will actually miss a lot. Well, not a lot, because there are no choices or alternate play styles, but you will miss a different length beard or slightly different color palate I guess. 

The characters are very boring and one dimensional, bordering on annoying, but at least they hit their diversity quota. There are also absolutely no real choices to the game beyond the superficial outfit changes, so it just feels like playing on rails. There is no reason to explore at all unless you wanted a lavender shirt but all you have is a light purple one.

If you can get it to start at all, the game is finicky and will crash semi regularly. Even with a 4080, 64G of DDR5 and 13900k, with nothing else running, anything with an overlay disabled, fresh installs, integrity check, latest drivers, and fresh reboot with everything that could possibly cause a problem disabled in task manager, I still get the error "Out of video memory trying to allocate a rendering resource. Make sure your video card has the minimum required memory, try lowering the resolution and/or closing other applications," which is patently ridiculous with the rig I have set up. 

This happens no matter how it is launched, either from EA, Steam, or directly from the executable, with or without admin rights. Changing to a higher priority causes it to not load at all, and this seems to be a recurring problem since launch.

I managed to muddle through it until the last patch, and now it won't start, no matter what of the many recommendations made in the past, including complete reinstall of the game. I am unwilling to do a bare metal Windows install (the only other recommendation made i haven't tried) simply to get a game to run.

So buyer beware. It's almost certainly an EA issue as I have similar problems with almost every EA game I own, and had frequent crashing problems with Fallen Order (although it would at least start).

Just doesn't run well on my system. Maybe in a few years they'll either fix the persistent stuttering or I'll have a computer powerful enough to compensate for the inexcusably bad optimization for this PC "port."

EDIT: Completed the game at 29 hours on patch 8.  Running a RTX3080 12GB and Ryzen 5800X3D.  Loved the game as a game.  Great gameplay, boss fights, story,  and graphics.  This should be a thumbs up but the performance is still atrocious no matter the settings and this never should have been released on PC in this state.  By bad performance I mean terrible stutters no matter the level or settings.  Koboh is the worst but other levels stutter like crazy.  When its not stuttering it doesn't feel smooth even at a locked 60 fps, something is up with how it presents frames and it always feels terrible.  If what I mentioned on performance doesn't bother you, buy it but it performance is something you care about, do not.  

EDIT: 15 hours later and 2 more patches (patch 8) - still runs like shit so I wouldn't recommend.  Why are they patching this game if not to fix it's biggest issue, performance?

Bought this game after the last patch because I thought it would run better.  This is hands down the worst optimized game I've played in years.  Stuttering on 3080 12gb with a Ryzen 5800x3d no matter the settings or resolution.  When panning the camera there are white flashes as it loads in the scenery.  I really wanted to play this game as I loved Fallen Order despite it's performance issues but somehow this game is worse across the board.

If you enjoy life as a beta-tester on a game 6-months after the release, this game is for you! Game is 1000% optimized for NVidia, so don't bother trying an Radeon video card (sarcasm). Game is excellent for world one, then you're greeted with it's best feature... crash, crash, crash (just long enough to surpass the return period). World 2 feels like an homage to Twisted Metal because it crashes so much. Enjoy restarting your computer, because that's exactly what this game will have you doing every 5 minutes (because it take 4.5 minutes to boot). Have fun!

UPDATE ~6 months later.
- Still had many crashes. Could set a clock by it to crash within 20-minutes. HOWEVER... after un-installing / re-installing the game, is now running smooth like butter. Loads way faster now as well. This seems like it was an issue with a bad file that did not update properly. Try a full uninstall / reinstall if you're still having issues.
- This is a great game, and improves on good mechanics from the first. Story is quality as well.
- Modified recommendation to :thumbsup:.

Combat is not satisfying, way too much Uncharted style platforming.

If you can get it under 20$ maybe worth it.

This game is the second game in the STAR WARS Jedi series. You will want to play the first one, called "Survivor," if you're interested in the whole storyline, but you don't have to. The main character, Cal Kestis, is gathering up old and new friends in his fight to rebuild the Jedi after their complete destruction. The Evil Empire has taken over the Galaxy and it's your job to find other Force users and bring them together. You're their only hope.

Sequels don't always live up to their parent games, but this one definitely does! Another awesome game, and story! Some of the achievements are bugged for me, but maybe they have patched this for new play-throughs by now.

(Update: Patch 8 still doesn't fix the performance issues. Especially when you enable ray tracing.)

I am a long time Star Wars fan but found this game to be quite disappointing. 

Bad performance that still isn't fixed with the latest patch (4). Constant frame drops and stutters in just about all areas/planets. Especially Koboh. I tried to wait for the performance to be fixed or at least a good bit better than launch before I beat the game but got tired of waiting.

Combat is better than Jedi Fallen Order but still feels sloppy. He can also only dodge without a roll which makes it annoying to deal with large enemies that spam unblockable attacks. Makes no sense how a Jedi can't do something as basic as a roll dodge. 

Platforming starts off interesting but gets excessive and tedious further into the game. 

Good boss variety but the last couple bosses just spam unblockable/gotcha attacks that drain your life quickly. Third from the last boss is the best in my opinion because he doesn't do that.

Story is decent but the ending makes no sense. Definitely could have been written better. The game also seems to drag on at one point then the next thing you know it abruptly ends.

Overall it is a decent game but I can't recommend it with the performance issues and the $70 price tag. Even if the optimization was good and the game ran well on PC it still wouldn't be worth $70. I would say wait to see if they get the performance fixed and then maybe pick it up on a sale for like $50 or less. The extra $20 for the DLC character skins is pretty stupid too.

Great gameplay : controller use is kind of a hassle, I needed to use DS4windows.

Solid story, very likable characters. Much improved gameplay compared to Fallen Order. Combat is challenging, but fair and fun. Certain boss fights have too many cutscenes for my liking, but otherwise they're really well done. Plenty of content, lots of stuff to do and places to explore. Even if I've liked to see more exotic planets. The ones in this game feel a tad basic. And I definitely want the battle arena mode from Fallen Order back in this game. I want to keep replaying the boss fights. Finally, the performance is a bit iffy, FPS drops do happen, on Koboh (the big planet) especially. But definitely playable with my old ass GTX 1080.

Updated review:
Initially, this game suffered from terrible optimization to the point that it was breaking high-end PCs. However, the game seems to have improved quite a bit. If you enjoyed the original Fallen Order game, then you will find this just as enjoyable, if not more.

However, the game is still not without performance issues. I have a higher tolerance as I come from an age of low framerate, low-poly games where the mouths don't line up with the words being spoken. On your average PC, it is likely you will experience all of these issues while playing. Running it on medium to high graphics, I often find Stormtroopers look like they're from Star Wars: Jedi Knight at times. It's actually *playable* after almost a year of optimization, but I can't say it will play *well*, especially after playing for a couple hours (Suggesting a memory leak).

While I do recommend this game, I would advise waiting for a sale. Do not take it at its full price.

TL;DR More and better of the previous game. Runs well now.

I refrained from buying the game for some time, because of reports of performance issues and glitches. It did crash a few times when I was running around one of the towns, fortunately a patch released a week it had solved all issues.

I enjoyed the story and the characters. Perhaps the foreshadowing is a little to strong for my taste, but it's still enjoyable.

The strongest parts of the game are:
- the combat, each sword form feels distinctly different, you really need to learn the opponents and look for cues to react properly, no button mashing in this game.
- jumping puzzles, the game introduces skills you can use to traverse the map gradually, allowing you time to learn them in various scenarios, there's quite a lot of them, but you don't feel overwhelmed, some puzzles require more dexterity, but they're not very finicky,
If you mess up a puzzle or a fight, you generally know what you did wrong and can improve in the next attempt. Generally, the game mechanics are well thought, so the game gives you challenges without being frustrating. That being said some bosses or enemy combos are quite hard, at least on the difficulty level one below hardest.

If you enjoyed the previous game, you'll definitely enjoy this one, I sure did.

Playing the game and enjoying. The EA APP  Launcher required to run the game got an update today and controllers no longer work correctly. The keys are being remapped by the EA launcher with no way to turn it off or change it. The in game menu says they are mapped correctly but when you use the controller keys in game the buttons do not correspond.

45 hours into the game. Will not give this a good recommendation until they fix the controller issue with their launcher and I can actually finish the game. 

work-around: I am able to get a controller working correctly by disabling steam input and plugging the controller into the PC.

I bought this game when it was 40% off and it was more than worth the price. The gameplay is pretty standard, but also a big step up from Fallen Order with the new stances, perks, and upgrades. The story is absolutely phenomenal and blows anything Disney has recently done with Star Wars by a long shot. The characters (especially Cal) really feel more fleshed out and like they've matured since the events of Fallen Order. The cutscenes also add another layer of excellent cinematography to the story. With all that said the game is not perfect. Apparently this was much worse at launch, but this game is buggy and unomptimized. I'd say I have a pretty good PC, and I frequently found myself below 30 FPS in the large open world areas. The game is also $70 which is why I bought this during the winter sale, but for around 30 hours of playtime to finish the main story and decent post-game replayability, I'd say it's worth it. 9/10 game in my eyes.

On launch, I tried to play the game and could scarcely take 10 steps without a crash. My PC specs were better than the minimum specs, but not as good as the recommended ones, so I upgraded my CPU and GPU. After that, on the lowest graphics settings, I was able to play for about 5-10 minutes at a time before the game would crash. After patch 5, I couldn't even boot the game, every time I tried it would crash before I even reached the main menu. I finally upgraded my RAM form 16gb to 32gb, and now I can launch the game, and the crashes have become less frequent but are still happening. Bottom line, the recommended specs are complete bs. Fun game if you've got a top of the line PC, otherwise you're wasting your money on an unplayable mess.

Best Star Wars game I have ever played. Fantastic story and continued character development. I felt emotionally invested in this storyline. The ethos of bringing old characters back but with their own, well thought out histories after the events of Fallen Order really hit home. I thoroughly enjoyed Jedi: Fallen Order, but found there to be little replayability, aside from just wanting to replay certain things. This and the overall gameplay are significantly improved in Jedi: Survivor. So many new abilities and play styles. But I think what makes me love this game most of all (Cal's story in general) is that it strikes a perfect balance of new content and existing content (fighting Clone Wars battle droids, imperial troopers) such that Cal's story seems to have always belonged. The occasional humor and cutscene transitions are so quintessentially Star Wars. I feel like a child again being so engulfed in this universe while playing this game. I wish I could relive the first time I played through this game and got to explore these worlds. This is so obviously a game made by Star Wars fans, for Star Wars fans. I just want more of this story. 100/10!!!

Game is poorly ported and crashes more often than not becoming extremely frustrating. This will ultimately be my last EA purchase, no longer a reputable studio.

Pros: Pretty awesome combat outside the boss battles. Force powers are pretty well done. Carving your way through a platoon of stormtroopers is pretty awesome.

Cons: Too short (22 hour playtime). Too much focus on increasingly punishing boss battles (including one recycled from the last game). The player makes no decisions of any consequence. By the time you have cool force powers for managing groups of enemies, you no longer have groups of enemies.

As with the last game, the story is painfully short and kinda just ends. It feels incredibly constrained for something set the Star Wars galaxy. Along the same lines, I know the storytelling for this type of game needs to be a bit linear, but it would be nice to have more choice on some of the details. Many previous Star Wars games have allowed you to decide how far you want to toe the line between the light side and dark side while keeping with a mostly linear story.

While alot of the reviews have mentioned the game being difficult to play I have not had nearly as many issues as other players have mentioned. the startup screen is very slideshow like but the overall game-play is good and the story and cinematic's were breathtaking. probably 2023s game of the year for me personally. only issue I have is that my achievements dont load sometimes, leaving me in the dark on what I have earned.

This game is truly tragic. It has fun and interesting level design with fairly intuitive platforming that rewards exploration. The story is well done and most of the voice acting is high quality as well. The performance however is too bad to excuse. Random frame drops, glitches, and unresponsive controls are frequent occurrences. I held out hope for a year that those would be patched out but the game still fails to perform acceptably. I would recommend Jedi Fallen Order but I cannot recommend anyone play this game. Should the performance ever improve, I would definitely recommend giving it a go.

Pros:
1.Story is well paced, emotional and incredibly well thought out which will keep you in your seat for hours just wanting to know whats next and whats gonna happen to your favorite characters.
2.Gameplay is way more improved compared with the first jedi game and at points you will feel like a total badass when fighting both bosses and group of enemies.
3.main quest are a beauty and a trill to play throught.
inbetween:
1.Lack of unique bosses, most of them are kinda almost the same just different skins and i had this same complaint for elden ring but i aint saying that the amount of bosses is bad just that it has a rather large roster of bosses maybe around 50 and maybe 7 of them are unique(random number not really representing the amount of bosses)
2.this one depends on the person but i found that the game was way easier than the first(could be because the first game was unrefined or that i dont remember the game as correctly as i think), never really felt like i needed to go back or been in a bad spot maybe once or twice. if i had to say this game is way lower in difficulty than a dark souls game but fun either way.
3.Maps are way to large and i kinda do prefer the last game maps more but at the same time i dont and the new maps got their charm like nova and shattered moon.
Cons:
1.Like many have said Performance is a little shaky(havent seen how it was at first) in some parts it would grind down to a halt, specially for me was the first array and it was in some parts of it not all so it was kinda weird.
2.Crashes are there but they are far apart thankfully, i would recommend not to go back to coruscant there is a nasty crash there that almost got me stuck.
3. this one kinda contradicts the pro before but gameplay are a while can get a bit boring if you don't follow the main story.
4.Too many collectivels which can increase the game time from 12-15 hour game to 30 if not 40 just looking for them which too me i find boring after a while but my ocd got me screaming for that 100%.
5.some colletivels you aint gonna be able to acquire them until after certain missions so a lot of back tracking is required.(which i hate with a passion)

Now i do recommend the  game to most fans of the first game and if you can buy it on a sale then you would enjoy it more(i believe i bought it during christmas and it was maybe 40% if not 50% off so it aint unheard off to buy it at half the price.
Do i recommend you buying it at full price? no, if i remember correctly it had a lot of issues when it launched so the only way to fight that kind of bussiness practice its to vote with your wallet.Do i recommend you buying the game? 100% yes.
Excited for the next entry and hopefully see a good conclusion to the trilogy.

So lets start the review with a disclaimer: i know that this game has performance issues, but i was lucky and did not have any problem with that, ran on high settings stable 70-90 fps.

The good: new stances, new mechanics, perk system, new enemies, new and more customization, did not take away all the force powers from the first game, like other games do in the sequel. There's a tactical minigame which is fun. The combat is still fun. Voice acting is really good. NG+ extra perks are fun.

The bad: Shallow gameplay, finding the optional collectables are 80% of the game's playtime. There's also no dark side clothes for New Game+.
About the gameplay:
Because its a terrible port you'll encounter with a ton of bugs. If you play on lower difficulty thats fine because most of them happened during bossfights, but as someone who finished Sekiro multiple times on NG+7 charmless and demon bell'd, i started it on Grandmaster Difficulty. The game itself wasn't difficulty at all tho. The problem is the random bs you encounter like: dodging's invincibility frame doesn't work, bosses' attacks randomly 1 shot you (even with max stats). You're out of the bosses' range and they teleport next to you and one shots you. You're out of the attack's range, their attack still hits you for some reason. Blocking randomly let's through the damage like you did not block (had full stamina bar). Some challenges are annoying because you go against 2-3 huge monsters who are just ganking you in a corner (more enemies doesn't mean more fun). Randomly falling through the floor. Special pistol skill randomly doesn't work, but used up the force energy that was needed for that skill. Main and sidequests sometimes softlock themself (a door closes that shouldn't have, enemies/npcs don't spawn) and you have to quit to the menu and restart again. Platforming puzzle's are not planned correctly, what i mean is i had to knock down some pillar to create a bridge from one platform to the other, but you could just simply jump over. Later on when you unlock the Dash ability its just game over for the platform puzzles. Dash is so OP you'll just skip 90% of the platforming with that, it can even get you to places you are not supposed to have access at that point. Also there are a bunch of places which looks like you can stand on, but no, just just fall through that and loose some of you HP.

About the story:
The main story is fine, nothing special. "Obviously will betray you person" will obviously betray you. Very suspicious person who might be a bad guy is revealed to be a bad guy. Nothing in the story will surprise you or make you go "i did not expect that". There are no real decision's in the game, there are no multiple storylines you can choose from. The game has 2 Jar-Jar Binks level of stupid side characters, one of them has his own questline where you have to listen to his lifestory which just doesn't fit the main story's darkness. Sometimes you literally have to just stand there for 5 fookin' minutes and wait for him to finish his stupid story. I would've done literally anything else other than that.

TLDR: Lower your exeptations and you'll enjoy it.

A worthy successor to Fallen Order, however not without its flaws. While the same fun movement and combat system you know and love from the first game has been expanded upon here (although not absolutely every addition is welcome) and the story is broadly very good, there are some very polarising points within the narrative (and one or two points that seem like outright oversights), and the game still has gremlins pertaining to technical performance and persistent, albeit minor, glitches.

+ Combat is excellent, and the new fighting stances are mostly welcome additions (not you, blaster stance)
+ Engaging storyline, similarly to the first game
+ Graphics are very pretty
+ Some of the new characters are excellently written
+ Holotactics is a fun minigame, albeit very RNG-driven. Potential to expand this further in future games akin to Gwent in the Witcher franchise
+ Cameos from two legendary characters in the Star Wars universe, including one with its original voice actor
+ You can customise Cal, his lightsaber and BD-1 in a greater number of ways than ever before...

- ...But the downside is, the Mantis is no longer customisable for some reason
- Movement mechanics have, in my opinion, gone too far in this game. Having Cal be able to double jump, flip, and dash forward all while he's falling mid-air ruins immersion; and some facets of movement such as the electrified ziplines literally defy physics and as such are immersion breaking. In my opinion, movement in this series peaked with the end of Fallen Order
- Some very odd character development (spoilers ahead): The vast majority of the characters you fight with [spoiler]are the same as those in Fallen Order[/spoiler], which feels a little lazy; the [spoiler]Cal and Merrin romance[/spoiler] felt like hollow fan pandering that contributed nothing to the story, and there was a missed opportunity to allow the player to [spoiler]turn Cal to the dark side. By forcing players into staying light side yet also to 'embrace Cal's darkness' in order to literally complete the game, you're simply painting him as an angsty episode-2 Anakin[/spoiler], which is character regression that literally nobody asked for.
- Some plot holes in the story including quite a large one (more spoilers): [spoiler]When Darth Vader attacked Jedha, why didn't he simply walk into the next room and destroy the Mantis after defeating Cere? Before the fight, Cere told BD1 to wait as she'd be along shortly - presumably they're still in Mantis in the next room with the communication codes - what on earth was he doing?[/spoiler]
- The "big planet" in the game that was hailed as a "hub that Cal can come back to again and again throughout the story" is 90% empty nothingness with barely any NPCs, not that many enemies, and very little diversity within the landscapes; and this just feels like lazy game design
- Planting seeds in a cramped rooftop garden has to be literally the dumbest side activity in any game ever, and aside from a Steam achievement there's absolutely no reward whatsoever for doing it
- The game crashed six times for me in 30 hours, the Steam overlay stopped working in-game for me after about 20 hours, and there are a lot of short freezes and stutters (particularly in cutscenes, which is very odd)

While the list of negatives is long, I would still say that this game is definitely worth playing for Star Wars fans, or people who were otherwise fans of the original game. It definitely lacks some of the polish that the original had, but there is still a lot to like about it, and it follows on nicely from the end of Fallen Order whilst simultaneously placing itself in strong stead to set up a sequel. Would recommend buying it on sale. 7/10.

**Original Review:**
As someone who is a STAR WARS fan, I'd recommend this game to every fan and non-fan of Star Wars, despite the fact it had some performance issues due to a rushed release (it's EA's fault, not the developers). Respawn did a great job on the game (fr fr no cap). But don't buy it until a good patch (day one and performance patches are bad)

My overall thoughts after completing the game:
Story: 9.5/10
It has its quirks but is still a good one, a tragic one, almost like Rogue One's. Characters are well-crafted. I appreciate that everyone has their own motives and is driven by them.

Graphics: 10/10
Visuals are great, even though it's not UE5. It still does the job and portrays the world as if it were a movie.

Gameplay: 8/10
I enjoyed the movements and battles, but some boss fights are annoying. Oggdo and ***** (Spoiler). The second one is like... there's no point in the duel because everyone knows the outcome. But you still have to tear your bum to get it right and "win" the boss fight.

Customisation: 10/10
Wow, you can customise EVERY aspect of your character - yourself, lightsaber, blaster, BD. That's fantastic.

Performance: 3/10
You have to compromise on FPS with this one. I played with a laptop 3050 Ti, low-mid graphics at full HD in 30fps with blur. I capped it to 30fps manually through the NVIDIA Control Panel. It almost feels like it's not the FPS that matters but the stutters. You encounter them less frequently if you have 30fps rather than an unstable, uncapped 45 that could drop to 20 for a glimpse of a second every so often.

NOTE: Do not buy for full price imo. I bought for 35 and feel it was worth that amount, but 70 is a lot for something with terrible performance. Great gameplay and story if you can handle blurry 30fps.

Reading the reviews for this game, you'd think it was a lackluster, buggy, broken mess unworthy of your time. But I don't think that could be further from the truth. 

[h1]Overall[/h1]
First and foremost, [b]Jedi: Survivor is an excellent game at its core[/b]. I'm a major Star Wars fan and loved Fallen Order, so I'm probably biased to some degree. But I found the story to be engaging; the characters likable, well acted and convincingly animated; and the gameplay to be incredibly fun. Respawn has done an fantastic job capturing the feeling of the Star Wars universe while providing a fresh enough story to not feel like we're just rehashing old and exhausted themes. Next to Rogue One & Andor, it's my favorite SW setting & story in recent years. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Regarding the core gameplay loop, Jedi Survivor will appeal to a broad audience. This is a game that gives you clear direction while providing you with enough opportunities to take brief detours, so that it doesn't feel entirely on-rails. If you're someone who wants to turn off your brain and enjoy an engaging, interactive Star Wars story, lower the difficulty and enjoy the ride. If you're a completionist and get your dopamine hits from exploring all the nooks & crannies for chests and collectibles, the environments in this game have just enough secrets to reward careful exploration. If you thrive on fast & smooth movement, wall running, and jumping/flipping about, I find Jedi Survivor is among the best in this regard (on par, IMO, with Spider-man & Titanfall). If you love the challenge of precise timing in combat (ala Dark Souls, Sekiro, etc), the lightsaber combat on higher difficulties can be incredibly challenging and rewarding.

Overall, this game greatly exceeded my expectations based on what I read in reviews. I came in expecting a 6/10 game, and was surprised to find that [b]this game is easily a 9/10 (9.5/10 for a Star Wars fan)[/b]. I'm shocked that it hasn't gotten more buzz and isn't more widely praised. But that's probably because...

[h1]Performance/Optimization[/h1]
There are definitely some performance issues. I'm playing on a setup that is much faster than what the typical gamer will be using (7950X3D, 4090), and I'm still experienced some stuttering in certain areas (particularly Rambler's Reach on Koboh). It is noticeable and occasionally annoying, but it's not a deal breaker for me because it's A) infrequent, B) restricted to specific areas, and C) doesn't affect gameplay. However, I must acknowledge that if I'm experiencing this on a high-end system, I have to imagine it's even worse for others.

With that said, I don't think occasional stuttering should be the deal breaker everyone is making it out to be. Maybe it's because the issues aren't all that bad on my system, or maybe it's because I'm in my mid-30s and grew up playing games that were [i]way[/i] more janky and stuttery than this.  Personally, I'm willing to acknowledge that 1) the optimization could (and should) be better, and also 2) this is a phenomenal game only slightly marred by suboptimal performance.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
If you are a Star Wars fan, the gameplay seems interesting to you, and you have a decently fast system, I recommend that you strongly consider giving this game a try. I'm glad I decided to take these Steam reviews with a grain of salt and tried the game out for myself, otherwise I would have missed out on what is one of my favorite games in recent years.

DON'T LET THE PERFORMANCE ISSUES STOP YOU FROM PLAYING THIS GAME.  This is a great follow-up to Jedi Fallen Order and improves on it in just about every way.  I like that they added more visual customization to Cal.  The combat is familiar but improved through the new stances.  There are a few boss fights with some cheap hit boxes, but they don't make the fights impossible, and I beat the game on Jedi Master.  The hub world is much larger and the player is rewarded for exploration.  The writing and characters are great and at times had me laughing and crying.  There are some nice callbacks to the original trilogy and the clone wars.  However, the final boss and ending were a but underwhelming to me, and a more interesting main villian(s) would have been welcome.  I did have a few crashes where I lost progress, but this game is very playable when matching the settings to your system, but it is a demanding game.  I have a 7800X3D with 7900 XTX ran at 4k/Epic/RT Off/FSR 2 On/100+FPS and I would sometimes be using 22 GB of VRAM...  It's not a perfect game, but I think it would have been a GOTY contender if not for the performance issues.  I can't wait for the third game!

The customization options were enhanced and I enjoyed that you were able to customize every part of your outfit. Definitely going to return to this amazing game and can‚Äôt wait to get the chance to play any future titles. Cal needs to become mainstream!

Original review: crashes more than my glucose levels after a mountain dew

Review after finishing the game:

It's a bloody shame that EA can get the Zelda-like open world right, twice in a row, only to shit the bed performance-wise.

I'm running a solid i7 10700KF with 32GB of RAM, and a 4080. I tried multiple settings, even low on 1080P, but the baseline is the same: the game is poorly optimised. Some areas barely get 40  FPS. And the fractured experiences, which should be uber small sandbox environments, well I've had framerate drop to 20 in those after just 5 seconds...

So the game is obviously a console port, and while I dislike the console-first development mentality it makes sense both financially and mechanically. Cater for the many, not for the few. However, having a 70 euro game run like utter trash on hardware that cost upward of 3K, I just can't accept that. If they are willing to charge this much for a game, they should be willing to offer continuous support, at least for 3 fucking years (see Witcher 3, which started out as a bug ridden mess too).

The story is decent, although it has an arc that you can see coming from roughly quarter way through. The first game was easier in this aspect, as they were defining where they wanted to go - but now they are locked in on that route.

Gameplay is much improved, mechanics are nice, a few interesting lightsaber stances added. One less planet to explore than in Fallen order, and only 4 are truly open world, one is a small sized map, and one is a glorified boss arena. I felt like I have less to explore, and more tedious cosmetics to gather.

And the real issue. The game has severe crashing issues, even in January 2024. I literally had to skip about 4 cutscenes and watch them on youtube, as they would constantly crash at the same spot. I find this laughable in a 70 euro game.

The game crashes at the exact same spot in two other places: one running up to a tedious bossfight, and one as I deliver the killing blow in the hardest bossfight imho. It was numbingly harsh to rerun these in the hopes of the game shining its mercy in me, and letting me progress. 

One of the planets crashes regardless of where you are, and as meditation points are far between, I found myself saving after every major enemy killed and every customisation gathered. (Once the save wiped the chests I found, and I needed to redo the whole region).

And the final straw: the game worked fine with a PS5 controller on bluetooth, until I reached the last 5% of the game. Then it just shat the bed.

I tried everything, from reinstalling drivers, re-pairing the controller, repairing the game folder, etc. Only to find in the community hub that it was the same for all controllers, and the issue started roughly on the 16-17th of Jan. So I finished the final boss with the controller on cable. Not a biggie, but fucking frustrating that this is something "normal".

My baseline: the game is 75% of the quality of Fallen Order, with both gameplay and mechanics being better - but story being a significant downstep.

They leave space for a third game, but I sincerely doubt I will buy it, if this game is in such a shambolic state even close to one year after it's release (and I read it was waaay worse on launch day, so glad I held my horses.)

Buy it with a 40-50 discount, but don't pay more than 40 euros for it. Not worth it.
Performance issues aside, this the game just broke controller and steam overlay support. Avoid this game. I real shame, as it is a fantastic game WHEN it works.

I enjoyed the first Jedi:FallenOrder despite its clunkyness, but the soulslite combat with a lightsaber, metroidvanian exploration and decent StarWars-story was right up my alley. But this follow-up underlines that this was lightning in a bottle and EA is still as incompetent as ever.

Performancewise it's a mess: crashes to desktop (especially annoying since the game only saves on bonfires, so there's a lot of progress to be lost); very demanding while looking dated and worse than its predecessor (especially the details) and it's very troubling to get a controller to work (SteamInput isn't working, and you'll need 3rdPartySoftware to use a DS4-controller) - and don't get me started on the need to install and use the OriginLauncher.

The game itself ist FallenOrder, just worse in every aspect. The combat system feels of, parrying unrewarding, enemies attack faster than the in-game response time gives you time to react, and despite dueling focused most encounters are against groups, with many enemies being resistant to the only crowd control system (i.e. the force). Instead of handcrafted linear levels, we now have boring open-worlds to waste time in to get from point a to b, with trillions of useless cosmetics to collect. Oh, and we have an useless perksystem now, cuz, ya know, many popular titles have one these days. Story is bland and uninteresting, with many plot contrivances (after you crashland on the next best planet after the intro-mission, this just happens to be THE planet where there was the big OldRepublicMcGuffin) - to the point where I skip the obligatory DarthVader cutscene simply because I just lost any interest at this point in what happens to the characters and the world at that point.

So yeah - everything wrong with modern game development today. Just string together the bare minimum of what could be exspected from a game, and hope people buy it for the ever declining IP that is Star Wars. GG EAids.

Absolutely incredible game. Story is amazing, gameplay is amazing, Character development is strong. Just to name one example without giving any spoilers, you fight the same boss three different times throughout the story and besides him there are only a few other different ones but EA makes up for this by giving each fight a unique experience in terms of combat and how the boss works in terms of abilities and move sets and such.

I'd like to approve of this game. It has a lot of great things. But like so many other games, they made the boss battles super annoying. It's bad enough trying to get through boss battles with the primary protagonist character whose fighting technique you've become accustomed to over many hours of gameplay. But then they throw you to the most difficult boss battle yet that you have to complete with an ancillary character who has only one fighting stance which you may have not been using the entire freaking game. Plus the ancillary character definitely doesn't have all the stim packs the primary character has accumulated. I mean, I went out of my way to find as many stim pack upgrades throughout the game as I could and then they just arbitrarily decide, "Nope, you get four stim packs now." So what was the point of all that?

But aside from that, the holes in the battle mechanics are glaringly obvious during boss battles. For example, why is it that pretty much any enemy can interrupt my attacks if they get a blow in before I land mine. And yet, if I get a hit in against any enemy during their windup, their attacks carry through without any hindrance? They intentionally add imbalances like this to create the illusion of a challenge. But it's only a challenge in the sense that you have to memorize every potential move the antagonist can make and be sure you never attack after one that has an immediate followup attack that you can't possibly interrupt even though their windup should leave them wide open to attack. 

Basically, there is a disconnect between when the enemy appears to be open for attack and when they are actually vulnerable. You can't go by appearances. You can only go by memorization of their attack sequences. Is that fun? I don't think so. I think it would be more satisfying to see when they are vulnerable and have the opportunity to capitalize on that. 

This isn't a game of skill. It's a memorization game. But to add insult to injury, every boss battle has three stages where they totally change up their attack sequences in the third stage. Which means you may have spent hours working up the muscle memory for stages 1 and 2, but then that all goes out the window in stage 3. Unfortunately, you have to get through stage 1 and 2 over and over just to get to stage 3. It is so f#@king tedious. And it's not like you can abandon the fight so you can go elsewhere to build up your skills to return to it later. You either get through the boss fight or... that's it! There's no other option other than just not continuing to play the game, I guess. It's just poor gameplay design.
