Jedi: Survivor is one of the very best Star Wars games ever made, further building on the incredible building blocks laid out by Fallen Order. 

The original's, "souls-y but not really" gameplay, is expanded upon further with more combat styles, weapons and abilities. 

Voice acting and motion capture is still top notch with great performances from the OG cast and the new additions. 

The story is emotional yet somewhat unsurprising, just like the first one's, but it's flaws are overpowered by meticulous and caring world building with a really strong art direction, once more extremely faithful to the overall looks and feel of the saga. There's more planets, cities and people to discover along with a lot of side-quests.

A really awesome game, deeply rooted in Star Wars mythos and lore despite another botched, untested, unoptimized, almost unplayable PC launch. It's better now.
Excellent !

Overall a great game. I liked the story, the adventure and exploration kept me engaged, and the game offered enough challenge and decent enough combat mechanics to keep me motivated to continuously get better. 

The story was interesting, and it avoided two of the big pitfalls of modern writing: First, the villains were all interesting, developed characters with understandable and at times even sympathetic motivations. Second, the writing didn't engage in the recent trend of making the main character's actions so dark that they become an unsympathetic villain themselves. If you hate shows and games where the main character is really a villain, you won't find that junk in here. This is a story about an actual hero doing his best in the circumstances. 

I played this game long after release, so I didn't encounter any of the technical issues that happened at launch. I have a pretty good rig (RTX 3080), and it would still have its fans screaming whenever I played this, but the frame rate mostly held up... and the game is absolutely beautiful, so you're getting something in return for all of the technical requirements. 

I've played several Souls-like games before, and I played through this game on Jedi Master difficulty and cleared most of the content, including most (but not all) of the optional bosses. I killed all the optional bosses in the actual world, but left two force tear boss challenges alone (I couldn't quite summon the motivation to fight hard bosses in featureless battle arenas shaped like a dark circle ... come on devs, you have to at least do a little decorating!). Honestly the force tears could have been removed from the game completely with no real loss, if I had known what content was in there I would have skipped them. 

If you like the experience of playing high difficulty, precision combat games, I think this game will leave you slightly unsatisfied on the highest difficulties. On Jedi Master and above, the combat starts to come apart a little bit and reveal some sloppy edges. Enemies are completely inconsistent on what attacks are interruptable ... at times, a small poke will interrupt even an enemy heavy attack. Other times, an enemy will be completely invincible during even a light attack, and there is no way to know the difference other than extensive memorization. Of course, ANY attack that you make will get interrupted by a passing breeze, so the lack of consistency between player and enemy interrupt mechanics makes the combat feel broken. Enemy heavy attacks (especially grab attacks) also exhibit huge graphical glitches. You will frequently dodge far out of the way, yet still get hit (the graphics effectively show you getting vacuumed back into the attack, even though you're well out of reach). I think it's due to a flaw in the game engine, where dodging the attacks is actually about timing, not your position, so if you are far out of range but your timing is "wrong", you'll still get hit and the graphics will have to interpolate whatever is necessary to make that be true. If you're playing the game on regular or story difficulty, this won't matter at all. However, if you're considering a play-through on Grand Master, I wouldn't recommend it. Find a different game with better mechanics. 

Anyway, most of this is quibbling. I put 60 hours into this game and have no regrets. Enjoy another great Jedi game!

I'll start by saying that I initially really enjoyed this game. The combat is fun, the story is engaging, the characters have depth, and the game ran fairly smoothly overall. Yes, in highly saturated areas of the game with multiple assets, the game still stuttered a bit. But as a casual player who doesn't care much about ultra-smooth gameplay, I could overlook the stutter issue. One fatal flaw with the game is EA's atrocious save system. First of all, they pretty much force cloud saves. That creates a whole host of issues with multiple user reports of hours of lost gameplay. Secondly, if your game file gets corrupted (which happened to me and is the main reason why I'm writing this) and you didn't backup your files, you lose pretty much all of your progress and have to start a new game. I tried the Jedi: Fallen Order corrupted file fix where you open the game folder in files, create a new desktop folder, transfer the main save file into the created desktop folder, and load up the game again -- didn't work. After losing about 20 hours of gameplay, I cannot recommend anyone to get this game until this major issue is resolved. Now, if you don't mind relentlessly backing up your save files, you can give the game a shot. I probably won't be playing again until this issue is resolved and, ideally, my save files are restored. [TL;DR: good game, still stutters a bit, EA has a horrible save system, regularly backup your save files if you get the game any time soon.]

I sincerely hope Disney doesn't do a live action story because after this game, Kyle is a much more complicated character and I don't want Disney to mess that up. The ending is a little surprising if you're expecting a neat, tidy ending, a couple things make not so much sense, but all in all, it was a blast visiting my friends from the first game again and watch them grow and evolve. Especially BD-8. I love that little droid! the ending suffered because choices made in the course of the game seem to be ignored. No spoilers, just saying some behaviors at the end seemed to come out of nowhere.

TL;DR If you liked Star Wars: Jedi Fallen Order, you will likely appreciate what Jedi Survivor has to offer.

Note: everything stated here is my opinion which you are free to disagree with.

Maps:
I felt that the maps in this game were more open and less linear than the previous game, which I saw as a bonus. It wasn't so much that it was overwhelming (except for maybe the first visit to Koboh), but just enough to where you feel like you are not solely limited to just following the story progression 100% of the time. I can tell the developers put a lot of effort into the level design and it turned out very well. On max settings this game is beautiful and had me in awe more than once. I will say that do to some of the less linear level progression I did find myself lost once or twice but due to my own tenacity I just kept trying to figure it out until I did which got me to the end. Free exploration is very rewarding as you go throughout the game, as you gain additional life essence, force essence, stim packs, and skill points that you might not otherwise recieve. Not to mention all of the paints, materials, parts, and other customizations. 

Combat:
Picking this game up after finishing Fallen Order truly feels like a sequel. It doesn't feel like you are starting from scratch and many combat features late game in Fallen Order carry over into Survivor and the skill tree builds upon that (albeit in a new way). I enjoyed this game for the story so I did not play on a difficult setting but I found that the combat was rewarding and challenging enough to where it forces you to learn how to use your skills and learn your enemy rather than just mash buttons. 

Puzzles:
I thought that the puzzles in Fallen Order were a bit overbearing as they stood in the way of the main objective. This is no longer as much of a case in Survivor. You may complete puzzles for a reward, but they are not strictly necessary to complete the game most of the time. I found that the puzzles were fun to figure out and not too obvious. The rewards aren't always worth it in my opinion, but it was fun just to complete the task.

Story:
If you are a Star Wars fan you will likely enjoy this game. If you are not a Star Wars fan, this game might be a bit cheesy for you. The cutscenes can be long but I thought they were all worth watching. One thing I didn't like was how often combat was interrupted by cutscenes, especially when its to keep you from actually killing the boss. If you play this game at a leisurely pace, I'd say you can expect at least 20 hours of gameplay out of it. Spoilers: [spoiler]The Tanalorr story arc was a good one to roll with in my opinion, but getting to Tanalorr was anticlimatic. The story ends when you get there and fight the final boss, but you are only left with a vague direction in which the story may go from there. I also thought Cal being prompted to "embrace the darkness" was extremely cheesy and it made me laugh every time I saw it.[/spoiler]

Technical Issues:
I understand that several people have complaints about performance and crashes. I played on max settings and the performance was fine for me. Granted, I have a pretty decent PC. I did experience a handful of crashes, in total less than 10. Just enough to make me paranoid about them happening, so I would save often. I cannot speak on how this game performs at the lower setting levels on less beefy computers, but I think the game is pretty well polished at this point and as of writing this review it has not stopped receiving support.

The combat system is fundamentally flawed. A HUGE step back from the first game. Fighting more than 1 enemy at a time leads to some of the most frustrating experiences I've ever had in a souls like. So many boss fights are buggy or cheese-able. I defeated a rancor because it got stuck on an invisible wall in the middle of the arena. Some bosses straight up fell through the floor during their attack animations and instantly died, and those same bosses would sometimes push me through the floor and I'd fall to my death outside the game world.
The visuals are also terrible. Running the game on the lowest settings I see frames as low as 15fps running around in the open world, yet there are collectibles that literally do not render unless you play the game on a high enough graphic setting, so good luck trying to 100% if you're not on the highest end PC. Running the game on a 3080Ti btw. 
I absolutely cannot recommend this game and I wish I could get the time and money back that I spent on it. Absolute waste.

Jedi Survivor is a good game with many fun and some annoying parts. The good: The Soulslike-gameplay is really enjoyable. Some of the enemies are rather aggravtaing, but most of the time the combat is really fun. The metroidvania formula is really executed well, I rellly liked exploring the nicely designed world and finding all the secrets. The story is engaging, especially the last few hours were great. The graphics are really good, same goes for the is the soundtrack. What I didn't like so much were the frequent platforming passages. I think the devs went a little overboard with these parts. Some were really frustrating, and what them even made worse was the camera, which didn't allow me to properly judge how far I had to jump or were exactly I had to jump to. It also happend quite often that I found myself wondering what to do next or where to go next. I think the devs should have given some more obvious hints in these parts. Apart from that, the game still has some technical issues like texture flickering and occasional bugs. But it worked fine most of the time on my rig. To sum it up: Jedi Survivor is a very good game with some rather tedious parts. If you liked Fallen Order, you will probably also like this game.

Right off the bat: if you liked Jedi: Fallen Order, you will love Survivor. 

All of the good parts from Fallen order remain. Almost every ability carries over from where you left off meaning there is no ridiculous backtracking to reacquire skills you "forgot". This makes for an incredibly rewarding start of the game to those who completed Fallen Order. The combat is slick and improved with 5 different lightsaber stances, brand new takedown animations, and a more diverse set of enemies. Force pulling a heavy assault trooper and having him shoot his own comrades will never stop being fun. And some bosses like Rick or SoO make for incredibly memorable experiences.

Platforming is elevated with additional abilities introduced early on making traversal so much easier and more satisfying. Although there are some tedious climbing sections Tomb Raider style, they definitely make up a smaller percentage of the overall game than in Fallen Order. The mountain ascent at the end is a culmination of all the platforming abilities and is one of the most stunning sequences in the game.

Puzzles are for the most part unchanged in their complexity and you can expect the answer to almost always be force push or pull. This is fine but I wish they did something more with the puzzles. Cal has grown since the last game and we would expect the player to as well. However, I really enjoyed the Jedi chambers scattered across the main planet. These introduced a slightly more difficult set of puzzles which gave a needed challenge. 

The story is as good as if not better than Fallen Order with more tight writing and excellent voice lines from enemies (new and old). The development of old characters pairs nicely with the new ones and none of the character arcs seem to be competing with another. Where the gameplay of Fallen Order felt driven by its overall story, Survivor's gameplay is compelling enough to drive itself. This is not a knock on the story at all and I think the rumors and bounty system greatly add to the overall lore of the universe. 

Performance in January 2024 is completely acceptable. I read horror stories of literally unplayable games or game breaking bugs but I never encountered any of these on my desktop PC (5700, RX 6600, 32gb, 1080p, high graphics, no FSR, no ray tracing). Occasional frame drops when loading a new part of the world quickly went away and I could easily game at 60 fps. Glitched walls or floating enemies only appeared every few hours and never took me too far out of the immersion. It is unfortunate that so many people report such terrible performance because this really is an incredible game. I hope Respawn can quickly address these problems for a game that truly deserves it.

I have not finished the game at this point, but it has evoked some strong feelings, so I'm doing it now.
Firstly, at the time of writing this, January 13, 2024, the game is still very unstable. I get a crash to desktop in practically every session of play, which means a crash every 1-2 hours. You will also lose all your progress since the last meditation circle, so be prepared to retread areas that you have already done.

Secondly, while the main story is engaging and fun, the side content is simply tedious padding.

In terms of gameplay, it is very good. There is a balance of exploration/platforming and combat. The former is what you would expect - environmental puzzles, hidden secrets, etc. Both feel pretty good most of the time. The controls are responsive, platforming sections are usually designed well, and combat encounters, while challenging, are also usually well designed. Take note that I say USUALLY, because there are some that seem to be intentionally designed to frustrate the player, but more on that later.

Most of the secrets are cosmetic, and therefore serve no purpose other than another box on the checklist. Some of them are more useful, such as skill points or upgrades to your health/force bars.
There are also optional Force Tear challenges. They take the form of a combat or platforming challenge. I have encountered a number of them, and for the most part they are fine. However, there are some where the design philosophy seems to be to kill the player over and over again until they eventually figure it out. One in particularly required down to the millisecond timing on a jump, and if you fail it, you have to do the entire section over again. And that wasn't even the end of it. Unless you are a masochist, I would say these aren't worth your time or sanity.

The exploration aspects are significantly expanded from the previous game. I find it to be impressive, but tedious. There are a number of MetroidVania elements, such as interconnecting maps, and barricades to your progress that you find the solution for later, and so are encouraged to backtrack. I find the back tracking tedious, but it isn't strictly required most of the time, so it's a neutral thing as far as I'm concerned.

Combat is good. You retain all your abilities from the previous game, and add more as you go. There are also new Lightsabre stances. There are 5 that I have unlocked so far: Single, Double Blade, Dual Wield, Blaster and Crossguard. Each have their own stats and advantages. You can get through most encounters with any stance, but certain stances suit specific situations better - ie. the Double Blade is the best against groups of enemies. I am a bit frustrated by the fact that you can only have 2 equipped at any one time. This narrows my focus, and prevents me from experimenting with the different stances. It also means that I have ignored some, and poured my skill points into Double Blade and Single, because this combination is applicable to the largest variety of circumstances.

Most enemies you can expect to deal with on your first try. This includes the story bosses. However, there are some optional enemies that aren't meant for the casual gamer to take on. I am of two minds about these. Sometimes I enjoy the challenge, but other times, it isn't clear what you are supposed to do (ie. Unblockable attacks that also seem to be undodgeable). The placement of the respawn points on these doesn't help either, and often requires you to retread an error with enemies just to get back to the fight.

I am enjoying the story and characters so far, and there have been some very entertaining moments, but I think at this point, I am just going to rush the main quest, and ignore everything else.

This game was wonderful. Great gameplay, great story and looked and felt amazing. Everything Star Wars should be. Can't wait for another one.

As for performance. I am not running a top of the line PC. Radeon 590 graphics card, and I had no issues with gameplay or performance worth noting. Sure, the graphics were not smooth sometimes, but completely playable.

In this review I will sum up on following points:

-my meaning to the negative reviews
-general quality of the game
-comparison to the first title


The negative reviews.

Most of the negative reviews tell about how unplayable the game gets because of bugs or bad performance. I myself waited for an offer and started the game with mixed feelings. And I was pretty suprised hoe good it was. It crashed only once and the little bugs (a very few i noticed ) were more funny than hindering me in any way. It also wasnt have as laggy as somke comments suggested [Ryzen 5 3600X, Radeon RX6750 XT, 16GB Ram, solid 60 fps on 2K monitor]

I can understand that the high price is somehow greedy of the PUBLISHER and the deemingly early state of publishing wasnt well timed, but it doesn't alter the effort of the DEVELOPER to create a nice game.

General Quality

The game in itself is pretty well made. 

The controls are as simple as varaiable and rich on funktions. Just the right method to make all aspects of the force as accesable as possible. You can now only use two sworstyles at the same time, but therefore there are 5 well designed possible ways to gut your enemies.

The story was wonderfull continued and pretty  ineristing. Even the tutorial was more actual gameplay than a tutorial, but still didn't lack the oppertunity to learn the basics of the gameplay. It stayed thrilling till the end and now i wish for more of Cal's story. 

The graphics are pretty good and adjusted nicely to the rest of the game. Overall the graphic designes of clothing, weapons, characters and surrounding felt really well placed.

The gameplay was astonishing. Also it wasnt't any specific trait it exceeded in, it proofed a  jack of all traits. The mix of Jumpn Run, Bossfights and Puzzles as possible challenges really made wondering, what i will have to face around the next corner. The devs really succeeded in making an accessable, storytelling soulslike, that came with a high variety of challenges and fun.

Everything of these points get added up by a richness in detail. But therefore it can be overwhelming in some situations.

Comparison

Star Wars Jedi seems to evolve pretty good. All expects of the first title where used to build up on. I pretty much liked how they seemingly tried to  improve every aspect of the first title and that they actually succeeded. In the end it is a good mix of old and new aspects, which seemingly grow with the main character.

Even with the big backlash of the cancelculture, i hope Cal's journey is far from over.

I refunded it for now, but may return on a deeeeeep sale. The game's not bad, it's just very mediocre. It managed to improve on a few points I disliked from Fallen Order; for example, the split saber is now a permanent mode like the double bladed, not a single attack. I wouldn't buy it full price just because the idea of AAA games being $70 is ridiculous, but it's probably worth $40 or so at most.
Wanna be a jedi? Play this game.

From the reputation I expected far worse but the game was just what I wanted and would have expected. Builds upon the mechanics and story of the previous game. Performance was pretty much as I expected after looking at benchmarks etc if slightly better. (RX 6600M)

Would recommend for anybody who like the predecessor.

If you like the "jump-run-wall-run-flip-dash or die to move forward" part of the game, you'll love it. I don't mind some of that but there are sections where it just seems so repetitive and, excuse the pun, forced.

Thoroughly enjoyed Fallen Order. Easily one of the best things to be released in the Star Wars universe in quite a while. Graphically impressive, slightly more forgiving souls-like combat that actually requires some skill, linear world design with some backtracking required if you want to get all the customization options, and some slightly annoying platforming elements occasionally. Decent characters, although not terribly deep, and a decent narrative that still stands out as one of the better stories told in Star Wars in quite a while as well. All in all? It was a great game, and I was genuinely excited to see where Survivor took it.

Problem is? I can barely play it. Completely rebuilt my PC this past year from the ground up, and this game crashes constantly, and stutters frequently with major frame rate drops. Glad I got it during the winter sale. If I had paid full price for a game that's clearly not optimized for PC? I'd be really pissed. Even at half price, I'm still pissed because I don't think there's a good reason for this game to run like it does on a higher end PC almost 9 months after its release. It's a damn shame too, because if this game ran properly? I'm sure it would be fantastic. I can't recommend purchasing this game, even on sale, until the technical issues are solved.

I had no issues with this game's performance.  I had a solid 75 hertz at 1440p through the entire runtime, at max settings, ray tracing on, using DLSS at Quality.  I experienced 1 major visual glitch twice across my playtime.  The cinematic kill animation for a particular enemy played out about 2 meters above the ground for some reason.  I would hardly call that disruptive.  My system is a 5600X and an RTX 3080.  Looking at other recent reviews it may still be the case that older hardware may struggle with the game.  But I hope not because...

The game itself, is a triumph.  Everything you loved about the original is waiting for you, with really fun upgrades in the complexity and variety of combat styles.  The boss fights are thrilling, and VERY challenging on grandmaster mode. the exploration is heavily rewarded.  And the customization is completely insane.  The amount that you can customize Cal's appearance and your lightsaber is incredible, especially in today's market of exploitative microtransactions.  There are none of those.  Everything is only unlockable through gameplay, and that gameplay is fun and challenging, never a grind.

Finally the story.  No spoilers.  This is the Star Wars I've been looking for.  The first game had a touching and memorable story featuring great characters.  This game has that, but it's something more.  By the end of the story you might agree with me that Cal Kestis is the most profound and complex Jedi we have gotten in the Disney Era.  The writers really took some chances, and the animators truly understood how to let moments breathe and develop.

I truly hope the performance issues with this game don't damage it's profitability, because I am longing for another entry from this team.

First, I'd like to address the elephant in the room. Optimization. The game is incredibly poorly optimized. It runs like total crap. I have an 8700k and a 3080. Running in 3440x1440, I was lucky to get 40 frames. HOWEVER, with some tinkering, (a performance enhancement mod from Nexus Mods and enabling rebar on my computer) I was able to get my frames up to 60-75 frames. Still not ideal given most people who attempt to play won't be on a machine as good or better than mine. HOWEVER, I'm going to move past this topic to discuss what a brilliant game lies underneath the poor optimization. 

[h2]Story[/h2]

This game has a fantastic story, told through in-game discoveries and brilliant cutscenes with incredibly well done mocap and voice acting. It's honestly my favorite bit of Star Wars content from the past several years alongside Andor. 

[h2]Graphics[/h2]

The poor performance isn't JUST because of bad optimization. This is one of the most ambitiously beautiful games I've ever played. Character models are stellar, and it has some of the best looking environments and set pieces in any game I've ever played. This is my new benchmark for visuals. 

[h2]Audio[/h2]

The sound design is incredible. The music very much fits into Star Wars, with many familiar motifs, and plenty of new pieces. The sound effects are incredibly well done too. From enemy sounds and weapon sounds, to the environments' atmospheric sounds, this game is astonishingly immersive. 

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]

Jedi Survivor has the best blend of gameplay elements from many of my favorite games. Let's start with the combat, which calls to the deep and challenging combat of Soulslike games. It doesn't have quite the same level of depth or challenge as something like Dark Souls or Elden Ring, but it comes damn close while staying approachable, and the difficulty options let you decide if you want the challenge or not. Regardless, the combat feels very satisfying and rewarding. Now exploration. The large set pieces and open areas densely packed with colllectables and upgrades, combined with the smaller, more tightly designed dungeons cut a balance between games like Uncharted 4 and Twilight Princess. Exploring these large areas is fun, but exploring them again with new skills and items makes it just as satisfying the second time. The skill trees aren't particularly deep, but they are immensely impact, so they really boost the experience. Lastly, the platforming in this sequel has greatly improved to the point that I rarely fast travel. It feels fun running around, jumping, and climbing over the environment to explore. 

[h2]Overall[/h2]

I absolutely recommend this game to anyone that has a machine with the horespower to run it. I really wish we'd get a good performance patch. It would be a 10/10 if it was optimized. But, because of the technical issues, I'll have to dock it a point, making my final score a: 

9/10

Everyone know about the performance so I'll skip it.

The combat sucks ass.

The stances are nice in theory. In practice, I never needed to use anything other than dual wield because of the speed. Blaster stance deals too little damage. Double bladed stance is unnecessary if you time your perfect deflects right. Single blade stance is inferior to dual wield. Crossguard stance is far too slow to be useful because enemies hit you mid-swing and interrupt your attack.

Bosses are overly easy, even on the highest difficulty. You simply stand in front of them, perfect parry and dodge their attacks, then you hit them a few times. You repeat it about a dozen or so times and you win. That's it. Doesn't matter which boss it is, if you time your parries and dodges right, you will always win.

The regular mobs are far more difficult than the bosses because you are at a disadvantage by default when you are outnumbered. It is impossible to attack anything if the enemies are grouped up and attack you. Which is always because all enemies have the same movement speed, regardless if they're stormtroopers, chickens or DT droids.

You like fighting the DT droid miniboss? Good news! It's now a regular enemy and you get to fight 2 of them at once while you get shot at by miniguns and run from flamethrowers. 

Fighting bounty hunters is straight up annoying, especially when there are multiple of them. They spam the charge shot attack from multiple directions, knocking you down constantly and not letting you heal. And they run away if you try to hit them because the range of your melee attacks is pathetic and they resist telekinesis because of course they do.

But dear Reader, I hear you saying: "Git gud scrub." I did. I completed the game on Hard mode. It wasn't enjoyable.

TL;DR Buy Elden Ring instead.

Star Wars Jedi: Survivor (TM) is not a game I can recommend on principle alone. The game (as of January 12, 2024) still runs pretty poorly (enough to be noticeable but not debilitating across a full 20 or so hour play-through); it's fun enough to play but nothing innovative (or that in-depth for people already experienced with more traditional Souls-like gameplay loops). Perhaps most importantly, the game is (without sales) $70 and (despite its lush environments, expensive-looking textures, and particle effects) doesn't do anything well enough to really justify that price tag.

But Star Wars has never been a franchise of principles. Star Wars is about vibes; it's about feeling. It's an aesthetic firstly, a vague retelling of Campbell's monomyth secondly, and a semi-functional story about hitting red and blue lightsabers against each other (and doing force tricks) thirdly. In this sense, Jedi: Survivor (TM) is the perfect Star Wars video game. It nails and perfectly expands the aesthetic palette of Star Wars with wonderful new creatures and species designs, better defines some lesser explored regions of the galaxy, and provides just enough Force bullshit to make it all go down relatively smoothly.

It isn't as deeply detailed as Baldur's Gate 3 or as photorealistic as Alan Wake 2 or as stylish as Hi-Fi Rush, but it has that undeniable and infectious Star Wars charm: aliens in strange jumpsuits pressing blinking buttons before jumping to lightspeed; massive dinosaur-like creatures waddling, cawing, and rolling over in desert-dusted ruins; sleek art deco High Republic relics and meditation chambers collecting dust in the forgotten corners of the galaxy. Its story is mostly forgettable and only gets worse the more attention you give it, but that is besides the point. It feels good to cut things with your fully customized lightsaber. It's fun cutting the mouthed spike-balls in half and then blowing its brothers away with your blaster before hitching a ride on a five-foot-long seal-faced bat creature. It's fun to break your double-bladed lightsaber in half and cut a charging rawka into a shish-kabob. In short, the feedback never gets old: the whir of a lightsaber blade, the crackle of stormtrooper comms through their helmets, the oblivious dialogue between two B2 battle droids, then the sound of it all getting effortlessly cut through with the premier tool of the primarily pacifistic Jedi Order.

The cutscenes might occasionally glitch out (the UI elements not disappearing as the black cinematic bars take over, the beginning and ending bits of dialogue getting cut off abruptly as gameplay resumes), but I honestly think that's a small price to pay for a Star Wars pseudo-Soulslike as engaging as this. If you like Star Wars, you should get around to it at some point, though probably in a few years when the price and performance has been drastically improved.

After playing through the game fully and working to get all the achievements I feel I can have a full opinion on the game. 

[h2] The Pros [/h2]
Jedi Survivor is genuinely a complete upgrade to the previous game in every single manner. Respawn have taken all the feedback and issues associated with Fallen Order (i.e. lack of fast travel on planets, intense backtracking with no shortcuts) and clearly show they have improved on it. 
The game's customisation through your playstyle and appearance has been improved tenfold, with weathering, aging, many material types, individually replacing aspects of Cal's and BD-1's appearance to really make it the player's own journey through the footsteps of Cal Kestis. 
The different Lightsaber Stances are also incredible, with more than double being provided over what Fallen Order had -- the extra stances are omitted from this review due to spoilers. But each stance comes with it's own unique playstyle that allows the player such flexibility on how they wish to experience the world through their own flavour of combat they prefer. 

A lot of the decisions made has been with the 'Player First' mentality. With the mountainous level of accessibility for any player wanting to enjoy this Star Wars story. 

The story and characters are also fantastic, seeing everyone grow and change from the Fallen Order to Survivor with the inclusion of new characters now introduced new avenues for Cal to go through his journey as a 'Survivor' of the Jedi Order. 

The worlds and attention to detail within them cannot be understated with just how [b] beautiful [/b] this game is. Being on Corusant and seeing the neon signs, the water vapours coming out of vents, the alive environment of one of the deeper levels of the planet-sized city was one of my favourite things about this game. But...lets talk about the cons...

[h2] The Cons [/h2]
Jedi Survivor on PC struggles intensely. Currently I am running an RTX 2070 Super and was required to run the game on medium settings with a lot of lower settings as well ON TOP of adding in a couple of additional external settings to make sure the game ran, let alone play. 
I had an issue where my game would crash consistently that I would find out was due to a bird flapping its wings. The game would process this in a very unfortunate way and crash the whole application. After I applied a setting, it would run, but my FPS would fluctuate heavily. 
In a lot of the open worlds, the game struggled to keep a consistent FPS, it would jump and drop and break the experience it was just managing to build. 

Granted, there have been 8 stability patches since release, but after finishing the game since the most recent patch, it still struggles. I have attached 2 websites that I would recommend to people to go through first if they were to buy the game. But please only get this game during a sale. It is still not worth full price due to the mountain of technical issues, which is such a shame because the game is genuinely fantastic past that. 

[h2] Websites for Stability Help [/h2]

https://steamcommunity.com/app/1774580/discussions/0/3828665650630021009/?l=frenchSteam  -- [u] Forum Crash and Stability Fixes [/u]

https://exputer.com/guides/errors/jedi-survivor-crashing/ -- [u] Exputer Crash Fixes [/u]

[h2] Final Verdict [/h2]
I would highly recommend this game but ONLY and O N L Y, if the above patches and fixes are applied as well as getting this game on special offer. I feel the issues plaguing it are more management level than the devs, especially how Respawn would focus mostly on their Apex Legends project due to how much money it brings in I'm afraid.

What I encountered so far during my playtime;

- 1 freeze / restart game(happened within the first hour).
- 1 bug where I couldn't progress the story, restart fixed this.
- A few bs encounters in the game, but encounters that has no time limits.
- I run a 3070, with all settings on at least high. The lowest drops of fps I've been down to is between 30-50, which wasn't unplayable, but certainly not something I would want to play at all day. Luckily this only happens at a few locations, and they're not places where you spend huge amounts of time. Otherwise 70-110fps with no issues is where I'm at.

---------------------------

- Combat is really satisfying, and imo far superior compared to Fallen Order. Where Fallen Order felt like PG combat, Survivor is much more raw, and you get the sense of power.
- Sense of scale is a 9/10, really well done.
- Great story & characters.
- Reasonable amounts of stuff to do at late game.
- Great graphics.
- Customization is also great, and I find myself spending quite some time checking it out.

despite all the negativity surrounding this games pc port, and issues on console, i went against all odds and got it during the (2023) winter sale. I have recently (near, like final boss near) cleared the game and i had zero issue. Yes i had frame rate stutters but the mostly stayed at 60 fps throughout except looking at the star map it would always drop to low 20s. Graphically there were some minor hiccups here and there some mostly funny, others were a texture in a dark area was missing; audio wise, zero issue. I played this game at near high settings all around at 1440p at (almost always) 60fps with no crashes, no game breaking bugs, nothing of the sort. yes i did have slow down were there i maneuvered too quickly in open areas, but that was very uncommon to rare. So despite its criticism EA after nearly a year got their crap together and delivered (finally) a fantastic story driven game. 4/5

*Note my pc isnt beefy like most people posting, im running a 2070 super with a motherboard from like 2018/19 and 32gb DDR4 ram, and a 8TB SSD.

Despite these drawbacks, I would still recommend Jedi Survivor as a must-play for Star Wars fans.

So, it's not a terrible game, but it's definitely the last EA game I will be buying for a while. I can tell I'll get more game time out of this one than I did the first one, even if it isn't a great deal more. That being said, here are some of the problems:

The performance issues are real, but they've gotten a lot better. At least now they're manageable. This game will have problems on the steam deck. If the dumbed down graphics or laggy combat don't get you, the freezing and crashing during cut scenes will.

Combat is boring, and that is a direct result of the dinky skill trees. Each lightsaber type is too similar to the others. I just went with the highest damage stance, the crossguard, and never really switched away from it. Once you unlock the powered up throw and the sweep attack, the double bladed becomes pointless, and the crossguard is already better than every other stance from the jump. Wait for enemies to come to you and every fight will be cake. This is on grand master, BTW.

None of the "puzzles" were challenging. Though, it is puzzling how coordinated all construction across these planets appears. The tons and tons of railing required to set up the dull, pointless, almost filler-style climbing in this game would result in a staggering bill even the funding for the death star couldn't cover. That includes all three death stars. Let's not kid ourselves here, the starkiller base was just another death star.

The characters were all pretty much the same as the first game. They have one or two goals, and there isn't much deviation. Spoiler, but not really because we all saw it coming, [spoiler]Bode's betrayal was the most tedious bit about this game. It was this whole thing, from the beginning, that was just done to drive a turning point for the main plot and add such a ridiculously boring subplot. Also, how many grenades have I force pushed back towards the thing that threw it? But I couldn't do that with Bode? No? Sure, makes sense. Gotta drive that plot and ignore basic things the force sensitive character has been able to do the entire time.[/spoiler] Bad writing packed with plot holes and stupid gimmicks.

The controls were sometimes unresponsive. I used a Playstation dual shock controller, which is fully supported, and there were many times when I would be smashing the circle button and Cal just wouldn't dodge. At other times I couldn't force push or pull for way too long after doing any attack with the crossguard saber. It wasn't consistent, either. Sometimes I would be able to do those things without problem.

Get this game, like I did, on a steep sale.

Addition: The game optimizes files every time you launch it. The first time takes the longest. It's funny, though. I wonder how this game would run if it didn't burn a minute or two of your time upfront- and it's a minute or two if you're on a good machine.

This game blew me away! It is my game of the year for 2023. I expected it to be ok... but it is really compelling and is the first  game in a long time that I enjoy exploring and collecting. The combat is awesome. Super surprised.
I love how they made the series, I cannot wait for the next one to come out!

Bug upon bug upon bug upon bug.

1. When you're in the key binding screen at the main menu, the mouse does not want to work. You have to click on buttons multiple times before the game finally registers you've clicked on something. Then, sometimes it will just rebind whatever key you clicked on to be the LMB instead of whatever you want it to be.

2. Game will randomly freeze. Even when I have my specs meeting well past the minimum requirements, the game will still freeze up about 30 minutes into every play session. Searching around online tells me it is the anti-piracy software being unable to check the EA app properly, thus it thinks you've stolen the game, and it shuts it down on you.

3. Some keys, if playing on a keyboard will be unbound at the start of the game. While playing through the start of the game, there will be tutorial sequences thrust upon you where the game pauses and instructs you to press certain keys to do certain actions. If those keys are unbound, however, the game will stay paused and you have no recourse other than to simply alt + F4 out of the game, reload an earlier save, and lose your progress.

This game is a bug-riddled mess that was never supposed to be played on a PC. It's very clear the devs had no intention of making this game usable for PC gamers, and I have no idea why it was released in this state. Unacceptable that they would charge $70 for this.

This does not match up to its predecessor (I wont mention its name, since it does not deserve to be linked to this game), and feels like a massive step backwards in terms of quality. I felt like this game was of a quality I saw 10 or 15 years ago.

1. Its controls were obviously designed for console gaming, this seems insane due to the predecessor being a nice combination of both PC and console controls. On PC it feels terrible and unintuitive. Menu use is not consistent and moving right on any menu could be mouse, arrow, D, or who the hell knows.
I am not normally a game-pad user, but felt forced to use one here (I tried an x-box controller)... and I hated it just as much. i am sure someone who normally uses a game-pad might be comfortable, but I was not.

2. The writing feels weak and mashed together to attempt to make a story. From the beginning i felt very little, if no connection to the characters, not even the ones I felt something for in the predecessor. I just felt like I was going through the motions.

3. Game-play felt less intuitive than the predecessor. it just felt clunky to me. Like I was being forced into playing a certain way rather than the fluid adaption of other Star Wars games. Multiple times I fell to my death simply because it was not obvious what i should be doing. I felt less like a jedi, and more like an untrained padawan, as if Cal had decided to unlearn even the ability to walk properly.

4. Graphics were the only half decent thing, however they did not feel like an improvement. It looks like they just spent more money on detailed textures and left the rest alone. the issue is, how many people seriously pay attention to the tiny leather creases in Cal's vest when playing?

Overall I simply did not feel involved in the game. i can tell I wont be finishing this one for several years and may become buried under plenty of superior games.

A great game crippled by one major issue that cannot let me recommend it, at the moment.
There is a massive VRAM leak that if not handled manually (by restarting the game yourself every 20 minutes to an hour) will simply cause it to crash and sometimes even crash your PC altogether. And on consoles having dips below 720p I mean what the hell.

The story is amazing, the characters likeable and relatable - The world is amazing and the combat is rewarding in a satisfying way. If you're a Star Wars fan this is a game that is simply made for you. If you're not particularly into Star Wars like me, there is everything to enjoy the same way. The exploration, the story, the gameplay are all a strong point for this game. 

So my advice is to wait until the devs actually fix it (which at this point we're starting to doubt they will) or grab it for cheap through a sale because shame on EA for charging $70 for a game that is broken and hasn't been fixed after a whole month since the last patch. So wait and see. If it is fixed at one point then go for it, and I'll even change my vote on this review. If not, there are plenty of other games that deserve attention and that don't crash in your hands.

[h1] Walking the Line [/h1]

Throughout Star Wars media, we've seen our fair share of stories that follow the path of the Jedi, who through hardship, sacrifice, and loss, stray dangerously close to the dark side. Cal Kestis is my favorite example of this yet. Without spoiling, our protagonist keeps me intrigued during the entirety of the campaign to see how he'll end up. Cameron Monaghan gives so much emotion to this role and I love every second of it.

Gameplay wise, Survivor doubles down on activities and collectibles tenfold from its predecessor, and although that may sound good, it can be overwhelming at times with how much there is to collect and grind for 100%. The campaign felt longer to me, but it was also much easier than the first game. I'm not sure if this is because I've gotten better as a gamer, or the fact that I already had the game's pace and fluidity ingrained in my brain, or maybe it was just easier, but I only struggled with a handful of scenarios throughout the game. Saying much more about it would be spoilers, but I think it didn't overstay it's welcome. 

Since launch, the game appears to have been fixed, mostly. I had a few crashes, plenty of texture loading malfunctions, and overall abysmal texture detail in some areas, with the occasional frame drop in high detail areas. Cut scenes played very smoothly, though. The hub area, Pyloon's Saloon, was the center of this problem. I can't say it affected the combat very much, but lulls in the game made it noticeable. There are also a few gameplay related bugs that can halt progress on certain side activities, but I only found this in 2 instances, 1 of which I circumvented and the other I ignored as it wasn't that important to miss. Nonetheless, It shouldn't be there. I would hope in time these problems will be patched. If you're thinking of picking this up, I advise you make sure you exceed the minimum specs, and get it on sale. It functions very well 90% of the time.

I had to upgrade my PC in order to even play this damn game, but I think it was well worth it. I eagerly await the next installment. 
8/10

Much better story and gameplay than Fallen Order but the obvious issue comes down to performance.
I played it on an AMD RX 5700 XT and a Ryzen 7 3700X and I ended up dropping down to mostly medium settings on 1080 and still had many instances of Frame Rate drops, the worst being large spikes in the middle of combat. It's mostly an issue on the large hub area and the AMD FFR would sometimes have to make Cal's hair and other fine details fuzzy to keep performance. I had one Crash to Desktop but nothing else that was game breaking. 

Personally I found the game worth playing despite these issues though it is a bit ridiculous it still performs this poorly after 6 months of patches. Your tolerance to pushing pass these issues should determine if you are willing to gamble. Unfortunately, if you are counting on the two hour refund, you might just be arriving to the biggest problem area and might not have that much time to test if its worth it to keep going. 

All that said, this is one of the best Star Wars games on the market and I'm glad I played it. But it still needs more optimization and its unclear if EA is planning on dropping any more updates.

All the other negative reviews are correct. This game is horribly optimised, and I've probably spent about 5 hours of my play time just trying to get it running right. 

Frame rates will plummet in larger areas regardless of what your graphics are set to, and the game will often crash when interacting with vendors or during very important cutscenes. This is exacerbated by an extremely lengthy "optimizing game files" loading screen every time you relaunch it, which also makes relaunching the game to test and apply fixes extremely frustrating. 

This game also enforces the use of Temporal Anti Aliasing, which looks absolutely disgusting, and is hugely taxing. If you want to simulate what facial blindness must be like, the TAA in this game can do it for you, because it makes everyone look like mud. The only way to fix this is with mods. 

Maybe buy this one when there's a definitive update, or the game goes under $20.

[h1] Spoiler free. Excellent game, with one glaring drawback. [/h1]

TLDR, Jedi Survivor is a VAST improvement over its predecessor, Jedi Fallen Order, that is also very welcoming even to those not very familiar with star wars. All components of the game are major upgrades, however the poor performance of this game cannot be ignored.

[h2] The Real Review [/h2]

I've been burnt out of a lot of games lately, and many games on the steam store just haven't caught my eye. This game changed that. I was very invested in this game throughout the entirety of its duration, which on its own is a colossal upgrade over Fallen Order. Fallen order was a roughly 20 hour game, whereas this one took me around 50. I explored as many avenues as I could in both games, and took them at my own speed and played on Jedi Grandmaster, the hardest difficulty available.

The story is easily the biggest improvement over Fallen Order. Fallen Order's story was fine, but there was just something off about it that I mentioned in my review of that game. It was the pacing! The game was paced like a movie, where you have a big action scene, then a slow part and a buildup to the next action scene. Jedi Survivor was finally given a story designed with gameplay in mind, and it breathes new life into this series. There's never a dull moment, every time you log off thinking "I'm gonna go do this tomorrow!" and it keeps you involved with what's happening at all times. 

The stances! The stances are the best thing this game could have ever gotten. Yes, there were different lightsaber modes in Fallen Order, however they served more as special abilities than proper weapons. In Jedi Survivor every lightsaber type is its own, fully fleshed out stance that has a full moveset and an entire skill tree.  

Combat has seen a major improvement by opting to overhaul the force abilities. There are many, MANY more approaches to combat now due to new force abilities as well as upgrades to existing ones. Every engagement has a powerful strategy to it that might not be immediately recognizable which greatly incentivizes out-of-the-box thinking and clever tactics for every enemy type. 

Exploration! Not all of us love it, but some do, and those of us that do will be happy to know it feels much more natural in Jedi Survivor as opposed to its predecessor. There's so much more to explore and you never feel forced to do any of it. It all feels natural in the sense of a curious "huh, I wonder what's down that path" as you go about the planets instead of there being this question mark on your map and you feeling forced to fill it out. As for the planets themselves, There's two main planets and a few extra, mainly story focused planets, which is more than the first game, especially given that the main planets are massive with loads of upgrades and other things to find. 

Downsides...they exist in all things, and this game is no stranger to them. There's been one thing plaguing this game since it launched, and that's bad optimization. The state this game launched it, whether it's better or worse now, cannot be excused and EA should absolutely be held accountable for it lest it occurs again in future titles. I have quite a powerful computer, so I can't speak too much on my experience, but I will mention that there were absolutely occasional noticable stutters. I averaged 80-110 fps on a 3090ti and 13700k, playing at 1440p with all settings as high as they'll go, raytracing disabled and dlss quality enabled. Do with that as you will.

Overall, Jedi Survivor is a phenomenal game that I enjoyed thoroughly. If you even remotely liked Jedi Fallen Order, I implore you to pick up this game the next time it goes on sale. $70 is definitely a high asking price, but $35 isn't so bad for a game with 50 hours of true content. Don't bother with the other editions unless cosmetics really interest you that much. This game is a marvel compared to Fallen Order, exceeding it in every possible way except for performance. It's still rough on some pcs, and it still runs hot. 

[h1] 8/10 [/h1]

Overall a pretty good game. My PC is the definition of mid and vie had it for 7 years... It runs right/ choppy in open areas on 2 planes, but besides that its honestly pretty good. If you have a decent PC that's under 5 years old you'll be able to run it just fine.  I saw a lot of reviews stating the game is still unplayable, and that is not the case. My guess i that these people have extremely nice Computers and the game doesn't run perfectly... although it should run better, its just fine for me to beat the game and then some. Overall the story is pretty good, but learning different combat styles with the light sabers and the different force powers is where this game shines, and I definitely get Star Killer vibes at certain points in the combat. I would definitely buy this game in the sale, but I beat the main story and got to about 90% finished with the game. There is a decent amount of extra things to do after the main story is done, but to me, it's not worth 70 dollars, more like 30, maybe 40 if you're really into the last game or the Force Unleashed games.

Picks up nicely after the first game, and this ones got some cooler customization options for sure! I feel like the combat is a little more fine tuned from the first game as well. If you liked Fallen Order you gotta finish the story with this one!

An outstanding action game. Maybe 30-40 hours of playtime from start to finish if you're taking your time and doing side-quests along the way. Lots of high-quality cut-scenes, great voice-acting all around, and intriguing characters that deserve inclusion into Star Wars canon.  The only downside I can spot is that it will require a BEEFY gaming computer to really show off it's best features. Processor and video card should be even better than what they're showing in the recommended specs. But if you already have a beefy computer, you should definitely get this one and turn up ALL of the visuals to Epic. Oh, and you'll need about 110 GB of empty storage to install it.

I just can't recommend this game with the performance issues. It's probably a great game under that but I couldn't get past the introduction without having stuttering 24/7 and even after tweaking the game a bunch and trying out different methods, I still get stuttering. Unless a patch comes out that actually makes the game it should've been at launch, don't buy it.

I wish I could recommend this game, but my God not only does this game have plenty of unoptimized problems associated with it that puts into the question of why it's even $70 in the first place, but it also is plagued with really bad open world elements that were not necessarily a big problem in the first game. Mainly this game attempts to double down on the amount of shit that you can collect to the point where I just said "fuck it" and ended up not wanting to 100% this game by going and collecting 100 rocks and plants in random areas in the game.

Jedi Survivor is one of the best games in recent years. The game builds off of the first game and excels in every aspect that was in the first game. The combat is very fluid and sophisticated, while being very easy to learn. During the beginning of the game I was struck away with how high quality it felt. As the game went on and progressed, it just kept one-upping itself, so to speak. The game was so enjoyable from front to cover and I enjoyed all of it. There was only really one exception to this almost master piece of a game. The performance. If you do not have a very up to date or powerful PC you most likely won't be able to get solid FPS while playing the game. The game had major stuttering issues for me in the beginning (first 1-2 hrs) but after that I had very occasional stuttering/FPS drops.  Now if you can bare slight FPS drops for 1-2 hours the game is so worth it. The last thing I want to talk about is the story to wrap up this review. 

The story of this game fits so well within all of Star Wars. Continuing the protagonists story after the first game makes it even better and seeing the character growth in all characters, as well as new. Both sides of characters (good and bad) were thought out very well. The lore and storytelling throughout the game was very satisfying and quite enjoyable.

This game is definitely worth full price if you have a great PC, if you don't have a powerful PC get it on sale so if it doesn't perform well you're not "losing a lot of money".

Overall this game is a solid 9.6/10

If you decide to purchase the game, enjoy!

Shoddy and Rushed work built on the back of a system intended to give under preforming systems a boost instead of making a game that Works at launch. The story is good the art is great, it's a shame that the game is very poorly optimized.

GAME KEPT CRASHING:
Had to refund my purchase as I couldn't get past the opening sequence. I have an RTX 3070, 16GB ram and an intel i7 10th gen, which puts me slightly above the recommended requirements for this game. The GeForce Experience app recommends the game be ran on Epic settings.

The game launched fine and compiled the shaders (which this game does every time on boot up for some reason). I started the game and everything seemed okay but then it suddenly crashed in the opening cutscene. I thought that's odd and lowered my settings to 'high' and upped the DLSS (upscaling). The game allowed me to get a little bit further into the game, and I actually gained control of the player character. I continued down the one path I was allowed until going into an elevator where another cutscene started. Crash number 2 occurred at this point. I checked the integrity of the game files. They were fine. I booted one last time and crashed even earlier in the opening cutscene. 

After 3 crashes, I unfortunately cannot play this game. Since refunding, I have looked into 'fixes' online and some people allocate extra memory for the game and such - but I really shouldn't have to be going out of my way to get a ¬£60 game to run on modern hardware. 

The game also appears to be having other issues running on PC with other crashes being reported in the reviews here and online. While I loved the first game in the series, it looks like I will be unable to continue playing what seems like an amazing title.

I have previously made a review on Fallen order about its issues with the game play and bosses.
This game follows suit with being quite unforgiving with its combat on the normal difficulty. 
There are a miriad of times where you get stunlocked or unfairly ganged up by about 4 high-tier enemies and they slap you to shit and then you die and then you alt+f4 because you cant take the game's shit anymore.

I'd say the bosses are better this time around. Except the final boss... Its still just as sucky as fallen order's final boss.
Unblockable attacks having less than half a second of time to react to... the only difficult part being the final bit where you get stunlocked into oblivion and having your guard broken over and over...

Of course its not meant to be easy... but isn't it meant to be fun to play too?

The new stances are... ok? i don't really know what to mention about them...
They are most likely meant to cater towards whatever playstyle you find best or easier but i found that basically the only one that seems to be viable at all is the dual wielding for speed.
Other than that, they ran the double-sided lightsaber into the ground, added the cross guard which was not interesting at all and got me killed every time i gave it a chance. Out of all of the new things they gave us, im glad dual wield isnt restricted to a single move like the last game. I also like how they gave us a gun/single blade stance which utterly deprecates the single blade stance

I do prefer this games usage and point of view in the post empire-ruled galaxy as it is the most packed timeframe of any star wars part.

I just find it funny that im at a loss for things to write about this game because basically all i mentioned about in my review about Fallen order is true here too.
Though if i had to sum it up...

Its the same game, but runs worse and takes forever to load.
I do hate to say it, but this game is somehow the best Disney Star Wars thing to come out in quite a while.
Congratulations Jedi survivor, you somehow managed to raise the bar an inch.
I just wish this game didn't have denuvo so it wouldn't have taken me ¬£30 to write this crap

An absolute beauty of a sequel.

A sequel is great, to me, when you're basically continuing where you left off, with all the controls, tools and skills already acquired still there, and the only difference between the first and the second is the story and adding to what wasn't there. Changing the entire game with controls, stories, skills and people is just irritating. Especially if you're a different character and it doesn't tie very much to the first.

This doesn't do that. It picks up where it left off as it should. 

EXTREMELY LOOKING FORWARD TO THE NEXT!

Cons:
1. Not as many places/planets to go to this time
2. Performance was an issue yet not as much as people say and it mostly was because of me(I debugged it from the beginning).
3. I only wish for more interactive dialogue options.

Pros

I recommend this wholeheartedly to anyone who loves Star Wars.

If you can get over the occasional stutters, I'd argue this is about as STAR WARS as a game gets.

Plot telegraphs pretty obviously, but it doesn't matter as the actual story is executed well so it still lands.

Locomotion feels excellent, although how you get around in some of the set pieces did require some suspension of disbelief (beyond even that of what force powers might allow), it's used to play up the spectacle however so it's at least fun even if a bit ridiculous.

Combat is just okay. I played it on Jedi Knight which was not exactly difficult, the power fantasy survives it. The different stances and being able to swap between them was nice, although I never felt any particular need to switch due for strategy's sake. Only major point of annoyance was occasional 1 hit kill moves which, thankfully, were not frequent. The tracking on those abilities though made it so it felt real bad when they were encountered (crazy eyed frogs, I'm looking at you).

All in all I enjoyed this one more then the previous Jedi game, and this one's conclusion has me eagerly awaiting another.

Seems to be an improvement in essentially every way in comparison to the first game. The graphics are incredible which is probably why so many have performance issues. There is incredible detail in the world from explorable locations and side routes. It is almost overwhelming how much there is to discover and its in a good way. The detail on in game models, textures, and environment clutter is incredible. I'm 10 hours into the game and JUST leaving the first planet you can adventure on, and I'm 40% explored on it with many areas I know I need to visit still. Really enjoying the game. 

For reference, im playing with a 5800X3D CPU and 6900XT GPU at 4k and get around 55-65 FPS with raytracing off, and I believe effects and shadows turned down one step. With FSR set to quality. At 3440x1440 I get around 75-100fps. I got a powerful system but I am playing on very high graphics settings. And as mentioned, the visuals are truly incredible.

I know I have a good PC but im ok with the performance given the fidelity of the game. The story, exploration, and customization options are very well done thus far. I'm actually surprised by how rough the recent reviews are. I know it launched in a super rough state but at least now in december, and at 50% off, I am super happy with the purchase and the gameplay.

Although I find this game excellent, the fact that the PC version is so buggy is cause for concern. The game should not have been released in this state and I would have expected patches by now to improve it.
Best game of 2023. Just get the May the performance be with you mod and you'll be fine.

Yes, I am aware of the performance issues many have had on PC. No, I did not have the same issues. I'm sure it's different for everyone but I'm going to skip over the performance issues for the sake of the review.

Overall, Jedi: Survivor is an improvement to the first game in every way. It does exactly what a sequel should do, that is to say it takes everything that was great about Fallen Order and expands upon it. The gameplay is tough but satisfying, although some boss fights do feel unfair to the point where they're more frustrating than fun. 

Where this game really shines is the writing. Fallen Order's story and characters were great, especially in comparison to all other Star Wars naratives that have come out in recent years. That being said, Survivor really blows Fallen Order's story out of the water. Not only does the overall conflict feel grand and important, the internal battle raging in Cal is what really sells the story. Survivor takes the characters from the first game and develops them further, making them more interesting and easy to get attached to. I cannot wait to see how the narrative continues in the third game.

Overall, despite the performance issues many have encountered, I highly recommend this game.

I think to myself "well that was weird", everything seems to be working fine so I boot the game back up. Upon trying to load back into the game I am greeted with "Your save file has been corrupted. No back up save was found. Please start a new journey." WHAT A STEAMING PILE OF TRASH! I can't believe they fucked this game up so bad. I truly love the game but can't play it because they royally fucked up the PC Port. Shame on you Respawn! I can't recommend this game til it's fixed.

13 hours in at the moment , Had a LOAD of issues at first, Game HATES Overclocked RAM , got a 4090 with a 12900K, My ram is rated a 3600mhz, Would crash all the time, Underclocked it a 3200Mhz and no more crash since 

Other than the fact that EA did one of the shittiest port of all time , What an EXCEPTIONNAL game , if you can get through fiddling with your pc and BIOS , i absolutely recommend it. 

It would be even better if Respawn would address the issues with the game stability but well, it's 2024, what can we ask anymore?

Amazing game, much improvements over the first and super excited to see another sequel, hoping Cal won't die in that one.. :s

But as great as it is, it also has many issues;

At least early on, every time you start the game you have to go through the 'initial setup' screen, and every time you have to watch/skip a recap video of the first game.

The menus and settings can be super difficult to navigate because pc controls do not work properly. 
When changing keybinds the menus can get stuck, it can sometimes lock up and fail to register keys being pressed anymore. 
Even in regular gameplay there are some keybinds for abilities cannot be changed and are awful, certain abilities will automatically be used because of the wonky way controls were set up, for example I am often automatically focusing on an enemy and unable to do anything until I hit the focus keybind again to toggle it off even though I never use it in the first place.
It seems this is because it was ported to pc without native pc controls in mind, you often can't click things in menus because it wasn't designed for a mouse, and even just using keyboard it can still glitch a lot.

Lots of crashes in certain spots, almost always DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_HUNG 

The 'Toggle Hold Pull' accessibility setting keeps stopping functioning, requiring to go into settings and toggle it off and on again to work.

A native FSR Frame Gen patch would be nice for those who don't have rtx 40X cards.

The UI seems somehow visually worse designed than the first game?

I'm really hoping there will be more updates to come and fix these odd thing for any newer players, because it got really frustrating early on and the badly done pc controls really weighed on me getting into it at first.
w

The devs have all the ingredients to make a great game, but they don't know how to cook. The combat tries to be souls-like, but misses the mark of having a clean/rewarding combat loop. The open world tries to be a metroidvania, but the exploration feels hollow. Couple that with a completely transparent story and horrible PC optimization, and you get a game that is all over the place. Worth buying on a sale if you played the first or are a fan of Star Wars - otherwise I'd stay away from it.

I wanted the game but waited because of all the reviews about graphic issues and crashing.  I can attest on first run it was laggy and choppy, but easily fixed after lowering Windows resolution to 1920x1080, disabling V-sync, and changing game from Windowed Fullscreen to just Windowed, that last step really helped.  From then on it has been smooth and pretty.  GTX 1660ti, 32gb ram, 2.8 i-9.

Edit:  I played through it once, going again on harder difficulty with more exploration, and really seeing more of the flaws.  I still think its a good game, but the flaws are glaring.  
-Enemies become invincible during certain movements despite attacks hitting them.
-Enemies go from prone to standing in an instant when attacked.
-Most enemies can resist force pull/push despite no explanation of how they can, like robots and raiders.
-Most of Cal's abilities require delaying or charging which is opposite of the game's entire premise:  speed/reaction time.
-Enemies can attack while in conversation and Cal cannot respond.
-Enemies 'combo' attacks cannot be dodged, blocked or parried once begun, (like original NES games where you get stuck repeatedly hit until dead.
-Enemies always get priority when attacking at the same time as your attack.
-Enemies instantly regain all block/stun meter after being hit 1-2 times. (I wish Cal's block meter did that!)
-Blocking is ineffective roughly 30-40% of the time, despite hitting block on or just before an enemy attack connects.  In addition, blocking is in too high demand.  You are required to deflect multiple blaster shots, and multiple melee enemies at the same time, yet you can only block once every 1.5 seconds.
-Enemies with AoE (area) attacks require fast & far dodging, meanwhile your main attacks are with an up-close lightsaber... an oxymoron if there ever was one.  In addition, enemies can perform red area attacks repeatedly, essentially making it impossible for you to attack until they decide to do something else.

There are other issues like places you should be able to walk or jump but are blocked by invisible barriers the devs didn't want you to cross, but didn't bother to put up an actual wall.

No game made in the last two decades has been free of issues like this because young devs and game testers don't have the experience to do their job well enough.
I hate you!

So I finally figured out how to make this game run nicely. I have cpu- i7-11700f gpu-4070 ti with and 32gb of ram. I was having the game crash on me and realized it was running my cpu at 99% and my gpu at like 30%. The game doesnt use the cpu and gpu correctly. So I figured I need to make it use my gpu more. Simple fix that you wouldnt think would work. I just maxed all the settings and it started using 95 % gpu and 30% cpu. No more poor running or crashes. This fixed my game hopefully it fixes yours.
Game performance is by no means fixed, But its definitely playable now. The narrative and gameplay are worth it IMO

Its clear they tried to just copy the first game with the story beats, which is understandable, its not unpresidented in star wars games and movies. however, so MANY story beats and twists are unbearably predictable. its like it goes, "oh no these bad guys totally have you BUT WAIT" and exactly who you think will do what you think will happen.

It's good, does have performance issues but still playable on fairly mid hardware.

EA launcher is a big negative, sometimes blocks the game from launching at all.

The game is fun and has some great new features and mechanics, so I would recommend for the game itself. Bad news is the game runs poorly and its quite buggy. If I remember correctly the characters moved more realistically in the previous game and it was much smoother with movement. Performance was also never an issue in the previous game. With this one I get dragged into a cutscene so unnaturally as they try to have us enter a cutscene from a certain angle and position while we could just be facing the opposite direction and it just makes it look silly. This game needs some serious optimisation. It can run fine at times and then suddenly I am on 30fps. I don't even get that low on any other game even with rtx on. This is very disappointing. 
Also the models could've used a bit more work. Cal looks deformed at times and a slight spoiler here, Eno Cordova looks straight out of a 2010 game while standing next to Cere who actually looks real. 

I would honestly say the game needed another year before release. Like seriously this came out in April of last year right? How can it run so poorly almost a year later? 

Also, any tips on performance would be helpful.

Edit: After playing the game a bit longer, it seems to run a lot better later on in the game. It still has some bugs but they are not so bad that it makes it unplayable. The gameplay took a huge turn and the new moves learned are quite fun to use and make getting around that much better. 
I do not know for sure but it could just be the beginning of the game that runs poorly, not a good look obviously as first impressions are big but as it is running a bit better it does make me enjoy the game much more. I would still wait for a fix or honestly a sale as it is not worth the full price with the bugs. Though for the story and gameplay itself it is definitely worth it.

Well... It's not bad. Someone who would want to play Tarzan with a lightsaber, might even find it entertaining. It has so much climbing and jumping around, that it becomes cumbersome and boring at some point.
The plot is also relatively dull, typical modern day star wars. Cal's is also annoying. Well yes, even more annoying than he was in Fallen Order. The blaster stance is totally unnecessary and useless. 
It's an ok game for the winter, but I was expecting something more exciting. 
* Keep in mind that it needs a pretty good PC, to play it in a decent way.

A game I absolutely and thoroughly enjoyed that is miles ahead of the original game which was already really good. The combat is super fun and engaging, the exploration is amazing and absolutely pays off and the story is good. [spoiler] I think Dagan should have been the final boss as Bode was kind of a weak final boss but it's fine as is it currently. [/spoiler] In my opinion, everything I have mentioned easily put it on my list of the best games of all time, up there with some of my favorites like RDR2, the Witcher 3, Celeste, Nier: Automata, Yakuza: Like a Dragon etc. BBBBBUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUTTTTTTTT . . .and this is a ginormous but hence the negative review . . . that fucking horrible horrible HORRIBLE performance is absolutely inexcusable. Just absolutely horrible a whole 8 FUCKING MONTHS after release. ARE YOU SERIOUS, RESPAWN?? ARE YOU SERIOUS??? This is a fucking joke and does a huge disservice to everything else about the game. A fucking shame! The rest of the game is so fucking good and yet you didn't give a single flying fuck about the performance. At first I thought "oh well the game must be in UE5 versus the prior one which was in UE4 so I guess just growing pains and technically a new engine." Nope, it's the exact same fucking engine. Such a fucking shame! IF you are okay with some performance issues mainly on Koboh although they show up on other planets, absolutely give this one a go. If not, it's absolutely fine to avoid it too. Just know you'll be missing out on a great game.

You spend your time hunting down chests and whatnot only to get a new hair cut. It's silly. I also find it silly that the cross saber is treated like an actual heavy sword. Taking longer to swing as if it's actually heavier. It doesn't make any sense with regards to it being a lightsaber with a guard. Such an amazing game and a worthy continuation to Fallen Order
