The story sadly wasn't as good as the first game. Not to say it was bad, but i wasn't as interested in it as i was with the story of Fallen Order and it even was very predictable in some cases.
I didn't had much problems with the performance, it does drop frames from time to time, specially on bigger areas, but i'm sure if you're able to mess around the setting you can work it out. Or play it on a console, that's another option lol

All around, i do think this was one of the best game of 2023, but the strong competition last year and the poor optimization it had at launch sadly made people forget about it.
The game is very well worth the price. Just a heads up, i HIGHLY RECOMMEND playing Fallen Order first. Both games can get pretty insane discounts for the type of games they are. So i don't think there is no reason to not buy it, even if you're not a Star Wars fan

Jedi Survivor is a game that is easy to recommend, but also easy not to recommend.

When everything works, it is a visual, fluid, story rich game with excellent audio, good combat and great production value.

However the technical side of things leaves a lot to be desired. I have an RTX 4090 and at 4K with RTX the stuttering is incredible and there are ton of visual glitches. The game crashed about 7 times in 58 hours making me paranoid about saving often. Thankfully with Frame Generation it becomes much smoother but if you don't have Freesync or G-Sync, you might struggle. Also, you have to wait every single time before playing for 2-3 minutes for "optimization of files".

There's a lot of content in the game and it can become a bit tedious with a ton of collectibles. There are maybe 300-400 of them in the game.

Taking into consideration the technical issues, this game is a solid 7/10. Without those, it is what you want from a Single Player Star Wars game and a sequel to Fallen Order. A 9/10 there.

I would buy it only on deep sale. I got it for 50% Off and would never pay EA 70$ for this.

It is difficult to recommend this game and I do not recommend it full price, but will recommend it for sales.

The game itself looks great and plays well enough on my 4070. I'm not through the main story so can't comment on that. I do like to 100% open worlds and that's where a lot of player frustration comes into play with this title.

Example 1:
Had a puzzle where you had to move a rolling mine from one point to another. So I cleared the route of enemies, got the mine, game respawned the enemies even though I didn't rest at a bonfire. Mine exploded.
Cleared it again of enemies, quickly got the mine. Enemies spawn right before the entrance where I had to drop the mine off, mine goes to the first enemy and explodes. 

Example 2:
Spent 40 minutes trying to get past a gust of wind on an open world obstacle. The game had been training me to turn off machines or pull switches to advance such puzzles. I looked all around the area, figuring I was missing something obvious. In the end I searched on the internet, and it turns out I needed a new power to get past that particular obstacle that I had not received yet. The game did not inform at all that I needed some new kind of power, even in the way of a simple 'can't get past this, I'm missing something' line from Cal.

There is a lot of frustration like that where mechanics teach you one thing, then open world traversal requires another. In that aspect the world itself is quite hard to navigate as well. Jump puzzles aren't hard (remember jump puzzle difficulty is often subjective) but some are downright insane, especially some of the tear/fissure challenges. 

The 'bonfire/sight of grace/dark souls save system' does not work consistently. Many enemies respawn even though I never rested or fast traveled, even when never exiting an area (see puzzle issue above, where respawning enemies kept exploding the mine that you have to precariously move across the map). 

Things are more polished than the first title. But it's still 'off'. I can't put my finger exactly on what, but my guess is that the issue is game testing. Either they didn't listen to their gameplay testers or ignored feedback, especially when it comes to puzzle solving and 'game logic', or they just didn't test it well enough, only testing the 'happy flow'.

Which leads me to the last issue with this game, 'can't do this/can't go there.. because GAME LOGIC'.
"You can't simply jump that 2 meter high ledge and get to that area, even though 1 minute before I jumped a 7 meter gap without issue, because..".. game logic. 
"You can't climb that ledge, which looks 100% identical to that other ledge that you CAN climb, because".. game logic.
"You can't jump attack here, but you can do it there, because".. game logic.

That game logic is illogical at best.
So when this is on sale and you have a few free days, buy it and play the main story. Do not try to 100% unless you are a masochist and love semi-broken-but-functional gameplay mechanics and logic.

Great game with a great story and amazing design elements. Well worth the cost. Definitely could improve its optimization I played it on a 3080 and still had a fair number of visual artifacts, freezes, and sluggish frames but the game-play more than makes up for the small performance issues.

So if you are me who has looked at this game every time its been on sale and looked to see if it was playable I have the review for you. Reminder my Laptop build is what is recommended on the page.

Over all: This game is playable runs well enough to get you through the story. In my experience I haven't had the game crash or had a bug that soft lock me in areas. I do recommend giving it a try when its on sale for around 50% off. For a $70 game wouldn't  recommend it at all.

The issues: As I said before the game is playable, but there are many bugs when it comes to graphics and the in game cut scenes. Fist one is this game goes through an optimization process EVERY TIME IT STARTS.  So When I bought the game I thought I had to refund it because the intro of company bumpers and logos where running at 10 fps. Then it hits the optimization process. Why they thought it was a good idea to have the optimization process after the bumpers and logos is beyond me, but every time the game starts up it will look unplayable. 

Game Play issues: I haven't had to many bugs that would affect game play. At most I would drop frames for a bit for them to pick back up again, but  this was rare in some cases. Only really happened when I was in an area for the first time or there was a lot of explosions on screen. When I fist started playing I noticed harsh lighting issues or objects that would be called in if I moved the camera fast enough resulting in the to flicker in. This happened often with tight or dark areas. Rarely I would be able to push enemies through walls  that tossed them out into the void. Things like the ships holo map for selecting planets looks like utter garbage with very low texture that made it look like it was being rendered by a ps2. It also made the game lag. 

Cut scene issues:  Here is where most of problems I would find. Since most of the cut scenes are in game most of the same issues persist from the game play section but worse some how. A lot of time you can see the frame rate drop dramatically objects be called in or flicker in and out of existence. At certain points you can see them accelerate and slow down for normal dialogue. Like the ultra-HD scam you would see in Best buy where it will be playing a movie and the movements of the be fast and when they people start talking it would slowdown.  I found this as an issue because I find it as an eye sore and explosions, light saber wooshes and blaster fire would have a delayed impact sound wise. When flying through space A lot of the textures would look compressed and grainy making ask what I'm looking at most of the time because it was hard to make out any details. At one point the characters looked at it and said "Its beautiful" for it to pan over and it be so low rez to the point where I had to nod my head and say sure sarcastically. 

Other than those issues the game is fine and playable and shouldn't stop yo from picking it up on sale.

Great gameplay and story, but still marred with technical issues.  Uneven frame times/stuttering.  

I still enjoyed it, but be prepared.

Overall, I am very happy with the game and enjoyed my time with it. I can absolutely recommend this to anyone with a higher end PC or is willing to play at 30 fps on a lower end rig, and hope that the third game improves on the core just as much as this game did for the first. I had no crashes, and while the performance is not what it should be, the game itself was  enjoyable enough to look past the drops. Characters were fun to spend time with, the core group being great to listen to and interact with. The story doesn't focus solely on the Empire which makes me glad - and allows them to shine when they need too without retreating the traditional "rebellion" points so much Ep. 3-4 media covers. The plot feels organic and largely isn't padded out. Game play is wonderful - the new movement abilities make the platforming feel better than the first game and honestly sticks out a lot to me in general with how great it feels. New enemy types and re balancing on some abilities (pull, removal of slow as a force ability) improves the flow a lot. Hacking droids and confusion were great abilities to not make Double-Bladed stance the go-to for crowd control. Bosses felt fresh, and the new stances like Blaster and Greatsword felt good to use and mixed up combat.

Bulletised Version:
Pros: 
   - Greatly expanded combat move-set and traversal abilities.
   - A great story that follows up on the previous game without retreading, character growth feels natural and while one twist is somewhat predictable, other parts are not and the journey still feels good to play through.
   - Planets are MUCH easier to navigate, there aren't any areas like the Swamp in the first game that are borderline impossible to travel across.
   - Enemy Variety is much larger than the first game, with the Bedlam Raiders helping mix up combat encounters and keep the Imperials from feeling fatigue.
   - Bosses were overall an improvement from the first game; (Skip this if you want to avoid spoilers)
          - Each of the Dagan fights felt different enough for him to not feel like the same boss, particularly the final one in the observatory.
          - Ravis was probably one of my favorite fights from the game, if a little easy, the pacing on it was excellent and the second phase felt really good to play against.
          - Bode could have been harder in the final phase, but overall was a very good fight to cap off the game.
          - Other smaller bosses and the bounty targets are a good way to add some encounter variety, non-Jedi bosses using a mix of blaster and saber was nice as well.
          - Some of the wildlife still feels a little overturned sometimes. I.E the Wampa things in some of the Koboh areas are a little crazy the first few times you encounter them.
   - The additional stances - Blaster, Dual, and my favorite, the Greatsword Crossguard Saber, did a lot for combat as well, as they were each very fun to use.
   - While jarring at first, the change to have some enemies resist pull and then make you parry them to pull them I think was a huge improvement over outright immunity to the status.
   - Removal of slow overall improved the game-play, the ability was effective but not interesting to use.
  - (Spoilers) I also liked how they actually made Cal more "grey" in the sense of how the dark side is utilized before and during the boss fight, I.E being necessary to defeat Bode but also an uncontrolled force as shown in the ISB facility. It feels realistic in how they handled it and doesn't just fall into the traditional "dark side evil jedi don't do" thing that so many other supposedly "netural" (i.e Ahsoka) Jedi end up parroting.

Cons:
  - Performance was a negative. I have a I-7 13700 with a 4070 and would struggle to hit 60fps in some areas. Raytracing I used some on Courtesant before turning it off due to perfomance hits. It is not unplayable but definitely should be better as most players do not have higher end rigs, and for how well these games preform there is no reason there should not be more optimization.
  - There was some graphical artificating present in indoor areas when quickly moving through or rotating the camera. This was only present indoors however, and was relatively minor.
  - Some enemy types are less thought out than others, I.E Flametroopers who reload too fast making pulling them the go-to to defeat them, and the spike balls on Koboh having hitboxes that do not match their attack animations.
  - I would have liked them to maybe have one more planet or so to the game to add some variety? Koboh is HUGE and some of the story destinations there could have been moved to another planet in the system just to add some visual change. 
  - I wish there was more to Tannalorr other than the Final Boss, having some exploration to it even if it was post-game only would have been nice to see more of it.
  - Rumors largely being useless aside from simply pointing you in a direction, actual sidequests with rewards tied to them I think would have been more interesting since many rumors autocomplete if you explore before they become active.
  - Fully optional abilities that you have to explore to find, I.E the electricity thing, as it kinda causes exploration to be discounted early on since progressing the story is the only way to unlock new traversal abilities.

Kind of a joke to be asking $70 for this when it still isn't optimized. Some really weird issues for a AAA release and that's only scratching the surface.

Are you a fan of invisible walls and poor level geometry? Well you're in for a treat. Think you can just jump past that pipe? NOPE, its a wall. Want Cal to grab that ledge you're jumping at? Well, that wasn't the developer's intention so you just have to sit there and wonder why Cal wouldn't grab the wall.

That's not even all!!

The combat system in this game is so half baked that it you feel so powerless as a Jedi. You have TONS of options. (They did a good job at making the game feel more robust than the first one.) But, your options don't really change anything. 

Wanna be a two hander big sword guy? Great, they have a play style for you. BUT you get no i-frames so you get knocked around constantly even by tiny bird enemies. I know what you're thinking, skill issue?

LOL NOT EVEN

you hit enemies to damage their "block bar" but legit if you let off pressure for half a second, their bar regens. As if that's not frustrating, your hits barely do any damage so combat becomes an attrition game of mashing instead of the pseudo-souls style combat we got a taste of in the first one. Now don't get me wrong, first one ain't a masterpiece by any means but holy crap did they really just phone this game in. Would've probably been better off just going full DMC hack n slash if they wanted to have the artificial difficulty like this.

There are SOME positives. Obviously the world building is there, its Star Wars; and the maps are pretty massive. But damn is the story predictable and how can I feel like a powerful jedi when I'm hitting things with my lightsaber like 50+ times before they go down. 

Wait for it to go sub $20 and you should be aight.
Honestly unplayable on steam deck save your money, running on low with 30fps, fsr on graphics look terrible which I could put up with but it crashes constantly aswell...... avoid this one.

Avoid this game at all cost. I'm only completing the game out of pure spite because I bough the game a year ago.

Fuck this game, fuck EA.

After playing the first game and this game now in a row I must say, that the story is great.
I played both games on Grandmaster for my first( and propably only, because it is very story driven) playthrough.
Pros:
-The game looks incredibly good.
-The Force Powers feel good against common enemies.
-The variation of playstyles is good due to the different stances.
-On highest difficulty most of the enemies and Bosses are worthy as enemies.
-Propably decent replayability due to some locations only being accessible with story progress.
-The Combat overall feels good and makes fun.
-The Skillsystem is good enough.
-Fast Travel is implemented which saves a lot of time.

Cons:
-Some Parts of some Missions are just annoying.
-Some Parts of some Missions (platforming) are very unintuitive
-Some Bugs made it from the first game to this one...
(fe. Being able to walk freely when a sequence should be played in combat where you have to press a button repeatidly)
-Sometimes it still stutters 
(but closing and restarting the game seems to fix it... still while having to save on meditation points, this is not a good solution...)
-Another major Negative Aspect has been some attacks in a few Boss fight.
(There are two types of attacks, 1 you can block and dodge, 2nd the red ones which you need to dodge. Yet some attacks that aren't red will lock you the defensive stance, so you can't dodge once you block them, those attacks get followed up by a red one that you obviously can't block, but because you are locked, you can't dodge them... This is just stupid, make the attacks red or something else... Yes you could dodge them all... but it is still stupid.)

Overall I have to say, even if those negative Points are annoying, they do not occur that often and the good ones, especially the very good story, outweighs them.
I would rate this game 7/10.

TL;DR: Jedi Survivor is the natural next step after Fallen Order. It improves on most things, but performance will probably never be fixed, and the combat will have initial appeal to those who appreciate soulslikes but it has flaws that will put off people who are experienced. If you can deal with that the game is overall good.

There's really only one area where more detail is needed than what you can get from a cursory look at the steam page and other reviews. Combat.

This game wants to be more like sekiro than dark souls, and while it can be fun it fails to understand what made sekiro good. Anything above a mook with a blaster you'll attack a few times, get parried, then the enemy will attack a few times and you're expected to time your blocks to deplete their posture which opens them up to taking more damage. However, unlike sekiro breaking posture doesn't guarantee you a kill or removal of a healthbar, it only lets you get about 3 or 4 hits in before their stamina recovers. Most enemies don't have a lot of health so this would be fine but posture gauges can take awhile to deplete and they regenerate pretty quick if you're not applying pressure to them. Also enemies can do unblockable attacks where they  glow red for a moment before striking to warn you. This system works well enough... in 1v1 combat. Against groups it starts to fall apart. What happens in a group is that the enemies will start to gang up on you, and typically in groups the devs will often put two copies of the same stronger enemy type and their attacks will overlap creating situations where it's impossible to avoid tons of damage without backing off entirely, letting their posture refill. And even in some cases there are enemies who will overlap unblockable ranged attacks. This is not helped by the fact that there's only one combat stance (dual wield) where you can cancel out of animations, effectively making it a stance you always have to have equipped on higher difficulties. Finally, you WILL have performance issues, I did even with a 3080, which can make parrying in areas where there are performance problems basically impossible.

The issue is Respawn doesn't really know how to make a good difficult game. You can make enemies harder by giving them punishing move sets, or making them harder to punish or making punishes less effective. You can make encounters more difficult by adding more enemies. Instead of intelligently picking and choosing from these methods, the devs decided to kitchen sink any encounter that they wanted to be hard. Or in the case of some legendary enemies (bosses that are just elites that do more damage and have more health) inflate their values to where there's effectively a minimum health requirement for encounters because on your first playthrough you will simply not be able to get out of any real fights without taking damage. As far as playing jedi go, Cal is the weakest jedi you can play in any game. He has a lot of different stances he can use but he's actually not that much stronger than a guy with an electro staff. Any melee enemy can block blaster bolts for some reason, and without heavy skill point investment force powers are not that strong, using a fat chunk of your meter to lift an enemy or mind control them for just a couple seconds. There are ways to make him stronger like increasing his max hp, max heals, max force, and skills that give him new moves or powers but you will feel like you're up against poor odds most of the time.

This is all to say the combat system will not impress the action game or soulslike connoisseur. It's a step up for sure from your normie movie game combat system that's afraid of depth, but Respawn didn't want to alienate those normies so the combat ends up having a lot of balancing issues. Bosses and your average fight can be fun and satisfying. However you will frequently, especially towards the end of the game, come up to an encounter which is just not very fun because the design of the encounter clashes with the design of the combat system itself. It's clear to me the devs realized this issue because you have a sort of "super" force power that charges up with attacks. Through most of the game it slows enemies around you until they've been hit once or twice (basically letting you 1v1 a guy for a little while, where the game is strong) which near the end doubles as a rage power letting you 1 tap all but the tankiest enemies. This power is a crutch to get through the hardest dogpiles so the devs wouldn't have to think too hard about designing their encounters.

If you're not looking for "sekiro/dark souls but it's star wars" there's a good game here. The combat simply fails to hold up to scrutiny of any real depth. If you have NO performance issues because you have a 4090Ti or something then you can play on the hardest two difficulties and probably still have a good time. Otherwise just put it on medium and cruise through it, this game isn't strong as a difficult or challenging game. It's stronger when the combat has enough room for error that you can appreciate the spectacle of it better and not be forced to bring the "good" lightsaber stances instead of the ones you like most.

Ok, so first off, gameplay. You start out more or less where you left off abilities-wise from Fallen order. You already possess all the force and BD1 abilities from the last game, though some of the lightsaber skills are innate, and a few need to be unlocked again. This game does however have its own suite of traversal upgrades for you to unlock (including a grappling hook), as well as the usual ability upgrades and a few perks on the side if you want to mess with that. Its the same basic gameplay as the first game aside from that: Sekiro clone, since we're just calling it that now.

As far as fighting and progression goes, the first half of the game is pretty strong, teaching new players pretty well and getting veteran players a warmup. But the second half of the game kind of ran out of ideas, and just starts throwing tons of heavy enemies at the player often, as well as a few multi-boss fights (which NEVER works, and is never fun) just to irritate you. The final boss was... well he was OK. Not sure what all the fuss was about, there were more challenging fights in the game.

Story-wise this game gets a higher rating from me compared to Fallen Order for the sole reason that it plays fast and loose with common tropes. In other words, it ended up being predictable at some points, but managed to be unpredictable and even surprised me more than a few times. I don't dislike it honestly, its nice to see things not following the typical predictable narrative pattern.

Though the game also did leave off on a bit of a cliffhanger. I won't spoil, but something major happens that affects both the character and gameplay in the second half of the game, yet the game doesn't really highlight this, or even attempt to elaborate much on it. It ends with it being unresolved, presumably for the sequel it is definitely setting up.

Overall good rating, not the best in the world, but for the most part it was enjoyable. I would rate it 6/10, simply because the composition of the fights in the second half of the game became more annoying than fun more than a few times.

The performance is the only thing holding this gem of a game back. It's an amazing sequel with probably the best setup for a story. I love the open world environments and ability to explore to find more items. You earn all the cosmetic items by finding them in game. It still has bit of hitches. At least it's not stutter city like it used to be. Makes use of new graphics cards. fluid motion amd 7000 series and nvidia frame generation 40 series. So It really asks for these cards. If you have 3070 to 3080 you should be fine. If you have 6800 to 6900 amd you should be fine.

The best Star Wars game since Jedi Knight 2 Jedi Outcast, if you can run it.  

It's a metroidvania souls-like with an abundance of rewarding collectibles.  Also, I have not seen any MTX promotions whatsoever, similar to something like Elden Ring where it almost feels like a game from a time passed.

I personally really liked Cal as a character.  I thought his dialogue was great in the way he carried himself as the Jedi Survivor.  Beyond him, the story overall for me was the weakest point of the game but still sometimes it was pretty good.  It was never not enjoyable, just  certain characters could be annoying.

Regarding performance, it's truly unfortunate that investors/corporates didn't set aside a budget for optimizing the game properly.  Performance was good for me overall but I'm completely aware that is not the case for most people.

The game gets the thumbs up for game-design and mentioned criteria.  I left out lots of details, such as the saloon, and some really annoying mechanics that with enough raging can be mastered.  I also would have liked more challenge missions even though they could take significant time on the hardest difficulties.  Still a great game.

I really can't recommend this game, and it kind of stinks to write that. Everything I've played of it has been good‚Äì combat, acting, and story. The problem is that I haven't been able to see much of it. I'm going on 10 hours played and I can't leave the first planet you travel to, Koboh, because the game literally can't go long enough without crashing. I've replayed the same sections 5 or 6 times, and I can go a max of about an hour before it crashes and I lose maybe 10 minutes of gameplay. I've fought Zeik three times. I've tried it on two different PC platforms, and it can barely run on either, and it sometimes crashes after mere minutes if you go to a shop or a workbench. Even cutscenes barely run, not to mention the difficulty it has even launching. It hurts because I love the series and it's entirely possible there's a great game there that people clearly worked hard on and care about, but it's in such an inexcusable state that if you're reading this and are on the fence, please wait to buy.

So I do not understand all of the negative reviews stating the game runs like crap. I had no issues whatsoever. Now, in all fairness I have a custom built Alienware laptop that I spared no expense when building that is not quite a year old so performance was not an issue. In the 38 hours of game play, I experienced 2 crashes. Annoying yes, but that is because the game does not have a regular autosave......most of the saving is dependent on the meditation spots and sometimes they are far and few between. I really liked Fallen Order, but I really loved Survivor. The story was amazing and gets better and better the farther into the game you are. I won't give any spoilers, but let's just say the game has a few jaw dropping moments that I did not see coming and true surprises in a game are so rare. I had a few personal choice issues that annoyed me. One was the map. Too busy and was not always helpful when you weren't sure which way to go, which happens often as you do double back in some areas and then start to think you are going the wrong way because wasn't I just here?! The lack of autosave can be annoying because if you are in the middle of something, you can't quit until you find the next meditation spot or you lose all of that progress. I also think they need to take the skill tree down a notch. There are too many choices that require multiple buttons to be used. In the end, I found I remembered only a few and most of the skills I purchased I never used.
I appreciate the lack of FOMO in this game.  It's quite linear and most of the extras are just that--Extras.

The game, story, combat, upgrades, skill tree are all top notch. But the stuttering ruins it. It's unavoidable and distracting. I bought it on sale and forced my way through it, 

I died due to stuttering and uninstalled it. Also, the achievements do not work.

This game is surprisingly very good despite it being from EA. I played the first one and this one got rid of any issues from the first while adding a few things many will like. If there was a game to compare this to, it'd be like if Hollow Knight was 3D and had a triple A budget behind it. The game also runs extremely well on my pc and while my specs can run somewhat modern games, it does usually have issues with very demanding games but this game is not one of them. The only thing I miss is that the first game had more planets while this one has less. Still around the same amount of game play if not more but having more planets just felt more interesting compared to this one. Especially since the main planet is very huge and takes a while to get around. A solid 9/10 in my opinion that will keep you coming back either for the story, combat, or collectibles.

**January 2024 update**

3080 Founders Edition, I average 140 FPS in Heaven Benchmark on everything maxed as far as it will go at 1440p. That's 4 frames below my monitor's refresh rate.

I get a fluctuating 20‚Äì80 FPS in Jedi Survivor on the following:
    Low everything
    DLSS on Balanced
    Ray Tracing off
    Motion Blur off
    Film Grain off
    Chromatic Aberration off

Stutters heavily, with the largest FPS drops in the more "open world" environments, like after you crash your ship on Koboh. 

Still do not recommend buying this game.

**Post October Update**
While slightly more stable, FPS drops are still insanely common. The addition of nVidia DLSS is a nice step, and setting it to ultra performance may stabilise the game, but also make it look like a load of crap. Yet another example of Game Developers using upscaling as optimisation. Game can't inherently hold a stable 60 FPS on medium or higher graphics at hardware specs above the recommended options. This game should still be on your "wait to buy" list. 

**Post July Update Edit**
Running this for the first time since June, there was an update in July and none in August. While not a potato in a dumpster fire anymore, it is still a potato. Rig is still well above recommended hardware specs as stated in previous edits, still can't run this game at max. Ray tracing off and medium at best graphics settings get me a smooth gameplay experience. Meanwhile larger games with better graphics run seamless at 90+ FPS on my rig. Respawn and EA Games still have a lot of work to do here, but I doubt they'll put much more effort in to it. Either get the best overkill hardware money can buy, or come to terms with running this at mediocre settings with arguably top tier hardware.

**Post June 20th Update Edit**
FPS still fluctuates heavily between 30 and 65 while overclocked, this is at max graphics turned on now. I am way above the recommended hardware specs, let alone the minimum hardware specs, so maintaining a minimum 60 FPS all the time shouldn't be an issue. Game is still not optimised obviously.

**Original Review**
TL;DR how did Respawn let this happen?!

Forget the steam deck, this thing barely runs on a good gaming rig. Fallen Prder (IMO) was a master piece, but Survivor? Jesus‚Ä¶

155GB? How and why?
22 FPS on the menu before you start the game at lowest settings? WTF?!
Crashing in first 10 minutes of gameplay?

Did they not even test the PC port before they released? Extremely disappointed in Respawn. In a post Cyberpunk world, how are devs still doing this?

Review:

I have a general rule of a game being worth it if it gives you around 1 hour per ‚Ç¨ you spend. I bought this during the winter sale for 35‚Ç¨ so it achieved just about my standard. The game improves on almost everything compared to the first one. I just completed the story and did a fair bit of side questing, though i have a lot more to do. That said the story was overall good but not mind blowing. Some moments left me really scratching my head. A certain sequence was particularly boring to play but i am not gonna spoil it here. 

As for performance i have a 5900X with a 3080 OC and 32 gb of ram and i got ''almost'' steady 60 fps @ 1440p everything on epic without RT throughout the whole game with minor dips and stutters on very specific areas, bear in mind this is with the latest performance patch. With RT my fps would tank to around mid 40s in some sections so i turned it off. Weird enough i think the game is somewhat CPU bound. Maybe it'll improve in the future but i highly doubt it. Sad to see a game this day and age that compiles shaders for a solid 2 minutes every time you launch it. I'll give it that it really does look beautiful nevertheless.

Sad to see such bad performance cause the game is really good. I can see myself playing for 10+ more hours to try and complete the skill tree and try new game plus. So there! you know what to expect.

The little bit I played was fun until I started have graphic errors. I currently have a NVIDIA geforce rtx2060, AMD ryzen 5 2600X six core, and 16 GB ram, and according to the store page I am above the minimum requirements for this game so it should be playable. I have tried lowering everything to the lowest setting, selecting high performance options both in game and on my computer, put on game mode, switched power settings, etc. For the first time in my life I can say I played a game at 1 fps against my will (this was according to NVIDIA performance overlay). I am very disappointed considering I enjoyed the first game and tried everything I could find on forums and videos to try and get this game working. When you hear the words "Forrest Array" get ready to truly test your GPU mine was unfortunately unable to withstand the magnitude of leaves, running water, and tiny blue dots. I will try this game again after I get a PC upgrade in a few years, but until then I do not recommend this game for the main reason of false advertising minimum requirements are bare minimum for a reason.

Firstly, game performance since that's what everyone seems to talk about. I have an RTX 3060 12GB and a AMD Ryzen 5. The game runs relatively smoothly; however, it's easy to find little glitches with enemies and there are definitely freeze frames. Nothing game breaking since it doesn't happen in boss fights or combat with large enemy groups but definitely something to keep in mind if you're not running a relatively solid PC. Put simply, the game is fine but optimization is definitely needed for PC Gamers. That aside, the story is great. I won't put any spoilers or anything but this game manages to build upon Star Wars Fallen Order without poking holes in the actual StarWars Saga. The only downside is knowing how some scenarios will end because of the characters involved. Anyhow, for any starwars game I'd consider this a must. On a scale of 1-10, it'd rank a solid 7.5 with the missing features really being replayability and of course the game performance for PC users. If you see this game on sale, def recommend picking it up like I did.

This game is a technical disaster. I am running this game in 4k, ultra settings, ray tracing on with an RTX 4090. I get 60 FPS without AI enhancements. DLSS frame generation creates ghosting in this game, so is basically unusable anyway. That performance would be fine if it were not for the fact that the game looks shit. Visual glitches, popping, stuttering in the first area. But the crashes in a specific section during the latter half of the game [spoiler]when you play as Cere on Jedha[/spoiler] caused by raytracing are surely the worst offender. An embarrassment of a PC port. If you don't have super high end specs, don't bother. If you are distracted by visual glitches, don't bother. If you don't really care for Star Wars, don't bother either, as the story is merely alright, nothing groundbreaking. It is sufficiently interesting nonetheless, so at least I got an acceptable Star Wars adventure out of this. I can only recommend this for those with high end PCs and on sale. And if you have any self-respect, don ot by the deluxe version.

tl;dr: Better at everything compared to its former title, except performance. 4/5

Pros:
- Great gameplay. They definitely upped the difficulty a bit, but once you progress you are also become OP compared to fallen order. It feels quite balanced in the end. Lots of variety to play. Definitely has a dark souls-vibe, but it's still star wars mostly.
- Lovely story. Great follow up to fallen order, and a good set up for the final title. The lines between good vs evil become blurred and enter the grey area. Cal is more experienced, but also still has a lot to learn. Great writing, acting & voice-acting from all actors. No character feels out of place. Plus a good set-up for the final title. 
- The exploration has been increased ten-fold. Much more to do, and none of it felt grindy. If you're looking to complete everything at 100%, there's quite a lot of backtracking, but if you follow along with the story, you'll unlock about 80% organically. 
- Music is great as ever. 

Cons:
- Obviously, the performance issues are still a thing. Although it's definitely more playable now, there's still regular framerate-drops, and you'll need a decent pc to play it. I got a mid-end pc, and performance was still struggling at big or open areas. Don't play with rtx yet, this game can't handle that. My game crashed 3 times during the entire playthrough without rtx, kind of annoying.
- Playing with mods disables achievements, but the game doesn't tell you that. I think it should.

Final verdict: Is this GOTY? No. But is it fun? Absolutely! If you can look past the performance issues, there's an absolutely great game underneath with a great story and tons of variety in gameplay. Worth 70 bucks? No, but worth it on sale. if you've played fallen order, it does everything better. I bought it on 50% discount, absolutely worth the 35 bucks!
If you liked fallen order, play this game! If you haven't played fallen order, play that game first, it's only 5 bucks atm and still a very strong title. Jedi: Survivor is a solid 4/5 for me, despite performance. I'll be replaying this title quite a lot of times probably :)
An example of how to make a great sequel! The only downside is the performance issues.

Very fun game with many improvements from Fallen Order. You start off already feeling fairly powerful, so there's no hard resets from the experience gained in the first game, and then you only get more powerful and competent as the game progresses. Skill is definitely rewarded in combat and everything feels earned. 

The story was interesting, though not as compelling as in Fallen Order. I feel this was mainly due to not having one clear antagonist throughout the game and splitting the screen time given between multiple which meant their motivations weren't fully fleshed out.

The customisation is great and with the new hub area at the Koboh saloon you really get immersed into the game and build a connection to all the different characters.

Performance is definitely not very good I was mostly at ~60fps with semi-frequent drops to ~30fps. The galaxy map was the worst however which would always drop me down to ~10fps. I've had multiple crashes to desktop, some while just exploring and playing the game, and others when tabbing out to my second monitor. I also experienced stutters once which was solved by changing the program priority in task manager.

All in all a great game just let down mainly by the poor performance.

I was hesitant to try the game because of all the negative reviews talking about lingering performance problems with the PC version of the game. I'll post my specs below, but after over 40 hours in the game I've only experienced one crash, and that was about 5 hours in. Outside of that I've had zero issues with performance or stability. 

I'll let better writers provide a review of the game and gameplay itself, there are plenty of wonderful reviews out there providing that detail, and I simply wouldn't do it justice. 

The only single gripe I have with the game is that it has to "compile resources" every time you start the game, and that can take upwards of 2-3 minutes. It's not a deal breaker by any means, but it is a little annoying. Outside of that, no major complaints. 

Specs:
i9-12900k
RTX 3090
32GB DDR5

DISCLAIMER: This game is extremely graphically AND memory intensive. No PC Port can be perfect even in the best of hands. If you want to run this game at high or max settings regardless of ray tracing, you need a GPU with at least 12 GB of VRAM and 16+ GB of RAM. The CPU also needs to be 6+ cores, maker does not matter. This puts your PC on par with the strongest current gen consoles.

I managed to get this game to run at a consistent frame rate (20 in intensive areas and up to 70 in less intensive ones) at ultra settings WITH ray tracing using a slightly kinked RTX 3060 and a Ryzen 3600, both are pieces of tech that are considered obsolete today. Now for the actual review.

REVIEW:

I will admit, I waited until the Winter 2023 sale to buy this game, since I do not support games by spending $70 for the "base game experience." However, the $35 I spent led to me discovering a complete sleeper hit from this year. 

I played Fallen Order finally last year and was genuinely surprised that it was a solid combat game with metroidvania style exploration, but the story fell flat in the end and the combat didn't feel... "Free." To put it in a basic sense.

Jedi: Survivor completely blows all of the shit Fallen Order did out of the water. If you are a metroidvania connoisseur, like Souls-like/Yakuza style combat, and/or love action RPGs, this game is quite possibly your GotY. Unless you're not a Star Wars fan, then you might only like the game in the end. 

On top of that, the story is straight up one of the best pieces of writing in 2023. Screw any kind of route you can take in Baldur's Gate 3, this story is consistent, never skips a beat, and always keeps you second guessing, which is something Star Wars fans have been waiting for YEARS after Rise of Skywalker. I actually got very emotional in the last third of the game. 

I highly recommend getting this game IF your PC can run it, or on a current console platform, and preferably when it's on sale.

I was very close to not buying this game because of all the negative reviews saying that the game runs horribly and is a buggy mess... Then I thought back to Cyberpunk and how everyone was saying the exact same thing there. Like with Cyberpunk this game runs very good for me, I hold a consistent 50-90fps with zero stutters and only one crash so far (In 5 hours of playing thats not too bad) and some mild frustration because the settings menu was bugged for whatever reason when I first booted the game up, a restart of the game fixed that. Other then that zero issues. Keep in mind I am running a 3070 currently so I am not exactly mr big bucks or anything and I am running the game on max-high settings ray tracing 2560x1440. 

The game does seem to be very CPU and RAM dependent for some reason though, it eats a good 8gb+ of ram at peek and absolutely devours CPU cores, I run a I9 7900x and I hit peeks of 70% usage, I never see any other game hit peeks that high, only time I have seen higher is when I am rendering something. So if I had to guess the game is just CPU hungry and most people skimp out on their CPU because 99% of games are GPU limited. Soooo maybe just dont run a old intel CPU and the game will be fine. The min specs are definitly very generous I dont think this game would be playable on those, but yeah if you struggle to run this game just consider a CPU upgrade and you will probably be fine, and/or stop trying to play modern AAA releases on a toaster and expecting it to work.

Also the gameplay: Uh yeah its good, its just the first game but better in every way. Darksouls + Zelda in Star Wars. 8.5/10

Really excited to play this game. I was given the impression it was in a stable condition. Played 20 mins of the game and it crashed. I do recommend it but I wish the story was more about the first theme the game starts with but it veers off into this rather less boring type stuff imo. I wish they would have went with the first theme all the way.

Star Wars: Attack of the Frame Rate

There's really nothing I can add to the review pile that hasn't already been said. I went for it because it was 40% off and Fallen Order was my gateway drug for souls games. The game itself is greatly improved from it's predecessor, more mechanics and play styles to mess around with. The new platforming mechanics are pretty sweet, but the gameplay loop is way too dependent on it, I feel like I have to platform for 10 minutes for every 5 minutes of combat.  

The combat is really only difficult because the frame rate will just drop to 10 FPS mid boss fight, or because you're surrounded by 30 enemies at a time, but overall is fun and satisfying to play. 

Games like this always just make we want to go back and replay Sekiro though, and when I do I just have more appreciation for how freaking good the combat system was in that game. 

If you're as emotionally attached to star wars as I am, go for it, if you're not and just in need of a good souls-lite skip it.

DO NOT BUY IT. IT IS NOT PATCHED.

I am running this on an ASUS ROG Zephyrus with an AMD Ryzen 9 5900 processor and an NVIDIA GeForce 3070 RTX and it continuously crashes and gives me the same error message now that I am seven hours in and can't refund it. I was really enjoying it up until then and felt it was an improvement on Fallen Order in every conceivable way, until I reached a certain part of Koboh and it crashes every five minutes. It gives me a message that says they are sorry the crash happened and I can send EA some data. I assume they use these crash reports for toilet paper.

You can see people on forums all over the internet having the same error (DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_HUNG if you're curious) going all the way back to May. I have tried disabling ray tracting and using all kinds of adjusted graphics settings that some poor bastards on random forums think might work. It does not work. When I try to email the donkeys at EA for help, the button to send the email is grayed out. They do not have anything in the help center for "My game shipped broken and you still have not fixed it." 

DO NOT BE TRICKED! You might be buying a game that stops working once you have played through the refund period.

Tried playing for 14 hours, I probably spent ten of them waiting for either the game to boot up, or waiting for it to crash. You need some kind of star wars tech to run this thing. I still ask myself, 70 BUCKS FOR THIS???

the obsession with tanalorr kinda cringe.

In all seriousness the story does get super crazy and gets a little "yeah whatever"
definitely gets "gamey" with certain moves in boss fights that are more "funny stupid" than "wow thats cool." 

Classic trait from the first game of a boss spamming unblockables on the last phase 
overall villains fell a bit flat and the block meter is just too short for the sheer amount of enemies you fight (especially the last level)
unnecessary amount of mechanics that you'll use for 20 minutes and not touch again until the end of the game

BUGS:
Buttons randomly deciding not to work was extremely annoying and immersion breaking.
Also don't go into steam overlay while interacting with a force echo, that was a guaranteed crash for me.

I played my entire play-through on Master yet that last level with no rest points was absolutely criminal and would not be possible for anyone above Jedi Padawan.

Definitely an improvement over the first game but has some serious bloat mechanics, just plain stupid boss attacks, a block meter which does not reflect the amount of enemies they throw at you (yes i maxed the block stamina) , and a last level that has NO rest points so its impossible on any difficulty above Padawan. 

Overall enjoyed, but has some annoying quirks just like the first game but in different ways.

At its current state I cannot recommend this game. I have a decent rig and the frame drops were bad, at times killing me because of it. As a Star Wars fan it really breaks my heart that this was released in its current state, and I hope they fix it to be stable.

"Star Wars Jedi Survivor" is a triumph for the franchise. Whether you're a die-hard Star Wars fan or a casual gamer, this installment is a must-play. 

The gameplay mechanics are both intuitive and challenging, a perfect balance that caters to both seasoned gamers and those new to the franchise. Lightsaber combat, in particular, is a highlight, with fluid and dynamic animations that make every duel feel like a cinematic masterpiece. It's amazing! The addition of new Force abilities adds an extra layer of strategy to encounters, allowing players to approach situations in a variety of ways.

May the Force be with you as you embark on this unforgettable journey through a galaxy far, far away.

I got the deluxe edition of the game, but I never received the deluxe rewards. I tried to contact someone within EA, but I couldn't. Steam support did its best, but it didn't count for much as it is items from an EA game. I didn't get far enough into the game to say if it was good. This is because I wanted to return it before the two weeks. I can say that this has been a known issue since the game's launch (I got it some months after release), and as far as I am aware, it has not been fixed. So, if you are interested in the deluxe edition of this game, you should check to see if this has been resolved. That or buy the base edition.

I've heard a lot of bad things about the game. Against my principles. (I don't buy EA games) Nevertheless, I surprised myself with it for Christmas. I was interested in the story. Unfortunately, the first boss has the first serious bug. I got it in about 1 hour. I would have continued the game the next day. The save before it is there, only the boss is not there. The game also indicates that there is a bug and prompts you to load an earlier save, which causes you to lose some progress, but then it's fine again. This loading option is also buggy. (Nothing happens when I activate it) So I would have to start the game completely from the beginning with all the walking parts etc. In the evening, of course, I only have myself to blame, because I gave money for an EA product.
EA you are a fucking pathetic cancer company.

The game runs pretty well now.  It has some slight stutter loading new areas of the map.

The main issue now is the complete crashes.   It happens a couple times a day.  Sometimes when you get a new ability like the grappling hook or Energy dart.   Sometimes flying between system.  Sometimes just beating a boss.

The Story is well written and has some expected and some unexpected turns.

Combat is fun and you can always switch lightsaber stances and skill abilities which can change your playstyle rather strongly and keep you engaged. Still you might need to change your password post it on your monitor to one with the combinations of force and/or lightsaber abilities (which were far too many for my brain to memorize).

The World looks quite good, though I expected more from the Unreal Engine 5. 
Respawn tried to embed their linear level-system in an open world setting which kind of worked, but navigation on the map and expecially the fast travelling system is exhausting. 

There are some problems that are arise from Jedi Survivor being a (bad) PC port:
The overall performance is really bad, with a
AMD Ryzen 7 5800x3D
AMD Radeon RX 7900 XT
64GB RAM
I was only able to get "consistently" over 60fps with
FSR2 on (quality)
Raytraycing OFF
Graphics MEDIUM
and thats rather sad in my opinion....

Still the game was a joy to play (but maybe not for 70‚Ç¨)
Finished the story and all planets > 85% within 27h.
This game is one of the only games that has made me cry, very good story.

Concering performance issues: I didnt really notice anything. Got a solid 60-80fps on Ultra settings and DLSS set to Quality on 4k resolution with a 3080Ti. Expected performance. 

The only bugs I noticed was enemies stuck in mid-air after execution. 

I'm not a great controller player but I definitely recommend playing this with a controller. 
Gameplay is awesome, world building is amazing, voices, characters, story very interesting. Not a lot to be said, all in all definitely builds and improves upon the first game. However imo NOT worth 80 bucks. These pricings are absolutely insane. I got it for 40 bucks on a sale and can't complain for that price. Finished the main story and some major side quests, got around 6 hours more content than in the first game. 

For any Star Wars enthusiasts a must play. One of the only issues I have with the game is that lightsabers are still just pool noodles. Pretty sure that issue could be solved better.
Also I dont get why Boss Fights respawn you at the last meditation point as well. It's a bit immersion breaking sometimes. 

Also don't buy the Deluxe Edition. 2 Skins per "item" is definitely not worth 20 bucks.

Can't get the screen onto my TV, so... not gonna bother.  Turns out TONS of people had this problem.  (Wish I would have known before I wasted my time.

#GetYourSheetStraightIfYoureGoingToPutOutAGame
Not as buggy as i thought it was going to be but if you like Star Wars, then you'll love this game like i did.

I've been through the ups and downs of PC gaming and yet this is the first PC game I literally cannot beat because it keeps crashing. The game itself has one of my favorite Star Wars narratives and the gameplay is incredibly fun, but this has to be the most unstable AAA PC port I've ever played, and that's saying something (beat Arkham Knight and Cyberpunk on PC at launch for context). Will eventually play this game to see the story through, but only on console. This PC port seems beyond repair.

So much controversy surrounds this game. The one thing I can recommend to anyone who is willing to give it a shot is to install it on an SSD or NVME. It does need a beefy computer to play, and even then I encountered frame drops here and there. Now, I will say that if this game wasn't surrounded by controversy with its botched release and many months of patching, it very well could've been a GOTY contender. The combat takes getting used to, but is incredible when mastered. The story is an excellent continuation from Fallen Order. The world is massive and rich with different content to enjoy. I finished it in just under 60 hours having completed most of the smaller planets at 100% and the largest planet at 98%. It's a massive game and deserves the praise and critique from all who've played. Can't recommend enough to any star wars fan, I hope to see more from Cal and Merrin in the future.

Really good follow up to Fallen Order. Good story with a lot of unexpected turns to keep you interested. Combat was good and allowed for a lot of options. Towards the end, i started feeling like there were too many force commands to keep track of and mostly focused on Lightsaber with a side of mind control focus. Graphics were great, but performance could definitely be better. Performance is especially bad on the main hub planet Koboh. Dungeons and medium sided areas performed well.

Overall 8/10

Dinged mainly for performance and for abandoning the game before ironing out all the issues.
Ripped off the entire combat system from Dark Souls and it sucks. EA should give this franchise to someone who can make these games fun to play.

I should not have let talk of performance issues hold me back from purchasing this - it is phenomenal. A step up from Fallen Order in every conceivable way - significantly more diverse enemies, superior world design akin almost to that of Elden Ring (more comparable to Dark Souls 1, except with larger levels), and a climactic and emotional story that hits the perfect sweet spot in length and satisfyingly expands on Cal's journey. There are stutters and there are bugs, but the game ran surprisingly well for me on ageing hardware and on gorgeous settings so it was, thankfully, more than playable. To reiterate, Jedi Survivor is an excellent game and you should absolutely play it!

After completing the main story for the first time, I have a few takeaways from this game.

1. The performance issues are mostly resolved.
Throughout my playthrough, I only encountered three bugs that caused me to lose progress (two of them were in the same spot). They collectively only set me back about five minutes of playtime, which is still too much for an $80 game, but it's a significant improvement from what some players have reported. I have a 12th gen Intel i7 with 16 GB RAM and a 3060Ti, and the game ran beautifully. The main disappointment was that I couldn't use ray tracing because it resulted in a loss of around 20-40 fps (averaging around 75 fps normally). Nevertheless, the game still looked impressive.

2. It is a substantial improvement over the previous game, Jedi Fallen Order.
There are more customization options for Cal, adding a unique touch to your experience. The combat system  options are more in-depth, providing a richer gameplay experience. The story isn't merely a repetition of the last game but set in the future; it holds plenty of surprises and challenging bosses (depending on your difficulty settings), making it feel like a fresh experience.

3. It is definitely a game you should consider buying if you've been waiting for the issues to be resolved. I purchased the game during the 50% off sale, but I would have been willing to pay more than $40 for it. If you're interested and it's on sale, it's definitely worth considering the purchase.

The performance is terrible. I can play everything on High or Ultra with 60 fps with no problems, but this game. I have a 3060 ti. With low graphics I can get 60 fps in closed zones, but the main hub of the game has run as low as 22 fps. It's really, really horribly done, I have no idea what went wrong but it's really awful.

That said, the game is amazing. Everything a sequel should be. Builds on everything done by Fallen Order and takes it to another level, both gameplay and narratively wise. To me no other SW games can compare to this one (no, not even KOTOR), and it's on pair with the best films. It's not perfect, parts of the story fall definitely flat. But the good is truly good.

Please, EA. I BEG of you. Let the third one be awesome.
It is fun when it works. Cannot even get off the second planet due to frame rate issues, completely killed my enthusiasm for it.

I'm really not impressed by this Star Wars title. It is not up to the quality of days gone by Star Wars Jedi Knight 2 Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy. We are in an era where triple A games have degraded alot. 
First of all I get a crash every 25-30 mins - since the game uses checkpoint save games I lose progress and gets me annoyed for repeating the sector..
Second - performance is sluggish , i get 20-30 fps drops out of nowhere with a 4090 and i9 CPU 32GB RAM..
And to continue the complaining - every time the game starts it needs to optimise.. takes 40 seconds for me.. 
Graphics is ok-ish but there are a lot of graphical small errors and bugs. 
Kestis moves like a skater-it slides on the terrain, running and sprinting is not really synchronised. Then he clips trough walls and objects. Ragdoll physics is kinda off. 
Lightsaber does not leave marks on every surface like in the old Jedi Knight 2 games but the combat is enjoyable with nice combos and finishing moves. 
I'm really trying this game for the sake of the story cause I'm curious what's going on. 
In conclusion : it's really unpolished so buy this game when its half price. Full price it's an insult to the consumer these days.

This is the first time I've left a negative review of a game. First the positives - I'm only 17 hours in and the story is great. Now we've got the good bits out of the way let's discuss the issues:

Lag and freezing: This game is so poorly optimised for PC's that AFTER running optimisation at loadup, and with graphics settings on medium it will still lag both in game play and with cut scenes. I will mention that I'm running a GTX 4070, intel core 17 2.9ghz, and 16GB ram. This is enough to run Cyberpunk 2077 on max graphics with ray tracing and it runs perfectly fine.

Then there is the issues with mapping the controller. Jedi Fallen Order everything worked fine. In Survivor you can't map the same button despite them being in a different function area if you want them different from default. For example you can't set under Basic ascension cable to RB, then under Force set slow to RB. It will say that one or the other is unbound. So I have to use my keyboard for less common actions/controls.

TL;DR Is the game playable with all the lag issues? Yes, but it can be frustrating and takes away from the experience of what is otherwise a great game. Don't buy full price, heck in hindsight I wouldn't even buy half price. Maybe 75%+ off until they fix the issues... if they ever do. After having played through Fallen Order and thoroughly enjoying it, Survivor is a let down due to poor performance.

I would love to give this game a 10/10. If I could actually play it without it crashing.

I haven't been able to complete the first level yet, though I have made it to more than one save point thankfully. My first time playing the game, I did not make it to a save point before the game crashed, randomly. It was playing well and smoothly, but just crashed and I have no idea why. Several other tries at playing have slowly progressed me a little bit farther on this first level of the game, but always there is a crash. My PC has well over the recommended specs enough to play this game on max settings easily.

I was really looking forward to playing the game. I even waited to buy it much later after it's original launch due to all the bugs I was reading that it was having. I thought for sure they would have hammered all those bugs out by now but it looks like they have not. A damn shame. Game looks great, but can't play it for very long due to the crashes.

----
Edit/Addition
---

The issues seemed to be with RTX entirely. Once I turned off RTX I no longer experienced any crashes. Shame because the game should work with RTX on with my 4070TI, but it doesn't. That aside, the game is beautiful even without RTX. I have greatly been enjoying my time playing it. The customization options have been greatly expanded upon from Fallen Order and it's awesome not being limited to just different color ponchos. It's a bit early but so far I can definitely give my current experience a 10/10 so far!

This is only about settings and performance - mainly good.
It took a little playing around with the settings, turning vsync and gsync off everywhere, and updated the dlss and dlssg dlls (BOTH) to 3.5.10 off TechPowerup and I'm getting 89/62fps stable Epic/RayTracing/DLSS 3 Quality 4k>1080p/DLSS 3 Frame Generation vs 58/46fps and jerky with constant jitter when not using DLSS at all except ray on a patch before any dlss support was added.   But I've only actually played it the last few days with dlss3.5 and so far it seems great at the highest settings I can play, 4070 laptop on an external 1080p TV, the only performance issue is the recompiling of the shaders at every start, but that is only 2 minutes and the game has never frozen on me.   I also have a 2070 laptop and I will try it on that, but just from what frame generation alone does for a 4070 (25+%) I'm sure I will have to turn ray tracing off and  probably turn a couple settings off of epic to get smooth 1080p60fps, will update.

This is one of those games where you wish there was more than a yes-or-no review. The game-play is fine; if you liked the first version, you will love this one. But the problem is that it is still very poorly optimized. So far, I have had a few crashes that make you lose progress and time. If you are new to the series, expect nothing spectacular when it comes to game mechanics. It is basically a Star Wars/Dark Souls-like game; there was not much imagination in that. That doesn't mean it's bad; there is simply nothing new when it comes to game mechanics.

If you are willing to deal with the poor optimization and the occasional crash, then by all means get it. At its core, it is still an entertaining game to play.

If you liked Fallen Order, you will like Survivor.  So far I have really enjoyed the game.  One thing to note, I have been playing with a Xbox controller, not the keyboard and mouse.  If you like Star Wars, you will like this game.

I'll admit it, things didn't start smoothly, but a quick graphics driver update and scaling down a few graphic options from HIGH to MEDIUM has made the game run over 50FPS consistently for me, and I'm running a 6 year old rig. The patches have done a lot to make the experience better for PC users and behind this small technical hurdle is an absolute dynamite experience.

If you even halfway enjoyed the first game, I highly recommend this one.

Specs: RTX 3070 | Ryzen 7 5800X | 32Gb DDR4 | 1440p Ultra (DLSS balanced)

Performance: The game is running smooth. I'm glad I waited to buy this, seems like most the kinks have been worked out. I experience a few crashes though (1 for low GPU memory, and 2 randomly on Jedha), which is annoying.

It needs a few more minutes in the oven, but it is nearly there. 

It is still a few graphics stability updates away from being a masterpiece, but once they fix the stuttering you will see the recent reviews flip over to overwhelmingly positive. 8/10 now, 11/10 once it is patched properly. 

Bugs aside the game is really very good. Much more customisation than the previous game, large beautiful maps, and a very good story. It is still a little shaky performance wise, and in my opinion it is version 1.0 quality in current state; if it truly was worse than this at launch, then it is not excusable for EA to release the game when they did. 

In the parts of the game that ran smoothly it was a very good gaming experience; in the not so smooth parts it was super frustrating because it ruins the immersion of a very immersive game. 

If you have a 40 series GPU and enable DLSS frame generation you can play above 100 fps with minor stuttering in the most open areas. I found turning the graphics down from Epic actually lowered the frame rate, so I played everything maxed out. I experienced 3 or 4 random crashes in 40 hours of play, but minor and never game breaking, just annoying as the game takes a few mins to load into. 

Definitely grab it on sale, it will be worth full price once they finish fixing the graphical issues.

An ultimately great game, marred by the hottest trend in gaming: releasing an unfinished game. Don't get me wrong, the story is great, combat is good, but it's hard to see them through the absolutely abysmal performance at times. Add in the fact that it uses the EA App and doesn't support Steam cloud saves (only cloud saves via the EA App which is far buggier and inconsistent) and the game leaves a slightly negative taste in the mouth.

If the game's frame rate only dipped when a lot was going happening on-screen, it would be understandable, but instead the frame rate constantly dips anytime you're out in the open. Thankfully combat is rarely effected somehow. In addition, this game tries to get away with "hidden" loading areas, which are painfully obvious as you are often left standing around for far too long as your frame rate absolutely tanks for a prolonged period of time. If this game looked amazing, I would give it a bit more leeway, but it ultimately doesn't look that much better then Fallen Order and I've played several games that look better while also performing better.

A smaller nit-pick I have is with the difficulties. The default setting (Jedi Knight) is overly easy, at least for Souls-like veterans, and the hardest (Jedi Grand Master) is too punishing. I played through about 3/4 of the game on Grand Master, only to go down to Jedi Master due to the fact you had to nearly play perfectly. Enemies take too little damage, your parries have a VERY narrow window, nearly every boss could two-hit you (even with upgraded health), and boss combos WILL kill you as you often can't escape once caught in one. I highly recommend Jedi Master difficultly as it gives a decent challenge (though still a bit too easy in my opinion) without being overly punishing.

Hoped the performance was somewhat fixed or at least to a point were it was less noticeable and tolerable. But it really is a mess. The game never really feels smooth to play. Cut-scenes often goes below 30 fps resulting in a very jarring presentation. Combat and platforming sections also has random stuttering and the fps is all over the place. 

DLSS FrameGen has been added to compensate, but unfortunately this is also poorly implemented with a lot of UI artifacts.

It is unfortunate that the performance of this PC port is so bad, because it feels like the actual game is quite great.

Another AAA publisher dropping a deuce of an unfinished game all over their customers. Wait 3 months, watch some YouTube videos, and see if it's ACTUALLY been released.

**EDIT**

Well... Here we are, so many months later. The game is now safely considered playable. However, I upgraded my rig from release until now. My rig benchmarks on 3DMark in the 93%-98% range on the toughest tests compared to all other users, so it runs pretty much flawlessly on that. However, on my laptop which is weaker, there are still some pretty noticeable frame drops. Turning off raytracing helps, although I should not have to on a 4070.

As to why I changed my review? Well, the game itself, if you can look past stability, is absolutely worth playing. The leap from Fallen Order to Survivor in features, mechanics, story, exploration, really just everything across the board is something I've never experienced in a sequel. It is honestly a fantastic, fun, addictive game with a moving story and epic experiences. If you CAN push past performance issues, do it. It is worth it. A shame so many have not experienced it. I could honestly see it being game of the year had it not had the performance issues it did at launch and for quite awhile after it. It's that good.
Awesome!

I don't know how the game runs on other systems, but with a 13900K and a 4090 the game runs amazing.  The DLSS and frame gen update were game changers.  With DLSS on, the game doesn't look like a blurry mess from a terrible TAA implementation, and frame gen pretty much double your frame rate.  The frame gen does leave something to be desired, there is sometimes tearing and pop in when you're moving the camera rapidly in certain environments, but for the most part I was able to ignore it for the huge bump in smoothness.  I am playing at 4K 120 FPS with DLSS quality, max settings including ray tracing, and frame gen on.  I did encounter a bit of stutter early on, but I don't know how it went away, whether it was a game update or if I just got past the area with the stutter, but my game isn't stuttering anymore at all.
The game play is great, the open world aspect tacks on a lot more play time.  I kinda wish it was a longer game, I probably spent half my time doing open world exploring and collecting. The unfortunate part is almost all of the collecting is related to cosmetics, so it's kinda pointless if you don't care about that.  The various stances you can choose from are fun to play around with.
I mainly wanted to focus on the performance aspect since so many people are still posting reviews complaining about performance, it ran perfect for me for 95% of it.

Well, after nearly 60 hours, i finished the new version of Starwars, ignoring, the fact that it had to crash three times on startup before i got to game play each time i loaded it, the random crashing with glitches that vanish the next time the game reloads.

Idk, for all the complaints about performance it runs fine for me. My issue is while everything looks better and is flashier, the terrible context combat was not improved at all. The number of times you'll hit block, or attack or HEAL and just nothing happens, simply no response. The "window" of timing for attacks is trash, the window is whatever screws you over, that's basically the rule. So many enemies require you to make a no hit engagement its just silly, and some enemies literally kill you in one hit. Ultimately this is just the previous game on steroids and I mean that for both the good and bad aspects of the game. What was good is better and what was bad is worse. Regrettably this game also suffers from the modern plague of huge play area with light content. In an effort to make you put more hours into the game they made the open world aspects annoyingly open world. They added some decent navigational tools to help cut down the dreg of it, but you will still find yourself walking for long periods. 

The frustrating thing is, a decent star wars story exists in here. But it is mired by unresponsive controls and p**s poor QTE combat events. It has some really good moments in it and Cal's executions are spectacular this time. But, the number of times I've pressed block and instead of parrying or blocking as I should instead Cal just stands there and takes the hit to then 'snap' into the block animation after damage is purely infuriating. This game is far more in line with dark souls than an action adventure. The 1st game was clearly dark souls inspired but this one wanted to go further, its a exercise in frustration which just isn't what I'm looking for when I play games.

Game is an improvement in just about every way from Fallen Order. Combat, however, if you've played Elden Ring or any of FromSofts game's, can be quite annoying and difficult out of nowhere. I don't mind difficulty but it seems as they deem difficulty as overwhelming you with a large group. I would say if you're interested in this game that you do not purchase it for retail value and look into downloading MSI Afterburner + RTSS Tuner to cap your in-game FPS via this software. I found capping my frames at 80fps via RTSS gave me MUCH better overall consistent performance. Capping via RTSS increases your frame timing for a smoother experience which you will want. Unfortunately, I have to fairly review this game as a downvote due to shotty performance, still. Buy on sale.

It looks like EA has abandoned the PC port of this at this point.  Unfortunately, Jedi Survivor is still an absolute performance mess.  It doesn't matter how powerful of a CPU/GPU you have, the game has completely nonsensical stuttering that occurs consistently throughout the game, even on an i9-12900KF with an RTX 4090, running off an SSD that benches ~4800 MB/s read and 4200MB/s write.

The game is definitely playable and if you don't mind constant stuttering when you enter or exit locations (or just when you turn around in certain open world areas) you will probably have a good time -- but you will have to be able to get over the fact that no matter what you do, you're never going to get a stable 60fps out of it -- it's just a shoddy port and EA has completely abandoned it.

I was hesitant to get this when I saw the reviews, but I wanted to continue the story from the previous game and I'm pleased to say it felt like an improvement on all fronts from Fallen Order. Traversal is fun, combat is engaging, and I only dealt with one crash that lost me maybe 10 minutes of gameplay (though I recognize I might just be lucky in this respect.)

The game itself is gorgeous, with environments that make you want to revisit them. This is good, because you'll be backtracking a lot! For the bulk of the game you'll find yourself going between two planets, and after a certain point you'll add two smaller levels (1 planet and 1 station). There are a couple other locations but I am not counting them because they're mostly there for story flair and don't contribute much in the way of exploration.

I'm not usually a completionist; I'll grab what pickups I can while going through the story, but Jedi survivor had me seeking out a number of collectible items or hidden locations. I put almost exactly 3 times as many hours into Survivor over Fallen Order. I feel like if you enjoyed the first game, I highly recomment looking into this title (maybe grab it on sale though)
Amazing game
love

Great RPG. If you explore towards the end game, you can also find terminals that will show you where all other collectibles, chests, etc., are, so don:t worry about completionism too much. Gotta be one until you find them (or look on youtube), but it is beating the crazy enemies out there that makes this fun. Vader, in cameo, is the easiest noob boss.

Was not able to get this to run in acceptable, stable frame rates. Even though i reached overall 60+ fps, the very frequent drops, micro stutters and dia shows make this unplayable for me. I also had weird lighting bugs. Refunded.
