When you consider how big EA is (yes, I am aware how shit of a company they are to work for) the amount of bugs this long after release is unacceptable. If you REALLY want to play this; I waited until it was 50% off, and I still don't think it's worth it for the price considering the headaches.
Gameplay is decent, some of the puzzles are testy with your timing or reflexes if everything isn't just absolutely perfectly placed/timed. The open worlds are nice, though two are a bit of a pain in the arse to traverse across.
Graphics are average, with a lot of visual bugs (half the Jawa I encounter, the robes are backwards, so the arms clip through and just float), with some lighting bugs sprinkled in for distraction.
The story is.. Well, it's better than anything that came out after Rogue One, but very predictable. Like, 'classic cliche' predictable.
Classic Star Wars sound design, on par with Fallen Order; so nothing bad, but nothing new.

Cosmetics (lightsaber customization, outfits, BD-1 cosmetics) are nice and varied enough I don't feel the need to get mods off the Nexus.

TL;DR - Wait for a 50% or more off sale; expect bugs unacceptable for devs/producers this size.

A legitimately good game with unfathomably bad optimization issues. 

Don't let people lie to you, this game does NOT run well even on high end systems. I had to modify way too much just to get it to function.

But overall, a good game that got crippled by performance issues. Unfortunate, really.

The game itself is great -- the exploration and focus on a centralized hub planet in addition to some really cool locales, the story that hints at New Republic stuff that is coming into focus elsewhere in the canon, it's everything that was great about Fallen Order but ratcheted up to ten.

Go play it on a console though -- this game crashes on PC CONSTANTLY. Rarely can I play for more than an hour without crashes. At first I thought it was my hardware, but it crashes on my new PC and my ROG Ally as well. Look at the forums and subreddits, I'm not alone here.

The game has been seemingly abandoned and I doubt that the notorious memory leak will ever be fixed. Instead, it's borderline unplayable.

The performance can be a little rocky in the big areas, but to me was never unplayable (3080, Ryzen 5 @2k averaging 50fps-90fps). Overall a great addition to Star Wars, really getting just the right tone that the older movies have.

This game was phenomenal! Highly recommend, but with some caveats.

-Story was super strong - each character felt developed and nuanced, and the narrative propelled character growth. There were some legitimately shocking plot twists, and the gameplay felt integrated into the narrative pacing without disrupting the flow. Made me very excited for the sequel that (I assume) they're working on, as they set up each character for some very interesting development.
-The music is phenomenal. Seriously, Stephen Barton and Gordy Haab deserve as many awards as possible for their work on the music. They understand the spirit of Star Wars (and John Williams), and are able to musically distill it without plagiarizing or using the classic themes as a crutch. 10/10
-Loved the added gameplay mechanics. Having additional lightsaber stances kept combat fresh and interesting throughout the game. The perk slots were fun too, my only gripe is that it's incredibly difficult to get more than a couple slots until you finish the main narrative. I was glad that they didn't reset your skills to zero at the beginning of the game, but incorporated new skills (i.e. grapple, Crystal maker, etc.) during the story.

Now for the caveats:
-This game's graphics had major trouble running on PC for me. Thankfully the issues were limited to certain areas in the game (the overworld on Koboh and the Observatory with Koboh matter), but the amount of time spent in these areas at the beginning of the game almost turned me off. The thing I struggle with (from a developer's standpoint) is that most of these issues were due to running too many assets simultaneously - in porting it over to PC, it would have been nice to have simplified graphics in just those 2 areas to make the gameplay smoother.
That being said, my roommate played through the game on Xbox, and had no issues with graphics or lag. If you have a console with this available on it, play it there rather than on PC. I also never had the game crash while playing, despite the lagging and glitches, so props to the dev team for ironing those out by the time I played.
-Very small issue, but finding the Force Tears was a pain. I wish there had been a map upgrade to show those locations on the mini-map.
-Also found the bounty hunter missions tedious because they all took place in postgame. Would have loved to have them integrated into the story a little better.

Overall, I'm giving this an 8/10, but if the graphics/lag aren't an issue then a 9.5/10. Highly recommend if you have the right equipment to play it.

Naturally, if you have beaten Fallen Order, you will want to play this. I hesitated to buy this due to the reported performance issues on PC. However, it runs fine on my system, though I did tweak some of the settings down from the default to help ensure optimal performance (default was mostly high and epic for each row, which I tweaked down to mostly high, with a few mediums - ray tracing is off, of course). Oddly, the holotable (for selecting destinations) is jerky for some reason, but I haven't had any real issues with actual gameplay.  My specs: i7-10700k, 64GB RAM, RTX3080. 

Note that you'll have to sit through a PC file optimization process after the splash screens every time you boot the game up, though it goes by a lot quicker from the 2nd time you run the game onward.

The game is stellar, but the optimization at current time is inexcusably ludicrous. That being said, no launch is ever perfect. I will gladly change my review once this is cleared up, because with this issue out of the way? So far the game is an easy 10/10.

Edit: The small optimization patch(es) that's been released have greatly increased performance for me. At this rate, I feel choppy and unresponsive gameplay will from now on, be mostly on my end as I am playing with a 1070. 

Regardless. From a gameplay perspective, this game is a massive improvement over the first which was still a stellar game. After my 4 or so playthroughs of the first game, I modded my game with what essentially became vanilla mechanics or luxuries in this sequel. The customization of all things is impressive, and even trumps other games that supposedly allow you to make your own character, despite the fact you're playing an established protagonist in this one.

I have not finished the story yet, but I am engaged and interested thus far. Shortcomings of the overarching narrative in my opinion is negated by the character stories and relationships. Just seeing what Cal has been doing and his journey with those he met in the first game is more than enough for me, personally.

When combat actually works for me (and isnt hindered by frame lag or slow input), it's fun. My favorite combination is the single blade and blaster stances. The latter is especially a blast (ha) in many circumstances.

Honestly, I say buy it. The performance is still terrible, but worth fighting through just to experience this gem.

Edit edit: Performance seems to be worse, somehow. Quite literally unplayable on Koboh which is a significant portion of the game.  Developers had the audacity to ask us to nominate this game for awards. A bit tone deaf, don't you think, Respawn?

Yes this game is stellar. The combat is fun (save for a few encounters/enemy types like the DT droid), the customization is excellent, and the story was very well done, not to mention the journey of the characters was well explored.

But what does any of this matter if it can't be played? Respawn needs to figure out what's going on.

I'm not opposed to there being areas that I can revisit later on for optional content, but this game has a LOT of it.

For example, there was a jump that you cant quite make when you first encounter it, you're close but its just a little off. I looked for a box to move, somewhere slightly higher to jump from, using abilities mid-air to get a tiny amount of extra airtime etc. but nothing worked.

Showstopper-level bugs that haven't been fixed in over 6 months. Can't progress through the main story. I'm not sure what is going on at Respawn but they need to get their act together.

Update: I decided to give the game another shot and I restarted (since it was my only option thanks to a bug with the Forest Array / Rehab Wing.) Here's my thoughts after completing the game.

From the very start of the game you'll likely get annoyed with the repeating requirement to run setup on the game and agree to a EULA every single time you start the game or go to the main menu. For PC, this seems to be due to certain files for game settings being marked as read-only. Why this hasn't been fixed after all this time is beyond comprehension.

I did encounter a stuttering performance issue using the holo map, intermittent at least. Evidently, this has been a known issue for a very long time.

The main issue I see with this game is that the save game system is too basic, mainly a UI limitation from what I can tell, e.g. you'll have to start the game over again from the beginning if your save is bugged because you can only have 1 save file per "journey." To me, that's infuriating.

Overall, the game was enjoyable so long as you don't run into bugs that block progression. I'm leaving this as not recommended because blocker-level bugs still exist in this game 6 to 8 months later. If they fix those bugs then I'll change my recommendation.

Anyways thats all the "bad things" i can think of other than that its an amazing game!

Great storytelling, great atmosphere, gameplay, visuals, action packed fighting and climbing action. As always with those games, if you start exploring too early, you will often find your path blocked, because the game offers you the necessary skills later in the story.

Great game . awesome story, very fun

I can only recommend this game to people who have high end hardware. I have an i7 8700k and a 3080ti and play at 3440x1440. The largest areas of the main planet I go down as low as 50 fps. In the smaller areas I get 80 to 110 fps. I have all settings maxed, RT off, and DLSS set to quality

Other than performance, the game is really fun, really gives the feeling of living out my jedi dreams. The world is incredibly detailed, lightsaber customisation is great, NPC interactions are memorable and the combat is very fun (outside of a couple very annoying boss fights)

Essential mods:
https://www.nexusmods.com/starwarsjedisurvivor/mods/1
https://www.nexusmods.com/starwarsjedisurvivor/mods/74
Stopped crashing ever since.

Giving it a recommended review in hopes they can optimize this game, but I play on a 4070 and have to use medium/high settings for smooth gameplay. I like how they expanded off of the established stuff from fallen order and the versatility of the different saber stances is great and makes combat enjoyable. Sucks that the game is poorly optimized cause it can look really pretty on max settings. The story is pretty good and the planets are once again beautiful. Much more customization as well which is nice. Overall great game other than the shitty performance issues.

If you can get it running smoothly this game has a lot to recommend it. At first I kept having persistent issues with lag and stuttering which was so bad I tried to get a refund through Steam but since I'd played for more than 2hrs it was rejected. Some persistence and a clean install later I had it running well enough to play.

The standout draws for me are the environments and the lightsaber combat. The sense of scale in the level design is really impressive. Special shout out to the crashed separatist ship on Koboh. Exploration is pretty enjoyable although I couldn't help feel the first half of the game was mostly exploration interspersed with the occasional boring wildlife encounter - you don't really get sustained groups of proper enemies until later in the game.

Overall, great world design and combat, slightly sluggish initial pacing, but technical issues really let it down. Hopefully something that becomes less of an issue over time.
Its great but the performance is dogshit, wouldnt recommend it to anybody that doesnt have a 1080 ti or higher
No Performance issues that I saw a lot of people had. Great Sequel! Get it while its on Sale this week!

Glitchy, laggy, generally not worth the headache.

I have had consistent lag issues with this game, despite having a pretty solid gaming rig, latest driver updates, etc.  Especially bad when streaming.  The game is also full of glitches that will get you stick in walls or rock formations, and be unable to get back out, forcing you to restart from your last save point and fight tooth and nail to regain what progress you made, which is made all the worse by the fucking lag.  Shame on EA for releasing this game in its current state, and shame on me for still being enough of a StarWars fan to buy it.  I really should have known better, but am now out $45 (sale price) for this nonsense.  Save yourself the headache and disappointment and don't buy this.
Waiter! Waiter! More stormtroopers please!

Game is awesome, complete upgrade mechanic wise and more open world vs the first game. Really enjoy the continuation of the story. I myself am not having issues running 4k with DLSS3 on quality, all other settings are epic/high. Ray tracing off though, unfortunately. I have an RTX 3070Ti, i5-12600k and 32gb of DDR4 3200mhz. Game is installed on an SSD. I have had a couple stutters in a cutscene but nothing drastic. Game when first loaded did an optimization file change for my system. Seems to run solid, not sure why all the hate still.

I didn't notice the negative performance issues people talked about and i'm below the recommended requirements. I will say, that the first 25% i was underwhelmed and kept thinking how the fallen order was better. Not true, it's one of the best games i've ever played.

As many other reviewers mentioned, this game as a port is terrible. Constant crashes and performance jitters, and it's been available for more than 8 months. And yes, most of the crashes occur when entering Koboh as others have also mentioned.

If it wasn't for those issues, I would have no trouble recommending. The story is engaging, the mechanics from Fallen Order have been polished & improved, and the areas have better ambiance along with the variety of little sub-areas to explore. However, as it stands, you'd better get the game on a super sale because it is not worth its full price at all or get it on console if you have a current gen one.
b

One of the most beautiful games I've ever encountered, and I'm not even halfway through the game!

The whole style, look this game alongside Jedi Fallen Order showed is stunning! I adore the interactions between the characters, love the mounts! Lots of confusing puzzles that has left me dumbfounded, luckily have only looked up help once! The rest I had figured out my self! BD-1 is of course as adorable as ever, lots of customization with Cal.

Theres lot of complaints about the game running badly on their decent computers... My computer is quite old now, and I lag terribly on Sims 4... but never had a problem with Jedi Survivor! It runs smoothly on high graphics... One or two lag spikes I've had but thats just because I didn't let it load before running around. haha!

Otherwise, a beautiful game that I recommend any Star Wars or non Star Wars fans play!


Only note for the game is, the ponchos! Where are the ponchos! The only bad thing about the game! Gah!

As of December 31, 2023, performance issues are not fixed. 

1. The game forces your resolution to be about half of your native res when setting the rest to native. For example, if the game is showing that your resolution is 1440p, it scales it down to like 720p and look horrible. 
2. DLSS is basically useless. 
3. The only way I've found to make the game look good to is to disable Chromatic Aberration and enable FSR and set to quality. 
4. Multiple points in the game I was not able to pass without the game freezing and I had to set my priority on the game to High (10700K, 64GB RAM, 3080Ti). 
The story is great, the gameplay is great, level design is great. If you can get past the horrible visuals and play without freezes, its a 9/10 for me.

10/10 story
8/10 combat/movement
.5/10 optimization
I really hate to leave a ‚Äúnot recommended‚Äù review of this game, but I feel I have no choice. I started playing months after release and heard all about the bugs and patches. Not my first time encountering a game with these issues, but you‚Äôd think they‚Äôd fix it eventually, right? 
Not the case as of now. I played on Jedi Grandmaster difficulty level and I‚Äôd say the constant frame rate drops were like an added difficulty setting at times. Sounds funny when I say it, but it was actually annoying to play through. There was another point where, when I entered a certain area, my screen started flickering like strobe lights. Now, I know my graphics card isn‚Äôt the best out there, but this was just ridiculous and that part of the game was literally nauseous to play through. It‚Äôs a long game with a lot of content and all these technical issues made an experience that would‚Äôve been fun feel like a chore to play through. 
Which brings me to my next point‚Ä¶frame rates I can sort of forgive, but after spending two hours beating a tough boss and being sure to save my progress afterward, my save got corrupted‚Ä¶that‚Äôs two hours of my time wasted. At this point, I was pissed and if it wasn‚Äôt enough that I had to redo the whole fight, it happened AGAIN later in the game. Absolutely the most frustrating thing I‚Äôve experienced in a game and, as you can imagine, this issue by itself left a horrendous taste in my mouth and more than warrants a bad rating in my opinion. 
To mention the positives though‚Ä¶the storyline was fantastic, I loved it even more than I loved the previous game's story, which is high praise. I loved playing through the quests and exploring. However, the technical issues ruined the whole experience for me. Like, I‚Äôm so disappointed that a game with such potential has been subjected to this poor optimization. Leave it to EA to ruin something like this.
not bad
The game as a base is pretty good. Love the story. However, I had a lot of frame issues in the beginning but those can be fixed by turning of v sync.

I know this was a mess on launch I played this in December 2023 and will be reviewing it as is currently. TL;DR great game with a few minor issues.

Performance/Optimization, not great not terrible mostly perfectly playable for me. Granted I have a 3090 but I was running it at 4k max settings(balanced DLSS). It is a very good looking game and I'd say I averaged 70fps. This does drop to 40 in a couple of areas but not enough to ruin the experience with one exception, the rift battles, the hardest fights in the game would stutter terribly which caused me to die multiple times. Even reducing the graphics settings didn't cure this. Very annoying that the hardest parts of the game have awful stuttering. For me it was relatively stable. I did have a section of the game where it kept crashing however a bit of researched pointed me to look at my VRAM I noticed my C Drive only had 5gb of free space freeing up some more space cured this issue, the game uses a lot of VRAM. Other than those crashes which I feel more somewhat my fault, I think I had 5-10 crashes in my play time which considering the hours I have put into the game isn't terrible. These were a mix of CTD and just freezing requiring to kill it in task man. While not great I think this is perfectly playable as is 

Gameplay, more of the same from the previous game no complaints from me I loved the first this was an excellent sequel. I liked the different styles of fighting and the Souls like gameplay with adjustable difficulty, Jedi Knight was a decent difficulty for me still died a lot and was a decent challenge I'd say I averaged 5-10 attempts per boss. I like that they have different tiers of enemies and throw different combos of them at you. It keeps it fresh and can catch you out when a group catches you off guard.

Story/characters, (minor possible spoilers) near perfection, I can't speak highly enough of the characters and writing in this game. While I saw the twist coming instantly, the further into the game I got I started to doubt myself. I'm assuming that was the intention which was really interesting in how it toys with you. I like the characters in the saloon and learning about their lives. (Although it upsets me none of their butts touch the seats, you can't unsee that now). I loved the emotion of the story boss fights one of them towards the end of the game is AMAZING. Really looking forward to more from Cal and BD -1 who is now my favourite SW Droid (just beats HK47 & R2)

I liked the ending I feel it is the ESB style 'downer' ending and sets up a third game perfectly. I'm really looking forward to another game I'll likely do the sameas I did with this one and wait till it is 50% off because by that time it should be in a playable state.

I soft 100%ed it, got all collectables and did everything in game but only on normal and didn't get all achievements. This took about 90 hours I think. All in very pleased excellent sequel. I just wished it was released in this state.
Game repeatedly crashes before reaching main menu.

Look the performance is not great but not nearly as bad as most people say. I only have some stutters in the open world of Kobah. As soon as i entered a cave or anything else i was above 100 fps stable and on every other planet i had no issues at all.  i had 3 crashes in total in my close to 30 hours.
But still they failed at the performance department.

The story is 10/10 
the characters 10/10
Graphics 9/10
Game-play 8/10
difficulty - 10/10 There is a difficulty for everyone! :D from story mode to pain in the ass.

The only thing that bothered me was the defense because if you are still in an animation you cant block or dodge/evade and that annoyed me personally. But that might just be my personal preference.
Besides this i can recommend this game to everyone. I truly believe that even if you don't like Star-Wars you might like this game.
It's good, no performance issues except for stutter at the start/end of cutscenes. Average 120 FPS with a 4070 TI at 1440p

If you have a computer at least as good as my laptop, you should be fine.

The game struggles to make it to 60 fps even at low settings with a RTX 3080Ti. EA installs a App on your PC that has to launch before you are allowed to play and it has to optimize its graphics every single time so starting the game up isn't quick. However, If your able to handle frames just below 60. The game is pretty fun, the story is better than Anything Starwars that hit theaters since the Year 2000.

Minor gripe, low spoilers: [spoiler]The entire game takes place on one huge planet with 4 much smaller side locations. There is tons of back and forward and it can get exhausting if you want to try to get collectibles[/spoiler]

I am a dipshit Jedi with same powers I had in the previous game
At least cutscenes and dialogues are not cringe like in the previous game.

Easy 150+ fps on ultra
Amazing game hidden under horrible pc optimization

The game definitely needed more time in the oven, and the last update as of now was several months ago. However it is a good game and I would recommend. Still wish the sabers weren't neon baseball bats, but it is what it is. There should've been more smaller planets to with different biomes rather than 1 main planet to explore. More character customization would've been better than a million different material colors for BD and the saber. Good twist at the end. Not worth $70, but on sale it's worth it. I would like to conclude by saying fuck EA.
After updates the game is finally stable enough, at least on my end where i can recommend it. The game was great but on release it was too stuttery to recommend.

Great game. OK Linux support. Although the performance really suffers at one stage where there are too many particles. I would prefer the particles to be less detailed and have more than 1 fps with my NVidia 3050 with 8GB VRAM. Maybe better with AMD or on Windows. But it runs very playable on Linux otherwise without any configuration being necessary. Occasionally it crashes though unfortunately. Seems intermittent.

Die hard Star Wars fan thoughts:

Updated December 2023:

TLDR: 
Good game, wacky performance, buy on sale, expect to file return if it runs poorly, great story.

You need a controller to enjoy this game. 

Long Form:
Game "works" - It's clear that there are some issues still, lag spikes from time to time even on my higher end PC. My recommendation buy the game on sale - set a timer so you don't play more than 2 hours (for refunds) test the performance on your PC. If you find the intro playable the rest of the game will likely run smooth enough in my experience. THE STORY is great and frankly leaves me eager to see what happens in the next game. This game isn't worth the headache.

Every time the game starts it has to "optimize game files". This can take anywhere from 2.5 to 5 minutes. It used to take 2:30 for me but now it's gone up to 5.

This wouldn't be a huge problem except for the fact that the game freezes constantly.

This happens randomly. But there's a boss on the planet Koboh that causes the game to freeze everytime I die and it's a tough boss so I die a lot.

Add to that all the performance issues, it's just not worth it.

Too bad, since the moment-to-moment gameplay is quite enjoyable. I don't understand why a game by such a huge publisher is such trash but I'm asking for a refund.

=== Edit after 17 more hours played ===

Steam denied my refund due to time played. That's understandable but still stings a bit. I was determined to play more and found out that there is a way to disable the optimizing file step so startup WAS under a minute. I say was because now the game refuses to startup at all.

This is ridiculous.

=== Edit after 61 hours total playtime ===

Clearing EA apps cache managed to get the game running...

But ya know, every time I feel like I'm actually doing alright with this game it come out and kicks me in the nards.

I was on my way to do a story mission when the game crashed like it does sometimes. But this time the game crashed whenever I loaded my save game. So I've joined the ranks of people who have lost progress to corrupted saves.

Luckily for me, I have a backup from only a few days ago but that's still such an unneeded headache on top of everything.

Srsly. DONT BUY THIS GAME.

IF YOU DO: BACKUP YOUR SAVED GAMES EVERY DAY (OR MORE).

Saves are under C:\Users\YOUR USER NAME\Saved Games\Respawn\JediSurvivor

=== Final Edit (I hope) == =

I was really hopeful I would be able to complete this game. But, alas, I cannot access the final mission.

The game crashes during the cutscene to reach the final mission. This has happened before. Some cutscenes just crash the game. I've gotten around this problem by skipping the cutscene then just watching it on Youtube. But for this one, it crashes so quickly skipping it is impossible.

This is very much the rotten cherry on top of the trash pile that is this game.

Alright, rewriting the review just after completing the Main Story on the highest difficulty. The core gameplay itself is once again excellent, the story serves its purpose and always throws in a surprise when you think it's becoming predictable, and the new Stances and enemy types nicely evolve the Fallen Order Formula. But, like with most AAA games nowadays, it dies a death of a thousand cuts due to bugs and questionable decisions. A quick list of what I noticed, in no particular order:

-Achievements are completely broken, both on Steam and in the EA App.
-While performance is far more stable than the average internet troll and NikTek subscriber is making it out to be, there are still some major drops in transitions and (strangely) the galaxy map.
-The game lacks DLSS support. There's only AMD FSR, and turning that off turns the game into a blurry mess for reasons unkown to me.
-Preorder bonuses are completely missing. I contacted support about this, but I guess releasing a game on a friday causes issues in that regard.
-There is no option to hold sprint. Only toggle is available. Even Fallen Order had that option.
-Certain cloaked enemies will have their cloth physics bug out BADLY, covering the entire screen in cloth and making them an absolute pain to fight.
-The open world sections are empty, boring and pointless. Luckily most of the main story still takes place in linear ares, like Fallen Order.
-On MNK, sensitivity is greatly reduced in non-combat zones, requiring multiple full mousepads to even turn a 90¬∞ corner.
-Some of the menu options, particularly the customization section, are often unresponsive, requiring the player to completey back out of the menu to reset it.

And that's not even all of them. I guess it's just the usual, EA publishing a Full-Price Beta Test, so no surprises there. Which is a shame, because the game itself is easily GOTY material.

UPDATE, half a year later:
-Performance seems to have improved, FSR can be turned off now (lol), DLSS is now supported and functioning properly as far as I can tell
-Menus are still VERY broken on occasion
-Preorder Bonus Detection is fixed! All items are added retroactively, even on existing save files
-Cloth physics seem to be fixed
-Sprint Hold is still missing. Reckon you could make a macro to add it yourself, but it's still poor that this is necessary in a AAA game (again, the Prequel had the option!)
-Achievement detection still seems to be wonky, but it's harder to tell now that I have all the story achievements (all of them unlocked at once at some point)

Originally I had this review as negative but upon further introspection I do think that it is worth the price on sale. The production value and scope of the game left me feeling like they had earned my money, even if the game has a lot of issues, and a metric ton of missed opportunities. I think that last bit was what bothered me the most about this game, the fact that so much of it feels like it could have been unbelievably amazing if resources were allocated a bit better or if they redid parts of their gameplay loop. 

There are way too many puzzles and way too much climbing, many characters are written in a similar fashion so they blend together into one general archetype, whilst  it feels like there isn't enough location variety [spoiler]because the game is a fair bit less "galaxy spanning" than might be expected and you're mostly on one planet[/spoiler]. The story, though beginning and ending pretty strongly, struggles a fair amount during the middle of the game. [spoiler]The villains are pretty weak[/spoiler], a lot of the voice acting is somewhat monotone, combat begins to feel somewhat boring when you figure it out, many (red) unblockable attacks feel unfair to play against, some new enemy types are not fun to fight, the collectables felt generally uninteresting and I could go on. Yet despite all this, I still think the game is very worth your time on sale. 

You should know some of the game's flaws and play around them, maybe stick to the main quest if you find yourself getting bored, and try to set your expectations accordingly. Still, I feel that this game deserves to be financially successful and I feel that it is worth your time. So if you like Star Wars, the previous entry, or souls-likes then please give it a shot. 

The review is over but if you were curious why I would leave a negative review then feel free to read on, because I do feel like this'll prep you for the game. 
So my perceptions were pretty mixed by the mid-point of the game so I decided on a fun way to settle my internal debate on what rating to leave.

I set two timers when I landed on the next planet I went to in my playthrough, one on my desktop to track my overall time and another on my phone to track the amount of time I spent climbing up surfaces or solving puzzles. Every time I wasn't climbing or puzzle solving I would pause the timer on my phone. When I did the math when I left the planet; I was looking at a hot (and extremely generous) 43.4% (repeating of course) time spent just doing those two activities alone. That doesn't sound like a lot but it really is. If you're used to Uncharted then this probably isn't the worst, but man, I was getting to set pieces and instead of going "Yipee, this looks so cool," I was going "Oh my God, this is going to take so much dang climbing and puzzle solving AGHHHH."

Probably worth getting though, it is a pretty cool game overall.

A good game mired by some really absurd EA garbage and technical issues. I would only recommend this on a sale, because these devs/publisher do not deserve more.

[h2]The EA garbage[/h2]
The game opens with a nice little message of a Privacy Policy and a [b]Cookie Policy[/b] that you must accept in order to play. Yes, in a [b]FULL PRICED[/b] video game you have to accept a privacy [b]AND A COOKIE POLICY[/b] in order to play. What the the actual hell?

But that's not all! There is telemetry in the game, that is enabled by default! Yay! Thankfully you can disable it in the settings, but who knows if that option even does anything.

Not only you no longer own your games, they are also becoming spyware, even the singleplayer ones! Screw EA.

[h2]The performance & graphics[/h2]
Yeah, the "rumors" are true. The performance leaves a lot to be desired. The main issue are micro-stuttering issues omnipresent throughout the entire game. From the first second you launch the game, even the intro movies lag like you are playing on a 20 year old PC. It's shocking.

I played on a 5900x/4070ti/1440p/SSD and on max settings no RTX the frameframe is very inconsistent. Some areas can run at 100 FPS no problem. Some areas run at 30 or less with insane stuttering. Most notably the main output area which you will be visiting a lot.

Pretty much all cutscenes have a hitch on transitions which makes you unable to see the first second or so of each cutscene.

Not only the performance is bad, the graphics are not that amazing either. Sure, they are good, but not that good for how badly it runs.

Lowest settings appear to have no effect on graphics, or the performance, compared to the maximum settings.

I'd also like to point out that there's absolutely no way to disable anti-aliasing (TAA), not even though config file editing. This results in a [b]very blurry[/b] and smeary game 95% of the time, which further ruins the atmosphere.

Other classic graphical bugs are present here as well, most often lighting bugs - certain areas being pitch black for no apparent reason. Other issues include volumetric fog "floating" above ground (on Jedha), effects flickering (Moon), etc.

[h2]What I liked and other issues[/h2]
The story is kinda middling, but still manages an emotional conclusion.

There are quite a few memorable things from all of Star Wars here. The hilarious B1 Battle Droids and others from the Clone Wars, some enemies are pulled from newer media such as the purge and dark troopers, etc.

There are a lot of collectibles. Most of them are either lore, cosmetics or currencies to unlock cosmetics and perks, etc, none of that "collect for the sake of collecting" collectibles.

The game does well to sell you the "being a Jedi" fantasy. When you get to dispatch multiple easier enemies with the many tools provided, you really do feel [strike]like batman[/strike] cool and powerful when it happens just like in the movies, and this doesn't happen too often which maintains the novelty of it.

Combat is not without its issues in my opinion, there are few frustrating things like a certain boss having an instant kill move that is difficult to avoid because he lunges across the entire arena, issues like getting stun-locked by multiple enemies or even 1 stronger enemy with multiple or long attacks, being hit mid air by melee attacks, etc. No animation canceling for dodge/evade makes me wonder how you are meant to deal with bosses without getting hit.

Sadly no starship battles, but I guess if you want that, there are other games for it. Still, there are a couple fights like that which you only get to look at, and not participate in.

Lastly, a nitpick, but inability to switch between all lightsaber stances really dampens the cool factor. You get only 2 at a time, and sometimes you just want to try a different one from the ones you already have equipped.

Other issues:
[list]
[*]Mouse controls in menus are atrocious in places, most notably the settings menu is UNUSABLE with the mouse.
[*]Weird controls for Keyboard, Tab is evade for example. BD-1 mechanics have unchangeable slow aiming, and the chosen key binds are annoying. Really the game has so many different keys to press I got confused many times and had to stop and conscientiously think about what key to press next. The game does warn you that its best played on a controller to be fair, but still. Thankfully you can rebind them. 
[*] Photo mode forces on depth of field that cannot be turned off. You can mitigate it a bit, but can't turn it off completely. It also does not automatically hide UI when taking pictures through the in-game method.
[/list]

Hello Spoiler alert
I purchased this game on sale for $35 thinking it might just be worth it, and besides an overheated computer and often frame drops it ran in an acceptable manner. However, the game's combat is a copy of Fallen Order and the map has an unfathomable amount of parkour, but I did not give this game a negative review for parkour, Its story is my main complaint. The game's characters are unfriendly to the main protagonist and most interactions are full of snarky remarks and poor writing. The game has a consistent theme of new characters being introduced with a wait time of 2 seconds to 20 hours until they betray you with unclear reasons and poor logic. When the game reaches its climax it pulls a U-turn to ruin a character you are introduced to in the first few moments of game-play. I have uninstalled this game and give a warning to those who want to play it I bid you adieu.

For anyone thinking about purchasing this game in December 2023/ January 2024 :

1. HAVE A GREAT PC SETUP - I have a 2016 setup (all components except for a 2022 AMD graphics card) and I was unable to run this game past potato graphics. This game requires the most updated or latest hardware to run. IF YOU DO NOT HAVE THIS TYPE OF SETUP ON YOUR PC I WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND NOT PURCHASING THIS GAME. The performance issues are true for PC players. This game will melt your system in a heartbeat. 

2. THIS GAME WILL CRASH RANDOMLY - I couldn't even boot this game up without crashing. I updated my graphics card drivers which helped but it still did not fix the issue. I still had random crashes or frame rate drops all through out the FIRST 30 MINS IN THE GAME. Even though my system is older, I still had past the recommended system requirements but it didn't matter. 

3. THIS IS NOT WORTH MORE THAN 20$ - I bought this on discount for around 35$ and its till not worth it. The game looks like KOTOR back in 2003. Which is a much better game in my opinion. Unless EA will fix these issues on PC do not buy this game.

One of the major complaints you'd see even today, approaching 2024, are the performance issues, mainly the first explorable area, Koboh.
I was running this game on an i5-12400f and a GTX 1060, which is below even the minimum spec for the GPU; and so I installed a performance mod from Nexusmods as a precaution before installing the game. Game bugged out on me 2 times, a story bug and a game black screen, which were fixed after a simple restart. 

And now that I've completed the game with an almost 100% exploration, I would say that 95% of the time the game was running surprisingly smoothly. It was smooth sailing at around 60fps and only dipped towards areas where the effect particles were excessive (first world, purple-ish particles area)

- As for story, I'd give it an 8.5/10, and it's expected to have another sequel, likely being a trilogy to finish off Cal's journey.
- Combat has more variety now with new stances, moves, stronger force abilities and perks (like Hollow Knight's charm system). The Grandmaster difficulty in this game is significantly harder over Fallen Order's. It is also a little more jank in its physics and hitbox.
The one thing I really appreciated was that previous moves and exploration abilities from Fallen Order was brought over from the very start, so it is a faster paced game than Fallen Order.
- The worlds in the game was just satisfactory, with 2 of them being large ones (Koboh > Jedha) and the rest being smaller ones. 
- Customisation for both Cal and BD-1 cosmetics has improved, with a variety of clothing, lightsaber parts, BD-1 parts and blaster parts. Unfortunately the Mantis cannot be customised (recoloured) like the previous game.
- New Game+ only offers new perks and a new lightsaber colour. No Meditation training which is a huge shame.

Conclusion, this game is a must-play for those who liked Fallen Order and it is a deserving sequel of a great game. While everyone's experience with its performance is different, I highly recommend you to try the game out yourself when it goes on sale.
Granted, you'd have to rush through the first area (Coruscant) to Koboh to really test out your performance before you go over the 2 hour refund period.
Runs like absolute garbage on PC, made it about 10 minutes before refunding. Get on PS5 or Series X if your gonna play this.

I'll start with the bad news: the game is definitely more buggy than the last one on PC. Upon writing 12/30/2023 my game has crashed twice. Outside of the rare and occasional bugs, I really enjoy this sequel so far. Narrative-wise the game is so far about the same level as the last, but I feel the actors have stepped it up a notch. The devs however have taken the Fallen Order formula, and really elevated the experience. While the last game had the souls-like/metroidvania exploration....the devs added more open exploration in the planets I've visited so far. Great for when I don't feel like progressing the story and grinding out for some skill points for more ability variety. All in all, the game has expanded on the solid foundational systems of the last game, keeping the experience fresh and familiar. Last game I beat it on normal and then did a Grand Master run, this play-through we are just going in for the Grand Master. I feel that this time around Grand Master is actually harder than the last game, and feels a bit more like Sekiro difficulty. Not quite as brutal, but you're gonna die a lot from normal enemies. Would highly suggest it for those looking to make it a difficult experience/more of a "realistic" Jedi role-playing experience. PS - even more customization, and more zany side characters too! If you liked the last one, you'll greatly enjoy the plethora of new mechanics and options this game has to offer. May the force be with you, always.

Star Wars Jedi Survivor thrusts players into a gripping narrative set against the backdrop of the iconic Star Wars universe, providing a unique and immersive gaming experience. However, the game's potential is hindered by notable optimization issues, even for users (like me) equipped with powerful GPUs such as the RTX 3070. 

The shining star of Jedi Survivor undoubtedly lies in its captivating storyline. The game successfully captures the essence of the Star Wars saga, delivering a compelling narrative that holds players spellbound from beginning to end. Rich character development, an intricate plot, and exploration of the Force contribute to the game's depth and authenticity.

Regrettably, Jedi Survivor falters in the realm of performance optimization, falling short even for players wielding top-tier hardware like the RTX 3070. Despite configuring settings to the highest level, the frame rate struggles to maintain a consistent 60 fps, creating a noticeable hurdle for those seeking a seamless and engrossing gaming experience. The lack of optimization may prove frustrating for players who anticipate flawless performance on cutting-edge GPUs.

Visually, the game excels with its meticulously crafted environments and character models, breathing life into the Star Wars universe with stunning graphics and meticulous attention to detail. However, the visual splendor is marred by performance issues, preventing players from fully basking in the beauty of the galaxy far, far away.

Despite its optimization challenges, Star Wars Jedi Survivor manages to redeem itself through its compelling narrative and faithful representation of the Star Wars universe. The game excels in delivering a story-driven experience that allows players to feel like genuine Jedi navigating the trials of survival. With focused efforts on performance optimization, Jedi Survivor could easily ascend to greater heights in the gaming landscape.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi Survivor is a must-play for die-hard fans of the franchise seeking an immersive and enthralling narrative. Nevertheless, the notable optimization issues, even for high-end hardware like the RTX 3070, hinder the game from achieving its full potential. For those willing to overlook these performance hiccups, Jedi Survivor offers a satisfying journey through the Star Wars galaxy, earning a respectable 7/10.

Now that I've finished it, I can now say that the story was really well made, and I'm interested to see where this is going in the future. However, I think I prefer the storytelling of Fallen Order a little bit more, as it tells a story in a much smaller scope, with (in my opinion) better antagonists. Don't let that discourage you from playing this game, though. It's still a solid entry.

Jedi: Survivor is the excellent sequel to Fallen Order. It's set years after the events of the first game with Cal struggling to fight against the Empire. A series of events leads Cal on the path to finding a safe place from the Empire and perhaps a chance to walk away from the constant fighting. 

Cal has matured from the previous game not only physically but also his control of the Force, though he still struggles with it. The story presents the dangers of obsession and the allure of the Dark Side. Both of which are explored not only by Cal but by the two excellent antagonists serving as foils for the main character. 

Gameplay wise, it is an improvement over the first game. The combat is more intense with increased difficulty along with more combat options. The game introduces new stance mechanic that fundamentally changes the way Cal fights. All stances are viable though some are easier to use than others - I'm looking at you Cross Guard. There is also great improvements of the map as it is far less confusing than the previous game. 

As for performance. I played the game almost a year after release and it was an excellent decision. The bugs and performance issues reported from launch was nowhere to be seen. Even with my low/mid tier gaming rig I was able to maintain 80 fps average on high settings. Though there is an issue though, the game has to compile files every time you start up the game. This was longest the first time you play and gets significantly shorter for every subsequent start up. Still though, I thought most games would only need to compile files once. 

Overall, I found Jedi: Survivors to be an excellent game and sequel. The story, characters, music and game play are all excellent and I would highly recommend this game.

An achievement in gaming, Jedi: Survivor eclipses the previous title in every possible way. More stances, four in fact, give you a huge variety in the way you play the game. The game world is huge, and you can spend tons of time exploring it. In fact, the way some levels open up into vast other unexpected areas reminds me of Elden Ring.

Built on UE4, the game performance isn't the best for what they are trying to do here. This game simply has outgrown the abilities of UE4. While there is stuttering in one particular area, the largest planet in the game, for the most part, performance is excellent. I have a 4090 and run it at 120 FPS in 4K all settings maxed, EXCEPT ray tracing is DISABLED.

I think the best way to play is with Ray Tracing disabled, yes, it makes the game look better in some areas, but it also gives the models a glowing effect that frankly looks terrible. However, the main reason to disable Ray Tracing is that it just tanks performance and also leads to crashes. The same thing was seen in another UE4 title, Hogwart's Legacy, where Ray Tracing just killed performance.

So, wait for UE5 games (like the excellent new Robocop game) to experience Ray Tracing. But for this game, leave it disabled. The graphics still look excellent with it disabled.

Game is very unoptimized for PC, but if you have a decent system, along with some patience (read the review), awesome game. 

As of writing the PC port is on patch 7 in Dec of 2023. That being said, DLSS Frame Gen is broken, even though its supported. Constant artifacting on the HUD. A great work around I found on Reddit is to download an older version of DLSS Frame Gen and upload it into the game files. This will make your play through experience very enjoyable. As I said, some patience is needed. I played on an RTX 4070 with a 7800X3D. Solid 80-100ish FPS on ultra wide 1440p and ultra preset with ray tracing. Some occasional frame-time stutters, specifically on the planet of Koboh, but nothing that was game breaking (for me). 5/10 on port quality, but 8.5/10 if we're strictly looking at this as a game. If you have a system similar to mine and are willing to install the older version of Frame Gen, buy it while its on sale.

Not a full review, just a some comments on performance.  I'm running an AMD Ryzen 5900X and an Asus Strix 4090 OC edition.  Basically, the game runs fine for me at 1440 at max settings (except motion blur, because fuck motion blur) and DLSS set to Balanced.  I played through the first bit on Coruscant and was able to maintain around 115FPS, with some dips when entering cut scenes down to around 60-70.  A couple areas with lots going on, lots of ships flying by, and plenty of different light sources, did get the game down about 85 or so.

Considering the hardware I'm throwing at it, that's honestly kind of sad.  I can play the game just fine, so I'm not going to complain too loudly, but for people without a completely overpowered GPU, I can see where their issues are coming from.

IF you've got the hardware, don't worry about performance, it'll run fine.  If you don't, well, you may may want to play this one on a console, where they apparently bothered to optimize the damn thing.

One little oddity, when I first started up the game, it had me defaulted to using AMD's FSR instead of Nvidia's DLSS.  Easy enough to fix, but really weird that it happened at all.

The game auto pauses for this part, prompting you to use "unbound" key, which, being unbound, is unusable. There is no unpausing this moment, not accessing the settings, nothing. Just a dead end. And a hard reset. Sorry sucker, you played past your refund time to get to this point, still very early in the game, and there is no way to play further. Thanks EA and Respawn. You made what might be a good game but you spilled sloppy garbage all over it. I want my money back. Yeah right.

This is a fantastic action-adventure game with tight, fun combat, lots of abilities and a huge world. 

Don't misunderstand, Jedi Survivor is a fantastic game, and I highly recommend it to people who like action-adventure games. But some of the choices I didn't like vs the first game:
1. Focus on huge samey worlds (Koboh) rather than a variety of planets.
2. Pseudo-Open World gameplay that is not really open world but gives large, directionless areas that don't have great rewards for exploring and/or wind up hitting gated areas. It just feels unfocused.
3. Over the top levels of collectibles. The first game had its faults with this for sure, but it is really overdone here. 
4. Major lack of new abilities. I like getting new abilities in games, they provide a major reward that is not really matched with anything else. It is over halfway through the game before I get my first new traversal ability. I much prefered a progression system typical to Metroidvanias like the first game.
5. I also really loved the 2nd Sister and Inquisitors in the first game, and the raiders are just not as compelling enemies IMO. Given the game's context as a Jedi Survivor, the Inquisitors are perfect villians. But, I am not finished with the game just yet, though I do know the final boss.

In short, I feel like it is a hybrid of a Metroidvania and a Ubisoft game, that doesn't let it excel in a singular focus.

Of course, there are things this game does better. More combat options, perks, fast travel, slightly better map, some new good abilities.

But the performance even after 7 patches sucks. There are some fundamental flaws in the engine. Fallen Order was a mess too.

Let's keep this brief. Jedi: Survivor outshines its predecessor, Fallen Order, in several ways. The combat system has been refined, the levels are more expansive, and, in my view, the storyline has seen significant improvement. While Fallen Order was a solid game, Survivor elevates the experience to greatness. I'm eagerly anticipating that the third installment will be even more exceptional, hopefully achieving perfection.

However, there's a caveat. If you have the option, I recommend purchasing the game for PlayStation. This is where I've been enjoying my journey through the game, and for good reason. The PC version suffers from horrible optimization. I know have been performance improvements since the initial launch, the experience still feels lacking, especially on mid-range or low-end PCs. While high-end PCs might handle the game adequately, others might not offer a smooth gameplay experience.

This is by far the best star wars game I've ever played. Luckily I did not buy the game at launch or pre-order it since I got this game on a great deal and it was stable when I played it for the first time. I also highly recommend playing this game after Jedi Fallen Order. This game improves on pretty much everything in the first game.

8 months later and this has still yet to be fixed. I have a decent PC, and couldn't even load the main menu without my GPU threatening to overheat with all graphics set to minimum.
Hopefully I'll be able to revisit this game in the future once it's playable and I can give it a proper review, but at the moment I cannot recommend this game because it seems to be actively trying to kill my computer even though it's not actually doing anything.

this was posted by "J.T."
Steps
1.Run the game.
2.Open task manager.
3.Go to the ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù tab.
4.Find JediSurvivor.exe.
5.Right click it and change set priority to High or Real-time (Loads have recommended not to set to real-time due to it prioritizing a
game over more important pc functions).

this posted by "Davidero"
This worked for me:
Disable Fullscreen Optimizations
Full-screen optimization and DPI settings are the default ones on Windows. You should try disabling it by following the steps below:
1.Locate STAR WARS Jedi Survivor game directory.
2.Find and right-click on STAR WARS Jedi Survivor.exe file.
3.Select Properties > Click on the Compatibility tab.
4.Checkmark the 'Disable Full-Screen Optimizations' box.
5.Now, click on the 'Change high DPI setting's button.
6.Checkmark the 'Override high DPI scaling behavior' > Select 'Application' from the drop-down menu.
7.Click on Apply and then OK to save changes.

Had to edit this review, finally got the game back running after the patches, safe to say this series is one of the best story based games out there, immersive, they dont bring you back to square one so you really feel like you're a grown jedi, getting good at the combat and spamming buttons are two very seperate games. but either way you feel like a badass the whole time.

I'm one of the lucky ones who didn't experience severe performance issues. Although, the game did crash on me twice, which is twice more than is acceptable, but other than that only minor bugs/glitches/stutters (RTX 3080, M.2 SSD, Ryzen 7, Dec 2023). Most of the other reviews have touched on them so I'll be sharing some other stuff the game has going for it:

+ Narrative, dialogue, acting is strong overall and presentation feels distinctly Star Wars.
+ The visuals (excluding performance issues) is absolutely amazing, especially with ray-tracing.
+ Combat feels satisfying and you start with (most of the) skills from the first game already.
+ Skills and abilities progress at just the right pace due to how the levels and unlockables are designed. Great implementation of open-world (again, excluding performance issues),
+ More customization for the lightsaber, Cal, and BD-1 for roleplay, if you're into that.
+ Intuitive UI.

+/- High variety of skills/stances/abilities you can use, might be overwhelming or redundant, especially towards late game. You won't be using all the available skills, I promise you.
+/- Plot doesn't have distinct climax and might feel a bit unstructured (the first game also has this problem). It feels more like a ballad/musical than a traditional 3-act movie. Some people might not be okay with this.

- Combat might feel too easy or tedious at times (especially towards late-game).
- Parts of the narrative could've been presented better and/or more dramatically.
- Few leaps in logic and suspension of disbelief required for ability usage and narrative details (e.g. "why didn't he/she/they just use this/do that?")
- Navigation sometimes unclear (e.g., with regards to whether you can survive a fall; "you should've made that").

[h1] It's Complicated [/h1]

When I finished the game, I really wanted to give a positive recommendation for the game. The story is beautifully touching, the mechanics are extraordinarily improved compared to the first game, and this game masterfully extends the formula that made its predecessor. I love games with a narrative, and this game has a story that is honestly more heart-throbbing then some of the Star Wars films (the Disney ones lol). 

Despite the endless praises I could give about this game, I had to be realistic about the issues that disappointingly rob this game of the respect it deserves.

I remember at some point watching a brief clip of an interview with Steve Jobs (I believe), and he was talking about the dichotomy between the promotions of engineers and marketing people. He argued that often corporations will promote marketing people when given the chance as opposed to the engineers because a marketer's job is specially to make more money. He goes on to suggest that this issue is what causes corporations who seem to initially express and act on good intentions to slowly transform into a greedy institutions. Unfortunately, this issue seems to have leached itself into the development of this game.

[h2] The Performance [/h2]
Everyone here acknowledges the performance as being [b] the issue [/b], and I agree. I wanted to give some examples of how the issues with performance are certainly a lack of optimization as opposed to just the lack of performing hardware.

I'm rocking a 5 year old Alienware Laptop with a 1070 and a i7-8750H cpu, a broken fan, and heating issues! Now of course, if I launched the game for the first time and immediately had issues with sustaining a stable framerate, I could honestly attribute it to my under-performing cinder block of a laptop. But the issues with performance are more nuanced then that and behave strangely!

I have one specific example where this happens. Inside the main ship that's used to get from planet to planet, there is a map in the center which is used to select which planet to travel to; just like in the last game. I will tell you that I will drop from a 30 or 40 fps to like just 5 fps. The interface is extremely annoying for this reason. I doubt that my reason that a MAP drops my frames by 85% is because I'm not boasting the latest hardware from Nvidia. And sometimes when opening that map, it runs totally great for a second before deteriorating into a stop-motion mess again. This is what I mean by optimization; issues that defy reason which clearly express a lack of effort and/or time to QA test. 

The game's maps are segmented like in the previous title, although of a much larger then before. Now naturally, a larger size means more of a performance hog; I'm fine with that. I ran most of the game around and above 30fps which is very playable and not distracting for me. But sometimes, I'll enter a room/hallway/section adjacent to where I just was that will drop me to 20fps and below; in that performance territory, parrying on-time becomes excruciatingly difficult and is extremely distracting. When trying to rationalize why such a small change in location produced such a severe change in performance, there is no reasonable explanation. There are scenes/locations you would expect to loose a tone of frame-rate just to left perfectly fine, and there are scenes/locations which you would expect to be perfectly fine but are just excruciating to get through.

There was one time that I was moving around the map fast enough that I fell into the ground because it simply had not rendered yet. And frequently I see textures and meshes popping into the correct LOD just because I rounded a corner too quickly.

Without a doubt, optimization is needed badly, but I was worried about giving a negative review. I don't want to bury a franchise into the dirt because of the poor decision making that went around a game like Battlefield 2042. But I've had my trust broken so many times that I can't let this bullshit happen anymore. I have to be harsh, not because I hate the game, but because I love it and I believe it can do better.

I would have honestly voted for this game under so many categories for the steam awards on just the positives alone, but I can't appease the careless decision making of a bunch of marketing people who will never care about this franchise for more then its monetary value. 

[h2] A Note to the Developers [/h2]
I don't know how long you guys will be working on stabilization improvements, but there is lots of work to be done. If your hands are already full, then keep on doing the best work you can. Otherwise, if you would appreciate information on how somebody with minimum specs is running the game, I would love to be part of the process to get this game on its feet. I can provide information on which regions/sections/divisions are performing the worst so that improvements can be made there. Just let me know how I can help so this game can finally get the respect it deserves.

First up: I got this game late December 2023, and I played through the whole thing WITHOUT A SINGLE CRASH or any performance issue.  I'm on a 13th gen i7, with a nvidia 4060.  

The game is AMAZING. It's absolutely gorgeous, immersive, and it stays fresh and fun the whole time.  

Before trying this game out, I gave Witcher 3 a try because it had better reviews and no history of stability issues.   For whatever reason, everything in Witcher 3 felt like a CHORE.  But Jedi Survivor was the opposite.  It seduces you with a great story, and drops you into the game in thrilling situation, where you immediately feel like you're a hero in movie.  It's challenging, but not overwhelming.

I haven't taken a deep dive into an open world game since Oblivion and Fallout 3.  I was absolutely blown away by how much the game mechanics have improved since then, and how beautiful these open world adventures have become.

There are a few things I didn't care for in the game, but they are very minor: the game is ripe with rewards in the form of skins... obsessively so.  Do I need 100 different options of the paint on my lightsaber?  Do need 50 different jackets for Cal? How many different gun barrels for my blaster do I really need.

I guess some people find this stuff compelling, and it's definitely fun to take a few minutes to change the way your character looks... but THIS is supposed to be my motivation and reward for taking risks in the game?  To be clear, there are plenty of performance-related prizes, too.  I just found the focus on aesthetics to be a very bizarre departure from the games of ten years ago.  Hogwarts: Legacy does the same thing.  I guess it's become the norm.

I have two moderate complaints about the gameplay:  There are a handful of points in the game where you are forced to perform some extraordinary feats, or you cannot progress... like a series of two-dozen intricate midair acrobatics in a row.  Sometimes the automatic follow-camera angle makes these moves incredibly difficult and counter-intuitive.  I wish there was an option to skip them if you get really and truly stuck.  Unlike putting the game in story mode to get past difficult enemies, there's simply no way around these insane acrobatics.  These types of puzzles have their place.  They should be optional and lead to extraordinary rewards.  But often they just feel too contrived to have any place in the story.  Like, Cal is supposed to essentially bounce across a canyon... in world where jetpacks exist? Like any sane person wouldn't be like "BRB, gonna go grab this incredibly useful tech instead of trying to be a literal superhero."

My other complaint about the gameplay is that the doesn't quite give you enough time to luxuriate in your newfound powers.  As you get stronger, so do your enemies... thus cancelling out everything you've worked for.  It would be a much more fun game if they kept throwing low-level stormtroopers at you even in the later levels.

I want to end my review on a high note:  My problems with the game are MINOR compared to the sheer joy of playing this extraordinary adventure.  This may well be the best game I've ever played in my life.  So incredibly fun!
8 months later and performance is still terrible. Good game but almost unplayable, as even lowering settings to minimum doesn't fix the issues.

All the reviews saying the game has bad performance are hoaxes. I run a 1650ti and a 9th gen intel i7 and I had no performance issues with around 40 fps. Over six months after launch, the game is still in a completely unacceptable state. The stuttering is so constant it‚Äôs impossible to enjoy. There‚Äôs really no way to mitigate inconsistent frame times either - enabling DLSS or lowering shadow quality might net you a few extra FPS, but it doesn‚Äôt help with the constant stuttering that makes the game feel so bad to play. 
There are so many other issues that haven‚Äôt been addressed since launch, I‚Äôm pretty sure EA and Respawn have given up on trying. The game stops to compile shaders at startup every single time, and yet it still compiles shaders at runtime, adding more stuttering. Something is also wrong with the game‚Äôs culling - every time you spin the camera, white polygons pop in everywhere, making a pretty game look like a glitch fest. All of this adds up to more frustration than fun. 
The worst part is that it is actually a very good game, improving on the first in every single way. Unfortunately, Respawn forgot that part of video game development is creating well-behaved software. I won‚Äôt be buying any EA or Respawn products in the future

Made a misguided decision of giving this game a go after putting it off for months due to all the PC port issues I've heard about. Hoped that by now, half-a-year later, the majority of the them would be resolved. Oh, how wrong I was...

Everyone is criticizing performance - and rightfully so - but for me the problems started even before the performance started being a factor.

The very first menu that greets you upon starting the game - the FOV/audio setup - breaks if you use mouse with it. The options would change if you click on them, toggling between "yes"/"no". Except that's not what they should be toggling between. "FOV: yes" doesn't make any sense. You're supposed to be switching between "tv" and "monitor" presets, but it doesn't work with the mouse, only if you use keyboard to interact with this menu.

This was merely a portend of things to come.

Imagine the clunkiest website or a web-"app" you had the misfortune of using. That's how the UI in this game feels like. Broken and inconsistent.

- The options menu similarly breaks if you use the mouse with it. Trying to change keybinds (an option that's only available under the "accessibility" category, but not under "controls" category for some reason. In fact, it is the only option that's available ONLY in the "accessibility" category) with the mouse will randomly make some buttons on the screen uninteractive. You won't be able to hover over them, to click them, and navigating through the menu with keyboard will skip over them.
- Attempting to change keybinds will sometimes only work after you press the key like 20 times. Often it would assign a wrong key. Often it would assign the "left mouse button" regardless of what key you're pressing, because I guess the game keeps thinking that LMB is pressed because that's what you used to access the keybind prompt.
- You cannot assign Tab to an action because Tab (and Shift-Tab) cycles through UI elements as if the UI was made in Flash of all things. Except sometimes you can. Why? I dunno, I got tired of experimenting when the first 19 out of 20 keypresses would result in no reaction whatsoever.
- Using arrow keys to navigate through the menus can will break the UI further. It will scroll the currently selected UI element out of view, it will skip over elements, it will fail to select a category etc.
- In fact, attempting to change options with arrow keys causes the same issues as in the aforementioned FOV/audiosetup screen, where it would fake the option being changed when in reality it isn't. A telltale sign of this is there being no "click" sound when you change options.
- Miraculously all these problems go away if you use WASD to navigate the menus instead of arrow keys. Why then are arrow keys EVEN DOING ANYTHING? Why not disable them entirely if the UI clearly doesn't support them for some unbeknownst reason?
- Using the mouse cursor to click on options will sometimes click on the wrong option, because the hitboxes of some of them extend seemingly across half of the screen.

And the cherry on top of all this: you can't even click "Start New Game" with the mouse. It simply doesn't react to clicks. If this doesn't showcase the developer's treatment of the PC port, then I don't know what does.

Only after all this, after spending like 45 minutes fighting the UI to set up the game the way I want, did I start playing. And wow, what a cinematic experience! At first I couldn't even tell if I was watching a prerendered video or an in-engine cinematic, because it was playing at sub-30 fps (all while the graphical fidelity was reminding me of 2003's Freelancer) and the screen looked smudged like from video compression artifacts. Little did I know back then that the game forces a <100% render scale on you, and you can do nothing about it short of modding the game.

And then - my god, the controls. The amount of camera turning interpolation/smoothing this game employs is disgusting - it really brings that experience of controlling an X-Wing, except you're on-foot. Camera sensitivity would change seemingly in every scene, good luck finding a comfortable setting that works for all circumstances. It's not quite as bad as the negative-acceleration mouse-emulating-joystick of the likes of Nier Automata or God of War PC ports, but it's not great either. Especially coming from Respawn of all developers, the studio with a pedigree of making first-person shooters where camera controls are paramount.

Combat feels very scripted, with enemies entering premade animations of interactions with the player character on every hit you make, instead of simply reacting to player's actions. Cal snaps to enemies like it's some kind of Assassin's Creed game, and your controls are locked while the canned animation is playing. Cinematic? Perhaps. Fluid? Hell no. Maybe I'm misremembering Fallen Order, but I don't remember the combat feeling this bad there.

All this at the glorious 20-30 fps. Strange how consoles don't have these performance issues while running worse hardware than the cutting edge PC components that the game manages to still struggle on. It's almost as if PC version has something that damages performance which console versions don't have... ...Oh yeah, Denuvo %&*@$#!

But please, refer to numerous other reviews for the actual overview of gameplay/performance issues of the game, because I didn't have enough time to experience them all: after giving it a short go, and then streaming the game issues to a friend so we can both have a laugh about it, I was nearing the end of a certain 2-hour period.

What happened? How is the second game this much worse than the first? None of the issues mentioned above were present in the Fallen Order! All you needed to do is NOT CHANGE ANYTHING. Yet it feels deliberately worse. It gives off the vibes of early 2000s licensed movie tie-ins, which would be developed by different studios and feel vastly different from game to game. Like the whiplash of Harry Potter 4 being a straight PS2-to-PC port after playing the first 3 games that were made on Unreal Engine directly for PC.

My first refund on steam and my first review. Stay clear.

Solid 6.1/10. 

After a year of incredible releases it's hard to love this. When it manages to maintain some pace it's pretty strong and engaging but it breaks any narrative progression with pointless side tasks that just don't feel rewarding. As soon as you feel like you're going forward it's time to have 2 line hollow conversation and engage in homesteading 'lite' - maintaining an aquarium... gardening... lots of content for contents sake that, apart from getting in the way of the core game, is all just implemented at such a simple level it feels like these mechanics were added as part of a graduate project and never finished or made 'fun'.

No real performance issues but a huge amount of fiddling to prevent random UE crashes on a high spec machine (can't say what did it but I believe it was finally turning off DLSS). 

Overall it's the definition of 'fine'.

its aight.

story: 3/10 - Incoherent and indecisive with bland characters and boring dialogue. most of it is a filler snoozefest, and the part thats actually interesting is all over the place with its writing, but its at least something.

gameplay 6/10 - solid improvement on the first game, although not without its issues. constant animation locking results in clunky gameplay where youre always stuck in animations and unable to move quickly enough for the pace of the combat. the hitboxes for some attacks are awful. its an otherwise atrociously easy game- i completed it on grandmaster. most of my deaths were simply to being stuck in an animation or getting caught by some weird hitbox.

maps/worlds: 5/10 - Theyre alright. Koboh has most of the content, while every other map is minuscule in comparison. side missions are almost all a snoozefest though, and the map design is super gameified with no thought put into immersion at all. random things will be strewn about in a completely illogical way that makes no sense, or enemies placed in locations they should have no way of getting to.

platforming: 3/10 - holy shit it sucks. most of my platforming experience in this game was me looking around confused on where i was meant to go, not to mention how inconsistent wall running is.

puzzles: 4/10 - better than the first game, but boring and frustrating to deal with.

bosses: 5/10 - they aight.

performance: 3/10 - runs like shit.

bugs: 7/10 - youll have random moments where you clip through things sometimes, or some other random nonsense, but its usually alright. (usually)

conclusion: worth trying! id suggest waiting for a sale though, cuz id feel robbed if i had bought this for full price. though im not satisfied with this game, im excited to see where they go with the third one.

Starting with the positives:
Just like the last game, this game is first of all fun. The combat is satisfying and varied, with 5 different fighting styles and various abilities. The strongest point of the game is its exploration, using your abilities to traverse the levels and find collectables is the best part of the game. I do think it takes too long for all the abilities to unlock but it's fun after you have all of them. A solid experience, especially if you liked the first game.

Now the bad:
The performance is still dodgy, there are constant frame drops on the main planet and boss fights. This is the most annoying part about the game, I was hoping it would have been fixed until now but no, it's still there. It prob won't get fixed so avoid it if it bothers you.
In terms of gameplay, the main issue I have is that the enemy ganks are annoying, The combat is very good when its one on one but falls apart in ganks, you just find yourself kiting and circling the arena due to the block meter and unstoppable attacks, the force abilities makes this more enjoyable but those are limited by a meter. Most of the time I just chose to take damage to get some damage of my own, I dont think it makes for good encounter design.

Summary:
Good game with some annoying enemy encounters, bad performance and some bugs.
laggy at times but still incredibly enjoyable

All in all really cool game, totally recommend.

Ok, so the game is really good. However, it still has major issues. Here's a breakdown:

The good:
- The story is amazing
- Gameplay is just the previous game but better (could be a plus or a negative, depending on what you're looking for)
- Character customization

The bad:
- There's a lot of stuttering before entering a cutscene. Sometimes cutscenes are bugged altogether where BD will be riding on Cal instead of in the scene
- DLSS doesn't really do anything and adds some terrible artifacting to the HUD. You'll want to download updated .dll's for better DLSS
- The game needs to optimize the game files before every session. Sometimes it's quick sometimes it takes 5 minutes
- Some enemies are rinse/repeat

Overall:
- They still need to fix some of the performance issues. The stuttering before cutscenes is the most annoying part. However, once you're in the world playing the game, it's really really good. I wouldn't recommend this without a 40 series or equivalent card. There looks to be more bad than good, but I still recommend the game based on my experience with it 4 hours in.
