An excellent successor to it's sequel.
Improving on everything though falling short partially due to one of it's main strengths and partially due to the rushed PC release.

PRO's:
- The cast is well written and likeable. I really liked the characters. Greez and the badass Gen'Dai Rayvis being particular highlights to me.
- More lightsaber style variation.
- A blaster.
- Plenty more customisation of Kal's appearance, lightsaber and droid. (though not the ship)
- A wide variety of side content.
- Some endgame content and a New Game + (the latter I have still to explore but it gives some extra options, a red lightsaber etc)
- The story stands on it's own but builds an ongoing arc for the next part and is strengthened by playing the first part.
- A lot of gameplay/leveling options, a lot of playstyles and difficulties that can be modified to cater to the current mood/skills/preference. From story mode (casual and laid back) to Grand Master for people that like their games rockhard.
- The almost metroidvania style approach to powers to unlock areas in old areas + the excellent jump/climb etc mechanics continue to amaze. But also at times hold a weakness. (see cons)

Con's:
- This long after release I still had several crashes, including one that lost me a lot of content due to the lackluster save system.
- No autosave bar once in a while, limited save points. Which due to the exploration grind can sometimes be a pain especially with an unexpected crash.
- I wish there were a bit more worlds to explore.
- The Gen'dai which is similar to the Lucas canon's Durge should have had an additional combat near the end. Disney has downpowered this species it seems.
- I'm not a big fan of the Disney version of the Inquisition or the High Republic. If you love the Disney canon this is a plus perhaps. For me it was a con. Though in no worry a huge problem.
- Some puzzles/jumping area become downright ridiculous both lore and entertainment wise, grinding things to a halt.
- Part of the game's content feels artificially gated or delayed. People that don't like excessive puzzles MAY dislike some parts of the game.

Conclusion:
Probably one of the best pieces of Star Wars content we've seen in a decade together with Fallen Order.
Definitely worth picking up. But due to the ongoing (very infrequent) crash issues only at a discount.
I hope they don't rush the launch of part 3. The game deserves a smoother release.
It's such a rare and awesome Star Wars gem.
Thoroughly enjoyed my playthrough of Jedi Survivor. Performance problems and bugs on PC are bad, but everything beyond that is fantastic. Highly recommend this game, and Fallen Order.

As others have said, it is broken! Crashes to desktop often, and a few visual glitches now and then.

But the story is epic..  and still worth putting up with the poor PC port.

The exploration and combat in this game are great fun. It's exactly like Jedi: Fallen Order but with a few extra elements added, so if you enjoyed that game then there's a very high chance you'll enjoy this one too.

Unfortunately that's where my compliments for this game end.

This game is so poorly optimised for PC, it runs like a turd regardless of how good your hardware is or what settings you pick. Probably about 70% of this game was playable for me, but there are sections that are just a stuttery and laggy mess. When you quit the game it takes a good 5-10 minutes for the game to properly close, and that whole time it is hogging all of your system resources, lagging the heck out of your computer.

The overall story leaves much to be desired. Without spoiling too much, it was incredibly predictable, and the ending felt way too similar to its predecessor.

Playing this game also requires you to go through EA's proprietary launcher. This means having to download another launcher and creating/logging into an EA account. If I wanted to use the EA launcher I would've bought the game on there, this trend of triple A studios forcing you to use their game launchers to play their games needs to end.

If the game was fixed I would consider recommending this game, but in its current state I just can't. If you really want to see the story I think you're better off watching a YouTube playthrough or a compilation of the cutscenes rather than spending money on this game.

What an absolute trash game.

People complain mostly about the performance but what is really the problem is the design.
What was great about Fallen Order? A well designed combat system, amazing mostly linear level design that still rewarded some side exploration with helpful items and the occasional fun cosmetic thing.

This game however is nothing but a design-by-committee disaster. Oh games have open world now, and hubs, and stores, and whatever else crap you can copy over from the latest Ubisoft game, God of War or wherever else you want to steal.

The result is a game where you have hubs that are unnecessary, unnecessary items that you only get to be able to buy cosmetics in some usless shop, NPCs that couldn't be more generic, an "open world" that serves no story pupose and just had you kill random animals for no reason, and tons of useless perks, an overcomplicated skill system and combat animations from Cal that make you think he's Geralt killing a drowner but not a Jedi dealing with an already disarmed helpless enemy. You are literally executing some people that are already helpless on the ground.

All in all this is everything that's trash about AAA games, makes everything feel generic and the same. You have companions now.. no reason.. just because games do that now. You have hubs and shops that add nothing but hey, AAA games have that now so it must be here too.

Waited for a significant sale before jumping in.

The game itself is pretty cool. I like the combat. This is less of a platforming/puzzle mess that turned me off the last one in this series.

Performance-wise, it seems mostly ok on my system. Some dips, some stutters, but not often.

What sucks, then?

It just crashes all the time. I've been tolerating it but this game came out in April, and it's December. I don't like having to plan around possible game crashes while I'm playing the game. There's no warning, just freeze and then an Unreal dialogue box for reporting the crash. Then, on relaunch, you'll sit through lengthy vanity cards, and then a lengthy "optimizing game files" screen (like 5 minutes I timed to relaunch the game after a crash) before you're allowed to continue from whatever checkpoint you last saved.

So, no, don't buy this, even at 50% off. They still haven't finished it!

EDIT: I seem to have solved my crashing problem by just disabling ray tracing. Would I recommend this game now having that knowledge? Absolutely not. It's still broken 8 months after release and I'm still constantly worried about getting ripped out of the game before I can make it back to a save point. Not great.

One of the most impressive games released this year. I waited until now to play it after the launch reviews. Now after more than half a year, i have played through the whole of main mission and 60 to 70 percent of the side ones and only encountered one crash and no notable bugs. My CPU is a weak one (i3-12100f) so the crash most likely related to the cpu getting overheated. The performance was very good with only occasional dips below 60 because of my weak cpu. BTW my rig is 6700xt with 32 gig ram (it was reporting over 16 gig all game sometimes around 25 gig ram and 11 gig of vram so i would highly recommend 32 gigs of ram and not going over high setting on 8 gb vram cards), and i was playing on ultra preset on 1080p with around 70 to 80 fps mostly with occasional dips to 50. All in all it was a great experience and i would highly recommend this game on discount of course. A solid 9 out of 10 for me.

At launch this game was an awful mess, with terrible performance, and constant crashing. Although that will remain a stain on Respawn's legacy, I am happy to say that after the best part of a year I was finally able to finish the game, and that it's at last in a state that I would highly recommend picking it up.

The game itself is a solid continuation of Fallen Order with the same fantastic cast returning to deliver an incredible and touching story that's really at the top end of what the Star Wars universe has to offer. There are few weak points in the writing, and some moments presented here are as iconic as anything in the much loved franchise. I would say that in combination with the previous game this is shaping up to be my favourite Star Wars trilogy since the original movies.

The world in which the game takes place is truly astonishing in it's level of detail and design. There really are some exceptional locations to explore, and there is a real sense of freedom. Sadly the collectables out in the world are still limited to mainly cosmetic upgrades, but it's a lot of fun just exploring the map. It helps that the game is gorgeous to look at. After many patches it's finally possible to see the game at it's best without having to own a military grade GPU, and with DLSS and RT enabled I was able to run the game at 4K on a 3080. With that said, it's still a great looking game even without all the sliders turned up to maximum.

Gameplay is a mild evolution of what was on offer in FO. It's still wearing it's soulslike credentials on it's sleeve and generally feels the same to play as it's predecessor, with some minor tweaks. If it ain't broke, don't fix it, and for the most part, it ain't broke. Boss fights remain tense and generally feel like a fair challenge, and regular mobs are fun to dispatch, though in both cases the continued use of unblockables still feels like a crutch. New stances offer some variety, but I ended up prioritising the one I liked best and sticking with it for the whole game. Where the game really shines is in its set pieces, which really take this game into cinematic territory. At times it's like being put right into the middle of an intense interactive action movie.

Overall this is a 10/10 game which delivers on every level, and any Star Wars fan that's able to should pick this up. Even without the legacy of the franchise to prop it up, this game contains some of the best moments I can recall in any game, which left me catching my breath a few times. Can't recommend it enough, and looking forward to the sequel.

This game really makes you feel like STAR WARS Jedi: Survivor‚Ñ¢.

Fantastic! Improves on everything Fallen Order established for the Jedi Series. You can tell a lot of love and passion was put into this game, with hours and hours of content to be done, tones of secrets, Easter eggs and fan service. The story has a lot of heart, and instead of having characters develop like 'magic' (*cough cough" the sequels) we see them change, through relatable aspects, such as a father just trying to protect his daughter in the only way he knows how, or a person faced with difficult decisions, trying follow the only code he knows while constantly having to question it. And I do like how they really dive deep into the emotional and sad aspects, how Cal deals with loss and him having to adapt and prepare for it. How his newly found confidence he begins with slowly diminishes throughout the game and how he has to stop his rage from controlling him. This game not only improves in game play but also in story, while some of the High Republic stuff being harder to invest in, the core aspects are always the most appealing. And the romance, finally in Star Wars, was actually DONE WELL. You actually root for the characters and it's built up throughout the game, and was even hinted at in Fallen Order. It actually feels refreshing to have things like this that doesn't feel forced. This is arguably the best sequel (game-wise), this game also has the best combat and customisation. You can customise Cal, his lightsaber, with 5 different lightsaber stances unlocked throughout the story (duel bladed, crossguard, single etc.). You can also customise BD-1, your lightsaber appearance and more. I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with this game. The only criticisms I would have is only because I'm not used to this genre of games anyway (though I do think some of the bosses are too difficult, but maybe I'm just bad at them lol) 9.5/10

I gotta say, it is a real shame this game has so many performance issues, because it is absolutely stunning and the story is fantastic and the acting is fantastic.  One of the most consistently engaging stories and best acted games ever made with great action and worlds that feel big while still not being so big you lose focus or tempo of the game.

The main place I encountered performance problems was the Forest Array.   Most of the time it is fine, but definitely things got worse once all those weather effects from Koboh Dust kicked in.   The weather effects seem to be the real culprit for the performance problems:  They just plain overdid it, and even high end graphics cards can't handle this much weather effect on a huge seamlessly pre-loaded map.  It was a miscalculation.

I don't agree with these other reviews that it totally ruins the game.  Is it annoying, yes.  Does it break immersion, somewhat.  But pretty much every other aspect of this game is almost perfect, so if you can look past some choppiness from time to time, it really is worth playing.

***I read all the more recent reviews and decided to grab this on sale. I've experienced exactly one crash in an early level when a very busy fight switched to a cut scene. Never happened again. There are some noticeable drops in graphics when loading new areas or there is simply a lot going, but nothing that affected the fluidity of game play. I don't personally care enough to be bothered by it. Rig wise I'm running an RTX 3050 and a Ryzen 7 3700x with 64GB of RAM. 

Game play wise either I'm garbage or the parry timing is just all over the place. I don't recall having such a hard time in Jedi Order with parry timing and dodging on the medium difficulty setting. The combat will punish you for not paying attention to the enemy timing and behavior, especially if you prefer to just brute your way through things like I do. 

The story is fresh, exciting, fulfilling and equally heart breaking at times and is well worth being patient enough for a stable build of the game to come out. The exploration is vast and generally well rewarded. Each new ability and skill opens new pathways and areas to find chests and echos along paths you had to skip during prior missions. Revisiting some areas can be a little tedious but the addition of various mounts eases the annoyance.

It does not matter how stacked your gaming rig is, this game will run horrible whatsoever. As it stands, unfortunately I think the game might be too broken for Respawn to ever be able to fix.

The next 0.6 hours of my playtime went a little something like this: I load into the first planet and walk around for about a minute. The game freezes. I open up task manager to end task. I restart game. I wait for it to "optimize my game files" and send me to main menu. *press continue* wait for planet to load again and walk around for about a minute. the game freezes. I close the program and continue this cycle.

The longest i was able to play without having to close and reopen the game, after arriving at the first planet, was 4 minutes. 4 minutes was the absolute best. I tried 6 times and adjusted my settings and the other 5 attempts only lasted for a max of 2 minutes before it would freeze.

After leaving the initial starting area and going to the first planet, the game just keeps crashing over and over. I've meddled with settings. Turned off things like RayTracing and Frame Generation. Lowered settings. But the crashes keep on happening. 

I can also see that I am not alone in experiencing constant crashes. Seems that despite all this time since launch, the game is still essensially unplayable for many people.

Jedi Survivor is a prime example of a great game unfairly marred by a sloppy mess of clearly greedy, corporate decisions. 

Whether on my 3080 Ti or my 4090 ray tracing performance is absolutely broken. And, even without RT, no matter the combination of graphics settings or resolution, GPU usage never climbs above 70%. Meanwhile CPU usage skyrockets to around 70%. I've been PC gaming since the original Wolfenstein 3D released in '92 and I have a difficult time remembering any competently made game performing like this.

I can confirm what you've likely heard elsewhere: the game is CPU bottlenecked 100% of time, no matter what you do.

The best-guess explanation I've seen is that the game's use of the Denuvo DRM software is bringing our CPUs to their knees with complex background encryption processes. 

So, that means we're getting an inferior product and a terribly stuttery and unoptimized game experience so the corporate bootlickers at EA can delay their inevitably losing battle against piracy and keep their out-of-touch shareholders happy.

Those are my primary complaints about this abysmal PC port.

The game also suffers from a litany of inexcusable user-interface problems that absolutely have no place being present in an overpriced AAA game from one of the biggest publishers and one of the most popular developers in the world.

These other issues include, but are not limited to the following:

1. Changing game resolution in the options menu simply does not work with a controller, it's swappable with keyboard and mouse only. Even if you unplug your controller while the game is running, it will not work. You must start the game with only KB/M active.

2. You must install the EA app in addition to Steam, and cloud saves are handled by EA, not Steam. In my five hours of playing I've already encountered issues with cloud saves not updating between different systems. A problem I've literally never had with Steam in my nearly 14 years of using the program.

3. The shader compilation "optimizer" that runs during game start up appears to be do nothing 9/10 times it runs, and it does absolutely nothing to help minimize stuttering in game. At this point, I genuinely believe its only purpose is to prolong the amount of time it takes to get to the start menu.

4. Even when using DLSS Frame Generation, and/or G-Sync/FreeSync VRR, microstuttering is a constant issue no matter what you do.

EA is the worst publisher in video games, and the decision makers in that company have nothing but disdain and disrespect for their customers. I regret buying this broken mess. Don't make my mistake.

I simply cannot recommend anyone waste their money on this atrocious port of an otherwise great game. Thankfully I bought this for $35 USD, not the insane $70 they've been gouging people with. But even 50% off is an exorbitant price for this slipshod product. Because of all the inexcusable technical problems listed above I don't think this game is worth more than $15.

Once those who are doing the Lord's work figure out how to get this game onto the Seven Seas, I'm deleting this version and going sailing. Yarr Matey!

[h1] A decent soulslike elevated by its Star Wars trappings [/h1]

First of all, let's get the obvious out of the way: The game ran decently on my PC. There were times where the frame rate dropped, mostly in open areas, but it wasn't something that made me want to tear my hair out.

On to the real review:

I think Jedi Survivor is a good soulslike that is somewhat elevated by being Star Wars. It's undeniably fun slashing things up with your lightsaber and doing jedi flips all over the place, but like with the Arkham games you could rightly question if Survivor would be as highly regarded if it hadn't had this particular coat of paint.

As someone who has completed almost all of the Soulsborne games (yes, I am giving out autographs) the combat mechanics and exploration of Survivor don't quite measure up to the genre's best outings. Fighting feels somewhat clunky compared to, say, Sekiro and exploration becomes a bit of an afterthought when you realize there is relatively little reward for doing so.

[h2] Cosmetics: The Game [/h2]

One thing I dislike about Survivor and its predecessor is how underwhelming many of the rewards for exploring are. When you defeat a tough miniboss or solve a demanding puzzle in Dark Souls you're rewarded with new weapons, armors, rings, consumables or other useful goodies. In Survivor you get a new hairstyle. Like a mullet, for instance. There are rewards that go beyond the cosmetic, like health upgrades or 'perks', which are small skill boosts you can equip at bonfires, but more often than not what you find is utterly useless unless Fashion Souls is your main reason for playing these games.

I actually thought this had been improved upon over Fallen Order, but I thought wrong. Halfway through the game, any dopamine surge associated with discovering a hidden area or a chest had evaporated completely, as I knew in advance these would most likely hold absolutely nothing of value beyond a new pair of ears for BD-1, some pink jedi robes or a yet another lightsaber hilt that looks exactly like the other ones when zoomed out. Sometimes I'd find a health or force meter upgrade, but that was as exciting as it ever got.

However, Survivor does improve on its itemization in some key areas. For instance, you now have access to five different saber stances that you can switch between at your leisure, which is an incredibly nice touch and one of the best improvements over Fallen Order. These stances somewhat correspond to the different weapon types you can find in souls games, with the regular stance being balanced, the crossguard stance being the equivalent of a heavy, slow weapon, the dual sabers acting as 'dex' weapons and so on. The amount of polish that went into these stances is praiseworthy, and I can only imagine it took some work balancing the game around all five. Maybe if certain upgrades to these stances or even the stances themselves could be found by exploring rather than just being given to you at story-appropriate times, exploration would have been more fun. The blaster stance, for instance, had immense potential for customization, upgrades and tweaks, but nothing like that is to be found in Survivor.

[h2] Like Sekiro, but slightly worse [/h2]

The combat in Survivor is like Sekiro, but slightly worse. Keep in mind that I played this game on grandmaster difficulty (the highest setting), so anything I say applies to that difficulty level only. Combat is good. Very good, in fact. But only 85% of the time. When things click, you're playing something that looks and feels like peak Star Wars, seamlessly slicing up hapless stormtroopes and combat droids, parrying blaster shots, lifting groups of enemy into the air with your force powers and tossing them over edges. It's very viscerally satisfying. But certain enemies, mostly bosses and minibosses, and their assorted attack patterns are insanely frustrating to deal with, for a few reasons:

1. Certain strong enemies can attack you through your own attacks. This means that if an enemy is gearing up to do a strong attack, you can't cancel that attack by hitting him first. Even if your attack connects, the enemy will just continue his swing as if nothing happened. It creates this annoying feeling that your own attacks have no weight to them and don't actually affect enemies, which is doubly egregious seeing as your weapon is supposed to be a lightsaber.

2. In connection with point 1, certain enemies - mainly bosses - have insanely long combos that you're expected to memorize perfectly. Once these combos are over, you have a very short window of opportunity to get your own attack in, and then the combos start over again. This is what I like to call the Elden Ring syndrome, and I absolutely despise it. Most lightsaber duels in this game feel less like give-and-take sword fights between two evenly matched adversaries and more like lopsided memorization exercises where you spend 97% of the time running, dodging, parrying, jumping and evading increasingly complicated combos until it's your turn to impotently prick your enemy for 3% of his health, after which you rinse and repeat until the fight is over one way or the other. Sekiro had some of the same issues, but its tighter parry mechanics made up for it, and in that game you could parry your way to victory. In Survivor, parrying is mostly a defensive manouvre (and also wonky and unpredictable, but we will get to that).

3. You can get stunlocked - this game features several attacks that can stunlock you. If the first sweep of certain combos hits you, you will get sucked into the remainder of the combo and forced to soak up all the damage. These attacks are fortunately pretty rare, but still absolutely infuriating. One particular droid with a spinning staff attack needs to just be modded out of the game entirely. And don't get me started on Oggdo-Boggdo, that prick.

4. There are many poorly telegraphed enemy attacks and cues: Some attacks, for instance, appear as if you can evade them, but then you actually can't. Even when pressing the evade button at the perfect time, they will hit you regardless. Parrying is also very wonky and hard to do on grandmaster difficulty. It almost feels random if you succeed or not, which is insanely frustrating when fighting bosses with huge health bars whom you're expected to parry. Some parry windows are very generous, others require superhuman reflexes, and there is really no way to know which is which in advance.

Let me again underscore that most of the combat is good and works as intended. I just want new players to know in advance that Survivor is not as smooth as other similar games. It seems like the developers studied FromSoft's mechanics but only got 4/5ths of the way there.

[h2] It feels like you're there [/h2]

Survivor's biggest strength is in how it brings Star Wars to life. Visually and sound design wise, it really feels as if you're part of a Star Wars movie. If someone had shown this to my 11-year old self, I would have fainted out of pure excitement. Lightsabers make satisfying whoosh noises, stormtroopers look, act (and aim) like you expect them to, the scenery is absolutely gorgeous and so on. I have zero complaints about Survivor's presentation. It's clearly a labor of love.

[h2] What story? [/h2]

I think the writing in this game is perfectly serviceable, but nothing rises above standard Star Wars fare as we've seen it in the last 8.295 Star Wars movies released last year alone. Not-Luke, I mean Cal Cestis, is leading a band of merry rogues as they battle the evil galactic empire. This band includes a funny sidekick (who is more grating than funny), a will-they-won't-they love interest, a wise mentor and a few other paint-by-numbers archetypes as we've seen them a million times before. I honestly zoned out a bit during most of the cutscenes.

In conclusion, I recommend this game and would probably give it a 7/10 on a non-binary scale. It's good, but I've played better.

Star Wars: Jedi Survivor Review

Graphics: 9/10
Gameplay: 8.8/10 Game will find every way to piss you the fuck off, combat is very fun though, very souls like.
Audio: 9/10
Story: 9/10 Characters are great, and I was very very invested by the end.
Worth the Price: 7/10 I could understand 60 dollars, but 70??
Bugs: 4/10 Game is a buggy mess.
Optimisation: 3/10 I get a stable 30 FPS on high graphics with high end specs (check profile for specs), before the new patch I could only get around 10 fps on low settings, so I guess it's better than before.

Overall, the game is a big pile of bugs and shitty optimisation, but if you ignore these issues it is the perfect sequel and a masterpiece of a game.

The good - New customization options for Cal, BD, the lightsaber, and gun. Feels like the old game in terms of souls-like combat. New areas to explore and the story of Cal is just awesome.

The bad - Sometimes the game likes to act like its being run on a toaster. Large lag spikes can occur, which often results in death during combat because you can't time parries correctly.

If you're into Star Wars or souls-like games you'll probably have some fun with this one. Just be prepared for some janky-ness.

The sequel to my favorite Star Wars game of all time (Jedi: Fallen Order) doesn't disappoint. I know there were lots of technical issues upon launch, but I haven't had too many issues with it myself on a mid-tier PC. The story builds upon what came before in exciting and logical ways, and the lightsaber combat has been dialed up to 11. Jedi Survivor is what every sequel should be; a refining and expansion of the qualities that made the original so much fun.

Fun game that vastly improves on the first. Much more challenging than the first one as well.

The only technical issue I had was with Ray Tracing. I had to leave it off because it tanked my frames.

Excellent game - if it were not for the multiple, serious PC port issues.
That some of the very basic ones have not been fixed in all these months is beyond ridiculous!

Trust the negative reviews as per the technical issues, and trust the positive ones as to what an awesome game this could be without the issues.
I will update this review when the most serious issues are fixed (and I'm still playing).

Just the most ridiculous: 
(1)
CPU usage is extremely high. FPS is CPU limited. 
I have to turn off ray-tracing to get to a manageable CPU load (still way too high). This is the only game with which I've experienced this in the past few years.
(2)
I have to disconnect mouse and keyboard to be able to play with controller.
If the game receives too many kbd/mouse input events (including unvoidable events from miniscule mouse movements) then the game switches to kbd/mouse mode, turning of the controller input and with no ability to switch back to controller input. Only solution is quit to desktop, restart and unplug kbd/mouse.
This game is strongly (and correctly) recommended to played with a controller - kbd/mouse puts you at a disadvantage.
(3)
Optimizing game files (compiling shaders) at EVERY start of the game. Caching appears broken. 
The workarounds that can be found all have their own drawbacks (you need to write-protect an entire config file).
(4)
Does not work with non-standard aspect ratios. I have a 16:10 display (which is not that uncommon, actually).
You either have significant parts on the sides cut off, or you get a stretched image. The game does not letterbox if you configure a 16:9 resolution.
In other words, the game does not display properly with 16:10 - no matter what workarounds you try, some parts with be distorted or cut off.

Not recommended even at a steep discount as long as these basics remain broken.

Just as fun as the first one, but I thought the environmental/map design, art design, dialog/voice-acting was much better. I found myself listening to more dialog and optional conversations than normal just because the atmosphere and voice-acting was that good. You also get multiple lightsaber stances to play with, which is nice.

I agree that there are major optimization issues the devs should have fixed, but it was playable. GeForce RTX 3070 Ti
- launch videos stutter, which is weird
- default graphics settings stuttered. 4K w/ DLSS Performance. I turned off motion blur, chromatic, film grain, post processing down, and it wasn't too bad
- Planet map screen has major stuttering

EA launcher is required, NO offline play. 1 day the EA servers were down, and I could not launch the game for about 20 minutes.

A few glitches that bothered me:
- Voice audio out of sync with lips (main character scenes)
- Jawas face glitch in wrong direction

On gameplay, I feel like the game could use more significant side quests to go back over areas. For example, there were parts of Jedah I never explored (where crates/secrets are), but the crates weren't enough motivation to go back. I would have liked to be able to use the landspeeder freely and go back there to do a few quests.

Yes, I could do New Game+, but there are other games to play. There is a perk that changes up the enemies during your Next Game+, which is a nice idea.

*EDIT*
- Potential Spoilers? -
-----------------------------------
Honestly this game probably could have used a few more months of polishing before releasing. After completing the game and watching the credits I noticed that there were quite a few other hands in the cookie jar than just Respawn developers and I believe that led to the myriad of issues that plagues the game. I understand others have reported no crashes or issues playing the game. I can't even begin to imagine how many times i said, "why is my 2080 super having such a hard time with the graphical side of the game?" Terrain looked so bad at times, sometimes wouldn't render at all. Every time I used the fast travel my game would need at least 10 minutes to recoup so that the frames would be stable. The side quests/bounty hunts all seemed like afterthoughts in the development process and felt immersion breaking as Cal had to go hunt the bounty hunters??? I mean I get it, im not a developer, but come on, at least like put them in places that Cal would run into them during the story or something. 

If you cut out all the sandbox exploration stuff, the story is also kinda just, meh? It kind of felt like a very long Part 1 of 2. Dagan Gera was an interesting idea but felt like a pushover. Rayvis was cool but probably could have been much more terrifying if he morphed like the guy in the 2D clone wars. Also the inquisitors just uh...gave up on Cal? He went from being consistently hunted to the empire being like, meh whatever he's in the outer rim, lets just send...purge troopers/DT's.... 

A lot of my friends have stated that they just rushed the story to get it over with and I completely understand why. The game feels disjointed at times and while I think the concept of the story was cool and very emotionally moving at times (Kata + Bode) and (Khri + Dagan) I think that there should have been at least some higher stakes than just what happened on Jedha with the Empire.

Overall I give the game a 7.5/10, mostly because I enjoy all star wars content regardless, just docking points for poor performance on PC and some personal views on the story direction/gameplay.

----------------------------

If you're anything like me the only information you really wanted to know before diving in was: this game works now. I had one crash throughout my entire play-through of the story. It would appear as if the woes of launch are behind us.

Ultimately, I need to recommend this game. I think it captures what makes Star Wars 'Star Wars'. The characters are good, well acted/voiced. It looks impressive. Customisation options. Main and secondary missions. Ticks all the boxes and bells all the whistles. 

Something that did riddle my biscuit though: 'hitting' enemies won't stop their attacks. I can understand this for unblockable attacks, but standard attacks still seemingly ignore damage dealt and hit me with my guard down. I hate this. Not only because my attacks are interrupted if I'm 'hit' (even force attacks), but because it stops me from setting my own pace in combat. I'm forced to submit to the pace set by enemy movements/patterns utilising block. Not quite my tempo. Like fighting games, if I see an enemy winding up for a heavy attack, I want to be able to halt them with a quick attack. I prefer an option to utilise faster reflexes and opportunity attacks, rather than wait longer to block.

Otherwise I can't really fault the game outside of genuine gamer moments when I get beaten. That's on me.

Think of this game as a huge DLC for the first game of the series. Very similar feel as the first one. Same main characters which is adds a nice layer of continuity. The lightsaber battles have a bit more flavour thanks to some new combo moves and finishers. Overall it's the same game as the first but with some neat added features.

There still are some bugs and performance issues but nevertheless a great game.

Like the last game but cranked to 11. I loved the first game and was excited to try this one out. I waited for a while for the updates to come in before starting it so I definitely have not hit that many bugs an issues. I have a 9900k and 3070 FE and play on a super ultrawide 1440p monitor. In general the game is really smooth. Occasionally on Koboh the frames drop a bit and twice on Jedha the frame rate dropped to unplayable levels for like 30 seconds, but other than that it's been fantastic.

The story is awesome, lots of turns and excitement. I don't want to spoil anything on that front.

My favorite part has just been the variety of fighting and platforming mechanics. They start you off basically where you were at the end of the first game as far as abilities and most major missions introduce a new movement mechanic be it a grappling hook or other type of movement ability that keeps things super fresh and fun. 

Some of the scripted sequences are just over the top and insanely fun. One in particular on Jedha was a highlight for me. 

Still haven't finished it yet, but if you liked Fallen Order, this is a very worthy sequel for sure. Worth it for full price? Yes. If you are dying to play it, buy it at full price. If you can wait a bit, there have been a number of sales this year already marking it down by 20-35 percent so patience can pay off.

Either way, great fun.

This is an amazing, amazing game. 
Incredible story, fantastic graphics, and some of the best gameplay you can imagine. It's not only a great video game, but a great addition to Star Wars as a whole. I feel perfectly fine adding this to the rest of the Star Wars properties, and it fits in much better than any of the new movies. It's awesome and I recommend it to anyone that like Star Wars and video games. If you're a fan of Star Wars and haven't played this, what are you doing? 

However the game is horrifically optimized. It is embarrassing. How can you have such a fantastic game wasted in such an awful package? For whatever reason this game has serious problems under the hood, and it is massively affecting my enjoyment of this game. There are much better looking games that run infinitely better. This is like watching The Last Jedi on a flip-phone. A phone that also occasionally just doesn't work. Frame drops are constant, stuttering is constant, and I've encountered a few annoying glitches. But honestly, as much as those suck, it's not like you can't play the game. Even at 40 fps, you can still play and beat the game. As much as I sympathize with other issues people are having, I think in some cases, the complaining is a little extreme. 30fps is not 'UNPLAYABLE'. That is objectively false. You can still play the game. It looks worse, but you can still play the game. But you know what does make the game unplayable? Crashes. 

This game crashes a lot. Like way too many times. For almost the whole game I was fine, except for Koboh. For whatever reason, Koboh has some serious issues. My game would constantly crash there, forcing me to reset my game, sometimes causing me to lose a lot of progress. I should never have to troubleshoot my game, pouring over tons of articles and editing so many settings just so I can get trough a single cutscene. Even then, it will still crash. When a game crashes, it is objectively impossible to play the game I spent 70$ on. THAT is what unplayable means. And the number of times it should happen is 0, for all games. This is unacceptable and is something I CANNOT tolerate, even for this amazing game. 

Even with all the crashing and technical problems, I have made it through what I believe to be 80% of the game's story. I am almost at the finish line. However, my game has now begun to crash every single time I open the game and I cannot continue. I have become locked out of the game and cannot move forward, no matter what I try. EA, you have forced me to write this review because now I can't do anything. I didn't want to do this, but I have no choice. Until you fix this game, and I can see the conclusion to the story me and many others have waited YEARS for, I sadly can't recommend this game. 

Update- 
The game is playable now and I was able to beat it. Thank you for updating the game. Excited for whatever comes next, but please make sure it is optimized well. Don't let this happen again.

I like the game when it actually works, but after enough time it always starts quietly failing to launch.  "Preparing Game' and then it just goes away and the EA client pops up.  This is a well discussed problem on the internet, and EA doesn't care (as you'd expect from EA) and none of the solutions I've tried (over a dozen) work, except uninstalling and re-installing the game.   Which means hours and hours of downloading 130 GB ONCE AGAIN because EA is a terrible company and I was dumb enough to buy this anyhow.

Edit: This has happened 4 times so far.  The last time this happened I was able to uninstall the 'EA App' from Programs and Features, and Steam automatically re-installed it when I launched the game, and then the next time it worked.  This didn't work last time, but if it helps it sure saves a lot of download.  Obviously I still like the game enough because I am still slogging through this BS, but I absolutely cannot  recommend it to anyone in this state.

This game still runs like garbage 8 months after release. Even the menus don't work well. I enjoyed the first game but this one is very poorly made, and the EA app keeps crashing. No thanks.

In general, this was a good game. Played in story mode it has just the right combination of battle and story.
Many reviews complained about bugs making the game unplayable. I only experienced one bug in the game with some "video tearing" . it only occurred once and didn't prove to be problematic. I played the game with a PC in 1080P 60 fps and high resolution, no ray tracing on...similar to an xbox. While the game designers recommend playing the game with a controller, i used a keyboard and programmable mouse. This worked just  as well as a controller if not better. 
The "Cons" on the game included too many chests with worthless contents. Gathering seed to grow a useless garden. Maps that were unjustifiably confusing. And finally a wimpy ending if you can call it that. I was also non-plussed  about some of the precision required for jumps and zip lines. While there were a lot of abilities one could acquire, not all were worth anything. Two weapons, health and Stamina, and some force selections are all you need.
All in all this was a enjoyable game and I recommend you give it a try.

The game is a nice improvement from gameplay perspective after Fallen Order, but unfortunately from story perspective it is weaker. Still can recommend to play the game, but maybe wait for some sale if you are not a fan.

Game frequently crashes after ~2 hours of game play. The 0.1% fps drops on some planets is beyond a joke. You spend more time doing parkour than combat and there are numerous times where you will ultimately perform useless parkour to unlock a shortcut all in the name of "content" - this is fun to start with but after a few hours it gets extremely repetitive. The parkour isn't even challenging and is extremely linear. Visually the game is nice and the story is pretty good. When the combat works it's fun but it's balanced by stupidly boring bosses that repeat the same attack over and over. There is 0 sense of threat because there is a bombfire after every fight and the sense of exploration feels very forced and fake. If this game wasn't StarWars themed it would be average at best and probably forgotten a week after launch.

You might have seen a lot of optimization complaints in the community hub, and they're all right. In my case, I had to disable raytracing and put all the visual settings on low to be able to have at least a smooth experience, and it did except on Koboh around the Saloon and inside the Saloon area there was a considerable amount of hitches and despite all of that this game still stands as great successor to Jedi Fallen Order, a game I loved and enjoyed as well, but this one is on another level entirely in a matter of the story, gameplay (The 5 Combat Stances/Platforming Mechanics/BD's exploration abilities), but what stole the show for me is the environment design.

As someone who came from Jedi Fallen Order, this one did not disappoint and it could have been my year's best if it wasn't for the optimization issues.

Incredible game.

This is how a sequel is done. Finished it twice in a month with EA subscription. Finally bought it on special.
BEST GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED

TLDR review, followed by spoiler free review, followed by mild spoiler review.

TLDR: 
Totally recommend the game, especially if you're a fan of Star Wars or challenging souls-like games (if played on hard difficulty).
Lightsabers, *light-side* force powers, and Uncharted-inspired platforming puzzles, OH MY!
Virtually everything from the first game is improved. 
Combat is crisp and satisfying.
Beware AMD users. I have experienced several game breaking graphical bugs even after AMD's recent patch. 
Story is good but not amazing. Basic McGuffin.


Spoiler Free:

Uncharted, in space, with lightsabers and *light-side only* force powers. If that doesn't sell you, this ain't the game for you. If you haven't played Uncharted and don't know what it is, think super acrobatic Indiana Jones. If you don't know either, then, I don't...jedi guy who hunts down McGuffins in space. 

Strongly recommend playing Fallen Order first as some of the character development will be lost on anyone who has not played the first game.

Pros:
1) Lightsaber combat in this game took a big step forward. It's probably the most developed saber combat of any Star Wars game to date. It really is excellent! It mimics souls-like games with the whole dodge/parry system, but thanks to the difficulty options it can be much more forgivable than the typical souls-like.
2) Combat is extremely satisfying across the board. Whether it's the parry system or reflecting blasters bolts or (my favorite) throwing a little B1 droid off a cliff and listening to it passively comment on its unfortunate luck, it's all well polished.
3) They do a great job of setting Cal (the protagonist) up to feel like a Jedi Knight as opposed to a fresh padawan. This is especially welcome since we spent most of the first game as a padawan who could barely swing a lightsaber without chopping an arm off and running scared from any real force-using threat. He's maybe not quite as strong as I would like, but they do a great job of making him feel like a bona fide Jedi guardian (more lightsaber heavy than force power).
4) The story is wonderfully absent any real reference to the movies. The story stands on its own with its own characters, several of whom are genuinely interesting and likable. 
5) I mentioned lightsabers and force powers right?
6) Several of the locations in the game have never been seen before. Seeing these new planets, all of which are unique and BEAUTIFUL has been a real treat.
7) The game is pretty lengthy. There are a good chunk of side quests, several of which have some pretty neat stories/scenery and all of which (that I've done so far) felt worthwhile. None of them have been at the level of the Witcher 3 side quests, but they've all been enjoyable.
8) This game has one of the most fun/awe-inspiring quick time battle events I've ever played. It sounds like a silly thing to put on a pro-list, but it was THAT much fun. I raved about it to several friends after completing it. There have been multiple moments like that. A unique fight mechanic. A fun environmental twist. Each mission campaign had something specific about it that I liked that was different from the other missions. That really helps the missions and worlds and even the bosses stand out as individual places. 

Cons:
1) I'm running the game on AMD gpu and it's pretty darn awful. Like Cyberpunk 2066 or Mass Effect Andromeda face-melting graphical issues awful. Some of them are game breaking. I think this is more of an AMD issue, and they've released one patch that helped a good bit. But, there's still some SERIOUS graphical problems. That said, still love the game. Still definitely recommend it. Just, if you have an AMD gpu, be prepared to die a few times due to random graphics issues. I had a moving blubber wall spawn in the middle of a boss fight. Couldn't see the boss at all, but the boss could still hit me through the wall that wasn't supposed to even be there.
2) The story is good but not particularly inventive. It's a basic McGuffin quest line, just like the first game. The hook for this game is that you get to play a Jedi doing Jedi things with lightsabers and force powers. The story serves as a vehicle for the gameplay rather than the meat of the game itself.  It's entertaining, but don't expect it to knock your socks off like an OG Bioware game or the Witcher or Last of Us.




MILD SPOILERS AHEAD******************************





The return of some of the old crew is very welcome, and the addition of Bode was fantastic! He's a great character and good adventuring buddy for Cal. 

BD is just as adorable and wonderful as the first game, maybe even more so. Really, come for the lightsabers and force powers, but we all stay for BD. Let's be honest.

The addition of a bunch of new "tools" for Cal to solve his Uncharted-inspired platforming puzzles was much needed. There was only so much life left in the Fallen Order's platforming puzzles, and I was honestly worried about how much more of it I could take. The tools add just enough newness to keep the platforming from feeling stale even 20-30 hours into the campaign. 

Cal feels...underpowered. This game focuses on expanding lightsaber combat, and boy is it ever so expanded. There are several different blade types and all of them feel unique with unique bonuses, though some of the move sets (for instance an aerial ground pound) are copy-paste. His force powers have barely expanded and, because they are exclusively *lightside* powers, lack the flashy and fun choke/crush/lightning/etc. Perhaps this will come if they make a third game? I don't know. But, Cal's lack of any really fresh powers stands in stark contrast to Merrin (who thankfully returns and plays a much more active role) who levels up like an anime protagonist. Seriously, the girl has some WILD powers now. And Cal can, I don't know, pull a droid to him? Mind control a space dog for like 2 seconds? Oh no, wait, scratch that. He can mind control 2 space dogs for 2 seconds each. This is even weirder when in some cut scenes he does crazy awesome things like manages to hold of an enemy force user while also holding up an entirely collapsed ceiling. 

Cal is definitely growing as a Jedi. He has some good lines about self-control, self-awareness, and forgiveness. It's a nice change to see him growing up a bit and becoming a little more aware. It's still not much though. It's tough to really develop as a character when 85% of your voice lines are said to a (ridiculously adorable) droid who just beeps and boops back.

8-29-2023: Nothing has changed since June. This game is broken and is still an unplayable mess. There has not been an update in over 2 months. Do not purchase this game. Not right now. 

When this works it is a fantastic game. If you enjoyed Fallen Order you will have fun with this one. 

The only issues with this game are technical. I don't know what's causing such an issue here a this point, but we are far past the acceptable point now. It has been 4 months. This game should have been functional at release. I can accept within the first month with how ridiculous releases have become. 4 months and people can't even open the game reliably for a game that cost how much to develop by one of the largest game companies in the world? 

This isn't worth it right now. This is ridiculous at this point. This is still not even getting into the fact you have to have an internet connection to play a ******* single player game. Whomever decided that deserves to lose their job. 

6-6-23: Not going to play this game anymore until things get fixed. I found a work around to allow me to launch the game consistently. You apparently need to launch it in the background and let it load into the main menu in the background because if you let it try to render the shaders as the active program it will immediately crash. 

I can't believe this was allowed to be sold in this condition. Being forced to be online for a single player game is still ridiculous. EA is awful. This game deserves better than this because when it isn't a buggy mess it's fun and the story is solid. 

If you're thinking about buying this, still don't. Wait for it to actually be fixed and completed.

5-23-23: This game is frustrating. The good parts are great, but it is not as much fun as the original so far. The technical issues have gotten a bit better since release but I am still randomly having single digit framerates during gameplay and cutscenes.

On top of that, the boss fights are generally lackluster. Currently in a super epic fight scene where everything is super dramatic and you know how it's going to go, but... you still have to work your way through a life bar, for no reason. Especially when it just dumps you back into the previous room with no options for leveling or improving your situation. You can only do this fight, with multiple cutscenes, from the beginning, with every single cutscene and QTE included with the same limited health bar and stimpaks. Didn't we leave this type of design behind 20+ years ago? 
Add in the fact that the technical issues plaguing this release are causing drops in frames to the single digits, making the precision defense and gameplay you must employ because of the limited nature of the fight, and you have an absolute recipe for disaster and a complete break in the natural flow of the game and story. I'm ready to just put this game down for the next few months because this isn't worth the frustration. Maybe It'll be better then and I can actually play and enjoy it then?

This game and series deserve better than this. This is just disappointing. Solid 4 out of 10 right now, rapidly dropping because of how disappointed I am.

Short and sweet of it is this: This game was released with too many technical issues and modern DRM measures that make it difficult to recommend at this time right out the gate. I am livid about this and am considering a refund while I wait for things to change. Overall the game is enjoyable outside of these issues and I was really looking forward to continuing to play, but the issues outside of the gameplay are just... well... indicative of AAA PC gaming in 2023.

ETA: Patch came in, game no longer loads. DO NOT BUY THIS. At least, not until they fix the performance issues. This is absolutely absurd and unacceptable. 

Long Version:

I am not running into a lot of the big issues that are making the headlines right now. I am experiencing mostly 60 FPS in 1900 x 1080 but with regular excursions down to as low as 20 FPS on a system running a Ryzen 9 5000 series with an RTX 3080 and 32 GB of RAM. A consistent 60 FPS at this resolution shouldn't be difficult to achieve. I've experienced multiple crashes, including a crash right when launching the game for the first time after installation.

These issues, I'm sure, will get smoothed out with time and if they were the only ones I could deal with it. PC gaming relies too much on patching broken product in the months following release, and that's not going to change. 

My real big issue is with the EA App being required to be installed and operating with an internet connection in order to even launch the game, and the requirement that the game must be updated to the latest version to play. A single player game with no multiplayer options, requires an internet connection, a separate app with its own log in, and I have no option to play the game offline if an update is pending?

I travel a lot for work. I am in places with absolute garbage for internet connections monday through friday. Right now as I write this review I am being forced to wait to download a rather large patch over awful hotel wifi that is going to take around 4 hours to complete. Which means I don't get to play this game this evening for what feels like no reason. Not what I want to be dealing with after a 10 hour travel day dealing with airports losing luggage on a non-stop flight.

This isn't the fault of Respawn, this is EA and we all know it. I would ask EA to do better, but we know they won't.

This is just what we come to expect from PC Gaming in 2023, and it's a sad state of affairs. 

Gameplay is enjoyable and is a great continuation of what Fallen Order set us up with. The story and voice acting so far have been fun and I really enjoy the exploration and combat. This game has potential and I really hope I get to actually play the rest of it.

I'm extremely conflicted on this one. Most negative reviews are about the performance issues, but I'm going to talk about the actual gameplay problems instead.

Fallen Order was a solid if somewhat hollow experience. It got all the little things right--the Star Wars flavor, the excellent cast, the well-paced story, and the exceptional production value--but it was let down by the nuts and bolts gameplay, which was trying to be a Dark Souls knockoff like every other game at the time.

In most ways, Respawn appears to have doubled down on both the positives and the negatives. The game looks stunning, especially the facial mocap (I've yet to see an alien as emotive and expressive as Greez in any other game), and the sound design is high quality. The visual design of the environments suffers a bit from that "Disney" look that the marvel and star wars movies both have these days--they really love that shimmering metal effect, as it's present everywhere both in this and in the GotG game. That's a matter of taste, though. I thought the main planet, Koboh, looked lovely, with verdant fields and dusty canyons aplenty. The sun-soaked desert of Jedha also looks quite nice, especially when a sandstorm rolls in.

However, looks aside, these semi-open worlds suffer from Ubisoft collectathon syndrome. There's tons of things to find, but almost none of them are worth exploring for. Typically you'll solve a puzzle or finish a difficult fight only to find a box with an ugly moustache in it. Or some paint colors for your robot buddy. 90% of the rewards in the game are cosmetics. The rest are useful but unexciting things like health and force meter upgrades. Every gameplay-changing piece of gear you get is obtained through the story, so taking time to go do sidequests is really only worthwhile if you want more shirts. Fortunately there are some pretty good shirts, and the customization is a lot better than in Fallen Order--it's not poncho city anymore.

There's plenty of platforming, and while none of it is very challenging--it largely follows the triple-A on-rails platforming conventions--it at least looks good and never overstays its welcome. Your aerial maneuverability feels great. Climbing is thankfully brief most of the time. There are several spectacular sequences where you have to leap through windy cliffs and dodge enemies.

Where things start to gradually fall apart is the combat system. Where the prior game was trying desperately to be dark souls, this one really wants to be God of War 2018. But it can't shake off the vestiges of the clunky, deliberately-paced Souls combat style. 

The majority of enemies have unblockable moves, and they like to spam them. Enemies don't take turns, so if you are fighting a group--which is almost always--then enemies can chain-spam unblockables and force you to either eat a bunch of hits or just back off with no way to deal damage. Crowd control options are weak and you don't even get the decent ones until very late in the game. The combat is designed around one-on-one saber duels, but the majority of fights are against upwards of three enemies. Like in Fallen Order, your lightsaber has been heavily nerfed, and it can take upwards of three unblocked hits to kill some basic enemies--and getting past their block can take another ten! You feel like you're fighting with a wiffle bat instead of a beam of plasma.

Yet even in the one-on-one fights where the combat should shine, problems plague the systems. The worst and most frustrating is the parry. The timings are actually quite generous, and an early or late press that would make you eat a hit in Sekiro will often act as though you parried precisely. The issue is that you can't animation cancel any of your moves (with one exception I'll discuss) into a block. This is a relic of the souls inspiration--you're committed to your attacks once you start them. However they all have huge windups, and enemies can hit you out of your attacks. This quickly turns into a shitshow because enemies can start up their own attacks after you begin yours, and hit you faster than you hit them. That means attacking at all feels completely random, and you will eat tons of damage just because the enemies decide to hit you out of a basic swing. Even more annoying, you can't parry every blaster bolt that comes at you (aside from another exception)--if you perfectly parry the first one, you're locked into a simple block animation for the rest that doesn't reflect the shots back. This means if you try to feather the button to reflect multiple shots, you will just get hit because the game thinks you've stopped blocking and you can't animation cancel the block into another parry.

What turns it from frustrating into enraging is that no enemies can be stunned out of their own hits. If an enemy starts winding up an attack and you cut in quickly to hit them, they'll simply complete the attack and bash you. Poise for me but not for thee is such an outrageous and disgusting combat model that I think it couldn't have been playtested heavily. There's no way anyone thinks it feels good. Hammering on the parry button only to watch your slow-ass attack get interrupted by an enemy who wasn't moving before you swung happens almost every fight.

The most baffling thing is that these problems are apparently intentional. The dual-wield stance DOES have animation canceling for the parry. I guess this is so that it feels unique? But locking a basic element of your combat system behind one of five stances is such an insane decision that again, I can't believe this was playtested. The multiple blaster parries thing is also "fixed" for the double-bladed stance, which will *automatically* parry multiple shots instead of blocking. It's like in a bid to make the stances feel more distinct, they wound up breaking the combat system for 4/5 of them in different ways. It's like if in DMC Dante could only start a juggle with one weapon, only do an aerial attack with another weapon, and only do a helm splitter with a third weapon--and you could only use two weapons at a time! Absolutely crazy. Play this with a mod to let you use all the stances, you'll have a somewhat less annoying time.

The combat is just broken on a fundamental level, and it really makes you appreciate how good the From Software games really are in this area. I hope for the third game, they really go back to basics and fix these issues. This could be a fast-paced, parry-heavy game that makes you feel like a god, instead of a clunky and slow clusterfuck that leaves you wondering what the devs were thinking.

The general difficulty is completely schizophrenic because of the busted combat. You'll cruise along for 2-3 hours having zero difficulty with fights only to come up against a wampa with trash hitboxes and a plethora of one-shot moves. The worst is a returning boss from the first game who was garbage there and is garbage here. Possibly one of the worst bosses ever designed. His whole appearance feels like a shitpost. I started on Jedi Grandmaster difficulty and got sick of the constant one-shots and broken parry, so I turned it down to Jedi Master and had a much better time. Not because the combat improved, but because I had enough health to just tank the inevitable hits and suck down heals in longer fights.

I really want to love this game. It does all the non-gameplay parts so right that it hurts when the combat and exploration let it down so badly. And the issues are fixable! Hell, they're probably even *patchable*. The whole thing doesn't need a redesign, just some tweaks and the addition of animation canceling. I don't have any hope for this one being fixed, but maybe the next one?

While I can't in good conscience give this a thumbs up because of these issues, I will still probably buy the third game. I like the story and characters, and it was starting to do some interesting stuff right before it abruptly ended. I just hope they fix the combat.

Overall, this game is a big step up from Fallen Order. The combat, exploration, and customization are all better, and there's just more things to do in general. HOWEVER, even on a fairly high-end PC such as mine with a NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050 graphics card, well over the recommended, the stuttering and lag is downright unbearable. This game was delayed six weeks for the sole purpose of polish and fixing technical issues, and it's been [strike] three [/strike] [strike] four [/strike] [strike] five [/strike] [strike] six [/strike] seven months since release. HOW IS THIS GAME STILL BROKEN.

I'd like to preface this by saying I only started playing the game ~7 months after the initial release.  The majority of the performance issues plaguing the initial launch are resolved at this time. While there are still some locations where I experience frame drops (holotable), the overall content doesn't have any issues. I'm certainly not excusing the terrible launch state, and I'm not supporting this new trend of releasing undercooked games, but I'm not going to be taking the performance issues into account in my review. If anything, the issues should just be a reminder to us consumers that we shouldn't buy content without properly vetting what we're receiving. 

As for the actual game, I loved it. This is a very well executed sequel to an already spectacular title. I thoroughly enjoyed the story, and this is coming from someone who isn't even a Star Wars fan. The lightsaber combat is satisfying, and the new "stances" system provides a good amount of variety. There are a wide range of new features and general improvements from the last title which just make the experience more pleasant across the board. One particular new feature I like is that the map has the ability to "guide" you to the main objective. Definitely a nice QOL addition. 

I got this game on sale, and I'm definitely happy with the purchase. Obviously, do your own research before buying, there's plenty of videos on YouTube to look at. While I enjoyed the title, everyone has their own preferences, and somethings that are non-issues to me, might be dealbreakers for you.

I hope this review helps. Have a nice day!

UPDATE - After completion of the story and much of the side content
Yeah, the tech issues not only never got resolved, they got worse with multiple crashes in play session and even one crash that required me to restart my computer. The gameplay wasn't much better and has become overly obsessed with the platforming that was handled much better in the first title. It's a constant chore going through the levels, often multiple times in the story. There are strings of wire sliding, jumps, wall runs, grabbing ropes,etc and they're all tied together meaning you'll be doing them over and over to get past them and it grinds all the forward momentum of the story to a halt. As for the story, it's okay. It folds in elements of the High Republic era along with the Age of Rebellion and I admit I found myself much more interested in the High Republic era than I thought I ever would be. The thing is that the game ends right where it feels the story is at a half way point. There is also obviously a DLC that was cancelled because there are blacked out planets on the map that never get revealed. It was a decent story, but I feel like I only got part of it. If the developers cared enough to deal with the technical issues of this game, I'd recommend it. Obviously after this long they clearly aren't going to and that speaks volumes to their character. All this is such a shame after the first game brought the single player Star Wars experience back from the dead. I hope that they take the time and care to prevent this for the third entry. This is still a downvote for me. The constant technical issues and over reliance on timing action made it a chore to play and I had to step away at times just out of pure frustration. That's not my idea of entertainment.

Performance was fine-ISH for me. What really sucked eggs was the combat. You'll have an unblockable attack coming simultaneous to two regular attacks you're trying to parry, all the while trying to avoid blaster fire from ranged enemies, all while you're trying to land a single hit where 4 of the 5 stances you'll unlock have un-cancellable attack animations. Attack windup, furthermore, is so slow, and the range of the lightsabers in most stances is perplexingly short. Arkham combat nailed group fights, because the game made certain that you were never in a situation where too many enemies were coming at you at once, and Batman could cover HUGE distances with single attacks. In Jedi Survivor, you'll be hit halfway through most of your attacks by enemies who start attacking AFTER you did, and you can't manage because EVERY enemy runs DIRECTLY toward you to stand within FEET of you and attack at the same time. Most enemies will take 5-6 standard hits on the Jedi Knight difficulty - you know, 5-6 hits from a lightsaber? The fantastical laser Excalibur? I know different stances are more or less ideal for different situations, but you can only have 2 to change between at a time, and can only swap those 2 for other stances at meditation points. I'm sure there's a reasonable and logical technical explanation as to why they COULDN'T just have all stances available to change between in some kind of radical radial menu (you know, like other games with more than 2 weapons), because the idea that they CHOSE not to is too baffling to be true.
If you want to forgo the lightsaber and utilise the many Force abilities, you'll be faced with a whole new set of problems. You just won't have the time to use any in group fights because, again, they take time and you will be SWARMED. My go-to strategies generally became standing atop ledges and using Confusion and BD's electric shock to turn enemies on each other - this means the game is more viable and less frustrating when it's playing itself.
One-on-one, specifically with saber-wielding enemies, it's stunning. I finished a lot of boss fights with a huge smile on my face. But when boss fights are 1% of your game, and the other 99% is bad combat and slow, laborious exploration, it isn't nearly enough.
In Star Wars, lightsaber fights were thrilling in part due to their simplicity: two sworn enemies would duel to the death with laser swords. When you think about lightsaber fights in all the Star Wars movies, they'll more often than not boil down to just that. Respawn chocked this game's combat so full of stuff. They could have gone simple, and made it excellent, but they made it complex, and none of it works.
If everything I'm saying makes you think "It doesn't sound impossible, it sounds challenging", and if that's your thing, then great, and I'm not going to say you're wrong. But I will warn you that it just isn't fun.
The lightsaber doesn't feel like a lightsaber, the Force doesn't feel like the Force.
imho, play/replay Fallen Order. In Jedi Survivor you just won't feel like a Jedi.

This game is the absolute buggiest and most frustrating thing i have ever played in my life. This game is amazing, and i love almost everything about it, and everything is an upgrade from the original game. But dear fuck this game is the worst experience on a PC game i have ever had. The steam release is unfinished, Laggy, crash prone, and at times unplayable. 

I was so unbelievably excited for this game, and i adored fallen order. i gave this game all of my patience now, and i want to save you all the anger i went through with this crap.
I have a good graphics card, and this game crashes every. single. game session. this game has absolutely worn my patience, imagine playing for an entire hour and having the time of your life, and putting up with the stuttering and the lag, then it crashing and you needing to start over from the absolute beginning. this game is **NOT WORTH 70 DOLLARS.** 
I once played the same level quite literally, 6 times because it kept crashing. each time getting worse for my mental attitude towards this game. (if you have played darksouls or any souls game, you can imagine how detrimental a lag in a bossfight or any fight for that matter will ruin your game, this happens all the time.

the cutscenes will lag and crash during what would be the most tense part of the story and you dont and cannot see whats going on, and after it's over (given it doesn't crash), you will be lost and the magic of the scene is gone. on top of that, my controller sometimes won't connect to the game, not the computer, the game, it works on other games, just not this one, and you cannot play this game correctly without a controller.

you should play this game on PS5 or XBOX, if you loved the original fallen order, this game is great for you. the maps are gigantic, the graphics are beautiful, and the little tiny details MWAH, like different color lightsabers making different sounds, MWAH, you can CHOOSE your own lightsaber fighting style! UGH AMAZING, and the story *unlike the first one* can actually be played out because you dont know (unlike the first one) whats going to happen in the end.

Don't buy this on steam, it absolutely blows, i am not kidding you, don't buy this, even if you have the greatest computer in the world, it will not play properly, it is ***NOT*** ready for PC. what sucks is that it is better than it was when it was first released, and it's still unplayable. Buy it on a console so you can actually play the goddamn game.

Don't give your money to EA for this unfinished garbage port of an awesome game.

TLDR: fantastic game GARBAGE port, unplayable mess due to unoptimization don't waste 70 DOLLARS and DEFINITELY not 90 DOLLARS on something you cannot play.

As The Sequel To STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ It Does Have A Certain Bar It Had To Jump Over, And It Did Indeed Clear That Bar. Thankfully It Didn't Fall Into The Hole That Certain Sequels Do Where The Main Character Suddenly Has All Of Their Skills Reset And Proceeds To Just Throw The Old Skill Tree At You Again With Extra Steps. Plus Making Some Of The Maps Of This Game Open World As Opposed To The More Linear Design Of The Previous Title Allows For The Collectible Aspect Of The Game To Feel A Little Less Tedious. However, While They Provided Some Better Quality Of Life Improvements To The Game, Other Aspects Of The Game Did Fall Short On Delivery. That's Not Saying That The Game Was Ruined By This, Only That It Could've Used A Little More Work And Polish. Things Such As Some Of The Animations Feeling Very Choppy And How Most Of The Stances With The Lightsabers Tend To Handle Fairly Identically Thus Making It More Of A Visual Preference Rather Than Being Different Ways To Play The Game. As I Said, Doesn't Ruin The Game, Just Needs A Little More Polish. All In All, I Can Whole Heatedly Recommend This Game Faults In All With The Only Warning Being That You'll Definitely Need A Modern Computer As The Game Is Not Well Optimized For Older Computers In The Slightest.

It just won't stop crashing. Despite having a 7800 X3D, 7900 XT, 64 GB RAM and the other specs are similarly high end.

"Optimizing files" every launch. Optimizing [i]what[/i] files?

Frequent micro stuttering & pop-in. For funsies I tried turning the graphics down to the absolute minimum, and resolution to 1600x900, and still experience this.

Combat mechanics are "mushy". The timings for block/parry are way off. There's a long wind up in all attack animations before damage is registered, no iframes, and no animation canceling. This makes Cal feel heavy and sloppy. A huge letdown from the light and precise Jedi we had in Fallen Order. But, every single hit taken staggers Cal. A lot. All you can do if you get hit is hope the enemies will have a break in their attacks so you can stand up, then hope the BD stim heals you before the next hit taken, Since you definitely won't get the time to block or dodge the next incoming attack and you can't animation cancel into avoiding the hit.

Incoming damage is the only real challenge to any of the fights. Taking a single hit is incredibly punishing, and going up or down in difficulty doesn't really change the damage very much, aside from story mode. The damage breakdown is roughly Grand Master (100%), Master (95%), Knight (90%), Padawan (85%), Story Mode (5%). Parry timing and enemy aggression are the same - no real difference unless you drop to story mode, in which case the parry timing is still really strange. And enemy aggression is basically "a bunch of guys in storm trooper cosplay circling menacingly without shooting because blasters aren't real."

I bought this the first day it came out despite the bad reviews due to performance.  I figured I would be able to refund it if I had any problems.  I got pretty lucky because it ran adequately after Coruscant and I very enjoyed the game and the story.
My wife got into these games and so after beating Fallen Order she wanted to play the next one.  We started in November and dang, it runs pretty good - - that is, if you have DLSS enabled.  If you don't have DLSS enabled, it's still runs pretty awful.  I have a 3080 with a 5600X - -  without DLSS, it is below 60 fps and stutters a lot on 4K, but with it on, I'm getting a solid 80-90 fps in the world and even higher in caves/enclosed spaces on 4K.  So if you have DLSS-capable hardware, you should be on your way.
Story-wise and combat mechanics, the game handily improves in just about every aspect.  I absolutely loved this game!  I would recommend this to everyone who liked the first one - - you won't be disappointed.
