I love this first one on PS4... So happy I can use my PS4 computer on Steam and play this new one. Lots of memories and FEELS on the pace and play. Big Thumbs up and I just started... and I LOVE that this is canon to the new Dave Filoni good stuff!

so far so good, seven-ish hours in and have only had two stutters but they have never come at crucial moments i.e. during combat or while performing precise jumps and traversal, however unlike any other game I have ever bought and download Jedi Survivor is a motherfucker to download, idk what it is, if it has to do with EA's servers or what but it took one and a half business days to download, granted my internet is not amazing but I've got a couple games of comparable size and they've all downloaded reasonably quickly, Jedi Survivor took like 15 hours or somewhere around there.

that being said: the game is a massive upgrade from the first in every way it matters, exploration has been vastly expanded and there are TONS of nooks to go hunting for all sorts of treasures within, combat is much the same as the first game with an impressive amount of expanse enabling you to really carve out your own niche style of fighting and as far as I can tell, there are still even more talent trees to be unlocked.
the open world is H U G E and beautiful and just wills you on to keep looking to see what is around the next bend, cave or building.

I'm running an NVIDIA GTX 4060 and a RYZEN 5600x cpu and haven't had any actual issues worth complaining about, however my tolerance for stuff like pop in and textures taking a second to load is quite high, however for what it is worth, I've not actually noticed much of either and the game's been running at a solid & consistent 60+ fps.I will say however the AI (mostly the fauna of Koboh) has some moments where it just acts really goofy, much like the first game if you are just outside of an animals preferred arena they'll start almost pacing back in and out of their preferred fighting area until you get back within the confines they'd most like to fight you in, the spiders of Kashyyk from Fallen Order did the same thing iirc, not a huge deal but does impact immersion.
I'm not actually far enough in to even begin to actually understand what this game fully intends to be or is, however, as a review based off of initial impressions; it is really quite exceptional, I understand the game had some serious performance issues and I understand how disappointing that must have been, especially for a title that oozes as much potential, promise and excitement as the Cal Kestis games.

idk about anyone but after falling in love with Fallen Order my excitement for the story these games are telling skyrocketed and hearing/seeing how broken the game could be both at launch and six months afterwards was rather disappointing, there is no good reason why it'd of taken as long as it did to resolve these issues, however I'd also point out it isn't like Fallen Order is a perfectly performing game either, still to this day it has a fare share of performance issues and I'm not saying this to excuse the state both games launched in, mostly just making sure new comers to the series understand what they're getting into.
amazing games but they can unfortunately often times be quite problematic.

I'll update this review once I've beaten the game and seen/done everything I've wanted to, but so far, yeah I would recommend giving it a try (especially if it is on sale as its full price is incredibly steep) doubly so if you've felt the latest Disney content to be rather lacking, Cal's story really does hit all the notes of a good and well thought out star wars saga.

Update: since writing this initial review I've since beat the game twice & jesus, what a sequel Jedi Survivor is, not only have Respawn doubled down on the movement based exploration mechanics, they absolutely blew it out of the park, refined movement and expanded mid air mechanics that enable the player to close massive gaps while maintaining tons of momentum, BD-1 being an absolutely essential tool for exploration as well as a much needed friend, not to mention he also has some very helpful tools for combat.
which you will often need because not only are there a bunch of rumours to go investigate that can be overheard in the Reach, there are also a bunch of different interesting and lovely side characters to discover, it's just a shame that more wasn't done with them and that they didn't get as much focus as I felt they deserved.
as for the new stances I loved and used them all pretty extensively aside from the blaster stance, some people say it is one of if not the most powerful stance in the game and I can't help but disagree, there is a blaster parry ability that is quite strong but I never once managed to find a situation in which I felt that it'd be easier to make it through a section with it, mainly down to how unattractive and I think neutered the moveset is, the added range and ability to stun targets does nothing for you when the range you have to keep in order for it to be usable are too great to get follow up lightsaber strikes in.
honestly it felt a bit under-baked. the four other stances however, especially crossguard are exceptionally well done and crossguard on it's own is almost a mandatory thing for two of the most important boss fights in the game.

I won't spoil the story but I loved it except for some specific things towards the end, and, that I wish it could have gone a bit further in depth into a certain friends back story, don't get me wrong the story, just like the game, are far from perfect and there definitely are some things that obviously could have been done better, still an 8.5-9/10 game, I just wish one specific character got more explanation.

as for performance, I had two crashes, one playing holotactics and the other after landing a double jump onto an elevator.
the game runs well and I've got a RTX 4060 & an AMD 5600x cpu, however without running DLSS it would stutter ever so slightly when running into a new area or when the camera would pan towards a grand, awe-inspiring shot of whatever natural/man-made marvel it is you're going to investigate, it never should have launched in the state is was in though and for that I'd have to bring my scoring of the game to an 8 max.
why EA feels it is acceptable to launch games in that state I will never know, as said before fallen order had and still has many of the same issues as jedi survivor and had an equally rough release, they'd (as in EA and Respawn) would get so much more positive press if they'd just release a genuinely functional game, especially when it is as highly anticipated as this one.

if it's on sale, it is a no brainer, even if it isn't on sale the game is still worth it however I do understand why someone would chose another title and hold off to grab it at a discount.
Despite the poor performance, I have to say this game is truly the closest I have ever felt to a real jedi knight. If you're a fan of star wars, it's a must have.

Its a great game for as long as I'm able to play it....Can play for maybe an hour or so before I run out of video memory and it crashes. Pretty ridiculous using a RTX 3090 and running out of VM? BS! Until the memory leaks is addressed I wouldn't bother. Its really frustrating playing for 30 to 45 minutes out of a rest point and it crashing.

Ryzen 7 58003DX, RTX 2070, 16GB RAM. Acquired the game while on discount + bundle discount (made it half off since I already own Fallen Order)

Was able to play on default settings (High, no raytracing, no vsync) with no stuttering and no framerate issues for about 24 hours. As soon I get to the part where you gotta go back to the "haunted moon" again, the game has absolutely horrendous stuttering, to the point I can't fight a small squad of B1's. No settings had been changed beforehand and new upgrades were acquired several hours before the issue started occurring. Rebooted PC, installed fresh updates, reinstalled graphics drivers, tweaked nVidia control panel settings for the game, installed the Nexus mod to increase performance, set everything to low and prioritized max performance, and even fucked my hz and framerate to try to line up with 30 fps, but none of those things worked. 

I've gone through like 2 hours of ingame time of just logging in, checking to see if *anything* improved, and changing another thing that *might* help alleviate the issues, but I feel like EA absolutely lied about their PC spec requirements for this game. It might be able to run with those specs initially, but there's something seriously wrong with the game still if all of a sudden it becomes unplayable. How are people supposed to finish the game if it suddenly loses its marbles halfway through the story progression?

This game still isn‚Äôt fixed. 

For around 20 hours I was having a pretty good experience running on a 4070 and a Ryzen 5 5600x. The occasional frame drop would happen but nothing that made me want to put the game down. That is until I returned from shattered moon to Koboh for the second time.

 No matter what I do now, the game freezes every couple seconds. Sometimes it‚Äôll stay frozen for 10 seconds, other times for half a second.

I updated drivers, did a clean re install of the game and the ea app, checked my device for issues, and nothing helped. 

Other games are running perfectly fine. I can run Cyberpunk at 90+ FPS with the settings all the way up and RTX on. 

Do not buy this game until you are sure these kinds of issues aren‚Äôt present anymore. I got the game for almost half off and still feel scammed.

Star Wars: Jedi Survivor is a fantastic sequel to the great Fallen Order.

Cal is no longer afraid of who he is and wants to help rebuild the Jedi order but there is a lot of work to be done and a lot of people in his way.

Sadly a poor launch filled with really bad optimization and a lot of bugs might have scared some people off from trying this game again but I can tell you it's definitely worth it now. It's still a hard game to run and you will encounter small bugs from time to time like enemies clipping through the ground or wall but nothing game breaking and thankfully I didn't encounter any problems during the "bigger" moments of the game.

Its story goes through all the emotions with you and ultimately is a great successor to Fallen Order. Your crew, the villains, enemies, lore, planets, and so much more will have your days turning to nights irl in no time. You can get lost just looking at the beauty this game holds, I've never taken so many in game screenshots before but some of the views in this game just blow you away, and I'm not talking cutscenes or photo mode stuff, literally just walking around you'll stop and go "holy crap, this is beautiful" out loud.

The soundtrack needs no long sentence, it's Star Wars, it delivers. You won't be hearing too many themes from the original movies which I actually didn't mind before this isn't those movies, this is a new character, a new time, and a new story. That said, listen closely in big moments and you might catch a thing or two.

My favorite part about Jedi Survivor as a sequel is the planets. In Fallen Order I felt that the planets weren't well made, they weren't made for you to explore instead to just move along the main story. In this game it isn't like that at all. Between collectables, side missions, lore, beauty, and much more the main planets are massive with so much to do and explore. 

As well the additions to customization and the combat were also well done. I won't spoil what they are, for that you'll have to play, explore, and defeat some enemies.

From gaining new perks, powers, and strengths as Cal and shedding some tears in the story to meeting new friends and seeing some old ones along the way, this was a great sequel that I couldn't have enjoyed more through my 65 hours and basically 100% completion.

I highly recommend this game if you like Star Wars, open world/action-adventure games, liked Fallen Order, or just want to be a Jedi.

Game wont launch do not buy. Just wont start click play and nothing happens. Played a few times have to find another way to open game every time and now doesnt load anymore.

About five hours into the game and it has crashed at least equally the same amount of times.

Now it is not fair to this game to give it a negative review in a way, because it is great, from a game play perspective. But considering how unstable it is, and the amount of time it takes to "optimize" every time you boot it up... It's clearly not doing a good job of it. It's Unreal engine so I'm guessing it's simply pre-caching here but every single time?! and without changing any drivers.

First time it crashed was during the introduction so it ended up with me having to go through all the pre-settings of HDR and RTX effects etc. Now I am going to mention here, that I have Ray Tracing ON, and run with HDR and these things MAY be what causes it to be so unstable.

But the simple fact that this is a game that you cannot save at will, you will need to reach a save point to do so, if it crashes constantly just because it's so unstable and so often, makes it nearly unplayable on PC.

It's a pity, because it is otherwise a fantastic game and a sequel to Fallen Order in about 500% more massive scale.

Usually don't leave reviews for games but figured since the dodgy start and the subsequent patches may as well give my two cents about how the patches have helped.

This was the game I was looking forward to most this year. My heart sank a little bit when I woke up on release day and saw the terrible reviews due to performance.

I decided to hold off buying until I saw some more stability checking in with the recent reviews with each patch. Bought the game a few months later but didn't bother playing it until 7.5 patch in which the reviews seem a bit more favourable.

I don't have insane specs. In fact I play on a razer laptop with a 3070 so not even the fully powered one. For these type of games I tend to use my old steam link and play in my living room which has 1080p/60 fps cap. The TV upscales to 4k.

I was pleasantly surprised. I had a pretty much a solid 60 fps with some occasional exceptions like overseeing the entirety of the main area of Kobho when you first arrive. There were the occasional game play problems but completely live with-able. These issues were

For some reason when using the holodeck to select a planet to travel to my frames dropped to like 10-15. I was fine with this since its only used for a few seconds at a time to travel.

Occasionally when playing a force echo in which the characters appear, it would only render their hair for some reason. Dialogue was fine though.

Sometimes I would try to access BD mode to use a dart to open a door to proceed but it would not let me as it bugged out and thought I was in combat when I was not and was certain no one was about. This was my main annoyance as I had no other way other than throwing myself off a cliff so I'd re-spawn. After this it worked fine but at times with lower health and no stims left a bit of a pain.

Only a couple of occasions, the game would randomly for some reason change to a small resolution. Not sure if this was the game or just my computer acting up but haven't experienced it in any other game.

But overall once I got past those problems I really enjoyed the game. Combat was fun and really enjoyed the story. Wouid recommend overall now and hopefully will still see improvements as patches come out.

The entire time that I played this game, I struggled with whether or not I would recommend it. Reading the other reviews of this title, I find that many of the positive reviews claim that you will enjoy this game if you enjoyed the previous title, Jedi: Fallen Order. While, many of the negative reviews focus on technical difficulties. I very much enjoyed Jedi: Fallen Order and my computer suffered only minor technical problems, nothing beyond what I would expect from a modern AAA title. I cannot recommend this game because the story is bad, the characters are poorly written, and the collections are egregious. This game took everything that I enjoyed about Jedi: Fallen Order and gave into corporate greed, the story and flow of the game is completely ruined by the, roughly 1000, collectibles scattered throughout the game world that consistently destroy the pacing of the story. Without going into spoilers, the entire third act of the story was completely ruined when I had to stop playing the story to backtrack across all the previous levels to make sure I had found every random piece of trash that the game dictated that I find, from fish, to rocks and scraps of paper, truly a quest for a Jedi Knight battling the most powerful Sith in the galaxy. I wouldn't recommend this game at full price, if you are a die-hard Star Wars fanatic, you probably already bought the game, but, if you haven't, save yourself the cash and go watch Empire Strikes Back, they ripped off the movies whole plot anyway.

I'm loving this game. Been waiting to get it since I heard it was coming out, spent about $40 when I finally saw it on sale, and I don't regret it. The story picks up a few years after the events of Fallen Order, but the gameplay feels like it picks up right where the last one left off. Some people are complaining that it didn't change much from the first one, and they're kind of right, but I don't understand why that bothers them. It's pretty much exactly what I wanted. Huge plus for me is the upgraded customization abilities! If you enjoyed Fallen Order, you will absolutely enjoy this!
Honestly, this is how you do a sequel. Everything from JFO 10x. Awesome game, highly recommend.

This game is some of the most fun I've ever had in a video game, but unfortunately I cant play it because it causes my CPU (liquid-cooled i7-12700k) to overheat after about an hour of play. No other game has ever made my cpu reach temperatures like I'm seeing here (90-100 Celsius), and I'm afraid to play further as those temps are likely to damage my PC. Fix the performance issues and I will gladly change my review, as I truly think this game is the best use of the Star Wars IP in years.

[b]UPDATE:[/b]
They mostly fixed the poor performance and bugginess, so I'm changing my review to a recommend. This in no way excuses the state of the release of this game, which I think was an abhorrent and very anti-consumer decision in an industry where public opinion can make or break your game's success. Given the popularity of the Star Wars IP, and the fact that this is a sequel to an established and successful game, AND that the gameplay itself is so incredible, there is no doubt that a delay would have effected this game's success. In fact I think a delay would have made this game wildly more popular than it already is. Games that release complete are games that people can love immediately, but this game will have a tarnished reputation forever. At least it's a playable experience now.

[h1]Significant Improvement over Fallen Order[/h1]

Star Wars Jedi: Survivor feels like a significant improvement of Jedi: Fallen Order in almost every way, and a majority of issues I had with Fallen Order I didn't not experience in Survivor. 
[list]
[*]The controls and combat have been significantly smoothed out and feel far more natural and responsive. 
[*]Cal's new abilities complement the gameplay without forcing you to play in a certain way. 
[*]Movement felt smoother and some new movement options were cool.
[*]And the over use of creatures and animals as enemies (that really pissed me off) in Fallen Order was significantly reduced.
[*]To name a few.
[/list]

[h2]Story[/h2]
The story in Jedi: Survivor is up there as one of my favourite stories in a video game with the likes of Red Dead Redemption 2, Titanfall 2, and Cyberpunk: 2077. The story in Fallen Order was already really good and Respawn just turned the dial up to 11 with the writing. There's nothing much else to say about the story other than that it was excellent, exciting, and extremely well written. The writers deserve a huge bonus.

[h2]Combat[/h2]
As mentioned, I felt as though the combat was much better in Survivor compared to Fallen Order; everything felt smoother and more responsive, and I felt even more badass than in the previous game. To be honest, I didn't really care much for Cal's new lightsaber stances, I mostly used single blade, dual wield, and the double-sided blade only and didn't think the other stances were very exciting. However, I can see where people will have fun with a more diverse range of combat styles compared to Fallen Order and it was still fun none-the-less.

[h2]Exploration[/h2]
Although Jedi: Survivor is a far bigger game than Jedi: Fallen Order, I felt somewhat underwhelmed by the exploration in Survivor compared to its predecessor. Don't get me wrong, the planets are so cool and Kaboh could almost be an open-world game in itself, but I felt as though a lot of the planets felt the same compared to the diverse range of planets in Fallen Order like Kashyyyk and Dathomir. Regardless, the planets in the game are still fun to explore and there are so many hidden treats throughout them.

[h2]PC Optimisation[/h2]
I purchased this game in November, 2023 when most of the significant PC optimisation bugs where squashed. For reference, I am running an i9 11900K, RTX 3080, and 32GB of RAM and faced no game crashes or freezes during my entire gameplay. I ran the game at 1440p on high settings (V-SYNC on, DLSS off) and achieved a framerate of about 65 - 80fps with dips below 65 being somewhat common. Micro-stutters and little freezes were very common though with the game often stuttering or lagging whenever I entered a new room or had to render a different part of the map, however, this didn't impact my gameplay too significantly, but your preferences for game smoothness may be different to mine.

[h2]Summary (written by ChatGPT)[/h2]
Star Wars Jedi: Survivor improves upon Jedi: Fallen Order in various aspects. Controls and combat are smoother and more responsive, addressing previous issues. New abilities enhance gameplay without restricting play style. Movement is enhanced with cool options. The overuse of creatures as enemies is notably reduced. The story rivals top games, marked by excellent writing. Combat in Survivor feels superior, with enhanced smoothness and responsiveness. The expanded game size, despite impressive, slightly underwhelms in exploration compared to Fallen Order. PC optimisation, experienced on a high-end system, showed minimal issues, with occasional micro-stutters. Overall, Survivor excels in gameplay, story, and combat.

Can't tell much about what others said about Jedi Survivor, but I can say that ‚Äúfrom a certain point of view‚Äù (Ah, get it? The short stories From a Certain Point of View).

From a story-wise perspective there's nothing much to say, a nearly perfect sequel to Fallen Order which includes things about the new canon and the High Republic Era (if you don't know about that check it out, you will not get disappointed). Yes, they could have been more creative about the incipit of the story, but it's not really a problem.
Obviously being the middle title in a trilogy it's a build up for the third chapter, and you can notice that especially towards the end.

Gameplay-wise it's far more action oriented than the predecessor with more lightsaber stances and Force powers. It has more fast-paced combat while still maintaining the derivations from Sekiro and its identity. Better and iconic boss fights with totally differents and fun movesets. It also contains more metroidvania moments and has a small but ideal number of ‚Äúsmall‚Äù planets and a HUGE main planet (I think it's big like all of Fallen Order)

While it's a really bad porting, they tried improving it (even if when I tried every patch it never changed anything so idk) it will be a real shame to miss this game, the best in the Disney Star Wars era (duh, looking at you Battlefront) and probably one of the best across the franchise (At least top 5, KOTOR and Dark Forces will always be better).
At least give it a try and if you don't feel it's right for you request a refund, you will not lose anything.

A lot of the performance issues seem to be fixed although in open areas there are slow downs and frame drops. 

I'm still encountering small bugs like the charged shot not always working and the EA launcher breaking stopping me from running the game without reinstalling it.

If these issues were fixed the game would be incredibly good. It expands on all the elements of the first game in good ways, and your power carries on from the first game. This means you feel more like a Jedi with powers like force push and pull from the start. The story is also one of the best I've seen in a star wars game.

I still have a few small gripes with how they script the climbing and restrict movement in some areas. The combat feels better but it still occasionally has weird timing on parries and attacks too.

Overall a fun game that is absolutely worth playing but with the bugs and performance issues I would not buy it at the ¬£60 it currently is a full price. It is worth it if you can get it on sale though.

I would highly recommend not buying this game unless you are certain that you enjoy the play style of games like Dark Souls.  Jedi: Survivor borrows a lot from Dark Souls frustrating combat system without taking any of the elements of Dark Souls that made it somewhat enjoyable to a non-niche consumer.

This game is frustrating.  If you get frustrated with Dark Souls, you will get frustrated with this game.  If you do not think Dark Souls is fun, you will likely not think this game is fun.  It has a definitively not fun play style.  Unfortunately, they slapped a pretty sweet Star Wars skin over it so it is fairly hard to resist, especially in a market where there are no good Star Wars games being made and EA has a monopoly on Star Wars content.  Thank you dear baby Jesus for taking away EA's exclusivity, may the future be brighter.

The story itself is good, the level design is unbelievably good, the graphics are great if your PC runs it, and it has a new game plus mode which I always love, but this is all shit on by the Dark Souls like combat that really makes it not fun.  If you are hoping for a revival of the old Jedi Knight (Outcast, Jedi Academy) games, this is not it, do not buy this game with hopes that you will have an experience as amazing as those games, you will be extremely disappointed.

If you absolutely must buy this game because it is Star Wars, wait for a deep discount.  IMO this game is probably an okay purchase for $20, for this price I think you have a chance of enjoying this game even if you completely hate the core game-play loop.  

For those of you who are unaware of the Dark Souls combat system and why some people do not think it is fun I will summarize here.
1) The controls are not tight, the characters movement feels sloppy.  It is more akin to guiding the character vs controlling the character.
2) You can hit enemies as many times as you want with your light saber, it does not stun them.  Most enemies have attacks that are faster than your most basic combos, so the combos are really kind of pointless.  You have a few attacks that can stun some enemies, but using those attacks generally leaves you completely open to attacks for a long time.  
3) Every hit stuns you.  You cannot control your stun recovery.  If you get hit, every enemy on screen can still hit you while you are stunned, there is no limit to how many times you can be hit.
4) The counter system is cool in 1-on-1 combat scenarios, however if you miss a single block, the enemies stun gauge resets.  If you do stun an enemy, they will recover after the first hit in your combo and if you started the second attack in the combo, they will hit you and you will be stunned.  Every time.
5) You cannot cancel any attacks that have begun.  So in a game that is built around countering and dwindling down enemy guard meters, you are best left dodging and doing a single quick attack.   Stepping back.  Dodging, single quick attack.  Rinse repeat till credits roll.

Some people like combat such as this, but to consider the Dark Souls play style to be anything other than niche, is just not being honest.

TlDR: It hasn't failed as a sequel to an awesome game, but Jedi Survivor needs to optimize its gameplay.

STORY:

We basically got what we wanted: an interesting continuation of Cal's journey 5 years after the events of Fallen Order. No spoilers here, as you have to experience it yourself and then rate it. I give the story an 8/10.


PLATFORMING AND MOVEMENT:

Huge improvement. Travelling around the map is alot easier than Fallen Order's. The verticality may be confusing sometimes, as some objectives blend in or may require you to go a very specific path to reach places. Same thing, no spoilers. It's 10/10


COMBAT:

The difficulty of this game is 3x harder than Jedi Fallen Order's. Enemy attacks are unintuitive and sometimes hard to read. For a souls-like game it's a good thing though. We have 5 different combat styles and all are universally good for specific situations, and you can change them to fit your current needs. I did my first playthrough on Grandmaster difficulty, and this time it really requires Sekiro level of concentration, except the enemies have almost no set rythm when fighting them, making it a pain dealing with especially droids. 7/10 for me, as some parts of the story were almost impossible on the highest difficulty.


CUSTOMIZATION:

A big improvement, as in Fallen Oder you could only customize the poncho and cal's scrapper outfit color. Here, we have many different outfit sets, and most of them look good. You can change Cal's hair and beard now aswell, and also have more customization options, like changing how polished your lightsaber is, or color specific parts of your saber to a different color. They definitely listened to the feedback regarding this section. 10/10


GRAPHICS:

Optimization aside, if you play on mostly highest settings, the game looks stunning. I played on an RTX 3070 Ti paired with i5 10400f on 1440p with high settings. The fps were acceptable; stable 47-70 fps. Ignoring optimization, this gets a 10/10. If we take the fps drops into account though, I would give it a 7/10.


OVERALL RATING

I give Jedi: Survivor a 9/10. It exceeded my expectations, since not many games deliver a good sequel. I recommend the game, but not for 60$. Wait until a sale drops, then buy it. You won't regret it.

At release this game was a hot mess, see below, unplayable. Consequently a huge disappointment and I reluctantly got a refund on a game I had been looking forward to immensely.

Time has passed so I thought I would give it another go and can report that as of today and patch 7 I have been having a blast. Performance is much improved, the introduction of DLSS a godsend. It's not perfect but looking back neither was Fallen Order.


Old...

This is frankly awful. From the first stuttering logo you are presented with a warning that it runs better with a controller - and yes using the keyboard sucks, for a start dodge is bound to TAB that only someone with 3 hands could use in conjunction with the ASAD keys, and yes using a mouse also sucks because there appears to be some kind of acceleration or smoothing applied which cannot be turned off and mouse sensitivity also changes depending on whats going on on screen (though this may just be the tanking frame rate). The menus cannot be navigated properly with just a mouse - where players are forced to select options with the mouse and then use key combos to change the options and apply them. Trying to use the in game map is also a nightmare because again the controls are completely unintuitive (have any of the devs ever used a mouse and keyboard?) 

Once in game the performance tanks, I thought I would be on the safe side and start with medium settings all around but even with that and a 2080 super, an 8 core cpu, 3000MB/sec SSD and 32GB RAM it was a bit of a slide show. FSR does not work either, and regardless of what settings are applied the overall image is extremely soft. As you probably know there is no DLSS, using Nvidias in built driver image scaling does however work, just, but not enough to make the game enjoyably playable.

As a fan of the first game this is hugely disappointing to say the least, I have been waiting for this release eagerly and am honestly thinking about getting a refund, regardless of whether or not they patch it to work.

Do yourself a favour don't buy this game for a long long time and get it in a galaxy far far away where someone gives a s""t about the content they put out.

Star Wars Jedi Survivor is a masterpiece that effortlessly immerses you in the expansive Star Wars universe like never before. From the breathtaking landscapes to the heart-pounding action sequences, this game flawlessly captures the essence of what makes Star Wars iconic.

The storytelling is nothing short of brilliant, weaving a captivating narrative that keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout the entire journey. The character development is exceptional, allowing you to truly connect and empathize with the protagonist's struggles and triumphs.

The gameplay mechanics are a stroke of genius, offering a perfect balance between lightsaber combat, Force abilities, and strategic decision-making. Each encounter feels exhilarating, whether you're engaged in intense lightsaber duels or mastering powerful Force techniques.

Visually, Jedi Survivor is a stunning work of art. The attention to detail in every environment, character design, and special effects is awe-inspiring. It's evident that a tremendous amount of care and passion went into crafting this game.

Moreover, the sound design deserves immense praise, as it flawlessly captures the iconic Star Wars soundscape, enhancing the overall immersive experience.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi Survivor is an absolute triumph in gaming. It not only honors the legacy of Star Wars but elevates it to new heights. Whether you're a die-hard Star Wars fan or a gaming enthusiast, this title is an absolute must-play and easily deserves a perfect 10 out of 10 rating.

(Edit/update: Jedi Stutterer is now even more unplayable for me after patch 7.5. Still no apology or explanation as to why the launch on this platform was nothing less than disastrous. EA have got our money and they don't care. I stand by my original review below as to how brilliant the story and gameplay are, unfortunately the performance has completely ruined what a lot of us were waiting four years for, and paid good money for. Only purchase this on console if you can. Guess I've got to watch the YouTube movie of cut-scenes to find out what happens on Tanalor now?)

First, let's address the elephant in the room- the game's performance. Like most of us on here, I absolutely adored Fallen Order and could not wait to explore the next chapter in the story. Despite the initial negative feedback surrounding the game's release, curiosity and spoiler fear finally got the better of me and I just went for it. The lagging started during the superb Coruscant intro, but was never quite bad enough to put me off. "Perhaps the game is just settling itself in", I naively thought. 
Enter Koboh. The frame stuttering went into overdrive, and Cal would often fall through solid floors into inescapable positions, forcing me to close the game. Two or three patches/weeks later, I returned and started the game from scratch to see things had only marginally improved. Ignoring my better judgement, I pushed on with the game through my sheer love for the story and characters. The stuttering actually improved once on Jedha, as well as on the Shattered moon and Nova Garon. However I would constantly dread having to return to Koboh's large, open areas where the performance drops off a cliff edge. All whilst having the graphics on the lowest settings. Fallen Order played beautifully on max settings on my trusty Nitro 5, and the graphics on Survivor aren't particularly superior in any way. The worst bug of all arrived at the worst possible moment- Cal appeared as a different (and very important) character during a crucial cutscene, completely ruining what was supposed to be the most emotionally charged moment of the game. Inexcusable. 

After almost completing the main story, the latest patch has now prevented me from having enough disk space to continue and finish the final boss fight. So here I am, uninstalling the game with no idea of what happens in the end, with the vague hope of revisiting it in a year or two when the PC port has finally got it's act together. As far as I am aware, EA/Respawn have issued no apology whatsoever as of yet, which is a rubbish way to repay loyal fans and customers to be frank. You guys had four years to make a game that functions...

A quick, separate review of the game itself: in a nutshell, superb. The gameplay and combat have improved massively upon the original, in particular when it comes to the new lightsaber stances and the wider variety of enemies. The dual-wield and crossguard stances are particularly fun to use. The different planets and space stations are wonderfully crafted. I especially enjoyed the beautiful shattered moon with it's moving asteroid fields. Perhaps my only gripe here would be that too much focus went into Koboh, leaving the other planets feeling a little rushed and empty. A "return to Coruscant" mission, perhaps to the old jedi temple ruins for example, would have been great and could easily have been integrated into the plot. The neat little stealth section on Nova Garon should also have been in the first half of that planet, before Cal unleashes all hell. Despite it's unnecessarily big size, Koboh really is stunning and the puzzles within the old republic chambers add a nice touch, as does the lucrehulk rescue mission.

The story is solid throughout, with the main plot twist being a stroke of genius. The character arcs of each of the Mantis crew members follow fascinating and entirely logical courses, and the romance between two certain characters adds emotional intensity and complexity to everything that is going on. The main boss villains are, like in Fallen Order, always challenging and charismatic in their own ways. Dagan does feel a little out of place visually, with a hairdo that belongs in a Kojima or Final Fantasy type game. But the whole sub-plot with him and Santari was a nice and refreshing way of expanding Star Wars lore and blended in well with Cal's story.

Fallen Order was the best thing to happen to Star Wars since Rogue One- the raw emotion and classicism of the original movies, combined with the spectacle and non-stop action of the prequels. Likeable characters, a complex antagonist and the feeling that you are literally immersed in this universe. Star Wars distilled to perfection. Survivor's challenge lay in continuing this standard whilst expanding possibilities and opening new doors (The Last Jedi tried and failed spectacularly in this regard). I am happy to say that Respawn have done a great job, and in many ways have outdone themselves. I just wish I could have played this one right through to the end.

Final verdict: Magnificent game and a fitting sequel to a modern classic. But DO NOT BUY for at least another few months or longer, until the PC port issues are resolved. And please, Respawn, please-  don't make us wait another four years for number three!

Bought it on sale about 8 months after release. There are still game breaking bugs, glicthes a plenty and a host of performance issues. Fortunately most can be fixed or mitigated. If you want to run it on max graphics you need a beast of a machine. Oh and it takes about 5 minutes to launch for pretty much everyone.. 

Still underneath it all is a good game. I think Fallen Order was a little better. It definitely had better pacing.
Combat sometimes feels worse for the simple reason that Respawn does not really know how evading works. Souls-like games almost universally know that if the player presses dodge, you dodge regardless of what you were doing. Most of the time anyway. In Jedi Survivor not so much. If you are in the middle of an attack animation you will not move an inch until said animation is finished. Stupid I know. It does the same thing with blocking. Took me a long time to stop making 3 attacks because by the time the third one was half way through its animation I would get slapped in the face. 
So, 2 attacks - wait - parry - 2 attacks - wait and so on. 

All in all. A good game that has seemingly had the standard EA post launch funding of pennies on the dollar. If you want Star Wars then wait for a sale, get it for 50% or lower and be prepared for plenty of fun but with more glitches and bugs than a $70 game has any right to have.

I Initially avoided Jedi Survivor due to the controversy surrounding its performance at launch. After having performance issues with Hogwarts and The Last of Us at the start of the year, I decided to pass on this.

Having been disappointed by Starfield, I needed a game to fill the Science-Fiction shaped hole that game left me with so I picked Jedi Survivor up on sale. I can say performance seems to be a lot better now compared to its launch state. I average 128 FPS on full Ultra with the above specs. There is still some lag when the game tries to transition from the game into a cutscene, so often, the first few seconds of a cutscene is ruined as it tries to catch up.

I never finished the first game as I was foolish and thought I could do it on the hardest setting on my first try. This time around I went for the normal difficulty and the game still provides a solid challenge. The combat is incredibly fun and I'm loving the new stances. The customisation is also improved and I have Cal looking like some fancy Victorian Ninja with a Samurai style lightsaber XD.

I'm yet to finish it as I've been distracted by other games, but I find it to be one of those games that's very easy to jump back into after some time away which is rare for me. A great action game with a good story to pick up on sale, that isn't filled with too much open world fluff.

Signposting can be a bit vague at times especially given the colour of the force prompt, how missable the climable walls and the little crevices that litter the map are almost impossible to spot.

The game is absolutely gorgeous and one of the best looking games out at this moment. The combat is the same as Fallen Order just better and more refined in every way. The open Castlevania esq world is fantastic and very well done. The extra combat stances are very well done and all of them are viable and fun and have a lot of good variety to their playstyles.

Single Saber Stance: The most used and iconic stance. Balanced with middle defense attack speed etc. If you want a stance thats a jack of all trades master of none type then this is the stance to choose. It has a lot of attack variety with jumps dashes throws and combos and is good for single and medium sized groups.

Double-Bladed Stance: If you want to take on large groups and be a flurry of death like Darth Maul then this is your stance. Some don't like this stance, but if your against a lot of blaster fire there is no better stance than this with its ability to deflect all blaster fire to everyone in the area. This stance is fast paced with the best defensive ability in the game. It is very fluid with how you can change attack combos at anytime and essentially have an aoe around you when you attack due to the extra range of a dual bladed saber whipping around your body.

Dual Wield Stance: This is a pure offensive high risk high reward stance with a low defensive ability. However it makes up for its lack of defense from its raw power and force parry ability. In the beginning before you upgrade it can be a little lackluster, but once you start getting some skill points into it it becomes a weapon of mass destruction able to contantly throw your saber on repeat. It  has an amazing attack combo variety that will let you deal with any size of group effectively once you master this stance.

Cross Guard Stance: The Kylo Ren. This stance along with the blaster stance are the most unused stances unfortunetly. Not because they are bad just have a much higher learning curve to them. This stance is very powerful and great for any enemy with a higher guard as it can decimate someones guard in just a few swings including some bosses. Now this stance is slow and has a small combo, but it makes up for it by having a great defense and the ability to stun, knockback, or even smash certain enemies in the ground. This stance is best for single and small groups of enemies however with its wide sweeping arcs even larger groups will fall at your feet. Now this stance will take some getting used to since it is so much slower to use than any other stance. If you favor parries and high damage this would be the better stance for you.

Blaster Stance: The bounty hunting Jedi we've always wanted. Okay this stance is a literal blast with how you can blast your enemies in the face with a gun along with being able to fire your blaster during your saber combos dealing extra damage. You'll need to do a little bit of micro managing with this stance since you only are able to build up blaster shots is by hitting people with your saber WHILE USING THIS STANCE. The playstyle is more akin to using a rapier sword, its a fast stance with lower defensive ability, but you have a blaster so shoot the weakling in the face widdle their numbers down hit and run build your blaster shots up until your left with a more managable enemy group size. The main downside to this stance is that the force saber abilities are replaced with blaster fire instead and to get better charge shots you need to complete all the bounty hunting missions which at this time are bugged as hell to the point you cant actually get the pucks to buy those skills.

Bugs: Jedha is very unoptimzed and will be the main point of the game where the  game will crash very often. 
Bounty Hunting is broken so you can still find the bounty hunters in the world and defeat them, but you will not get any of the puck rewards from Caij leaving the blaster stance feeling very lackluster since all the extra abilities you need to buy with pucks. If you do not rest at your meditation point the game will not save and you will have to redo everything you did prior to resting which can cause a lot of problems. There is quite a bit of stuttering in the game though after the first few patches i personally havn't had many if any issues at this point.

This game is amazing. The story and gameplay are exactly what I expected, hoped, and more from a sequel to Fallen Order. It's genuinely a great game and gets a worthy recommendation from me. However it's bogged down by the technical aspects of this game.
Unfortunately it's twice the filesize of Fallen Order, it's so demanding that I have to wait 5 minutes after startup on my $1000+ gaming computer to compile the game files, it runs at 15fps on SteamDeck (low settings) when Fallen Order ran at a constant 30fps (medium settings) and drains the battery super quickly, and even on high graphics on my expensive Gaming PC it wasn't noticeably graphically better (both games look amazing it doesn't look bad, but this game is horribly optimized for both filesize and for lower powered computers).

Gameplay: 10/10
This is why you would play this game. It's a jedi sim souls like and it's good at it if that appeals to you.

Visuals: 10/10
Easily one of the most stunning looking games of 2023.

Sound: 8/10
Not bad, but not good enough to leave an impression but that said, it is star wars, and doing audio up to the standard Star Wars sets in general is good enough to warrant an 8/10, not just a 7.

Optimization: 6/10
Technically i'd rate it as more an 8.3 now but at launch it was unplayable, and these people need to learn to stop releasing broken games. I didn't even consider this for game of the year because of it, and I would have otherwise.

Story: 4/10
I could not care less about the imperial era of star wars it's so overdone and how Bode acted at the end makes such little sense it's just dumb. Like sure it had some good moments, hence why it's not a 2/10, but yeah, it's bad.

Characters: 6/10
The main cast was great and well voiced but most of the side characters made me want to join the dark side to shut them up.

Animations: 10/10
Easily one of the best things about this game. Especially Greez. Well done.

Maps: 9/10
The maps design here is superb. From software levels of quality and even better than fallen order. It's just a 9/10 because I've seen better and there are more than a few moments that have left me critical of what I've seen.

Overall 8.1/10
While this game is a strong sequel to fallen order in many ways, it suffers from the weak writing we all know and expect from modern star wars.

Fun game. Has some visual issues such as poor optimization, screen tearing, pixelation, and some physics issues during cutscenes. Besides the main issues, the game itself is very fun. The combat has much more variety than the first game, the platforming is slightly more varied, and the story and missions are solid. A good star wars game, so if you enjoy the franchise you will probably like the game.

The developers really tried to give us a fun game, taking what made fallen order good and expanding on it, for example a choice of 5 lightsaber combat stances that all feel different and unique, amazing scenary and views, a incredibly fun bossfight with [spoiler] merrin using her nightsister powers to fly around this giant machine as is destroys the temple [/spoiler] , new methods of smoothly traversing the world, a hub and customisation options ect.

however the last ark/ending was atrocious cals jetpacking gunslinger sidekick and best friend suddenly turns out to be a sith that no one could sence kills a jedi and betrays him- you then hunt him down and kill him in front of his CHILD daughter WHO IS COMPLETELY OK WITH HOPPING ON A SPACESHIP AND BEING BEST FRIENDS WHITH HER FATHERS KILLERS- roll credits...

I'm on a Geforce 490 RTX 24gb with 64gb of ram,  a 4TB SSD drive and this game stutters, lags, and glitches like none of the other games in my games library. It is insanely poorly optimized, especially compared to its predecessor having just finished it.
Somehow, the game's controls feel clunkier, as well as throwing so many abilities at you that you can't keep up nor do you use them all. The textures don't look as polished (especially the spaceships, with no specularity maps for shine on them to make them look like metal AT ALL) and the colour palette and shaders are all over the place (Cal's hair turns from dark auburn, to gold, to comedy bright red to dark brown and even black at times, even if he's not in the dark.) 
The devs even started running out of ideas, giving you busy work to do on planets - like side jobs, which is always a bad sign. Filler is filler because you lack creative ideas of how to flesh out your story.
The only bright points about this game are the story itself, the characters, and it retains the feel of being authentic Star Wars - unlike the trash Disney pumps out.

A very positive experience - PC optimization is much better than it was, although I still suffered a few FR drops ( and 2 crashes in around 35 hours). Otherwise an engaging combat, world design and a touching story in the best of Star Wars tradition. Too bad the merits of this very good game will always get overshadowed by all the optimization mess of an unready release. Hope there is going to be a part 3!

In that moment I felt deep regret and really missed the 70 euros i have thrown out the window.

And in this review I am not talking about the story (wich is probably not that bad) or the gameplay (wich is nearly the same as fallen order), I just want to protect you from this madness of a game and not going through this like I did.
But if you want lag, bugs, motion sickness and countless hours of unbearable pain go ahead, that would be the game for you.

Edit: in 2023 it is still a completly buggy and lagging game do not buy on pc EVER !!!

STAR WARS Jedi: Survivor‚Ñ¢ was a game that we all wanted, the follow up to Cal Kestis's story. We got teased with mind blowing worlds, fights, graphics, animations e.t.c. What we got was an un-optimised mess. This was on the release day of the game - April 28th, 2023. So, let's skip ahead months to December 9th, 2023. Has it improved? Is it more optimised? Well, below I will let you know.

[h1][b] My issues/Cons [/b][/h1]
‚ö´So first of all, let me explain this. My PC is WELL beyond minimum/recommended specs. It can support RAY tracing beyond your wildest dreams. Now, let's get to the matter at hand - I started up the game. Enabled all my settings. Turned Ray Tracing on. The game was a STUTTER fest. It was a CRASH fest. Several times in my 1hour and 55 minutes of playing I must have crashed 5-8 times in an hour. Here is the error I kept getting: EXCEPTION_ACCESS_VIOLATION reading address 0x00000102144455d0. If anyone knows how to fix this, PLEASE, please can you help. (MY PC SPECS ARE ON MY STEAM PAGE)
‚ö´From time to time I noticed buggy animations on OTHER characters that are NOT Cal Kestis. BODE, the guy with the jetpack, when he removes his helmet... his hands gltiched faster than the FLASH could run. His jetpack also seemed to have come off of his back. The "7th" sister also managed to use her lightsaber without doing ANY animations at all. Fantastic game design EA. 
‚ö´I was told that the MICRO STUTTERS had been, somewhat, fixed. Yeah, ok. They have been fixed A LOT since launch day and you can actually play the game somewhat but I feel like this was a bold face lie told to us by EA. It still microstutters. Not all the time but its VERY annoying. 
‚ö´The AI, YOUR friends, stick to you so closely when you have to do jumping puzzles. BODE from the first mission AREA with his annoying JETPACK would not GET OUT OF MY FU**ING way when I had to climb. He just hovered there facing a wall I had to climb on. It took me 10 minutes to push him out of the way. Here, look for yourself: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3109174675
‚ö´When I reached the FIRST planet you manage to explore after your ship gets damaged, I was able to reach the TAR, opened up the shortcut and then my game crash's on me instantly. Why is this bad? Every single time I reloaded the game it took me 5 minutes to pass the "OPTIMISATION" screen and then I found out I had to do that ENTIRE segment all over again. 
‚ö´So I found out that one of the reasons I am crashing is because of the BIRDS FLYING. here, have a look yourself: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1774580/discussions/0/3828665650630021009/?l=french&ctp=2

EDIT: So about the MICROSTUTTERS, turns out the game actually has almost NO microstutters with RAY TRACING disabled.

[h1][b] PROS [/b][/h1]
‚ö´The game looked very good from what I was able to play and experience.
‚ö´The combat was very fluent and it felt fantastic when you mixed up your combos (well, from what you have at the start of the game)
‚ö´The audio was done to perfection in my opinion.
‚ö´The game has a plethora of LORE for you to read in the Star Wars Universe.

[h1][b] My Verdict [/b][/h1]
I sadly, cannot recommend a half-assed game like this, STILL. I wrote a negative review day 1, and again... 8 months later, the game is still poorly optimised. I think... this is the last time I trust EA with ANY game that I buy. They clearly do not care about the quality of the games they are releasing.

[h1][b] STAR WARS Jedi: Survivor‚Ñ¢ - 3/10. A terribly optimised PC game being charged at an EXTORTIONATE price by EA [/b][/h1]

When first purchased, I would CTD before getting to the first meditation spot. That means every time I played I would have to watch the entire intro over and over, only to crash. Now, I get consistently 50-80 fps depending on the area, and near the upper 90s when in space or cutscenes. (3080 & i9 9900k, 64gb 3200ram). I prefer the story driven style of fallen order as I dislike open world but 60hrs into the story (about 80%) I can say the game captured me and I really like it. one of the best (semi?) open world games. Normally they dont keep me connected as for example I quite red dead redemption 1 and 2 about 40% in.

The game seems meh. Cookie-cutter semi-open world done-it-a-thousand-times-before type deal. Would still probably enjoy it cuz I'm a Star Wars nerd.

But you just can't enjoy it. Even with performance-enhancing mods, it's a shitshow. 10900k, 4080, 32gigs of RAM, NVMe SSD, all the good stuff. Nuh-uh. 50fps lows in the opening half hour. DLSS is almost useless because the game is completely CPU-limited. Tried frame gen to get consistent 60+. Nuh-uh. They didn't bother tuning it at all. Every time you move the camera, Cal's head breaks and it looks like the worst ghosting you've ever seen. Subtitles break too, and the menus, and feet when walking up the stairs. They get all fragmented and messed up. It's a joke.

And then you've got the stuttering for dessert. Forget what smoothness means, because this game will remind you it's a barely functional piece of shit every 10 seconds with shader comp and traversal stutters. This happens regardless of settings (still stutters on low), DLSS, or frame gen. 

So you're prolly thinking: "Maybe I'll just buy it 6-12 months from now when it's fixed and on sale." Ha. Don't count on it cuz it's Respawn Entertainment - they're famous for leaving their games busted. This shit released at the end of April let me remind you. It's been over 4 months and the game is still not playable. I held off on launch and waited *this* long and it *still* doesn't work. Might be playable when someone cracks it and gets rid of Denuvo lmao

Refunded it of course. Save your time and money and find something else to do with your day.

In two hours of trying, this game has failed to launch, launched and crashed with no error code, crashed all other open programs, and crashed with two distinct error messages. At this point, I give up.
It is a great game when not crashing or stuttering.

The game is really damn fun!  I recommend on a sale, however there are technical caveats.  If you can look past these technical issues which are still present, the gameplay and exploration is really damn fun if you enjoy any souls-like style of game (Dark Souls, The Surge, Bloodborne, Elden Ring etc.) mixed with the Star Wars universe.

Technical issues still experienced so far:
- Had a couple of crashes in ~5hrs of gameplay which are very annoying as they reset progress back to the last meditation point AND you lose everything you did after it.  Meditation points are a bit too far apart for this not to be an issue.

Also it's a very bad PC port.  Performance is pretty awful and although I appreciate a lot of the options being present to remove a lot of the console-centric settings (like disabling 'hold button to do things' and what-not, there is this annoying camera shake in every cutscene which cannot be removed even when putting BOTH camera shake settings to 0%.  IDK why they insist on doing this in video games (and movies), but it's absolutely horrible so most of the time I hate watching the cutscenes because of it.

Lastly I don't know why it has to 'optimise for your PC' for at least 2 minutes every time booting up the game.  Again, just a junk port unfortunately.

Don't even bother with raytracing.  It does nothing for the visuals and just tanks performance as well as making it much more likely to crash.

Picked this up on sale at 40% off, very worth it. Just about everything you'd expect out of a sequel. QOL improvements, earlier access to features from the previous game, a continuation of the story, and an expansion of progression and cosmetic features. Combat feels about the same as the previous game with some tweaks to improve flow, etc. If you liked the previous game, you'll like this one. I personally haven't had the same performance issues as some other players, running the game at 75fps at Ultra-High with DLSS enabled on a 3060ti. I have noticed that my CPU is significantly more capable than most people who are having issues with the game's performance, so if you have an older CPU or less powerful CPU, be aware that the game might be CPU limited, otherwise you should be good to go.

Edit:
Just finished the game. Was honestly one of my favorite Star Wars games released in recent memory. The writing was honestly pretty good and combat throughout felt challenging, but very flowed pretty well. If you can get past some of the performance issues with the game, which honestly aren't that bad, I very much recommend picking it up.

I persisted, and the overall gaming experience turned out to be worth the frustration. Everything has been elevated from the first game, which I really enjoyed. Nevertheless, the lingering concern revolves around performance ‚Äì one would expect that, several months post-launch, the significant crashing problems disrupting game play would have been rectified. I endured game breaking freezes and over 30 game crashes and I made sure there were no possible issues on my end that could be contributing prior to game play. I have an amazing computer and everything is up to date.

The combat and abilities in this game are awesome, making the experience very enjoyable to play as a Jedi. I appreciate the inclusion of elements involving the dark side.  Overall it was a great experience compared to the first game. I do plan on playing future games but I sincerely hope the developers address and resolve the existing performance issues, this has cast an unfortunate shadow on the series for me and makes me apprehensive for future purchases.

It's like Uncharted had a baby with Sekiro. If you love any of the two, this one's a must play. Also, it seems they have fixed the performance issues. I did't have any and I am playing it on a gaming laptop with GTX 1650 so that says a lot.

So I've heard the PC launch of this game was a shitshow, at that time I had no interest in buying the game anyway simply because my backlog is as long as list of my sins. Anyway I've got it on 21st of November on sale for about 38 buckaroos and it was a great timing because couple of weeks before that I've finished Fallen Order on pc as well and guess what. It has been worth every single cent I've paid. Just for the record I'm running it on i7-6700k (yes 8 years old cpu) and 3070ti in-game settings maxed out in 1440p and it held 60fps most of the time with occassional hickups.


After finishing 100% of Jedi: Survivor I can say one thing, it took Fallen Order and expanded on every single element. Characters that were tasteless in Fallen Order? Fixed (Even Cal who I really didn't like in the first game). I certainly don't care about customizations but if you do hell you have some serious content to unlock. Combat system is the good ol' but upgraded with 9 skill trees, yes 9 (5 for weapon skills, 3 for force skills and 1 for general character development) so you have the freedom to choose which weapon type suits you best. Sound design and music is spot on just like in previous game but what's added is countless dialogues between enemies and I really took my time to just listen before I engage, so great immersion upgrade as well. Graphics fidelity is overall great and map designs are great as well so there is always something to see or something to do.

Now lets talk content. There are 6 locations or planets if you will (1 humongous, 2 large and 3 small) all of them are different and all of them are visually great with some awesome vistas to see.
Just like in Horizon Forbidden West you are not stripped of your skills from the game which is greatly appreciated and it only underscores that this is in fact a sequel even though if you don't want to play Fallen Order both of these games are start to finish standalones without cliffhangers or open endings and can be experienced like that.

So now to the technical side. Fallen Order had stuttering all over the place, Survivor has it somewhere but not too often for it to become unbearable and it has some places with fps drops but I cannot say 100% if it was the game or my rig. What I can say 100% on the other hand is that you don't want to turn ray tracing on simply because it will cause you to lose 20 fps and the effect on visuals is marginal maybe mainly because this is AMD sponsored title.
During my 60 or so hours in this game I've encountered 1 or 2 texture glitches, couple of weird clothing animation behavior and 2 crashes.

Overall this game is just a pleasure to experience, it's not flawless, it came out broken but still at this point I am glad I've bought it and played it.

I have about 1-2 hours of gameplay so far and maybe some stutters or even a hang to load a cutscene, but the game is very fun, story is good and not as bad as expected based on all the reviews since the release. Its not perfect by any means, but playable and fun...I even feel like I could scale back a bit to 1080p with ray tracing off and probably get better FPS but I like the quality of the environments and its not unplayable yet so I will keep high quality gameplay going.

This game almost made me hate it.  Almost. There is alot of good here, the graphics are nice.  The traversal mechanics and puzzles are excellent as usual. The story is quite good  and the characters  entertaining and grounded.

The core issues are two. 1 the combat and 2 the side content.

1. The fundamental issue here is that this is a game that breaks its own rules in combat constantly. It has that slow , deliberate  high committal combat  that dark souls is known for. But you will be facing  a half dozen to dozens of enemies all of which can shoot through eachother and attack through eachother.

The game wants you to parry but more often than  not the enemy you want to parry is hidden by a blob of goons all clipping into eachother.

The bosses are even more annoying because many of them are stun immune for what seems to be arbitrary reasons. one second a hit will stun them. other times they will just power through a light saber to the face while starting some ultra ridiculous combo.  The boss fights were not enjoyable because of this. They were more of a chore I wanted to get through than they were fun.

2.  90% of the side content is pointless, you can collect fish to fill a fish tank, collect plants to fill garden. neither do anything.  Plus the game continues the rather pointless persuite of populating most secrets and chests with  color swaps , and skins for cal and his light sabers. something I wager most people ignore.

Its alot of fluff that pads the run time needlessly.

Great sequel. It improves on Jedi Fallen Order in almost every way. It has a rich story, with intelligent and cohesive combat. Platforming still remains a big part of the game and does feel a little forced when compared to Fallen Order. There are optimization issues. The game was borderline unplayable at launch. Recent patches have improved performance, but there is a way to go before it is fully optimized. I prefer to game at 1440p and consistently get between 70-90 FPS on Max settings with RT on. Turning RT off will obviously result in higher FPS, but I like the eye candy. When playing in 4k my FPS does take a hit. With some areas running under 30 FPS. 

Overall the pros out-way the cons. If your fine gaming in 1440p or 1080p I feel like the game is great and definitely worth getting. If your gaming in 4k, just understand that optimization issues will heavily throttle your FPS.   

(Gaming on a Ryzen 5950x an RTX 3080 and 32 gb of ram (two 16 gb sticks) running at 3600MHz. Game is installed on a WD black SN750 M.2)

This, and its prequel, are by far the best Star Wars entry in the Disney era, everything else should be avoided.

That being said, this game is not without fault. I played this game well after it came out. I patiently waited seeing as how many people were complaining of performance issues. I was lucky enough to not have any visible moments of poor performance during the entirety of my time with the game.

I think the game has improved over it's last entry which was already pretty phenomenal. Without taking the story into account this is one of my faves of the year. However the story is where my issues largely stem from. It's hard to talk plot without spoiling a lot of stuff later on down the line, so from here on out is story spoilers and my gripes with it:

[spoiler]Unfortunately for myself, the biggest twist of the game was spoiled for me early on into the game when i simply tried to google search who the actor was that played Bode. Because of this every time he was involved in a cutscene I was looking at him with pretty intense scrutiny (that being said, I'm only human and could have missed things). The major twist of the game is that Bode is a secret, hidden Jedi who has learned to blend in amongst the empire & rebels alike and is making a life for himself as a double agent in the galaxy.

Back to the beginning, you are try to get information from a corrupt Coruscant senator with the help of Bode and a bunch of crew members who die almost immediately after being introduced, with only you and Bode being the lone survivors. Looking back at the cutscene in which you, bode and your one other member are flying out of Coruscant and only you seem to make an escape, Bode seems to be off, but nothing really noticeable beyond that. By the time he comes back into the story he seems ENTIRELY devoted to your cause, willing and able to help you out, asking very little in return.. Almost the entirety of the plot revolves around a Jedi you find healing in a Bacta Tank named Dagan Gera. Immediately after freeing him he reveals that he had betrayed the Jedi order and that his intentions were finding and resettling on a hard to reach planet where they could train a legion of Jedi to overthrow the empire and basically cleanse the galaxy. He very very much seemed to be set as the main villain of the game, especially since the entirety of the plot stemmed around beating him to get to this hidden planet. But when you defeat him and slay him at the end of the second act, the story seems to have plenty left in the tank.

This is where Bode comes back into the game. Immediately after defeating Dagan, Bode confides that he has reservations about restarting the Jedi Order on this hidden planet, as he only cares about the safety of his daughter. Something that feels like was intentionally hidden until this moment. This now becomes the obvious set up for the bounty hunter type character to selfishly betray the rest of your team. All of this i can understand, he is looking out for his daughter above all, and wants to go to the planet by himself to save her from the cruelty of the empire. BUT WHY DOES HE KILL ENO CORDOVA ON HIS WAY OUT? for everything the game set up, that seemed ridiculously out of character when he very well could have just left them all in the dust and fled.

Immediately this begins a chase sequence that ultimately concludes with a lightsaber duel when Bode reveals he is a secret jedi blah blah blah. When you get knocked out upon losing the fight, it cuts to you playing as Cere, Cal's Jedi mentor, where she defends this ancient Jedi temple from the Imperial invaders... Of course, this sequence concludes with the inevitable fight against Darth Vader. I had expected they would put this game, and hell, i was even looking forward to it. I cannot understate my extreme disappointment from the developers to make Vader look this f***ing weak. Really? with each passing cutscene in the fight he looks weaker and weaker and only manages to beat Cere via complete fluke when she had the upperhand the whole time? Nah, I can't accept that. This man is suppose to be the most terrifying force of nature in the history of the Sith/Jedi and he BARELY beats Cere, a Jedi who has only been seen in the previous game and this? No. I simply do not respect their decision to make that Canon. f*ck that.

after this 100% tomfoolery, you go and do what I will say is one of the cooler sequences in the game, when you sneak into the Imperial base to chase after Bode. Just before finding him, it starts one of the more interesting cutscenes in the game. I applaud Respawn for their attempt at something a little more dramatic and interesting here, although it somewhat misses the mark. You find Bode's daughter Kata in Bode's apartment and begin to question her about her dad. The sequence would take long to explain but it is phenomenal. Once Bode enters the scene, I'm not 100% sure whether or not he is trying to deceive Cal or convince him, but he says something akin to "hoping Cal forgives him and that they can work together again". This confused the hell out of me, because this scene would have 100000% worked if Bode didn't kill Eno Cordova on his way out. but instead it just feels like he is bullshiting. Ultimately the scene is bookended with Cal giving in to dark side and calling upon amazing force powers to chase after Bode. The sequence is fantastic, because there were many moments throughout this game where i found myself saying "Cal isn't really coming off like a light side Jedi as much as one of those Grey Jedi's  or even like Anakin before he went to the Dark Side.

anyhow, the game culminates with You and your crew managing to find an alternative route to the hidden planet, Tanalorr. Once their, you have the final battle of the game against Bode. I feel like with some slight adjustments to the story as i had mentioned earlier, this battle would have been an amazing end to an amazing game, but it felt like it came up short. Again, you try to convince Bode to give up and come back to the light side, before a lightsaber battle ensues. During the battle, Bode gives in to the Dark Side and force pushes Kata accidentally, which is an indicator that he has lost himself to the Darkside, which ultimately concludes with Cal disarming Bode, and then after a few moments, Cal - in what i view as doing a dark side move - shoots Bode several times, ending the conflict once and for all.

the game then concludes with what I assume many people might not like for an ending, but 100% works for me, and would have hit better if they did those small adjustments to Bode's character as previously mentioned, but Cal looks on as they give a Jedi cremation to Cere, Eno Cordova and Bode. As time passes by, Cal looks on, everyone leaves the site in a fast forwarded scene, but Cal stays and looks on at the funeral pyre. A feeling fell over me, that the future for our 'hero' is unclear, that in what I can only assume will be the final chapter of Cal's story will be a inner battle between whether or not he will give in to the darkside. I hope Respawn can execute that without flaw, but after seeing them fumble Bode, I have my reseverations. [/spoiler]

Jedi Survivor is a fun game. I think Respawn did a great job here in terms of game play. There were some random difficulty spikes that I think could have been handled better, but the combat is solid. You have 5 different stances to use and they are enjoyable. The traversal feels good and the shortcut system always feels satisfying too. I didn't like the story but the voice acting and mo-capping were very well done and carry the game. As long as you don't think about character motivations and roll with what's happening it's enjoyable enough. Overall I had fun with the game and it wasn't buggy on my PC which I heard was an issue at launch.

I have issues with the story and will be getting into full story spoilers. 
[spoiler]First the game opens with us finding out the OG team disbanding because Cal is too "obsessed" with fighting the empire. They make it seem like he needs to just go on a holiday and there's more to life than the fight... Except he's a Jedi being hunted by the empire so this makes no sense. Additionally Cere and Merrin abandon him and then just go and join/make a resistance and don't tell Cal about it. Again he wants to fight the Empire and is one of the most valuable weapons against the Empire so that's just dumb. 

The game also won't stop telling us about how great Merrin is and I found her to be the most boring bland character in the game. Outside of magic she has nothing going for her. Her magic powers are god tier until something actually happens in the plot and then she's useless. The romance between Cal and Merrin felt forced and I didn't feel any chemistry between the voice actors at all. Dagan Gera is a 2D villain that makes no sense and is underused. He's mad at the Republic for betraying him but they are gone and he knows this. He immediately wants to kill Cal who wasn't involved with them so again just 2D villain stuff. 

I liked Bode but by the end his motivations also make no sense... he wants to go to an uncivilized planet with his daughter and live there alone? With her tiny backpack being the only thing she brings? Also his daughter's reaction at the end is the least human thing I've ever seen.  The only person you care about dies and you don't react and just chill with the people who kill him. The game has a problem telling characters' stories and has an emphasis on them doing what the plot needs them to. There are still some fun moments and well done scenes but this reoccuring issue took me out of the game. [/spoiler]
