Absolutely incredible game that stands out even in 2023. Despite generally being very sensitive to tech issues, and despite the tech state being far from ideal, I found this game so engaging I soon forgot all about its troubles and found myself lost in the story and the gameplay.

The combat gameplay is not going to win any awards, for the most part it is a worse version of most melee action games in the post-Souls era. But the game is diverse enough so that never becomes a problem: between traversal puzzles, physics puzzles, different stances and memorable set pieces, the somewhat shallow combat never becomes a problem. I think the overall gameplay loop, considering all its diversity, is a lot better than some other highly acclaimed offerings this year.

The story is incredible, if you are into Star Wars. There is a lot of typical Star Wars fantasy fluff in writing and would-building and it can detract from the experience, for sure. But if you go into this one without expecting hard sci-fi and instead expecting a galaxy-spanning space fantasy epic, you will not be disappointed. The story is emotional, satisfying, easy to follow and has a couple of good twists.

The only problem I personally have is that compared to Fallen Order, the facial animations and VAs aren't quite on the level. Trilla Suduri mo-cap and VA in Fallen Order several years ago raised the bar very high and I don't think anyone in Survivor is even 75% as good. Which is a shame, as that was something that truly stood out in FO even when compared to industry's best titles today,

All in all, this is a game that is very easy to recommend to all SW fans and to gamers who don't mind an occasional gaming equivalent of "burger and fries". It is not going to win any awards, but it is satisfying, fulfilling and doesn't overstay its welcome. I've finished the story in ~40 hours with a ~80% completion and wasn't bored for a second of it. 

More, and it'd probably turn into something greasy and unhealthy, like Assassin's Creed and Far Cry games.
Less, and I'd probably be left slightly hungry and slightly disappointed with the money I've spent (I got it at -40% last sale).
So personally, I think this game is "just right" and absolutely worth considering, if you are already done with all the other big titles that came out this year. After playing most noteworthy PC releases, I am sure that there is a place for Jedi: Survivor in my personal Top5.

[h1] Performance, Story and Gameplay [/h1]
Spec:
Ryzen 7 3700X
GTX 3070
16gb of DDR4
Windows 10

[b] Performance [/b]

Admittedly, I got somewhat lucky. In closed-in spaces I got around 60 to 75 fps. I took a chance knowing the performance was bad for most people and got the better end of the stick. It was still a struggle however. The updates have helped the game significantly for my specs but I doubt this will be the case for most users. The game mostly revolves around the planet Koboh. I remember seeing a lot of people saying once you get past this area the performance improves significantly but the lion's share of the game takes place there and that is where most of the performance issues are. I never got above 45 fps in the open areas of Koboh. 

[b] Story [/b]

Jedi: Fallen Order's story always felt tacked on to the Star Wars universe to me. It felt very safe and not too involved with the larger story. So much so that I can only remember a few specific story beats from the game. Survivor completely turns this around with involving planets and new enemies from both the shows and the movies. It feels like what is happening in the universe is actively effecting Kal's story. It is paced great and with set pieces that are amazing spectacles that will keep you playing for hours on end.

[b] Gameplay [/b]

Right off the bat you get to keep a lot of your core abilities from Fallen Order and through out the game you will get new ones such as a dash through shields, grappling hook and a special grappling hook. These allow you to unlock new short cuts and explore new areas of the worlds.

Kal's arsenal is also improved with new lightsaber stances. There is the original single blade and dual blade as well as dual wield receiving its own stance, so all the star killer fans can live out their fantasies. Two brand new stances are introduced with the single blade and blaster combo and the cross-guard. Each one offers a unique play-style but I found the blaster and dual blade to be the best for handling almost any situation.

Most of the main traversal in the game is fairly easy with only a handful of slightly more challenging areas. Survivor remedies this with very difficult secret challenge areas. One of which made my intelligence feel so respected as a player I am going to add a spoiler tag because I think you should experience it yourself. [spoiler] One of the challenge areas has an instant death wall that alternates halves sporadically as it moves toward the player. You need to navigate an obstacle course while avoiding the wall of death as it sweeps past you over and over. I initially thought that there was a pattern to the alternating halves and I needed to memorize the pattern to make it through the puzzle. I thought I was figuring it out with one attempt where I got further but quickly found out this was dumb luck when the path I was taking became less and less successful. I began to believe the alternations were random which meant the course was impossible without being extremely lucky. And I was right, they were random. There was no pattern, next thing I figured that there had to be away past the wall that I wasn't seeing. Perhaps I had to jump around or hide behind some form of cover from the wall. Over and over again I sprinted as fast as I could trying to get past. Sometimes I got a little lucky, most times not. Until I decided to stop and observe. And when I stopped, the wall stopped alternating too... This was the moment where I felt the game had greatness tucked away inside it. It never told me (at least that I saw) that the wall alternated only when I moved. I had to figure it out on my own. I have no doubt that some of the more patient players figured this out immediately but for me it was an incredibly engaging experience. If more of the game was like this it would be one of my favorite games of all time [/spoiler]
The game has lots of extras secrets where it asks more of you as a player to solve its puzzles and those are some of my favorite parts of the game. 

Unfortunately I just cant recommend it. The performance issues on a big game like this with a new big price-tag are unacceptable. I recommend picking it up when it goes on sale down the road. By then performance will hopefully be improved. A good game that has the potential to be great but is cut deep by poor performance.

Phew, that was a pretty darn good play.

Took me about twice the time of Fallen Order to get all achievements and collectables. Story is solid, maps are much more open which lends to more exploration than the previous title. Performance fell in 2 areas, but for the most part seems to be okay compared to all the complaints on Launch.

I will say, I bought it at 50% sale and got way more than my money's worth. Is it better than the first title? I don't know honestly, it's great, but Fallen Order was absolutely amazing so it's hard to beat. As a sequel, it's quite good and a must buy for any fans of Star Wars games and of Fallen Order.

8.5/10 would recommend!

As a dedicated Star Wars fan who has been immersed in the franchise since the days of Dark Forces, I was eagerly anticipating the release of Jedi: Survivor. However, my experience with the game left me more disappointed than a moisture farmer on Tatooine.

One of the most glaring issues with Jedi: Survivor is its abysmal performance. Despite wielding a formidable Ryzen 7 3700X paired with a powerful GE 3080 that effortlessly handled Cyberpunk, I found myself navigating the game in a stuttering mess. The sudden drops in frames per second mid-movement not only hindered my precision but also made the entire experience feel like navigating through hyperspace with a faulty hyperdrive. It's a shame that a game with such potential is plagued by technical issues that should have been addressed.

The combat mechanics, touted as a central element of the game, turned out to be disappointingly wonky. Facing opponents with the ability to execute one-move kills left no room for error, turning every encounter into a frustrating exercise in overly defensive play. While it may be argued that this adds a touch of realism by not portraying Jedi as invincible beings, it detracts from the enjoyment and fun that should be inherent in a Star Wars game. Furthermore, the inconsistency in opponents' power-move charge times only added to the frustration, making it difficult to predict and adapt to their attacks.

The storyline, billed as a captivating journey through the Star Wars universe, fell flat. Instead of an engaging narrative, the game was filled with "MacGuffins" ‚Äì plot devices that served no purpose other than to trigger the next set of events. The story lacked depth and failed to captivate my interest, leaving me questioning the choices made by the developers. Additionally, the inclusion of Clone Wars droids with their incessant and mind-numbing chatter felt out of place and did little to enhance the overall experience. It was a puzzling decision that further detracted from the immersive quality that a Star Wars game should deliver.

In conclusion, Jedi: Survivor falls short of expectations on multiple fronts. From technical performance issues to lackluster combat mechanics and a flat storyline filled with unnecessary plot devices, the game struggles to capture the essence of the Star Wars universe. As a longtime fan, I can't help but feel let down by what could have been a stellar addition to the franchise.

Bought during black friday and didn't have time to play until the next weekend. Upon launching the game EA app was installed and I received a  message from EA app that "I don't have access" to the game. I spent over an hour on Chat support with EA before this issue was resolved. They did something to my EA account to grant me access (the ea customer support was also a nightmare). Once I got into the game, things seemed fine at first, smooth 60fps amd 5900x and nvidia 3080, 32gb ram, nvme ssd. Then I entered the area containing the first check point and the fps dropped to around 15 frames. I stopped, tweaked some settings, tried again only for this issue to occur 3 more times within the first hour of play. I would be in an area with 60fps smooth, and suddenly the fps would drop below 20fps in that same area, with nothing new happening on screen, just idle. Seems the game still hasn't been optimized. I have applied for a refund.

Updated 1 December 2023: Re-installed the game tonight so I could play with the updates/fixes and possibly change my review to a positive. Thought I might try NG+ for a little while. After downloading the entire 128G, I went to play it, and now my computer is SLOWLY downloading the EA app. It has been about 10 minutes now and I am at 7%. At this rate, it will take me longer to get the EA pp installed than it did to download the game itself. Seriously, WTAF?

Update 1: Crashed on me three times today in less than an hour. Keep getting: 
LoginId:[redacted]

LowLevelFatalError [File:Unknown] [Line: 686] RetCode = Adapter->CreateCommittedResource(Desc, GetGPUMask(), HeapProps, InitialState, ClearValue, &NewResource, Name, false) failed at D:/depot/r8branches/r8release/Engine/Source/Runtime/D3D12RHI/Private/D3D12Allocation.cpp:1411 with error DXGI_ERROR_DEVICE_REMOVED

I've played about 14 hours at this point, and all 3 crashes were in the same area, so I have now played through this same area 3 times just to have it crash again in between save points.

I'll wait for another update before trying to play again. This is ridiculous.

Edit: After disabling Ray Tracing, I was able to get through this area and play a good bit longer. Much smoother experience, and really didn't look much different without RT. Also noticed that I can't easily change the display resolution. I was unable to see the full screen when looking at the map and some of the menu buttons, so I changed to a different resolution, but to do so I had to switch to windowed mode and use the keyboard/mouse to select and apply the change. Trying to use a controller would not allow me to actually apply the edit, so it kept reverting back. Seriously, who quality controlled this game?

Truth be told I‚Äôm dissatisfied with the whole package. I don‚Äôt remember being frustrated with the combat this much with the first game at all for one.

They also pad out the game way too much with enemy gauntlet type encounter where they‚Äôre waves and waves of progressively difficult enemies where if you mess up you have to do it all again from the start‚Äîand this happens way too often.

Another issue is this game suffers from Skyward Sword syndrome‚Ä¶ unlike the first one where you see and explore several different unique planets, this one mostly revolves around just three planets you have to revisit over and over again albeit going through different parts of it, but it grows aesthetically super stale.

Finally I found the story to be significantly weaker than the previous one. There are certain daring things it does I respect it for but the execution of those is debatable as well. But the writing is far worse in my opinion with cliche or on the nose dialogue, predictable twists, and a premise that we‚Äôve seen before a thousand times. Oh, and the villain(s) were far worse and less interesting than Second Sister was. The only interesting thing about it is that it delves slightly into High Republic stuff which was interesting.

But overall, even without the performance issues, this was a disappointment.

I did not know anything related to the story, and it was a intriguing story with some surprises.

I was wondering what they could put on the table to make it feel like a new game, and not just a story expansion. They have two new stances, so i think there is a stance for every type of gameplay, but i felt the normal stance with a single normal light saber was weaker then the others. 
This game is also more open world, whereas the first game felt like the planet had one main route from a to b, with some explorations, this has an open world as a central part, and different routs to go from there to wherever you want. I found it a bit more confusing to read the map, because it is big with separate levels, and a lot to explore.

They even have side quests in this game, that will improve the character or help the saloon in different ways. You can find a diver that will help with the aquarium in the saloon, musicians that will play music, you find, or buy in the store. There is one set of mini game  where you can play something similar as to what they play in the millennium falcon, which reminded me of "dejarik". The characters you then scan in battle, are playable characters in that mini game. There also is a garden on the rooftop.

The climbing and movement is now improved as well, where you have a grapple pistol and are able to dash in the air. It was interesting, but with all that and being able to squeeze in tight places and use some walls to jump up against, almost like climbing it made it more confusing. It is difficult to know where to go since not all of the special walls or tight places has marks on them, so i found my self walking in to what i thought was a tight squeeze or tried jumping on walls that was not climbable, and with the dash you are able to reach stuff far away. Some times so far it is difficult to know you can reach it by jumping.

It is a good game. Might be difficult and have a lot of mechanics to learn. I recommend playing the first one for the story and to learn the beginning mechanics before advancing on this game with even more mechanics. I don't think the game told me enemies re spawn after i rest in the meditation spots, but i knew from the first game. There might be other minor details the game fails to inform on, but this is one of them i picked up on.

Kindest thing I can say is, that the game is unfinished. It crashes, it has bugs and glitches. Performance is not good and it didn't get (enough) attention to details.
I bought the game in a discount, but I wouldn't do it again.

I returned to the game after some time and several patches just to find it in even worse state it was in before.

Overall, so far so good. Let's get the first two biggies out of the way. 

First and foremost; EA forces you to download their launcher and of course it defaults to launch when you start your PC. Even if you disable it as a startup program it still runs as a service. Switch this to "Manual" in services so it doesn't run every time you start your PC. Seriously, we are so sick of these publishers forcing us to use their launcher when we've already purchased the game through a storefront. I was very close to refunded before even trying the game due to this. 

Performance: Overall, performance has been stable with a stutter here or there. The exception is in the massive open area on the hub planet. This place has very inconsistent performance. I imagine this is due to them using the engine and full graphics designed for a linear short rendered game. Once you move into a linear area, the performance clears up. 

Gameplay:
The gameplay picks up off the last game with some immediate improvements. The first one is how much more fluid the movement is. Combat overall flows well. The enemies aren't as difficult as the previous game. I set my game to Jedi Master out the gate and found it a bit too easy especially considering I've beaten the original game at least 4 times with once being on the highest difficulty. One might think "this lower difficulty is probably from Cal becoming more powerful." No, the enemies are easier, parry window more open, you can take more hits, ect. Speaking of which, you immediately feel that Cal is now an experienced Jedi. I was going to lose it if you start the game and for whatever reason lose all your powers. But that's not the case. You start the game with double jump, wall run, and all the basic Jedi powers. You have both single and double blade out the gate and unlock dual blade during the prologue / warm up opening. While on dual blade... it's good, but I can't get over how stupid Cal looks while running with dual blades. It's weird; but I imagine they did it so that blaster reflection is more fluid while sprinting.

Graphics:
This game of course is gorgeous. All the textures are top notch, but the lighting is really where this game takes the cake. We have more areas to hold our light saber up like a light and it's a true light source based on the color of the saber. It's breathtakingly beautiful. 

Story:
A solid story is not make or break for me as honestly, I don't play games for stories and half the time I skip them. This game has a good enough story that I haven't skipped once. It's engaging but not exhausting.

Based purely on gameplay, I would like to recommend this game - the game part of the game is awesome. When you can play it. But the game runs like a one legged horse in a tar pit. When I'm just standing there, it does 66 fps. Fine. I'm cool with that. Even 30 is fine, I'm no snob. But then I start jumping, and fps drops to 2. Literally 2, I enabled a tracker a checked. This on Nov 30, 2023, after they released several patches. I bought the game on sale, and regret it.

What's worse is that the first several hours of the game didn't have any performance issues. It wasn't until I got to a sort of town thing, 6 hours in that the incredible suttering slowdowns started. And not even as soon as I entered that zone - not until I ran around doing a quest thing explored for a bit, left, and came back to the town. And turning down graphics settings does not help - it may even have made it worse. Restarted the game in case it was a memory leak problem or something - nope, still runs worse than a broken down chrysler on fart fumes.

My computer is not bad. I've got a 3070, 32gb of ram, and 8th generation i7 cpu. CPU is a bit on the old side, but good enough for every other game I played and above their minimum requirements.

As I write this, the game is using 11gb of ram and 6 gb of vram, and 50-60% of my cpu, despite me just standing still. Amusingly, the game immediately fills 2gb of vram as soon as you turn it on, just during the splash screen. Then it fills another 2 when it says its compiling game files, which it does every time you launch it. Then you load a save and it fills another 2.

So I dunno, if your computer is super amazing, it may work for you. But you won't know until you're conveniently past the return period.

TL;DR: If you like Exploration, Collecting, and Star Wars with decent gameplay this is a good game for you; If you want a gripping story like the first game that will keep you on the edge of your seat or take you for a ride, look elsewhere.

PERFORMANCE: 4090, microstuttering, can dip down to at low as 30 fps and be as high as around 170 fps with Quality DLSS and Frame Generation. Odd graphical glitches occur randomly and texture popin in noticeable.

DIVERSITY: Uglified Woman. Most characters who interact with you are Asian or Black women. Very few male characters, this includes historical characters. Women characters are also icons of virtue and very capable. Merrin can basically do anything you can do. Can be distracting, was for me.

GAMEPLAY: feels quite good, however some gameplay elements are locked away at seemingly trivial story beats even though they affect your gameplay style in combat. The game could use a training mode where you can curate the number of enemies and have unlimited force resource to train with, otherwise putting points into combination skills depends on you practicing in the field, which seems like a small change that could have been implemented. The new stances system is uninteresting, I have most of them, 1 missing I believe, but I am most of the way through the story at this point and I don't really like any of them. Perhaps that is just my experience. The skill points that you choose don't feel like meaningful changes or upgrades to your game play pattern ,but that may not be an issue for you if you choose to spend your points on increasing your survival or force stats. I choose to go the combos route.

STORY: The story is no where near as strong as the first game. It is perhaps actually the weakest part of the game. The most thrilling segment was the very beginning while you are on Corosant. It is quite linear, but allows you to experience a high stakes situation. The tension practically drops off a cliff after that where things just don't seem to be a big deal in terms of urgency. The story doesn't demand it. To speak further about the story beats (no spoilers), in the original the story is akin to a coming of age story where Cal is figuring things out about who he is and what he wants to do with his life. In the sequel he is learning something else, but the stakes are no where near what they felt like they were in the first game, and the events seem leisurely. Hard disagree with others who claim its a better story, it's not. It is barely interesting at all and kind of feels tacked on at the end. There isn't a romance in the story either, but that is fine, since there wasn't really one in the first game either. 

EXPLORATION: This is the strongest point in the game, if you like exploring the world and traveling at your own pace, you will have a great time, in fact, it feels like the game was made for you. Nothing bad to say about it.


CONCLUSION: The game is not a 9/10 insane story that should be getting a near perfect score from reviewers. Not much has changed or been upgraded from the original. Developers seemingly phoned it in on new and interesting changes from the original formula. Exploration and combat are still great, but the new stances leave much to be desired. They do not feel interesting or like they fit in rather than tacked on and the skill tree system feels practically useless as well. The maps are bigger, but doesn't mean its better. 

The story feels like it drags on, padding to increase the length, mostly because there isn't much interesting to focus on and neither are the characters. Merrin for example was quite interesting in the first game, but there is no romance in the sequel to make her a more interesting character and she seemingly has nothing to develop inherently in herself, she is just there because she was in the first game. Cere and Greeves seem to serve similar purposes, they serve as points to reflect back to Cal his experience in the story, but they don't inherently seem to be necessary for the story to take place. These characters seem like they just happen to be at the right place at the right time to see Cal again. All in all, this amounts to a story that is uninteresting and falls far behind his predecessor in this department.

In conclusion, the story is poor, the characters are uninteresting, I am not sure what Cal is supposed to be learning or struggling with even though I have been told what he is supposed to be struggling with multiple times, its not believable. The gameplay is good, but lacking in augmentation, and the exploration is great. This game is ultimately held back by this and, like i have said many times now, the story. If you aren't looking for a good story, and you just want to play some star wars, this game is great. Just ignore the ugly women you will meet along the way.

Jedi Survivor is a top-of-the-line Star Wars experience and one of the best story-based games I've played recently. The game is designed to give you those top-tier Star Wars experiences that you (at least if you're like me) always imagined yourself in - plus some even better than I ever dared imagine. 
All the mechanics from Fallen Order are back, plus some new ones. I think most of them are rather preferential, but if you don't like them, they don't really get in the way of normal gameplay. There are a few minor quality-of-life improvements - not having to hold the trigger while climbing, for example. The new lightsaber stances serve to really add variety to the gameplay and also allow you to really find your personal style. 
Overall, one of my favorite games among recent releases, and probably all time.

Alright, so after like 7 months I decided to give this game a chance again, and am very glad I did. Overall the actual game itself is fantastic, it has a fantastic story, good characters, and fun gameplay. The planets and art style is great. This game is truly an amazing Star Wars game. 

However, this game is held back by very VERY poor optimization even to this day. It still has plenty of bugs as well. Every other location outside of the main Koboh area runs really well, but even with a 3070 and a Ryzen 7 Rambler's Reach still chugs for some reason. Its quite pathetic that a AAA studio like Respawn can only launch 7 updates in 7 months whereas the Lords of the Fallen devs can pump out a few patch every week and its their first game. There is so much passion from the artists, writers, and actors that its sad to see the downfall of the game comes from the engineers being incapable of optimizing the game on PC. If you're fortunate enough to own a PS5 or Xbox Series X and are hesitant about the PC port I would give the game a shot on those platforms because I heard they run and look better there.

TLDR: This game is an absolute must play for any Star Wars fan, however the optimization and bugs are still an overarching problem. If you can stomach low frames in SPECIFIC areas then I would suggest getting this game. If not try it on console and see if its better

Genuinely a fantastic sequel although the performance really isn't great. Playing at 1440p high settings with a 12th gen i7 and an RTX 3080, I averaged about 80-100 fps which is perfectly fine under normal circumstances, but frustratingly the game stutters like crazy. It's really noticeable during the 'open-world' sections but even the more linear levels suffer from constant traversal stutters when moving from one area to another. The ship's holomap, where you choose a planet to visit, ran at literally 10 fps and I have no idea why. I also experienced numerous crashes, again very frustrating as the game only saves whenever you reach a cutscene or rest at a meditation point so there were a few occasions where I lost progress.

Such a shame as beneath those issues the game is fantastic. It's a great continuation of Cal's story and I hope to see him in live action Star Wars at some point.

This review is written by someone who intensely hates pretty much everything the big D has done with Star Wars since they took over.

It makes me sad this game isn't sitting at overwhelmingly positive. It's the best Star Wars game I have played in a long time, and I've played them all. It's one of the best AAA games I've played for awhile. Whoever they have working on this series is doing a great job. The game actually *feels* like Star Wars again. It's reminding me of the old school Lucas Arts stuff we all loved. It gives me hope for the future of Star Wars again. 

Great sound, great level design, and fantastic story. It brings a lot of lesser known lore to the forefront and adds some great stuff to the universe. I'm probably around half way through the game, but so far it just keeps throwing cool stuff at me. Tons of variation and play styles to mess around with. And they got rid of that stupid Poncho too. Playing on normal is definitely nowhere near as challenging as the first, but not too easy either.

I'm running on a 2080TI with everything maxed out and the game runs buttery smooth. It sucks people are STILL having issues. If you're holding out for them to fix the performance issues I would implore you to give the game a chance now. You'll know within an hour if it's going to chug for you. This is the first full priced game I've bought for over a year and it was very much worth it. Good job Respawn.

Barely started the game, but after 4 hours of gameplay there are already some apparent positive changes after the first game:

- no "lost all my powers because of some macguffin" BS
- straight to the action, no build up / flashbacks etc.
- Cal been through some shit since the end of the first game, his character is more gray which I like
- finally no poncho or not only poncho as clothing option
- cool hair and facial hair customization options
- more lightsaber stances
- bigger maps

Overall a better experience, more mature protagonist and storyline, keeping out all the annoying storytelling elements.

It took me about 28 hours of playtime to complete the story and I don't regret a single second of it. I can't recommend this game enough! Although you absolutely MUST play Jedi Fallen Order before playing Jedi Survivor. Otherwise, the details in the story will not make as much sense.

Amazingly rich story, heart wrenching/warming plot twists, and new game mechanics that blew me away on many occasions. The fight mechanics alone are awe inspiring, and don't get me started on the customisation! You can customise practically everything about Cal, Cal's lightsaber and BD, similar to Fallen Order, but now with SO MUCH MORE! For spoiler reasons, you can play the game to find out the full extent of the customisation options or Google it.

The smallest details in this game are just amazing - if you pursue every conversation, explore every corner and eavesdrop on all the enemy conversations (I recommend having subtitles on), then the jokes and quips are enough to break out smiling every time. I massively appreciate the colossal effort the game devs put into the game, so those details will not go amiss.

This is probably my current favourite Star Wars game, having just bumped Fallen Order off the top of the list and has beaten even Lego Star Wars The Skywalker Saga.

I have yet to get 100% completion but I will update this review when I know how many hours total it took for me to get there.

Incredible game across the board. Full disclosure, ran this thing on an almost decade old PC, got like 55 frames max from hanging out in certain spots, ~40 frames in combat, and ~15 frames at its worst moments, but DO NOT LET THAT STOP YOU FROM BUYING IT. Literally every part (except the performance lol) is a drastic improvement over Fallen Order. Story and worldbuilding is incredible, combat is super fun with the additions of more lightsaber types and enemy types. There's more of a focus on lightsaber wielders in combat, there's a bigger focus on movement and parkour abilities, there's fucking BOTW Shrines which bring in a bunch of puzzles to solve. The game looks so good with the scenery, often times in my playthrough I'd just screenshot a view just for the sake of taking a picture of the amazing landscape. Side Quests are a big part of the game, ranging from helpful gestures to point you towards something you might've missed to full on faction takeovers of old areas to spice it up. There's truly a ton of more love and care put into the game, like there's SO MUCH optional dialogue you can check out with NPCs and "pre-combat" enemy conversations, of which Cal will occasionally chime into. I think one of my favorite moments in the game was early on, when an unsuspecting enemy is talking about the great view, after you beat him up Cal makes a comment to end the enemy's monologue, to which you are then able to actually inspect said view where Cal then does realize that it is, indeed, a great view. It sounds weird, but I am very glad that the performance is, in my opinion, the only bad part about this game, because shoddy performance can be fixed over time, it can be improved through updates (it should've been good from the get go tho don't get me wrong), but a bad story, bad combat mechanics, bad graphics whatever, are much harder to fix, and I am very glad that none of those are an issue.

Mixed bag overall. A great game is hidden because of the lack of polish and bugs that should have been removed in the first run of play testing.

Pros:
I like the game, story, and concept. The puzzles are ok. Combat forms allow multiple ways to play. Building the town, teams, and order concept is amazing. The customization aspects are cool. I even like the taming/mount aspect.

Cons:
Constant glitches, crashes, stutters at certain points in the game. It's not unplayable but I am constantly worried that I have to save at every meditation point I see not because of my health but because of worries the game will crash or freeze. I've gotten stuck in walls more than a few times, which is a bit annoying considering the sheer amount of jumping puzzles. Other times, the wall run, wall grab, etc mechanic just doesn't work at all--like the game decided not today. These times are usually followed by certain buttons not working. "Hit the attack button" -nothing- "Bedlam raider laughs" -button still not working- WTF game? Restart...continue until the next glitch.

System:
i9 13900K, 128GB RAM, GTX 4090, Game installed on 4TB M.2 SSD
There should be no "hardware" reason that my system can't keep up.

Visual

Graphics quality: Custom
Then high for everything until Field of View
Field of view: Wider
Vsync: off
RTX: off (Unless you want studders)
AMD fidelity: off
DLSS 3: Balanced

Motion blur: off
film grain: on
Chromatic Aberration: off (unless you want flickering water)

I have been waiting to write a review for some time because to me personally, the game in itself - the mechanics, the story etc. - are more important than technical difficulties you may encounter while playing. Several bug fixes have been released since the game launched and I¬¥m no longer running into any major problems while playing. Anything else really isn¬¥t that much of a concern for me honestly. 

What I¬¥m really interested in when I look at the reviews of a game is the game itself. And for me, the game delivered. If you¬¥re already familiar with Jedi: Fallen Order, you know the combat system and world design. (If not, then what are you even doing here?? This is a sequel!) Both have been greatly expanded and improved upon and left me more than satisfied in every gaming session. Instead of two there are now five individual lightsaber stances, each with its own skill tree. (you start with the skills you acquired in Fallen Order, by the way; you don¬¥t have to "relearn" anything.) It¬¥s also the perfect mix of familiar and new planets for me, and the old ones you get to see from a new perspective. The story goes into a little different direction this time, but I liked it a lot and it kept me thinking for a while even after completing the game. 

A piece of advice for anyone who usually skips optional NPC dialogue: please don¬¥t do this here, especially late in the game / during post-game cleanup. They did something really good with this in my opinion and I¬¥m keeping this vague on purpose. It left me with a feeling I didn¬¥t have in any other game before, despite it only being a side aspect.

It also offers a good chunk of High Republic content for those of you familiar with or interested in the era. It doesn¬¥t spoil anything from the books or comics, and on the other hand grants a slightly better insight if you know (part of) them. Both groups can enjoy it here. 

For the completionists among you: the game offers 53 achievements in total, and most of them aren¬¥t too tedious to get. There is some grinding involved, but nothing too annoying and I found the specific tasks varied enough to keep me engaged (unless maybe you insist on finding all collectibles as well, which I did. I¬¥ve had worse, but it wasn¬¥t the most fun, either, but don¬¥t worry, no achievements are tied to this and you can get the map to 100% without it, if I¬¥m not mistaken). Don¬¥t worry about locking yourself out of anything, the game allows you to travel back anywhere you like after the credits and there is a New Game+ option for subsequent playthroughs.

Overall, I¬¥d definitely recommend this game. It allows you to immerse yourself in a mystical journey in the Star Wars universe while also having fun gameplay and a thought-provoking story. And it¬¥s up to you which aspect to focus on: story/role-playing, combat, exploration, or collecting. Give it a try, you won¬¥t regret it!

Well, EA, Respawn and Disney SW Games you had a great shot at a sequel to what I think is one of the top Star Wars Games.  But due to the very large amount of technical issues I've personal experienced (nowhere near the amount of others) makes me just not want to continue in the games story even though I've been waiting for this game since the first one.  I have a mid-tier high end PC and it was running at most 30 fps and so I wasn't even able to get to the first boss in a timely manner.  I waited for the patch just like they said they would release during that week (they waited till the end of those 7 days BTW) and booted up the game to give it another shot.  3 and a half gig patch and yet no real improvements other than a frame rate increase, BY 10.  Yup, I was able to beat the first boss on my first try but the game just looks unfinished with the amount of texture issues I had during cut scenes, the super low frame rate and not to mention that this is a "next-gen title".  I really want to play and finish this game and I've seen a lot of players enjoying it but I just can't support this game till It's fixed and by then I'll make a more in depth review.

I love Star Wars. I would endure basically anything to experience a story in the SWU where I can be a Jedi, explore cool worlds, and fight the Empire. But this game has reached my limit. Between bad writing, cheap animations, and, worst of all, optimization so poor that major combat sequences are essentially unplayable, I cannot stand this game. I would suck it up if the only problem were that the characters were poorly-written cartoons. But if I can't even kill a giant frog monster without frames and inputs dropping faster than battle droids, then what's the point. 

Do not buy this game when it is on sale, do not buy it at full price. That is all.

Edit: I've now finished the game, having refused to waste seventy dollars. My only addendum is first, that the performance never improved (I resorted to minimizing all graphics settings and playing with all other apps and programs on my computer closed down, and at times it was still unplayably stuttery), and second that the combat system is painful. It's fairly restrictive - as far as I can tell, it uses some sort of list of conditions (is character facing enemy, is character in range, is enemy posture lower than some value, etc), rather than say a hitbox-based calculation to determine if something hits or dodges or whatever. This results in extremely inconsistent combat experiences, enemies and characters sliding wildly over the ground, being hit or grabbed seemingly from meters away, and wide open attacks completely missing. They made a one-on-one swordfighting game fairly successfully, but then make you fight giant monsters and groups of enemies, and of course it doesn't feel great. Do not buy.

I'm sorry, but I just really don't like this game. Even I'm thinking, "Well, you don't have to write a review for it, you can just keep it to yourself." But for some reason I just really want to. So if you liked this game, please don't read this.

First off, I'm not sure if it's just me, but when it comes to the difficulty, the best example for why I think it's artificially hard is when you're up against a normal Stormtrooper, once they start charging up their shot and you try to jump over it (like a lot of Jedi would...), their aim just snaps up and shoots you right out of the sky, even though it makes no sense and is just there to annoy you. The character's aren't very well written, nobody's really that interesting, a lot of the characters just feel artificial, in that they're only feeling certain emotions because the writers thought it would be interesting, and most of the random NPC's you meet just don't feel like you'd see them in Star Wars. The bugs are really annoying, like when I went through a really long 15 minute section, and around the end I had to let go of a grate to try and land in a tunnel just below, only for the game to glitch so I couldn't let go, or do anything. And because this game relies on manual check-pointing, I had to do the entire section again. I don't mean to go after anyone, but I just can't understand how people could enjoy it, especially with the boring open levels. Just beat the game a few hours ago. To put it bluntly, this game is peak. Optimization seems to be a bit of a crap-shoot even still so there's no shame in refunding if you're getting lots of frame drops. I had a bit of a scare at the start of the game but not long after it all smoothed out. Additionally another thing I will stress is you're thinking about getting this game is to play Fallen Order first. Not just for story reasons, but also due to the fact that this is a sequel that improves on so much from the original that it's going to be hard for me to go back to the original.

The moment to moment gameplay is fantastic. I had a gripe in the last game that while the system was overall very polished, there were many times where it felt a bit jank and like deaths weren't your fault and I can safely say whatever fine tuning they did, those moments are gone completely. There's still a few moments where it can feel a little unfair, mainly in regards to being swarmed by enemies and/or being in a very small enclosure, but the combat overall has been perfected. To top it off too you get 5 different stances to choose from in this game compared to the 2 of the previous game and to top it off they all provide very distinct gameplay styles and use cases and I was always torn about which ones I would bring whenever I would switch up the two I could swap between. Another nice touch is that pretty much all of your powers from Fallen Order are unlocked right from the start here which really helps sell this game as a proper extension of the first.

As for level design I'd say there's a marked improvement in that department as well. In Fallen Order it all felt very "gamey", levels were levels and all the planets were very straight forward. In Survivor the levels feel much more organic, and while there are fewer planets overall, they're much more involved. A good chunk of the game actually takes place on one planet, with a semi open world on said planet with a lot of fun nooks and crannies. And while it may sound like the environments get really repetitive being on the same planet, this is mostly remedied by a nice variety of locales on said planet which keeps things from looking samey. The open world is also paced out by the few extra planets that are more straight forward linear levels that are a welcome change of pace. Lots of sidequests too that help you get the most out of your open world that are sure to bump a playthrough time to around 40-45 hours.

Exploration is a lot more rewarding as well compared to the last game. While for the most part most of the unlocks are purely cosmetic (another aspect of the game that's greatly improved upon), there are a fair share of goodies that help benefit gameplay beyond the extra stim canisters for BD-1.

Story: I am not the best person for determining narratives in a game. I went in completely unspoiled, the most I had ever seen of even the game itself beyond the vague reveal trailer was about 4 seconds from an ad so I went in about as blind as could be. It was worth it, but it's also not a narrative I'm going to be telling my friends about. Characters are characters, everyone is generally pretty well written, and barring one character in particular I understood everyone's motivations very well. It works for what it is, has some good moments, and there wasn't ever a point where I was groaning. Good length too. I did a decent amount of exploration and clocked in at 28 hours, though I could see this being around 20 hours if you just solely focused on story content.

Overall this is easily a game worth your buy if you were a fan of the first game. It's a shame the optimization has been a bit of a hurdle because this is easily one of if not my favorite game of the year.

Oh also there's a perk system in this game. I forgot to mention it in this review as I forgot about it in game. It doesn't add a lot but it also doesn't take away from anything.

If you enjoyed Fallen Order, then you are in for a treat.
If you enjoy Star Wars, then you are in for a treat.
If you enjoy amazing games, then you are in for a treat!

Hello, hello? Uh, I wanted to record a message for you to help you get settled in on your first night. Um, I actually worked in that office before you. I'm finishing up my last week now, as a matter of fact. So, I know it can be a bit overwhelming, but I'm here to tell you there's nothing to worry about. Uh, you'll do fine. So, let's just focus on getting you through your first week. Okay?

Uh, let's see, first there's an introductory greeting from the company that I'm supposed to read. Uh, it's kind of a legal thing, you know. Um, "Welcome to Freddy Fazbear's Pizza. A magical place for kids and grown-ups alike, where fantasy and fun come to life. Fazbear Entertainment is not responsible for damage to property or person. Upon discovering that damage or death has occurred, a missing person report will be filed within 90 days, or as soon property and premises have been thoroughly cleaned and bleached, and the carpets have been replaced."

Blah blah blah, now that might sound bad, I know, but there's really nothing to worry about. Uh, the animatronic characters here do get a bit quirky at night, but do I blame them? No. If I were forced to sing those same stupid songs for twenty years and I never got a bath? I'd probably be a bit irritable at night too. So, remember, these characters hold a special place in the hearts of children and we need to show them a little respect, right? Okay.

So, just be aware, the characters do tend to wander a bit. Uh, they're left in some kind of free roaming mode at night. Uh...Something about their servos locking up if they get turned off for too long. Uh, they used to be allowed to walk around during the day too. But then there was The Bite of '87. Yeah. I-It's amazing that the human body can live without the frontal lobe, you know? Uh, now concerning your safety, the only real risk to you as a night watchman here, if any, is the fact that these characters, uh, if they happen to see you after hours probably won't recognize you as a person. They'll p-most likely see you as a metal endoskeleton without its costume on. Now since that's against the rules here at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza, they'll probably try to...forcefully stuff you inside a Freddy Fazbear suit. Um, now, that wouldn't be so bad if the suits themselves weren't filled with crossbeams, wires, and animatronic devices, especially around the facial area. So, you could imagine how having your head forcefully pressed inside one of those could cause a bit of discomfort...and death. Uh, the only parts of you that would likely see the light of day again would be your eyeballs and teeth when they pop out the front of the mask, heh.

Y-Yeah, they don't tell you these things when you sign up. But hey, first day should be a breeze. I'll chat with you tomorrow. Uh, check those cameras, and remember to close the doors only if absolutely necessary. Gotta conserve power. Alright, good night.

This game is one that comes with ups and downs but overall I would say that is it undoubtedly worth a play.

The game is a wonderfully presented follow up to Fallen Order carrying on the story with much of the same great story telling from Fallen Order. The game features a revamped combat system although still similar to the soul's like genre its use of force abilities has been better incorporated from previous games. 

There is plenty of other great ways to spend your time as well given the games bigger focus on a open world allowing more exploration and other side activities such as the holo table mini-game and bounty hunter fights as two examples as well as  other secret areas with unique rewards.

The general quality points are also worth mentioning, the graphics are beautiful and detailed and the audio design is also on point.

The downsides are that the game has had many different performances issues in the multiple versions since launch as well as general bugs and crashes which can affect your overall enjoyment depending on what issues you run into and when.

Overall I would say that this game is worth a play regardless but anyone with even a slight interest in Star Wars and its stories should 100% give this game a try. I myself am a large Star Wars fan and a somewhat ageing gamer at this point and this game brought me back feelings from when i was a kid playing games and truly hooked me into the story and the game.

The game is a very big step up in terms of characters, story and writing, like really good compared to the writing in JFO.

But same cannot be said for combat and movement, it feels worse than JFO and there is more stances, but no fluidity in combat like there was in JFO, movement also isn't that good despite there being more movement options. its just more janky.

Enemy designs are a stepdown too, there isn't enough telegraphing to block to most of the fights with Fauna becomes a dodge game, with very wild flails hitting you in ways that dont make sense and knocking almost all your HP off(especially on GM).

The worlds here aren't also that good or varied compared JFO, which had a lot of distinct environments, here is Koboh, Jedha and a few same bases of empire that's it.

The thing that makes it worst is almost ALL BOSS FIGHTS have mid fight cut-scenes and even on retries, it breaks the flow fucks up camera and made me give up on playing boss fights on GM difficulty, the game isn't refined enough to bother with. And the fact that last act turn in an Arena where you keep fighting waves of enemies after enemies. this is NOT a SOULS LIKE, but it has soul like elements which kind of makes it worse. limited HP and heal with a SHIT TON of platforming makes it very very irritating.

The game is also a little short, i mean main story is shorter than JFO,  there is a lot of extra stuff, which is kinda fun, but not really substantial. 

The game is still not very performative, barely runs 1080p@60 on high.

YOU SHOULD NOT PAY MORE THAN $25 WITH ALL THESE ISSUES!

UPDATE 11/26/23:  It seems my keyboard disconnect issue has been resolved by turning off LED lighting options on the device.  I have tested two separate keyboards with this game and with LED on it will disconnect randomly every few seconds to every few minutes.  I have not experienced the issue with the lighting options off on my keyboard.  Hope this helps someone out there.  

Purchased the game during the Autumn sale and was cautious due to the mixed reviews but I liked the first game and wanted to continue the story.  After install, I gave it a brief play through and was pleasantly surprised that the only issue I experienced were some minor FPS drops.  Then I started it up again later that day and the crashing started.  It's about 50/50 for me whether it will crash after the main menu, which really sucks because the game itself takes about five minutes to load  up.  Do you really want to pay for a game that might take 10-15 minutes just to get going?

Then there's the in game crashes which are terrible and the only saving grace is that there are a decent number of save points so hopefully you don't have to work too hard to get back to where you were when it went down.

On top of all that I seem to have the unique issue of my keyboard turning off and back on repeatedly while playing this game.  On no other software does this issue occur, but in Jedi Survivor it's every couple of minutes.  I will be walking forward and a surprise disconnect will ensure my character keeps walking off the cliff to his death or any other number of mishaps will occur.  

I have tried many different settings and workarounds for these issues with zero success.  I have 7.8 hours in game at the time of this review.  Out of that, I would say about 6.5 hours has been spent troubleshooting and trying different settings within game and Windows OS.  The worst part is that I would even be willing to tolerate the crashing and framer ate problems, but the keyboard thing is impossible to deal with and what's the answer to that?  -  "We recommend playing with a controller"  

Well no thanks.  I play on PC and have been using keyboard and mouse since 1986 to game.  If you're going to offer a game listed at $70 for the PC, I think the least you can do is ensure it's playable in that environment, which is something EA clearly didn't do and they don't feel bad at all for price gouging consumers on the lemons they've been selling.

It all really sucks because the game looks great and the story line is interesting.  The actual gameplay, when you get to enjoy it, is fun and combat is exciting.   Too bad that's all obstructed by the numerous issues which have plagued this game since launch.  I feel sorry for the people who put hard work into this product only to have it marred by terrible management of the PC port.  Maybe some of the actual talent at EA will grow a pair one day and start their own company free from the large corporate influence and greed that has produced these unplayable turds.

I'm so tired of companies not finishing/fixing their crap when they throw it out to the masses even after months of it being out and seeing all the PC issues with it.

An excellent sequel to the venerable Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, Star Wars Jedi: Survivor improves upon nearly every aspect of its predecessor.

Though it is worth noting the technical issues and lack of smooth, consistent performance on even high end machines, the video game itself from a narrative, artistic and game design perspective is more of the quality work we expect from Respawn.

So the game had a rough start on PC, no denying that... luckily after Patch 6, things really smoothed out and any issues i was having were solved.  I can't say I had too many issues overall, but maybe my setup was able to brute force its way through the game performance wise (RTX 4090 + 5950X OC'ed).  I played the entire game at max settings, RT on, 4K resolution and none of the FSR junk.  I simply used NVIDIA freestyle to get some sharpening on the TAA in the game and overall the entire game was smooth sailing.  My only complaint is this game should have had DLSS 2 and 3 with Frame Generation for 4 series nvidia cards.  There is no reason to exclude this from the game considering it is UT4 engine unless AMD told the studio to exclude it, which is dirty marketing.  The Frame Generation alone would have made the game smooth as butter for anyone with a 4xxx series card to overcome the CPU issues with RT on.

NOTE (edited):  They finally added DLSS 3 and Frame Generation.  Gave the game a few tests and it is smooth as butter overall (except when there is a traversal stutter).  Wish it was in this state when it was released, but better late than never I guess.

If you are on an nvidia card, be sure to force ReBar ON for this game using nvidia inspector, improves performance and has no issues in doing so.  Helps overcome CPU limited scenarios with RT on in this specific game.

All of that being said, I enjoyed the game overall and the story as well.  It made a lot of improvements over the first game (which I really enjoyed) and the open world in spots was not too random to distract you from the main story.  I really hope a sequel is made for this game!  Such an enjoyable series of games so far.

Considering the rough start for the game, I am still satisfied overall and would recommend this game, as it is in a much better state now than it was at release.

Here's how my experience went with a low end pc. On my first play through the game ran fine, granted I played on low settings and a slightly lower res but I didn't crash a single time, frames went low at times but didn't take long to return normal. On my second play through I played around with settings by increasing graphics and res, frames ran lower for sure and I crashed 3 total times with my 74 hours, I didn't loose that much progress because i would always save at checkpoints to make sure. I was hesitant about getting this game because of the reviews and everyone struggling with ghigh end PCs but I bought it and glad I did. If I were you I would definitely get it and if it doesn't run well return it in the 2 hours steam gives you but I believe it will be fine.

The collectables are a step up from the last game and fast travel makes exploring the planets more fun than a chore

Star Wars Jedi Survivor, the latest addition to the Star Wars gaming universe, is a breathtaking experience that surpasses its predecessor, Jedi Fallen Order, in every way imaginable. From the vast and immersive landscapes to the meticulously crafted characters, this game is a testament to the dedication and talent of the developers at Respawn Entertainment.

One of the standout features of Star Wars Jedi Survivor is the awe-inspiring beauty of its landscapes. From lush forests to desolate desert plains, the game often feels like an open world begging to be explored. Each environment is crafted with incredible attention to detail, transporting players to a galaxy far, far away like never before. The seamless integration of exploration and storytelling creates a sense of wonder and immersion that few games can match.

Respawn Entertainment has taken player feedback to heart and improved upon every negative aspect of Jedi Fallen Order. The gameplay mechanics are refined and polished, offering a seamless blend of lightsaber combat, force abilities, and platforming. The controls are responsive and intuitive, allowing players to unleash their inner Jedi with precision and grace. The challenging difficulty curve strikes a perfect balance, rewarding skillful play and strategic thinking.

The characters in Star Wars Jedi Survivor are nothing short of extraordinary. The protagonist, Cal, and his trusty little droid companion steal the spotlight with their endearing personalities and unwavering determination. The attention to detail in their designs and animations breathes life into these characters, making every interaction feel genuine and emotionally resonant. The voice acting is top-notch, further enhancing the immersive experience. The game effortlessly weaves humor and heartfelt moments into its storytelling, creating a captivating narrative that keeps players invested from start to finish.

Another commendable aspect of Star Wars Jedi Survivor is the ability to customize Cal and his droid. The game offers a wide range of cosmetic options, allowing players to personalize their journey through the galaxy. Whether it's changing Cal's outfit or customizing the droid's appearance, these customization options add a layer of personalization that enhances the connection between the player and the game world.

I can't express enough how much I love Star Wars Jedi Survivor. It's a testament to the skill and passion of the developers at Respawn Entertainment. Despite the game's relatively short development time, the final product is a masterclass in game design and storytelling. I am immensely grateful for the opportunity to step into the shoes of a Jedi and embark on this incredible adventure.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi Survivor is a true masterpiece that surpasses its predecessor in every way. The breathtaking landscapes, improved gameplay mechanics, detailed characters, exceptional voice acting, and engaging storytelling combine to create an unforgettable gaming experience. The ability to customize Cal and his droid adds a personal touch that further deepens the connection with the game. Respawn Entertainment has truly outdone themselves, delivering a game that will delight both Star Wars fans and gaming enthusiasts alike.

MY OLD REVIEW:It's outrageous and unfair that the people involved in the game design, music, animations and script are all marred by the horrendous performance of the game itself. Unreal engine4, nvidia, respawn's dev team I am not sure who to point fingers at, but the result is all the same with "AAA" titles: put the product out before it is actually done. Investors that push game release time over quality, burn in ******* ****. 

I feel this way because my game has crashed MID CUT SCENE and then when I continue the game from the latest save, it PROCEEDS after the cut scene and there is 0 way (that I know of at this time) to re watch the cut scenes. I literally replayed the intro because I missed the post-senator capture cut scene due to a crash. Without that scene, the next sequence is CONFUSING for people who need story to back the immersion of the game. 

The lore is important to me personally (good or bad) because I am invested in this universe and if the game is only going to use 50% of my cpu and gpu (which i spent a **** ton of money on) and not give me above 50 frames in a good hallway, then that defeats the purpose of upgrading my rig and purchasing "AAA" games. 

Do better gaming industry. 

(everything else about this game is incredible, but I do not recommend a purchase at this time unless you like error windows every 20 min)

This is a really substantial sequel to SW Jedi: Fallen Order, not just in the mechanics, but on storytelling, the background of the characters and even following the old powers with the new additions.

It is not like other games where you have to start over with your journey, but it actually feels like the continuation of Cal's journey and the roller coaster of emotions he carries. Not just with himself and his past, but also with his companions.

The missions are good. Even not having a fully open world experience doesn‚Äôt feel wrong. The music, as always, is top class. And the acting, it‚Äôs too damn awesome. Cal‚Äôs character really grows from one game to the next one, and every turn you take with his story really blows your mind.

It‚Äôs been a while since I enjoyed a game of Star Wars like this one. I do recommend it since it feels different to other previous games, but at the same time doesn't make you feel alienated to the SW world.

In almost 20 hours, I have seen the launch day struggles on an Ryzen 7 5800x / 3080 / 32GB system, with frame drops during random moments with both open world areas, most notably near the main world's town, and randomly during heavy combat.  Since the follow up patch, it's improved and plays much much better now.  

Technical aspects aside, the game improves on every aspect built on from FO.  Bigger worlds, more detail, more signs of normal life instead of abandoned areas.  Expanded combat options, environmental navigation and side quests.  A story that doesn't reset you at square one like so many open world sequels rely on to force you to re-learn all the skills you had previously.  A story that also raises the stakes while connecting to the old story in a great scene/fight.  

It's pretty much exactly what I wanted to see in a sequel.

I have finished the story and seen the technical aspects fairly resolved and unlike other early 2023 released games have wanted to go back to it both for the post-clean up activities but some new lore that unlocks after you finish the game and helps flesh out the story.

This game released on April 28, 2023. It is now November 25, 2023. This is a AAA title and is marketed as a complete experience...

Yet this game is broken. It's genuinely unplayable. The developers and publishers have had 7 months now to fix it, and they haven't. Instead they've focused on trivial issues, not the game-breaking issues affecting tens of thousands of PC players around the world.

Please, people, do NOT buy this game even if the deluxe version is on sale for $30 (1/3 normal price). It's just not worth it for 2 hours of partial gameplay before the game completely breaks on you and prevents you from progressing any further in the story.

I have a 6800-XT Graphics card, a Ryzen 9 5900X CPU, and 64 GB of RAM. I have what I believe is a high-end computer and it is more than what is recommended to be able to handle running this game. On the lowest settings with no ray tracing or anything on, I am getting, at best, an unstable 60 FPS and my GPU is being pushed to 100% utilisation within 10 minutes of loading any save, which should not be happening.
On top of that, my game is crashing every single time the unskippable cutscene for landing on the second planet, Koboh, occurs. I am hardlocked from playing past the first planet, the tutorial planet essentially. I paid $60 to be able to play a complete, unbroken AAA game. The only reason I have 6 hours in this game is because I tried troubleshooting it to no avail after my refund was denied after playing for 100 minutes.

So unless you rush to the second planet and don't bother to immerse yourself in the world or environment and skip dialogue and story cutscenes, then you will likely think the game is fine so long as you have no issues with low fps, clipping issues, and visual bugs. Why? Because the tutorial area is probably the only place that's been given the development time it needs. Again this is a AAA title that's been out for over half a year now. And that starting area takes, on average, 2 hours to complete by design to prevent refunds.
So unless you rush and ignore the story entirely, by the time you are able to find out if the game will work for you or not, it's too late.

And the thing is, it's not like this game-breaking bug hasn't been known since launch, because it has been there since launch! And they STILL haven't fixed it despite literally tens of thousands of people complaining and reporting issues with it on the PC port!

Mind, I want to play this game. I want to enjoy the story. I want to immerse myself in it. I want to support the developers and game creators. But how can I when I can't even play the game I paid for?

Seriously, if you really, really want to play this game, buy a PS5 and play it on console. They clearly don't care about the PC port and focused entirely on making it a console-only game. Maybe Denuvo has something to do with this, or maybe it doesn't. Regardless, I very strongly urge you all to not try playing this game on PC as it is oh-so-very and irredeemably broken to the point of being unplayable.

[b]UPDATED REVIEW (at 5.1 hours)[/b]

Unfortunately, the game started having issues again further into the second world. As soon as I reached a more vast area, the fps dropped again, stutters started happening again, graphics went down again somehow despite me not touching any setting (I have no clue what's happening here, but I swear the graphics look horrible and pixelated all of a sudden, I suspect there might be issues with the shader compilation or something). Mind you, the game is still playable for me, however it's pretty annoying on the eyes. It's wild cause while my laptop is no longer on the high-end spectrum, it still has pretty good specs (I satisfy the recommended requirements of the game) yet it's not enough for the game to run decently.

I was willing to let it go if it was just a problem of the first world, but this seems to be a consistent problem. The game is clearly either incomplete or badly implemented, either way it's unacceptable for an AAA-game sold for 70 bucks, but I guess I should've expected it considering that it's EA. On top of that, it seems that PC players are getting the short end of the stick in the last few years with these badly released games. It also seems that companies are cutting back on proper beta testing and are using the audience for beta testing against their will instead. There's no other explanation. 

I'm a bit disappointed cause I really loved the first game and couldn't wait to play the sequel. At this point I don't think I can ask for a refund as I'm on 5+ hours of gameplay, and I was going to play the game mostly for the story anyway, so I'll just play the game on 30 fps and suck it up I guess. Mind you, the gameplay is awesome, and so far I've seen a couple of improvements in the gameplay (the best one so far for me is the fast travel between meditation circles like in Tomb Raider, god bless) and a few positive additions that I'm excited to explore further, but it's a shame that the game is in such a poor state.

[u]TL;DR:[/u] If you're only interested in the story, don't care much about performance or graphics, and are willing to stand a sub-par experience for the story, go for it. However, in the state that the game is in currently, I'd say wait until the game is either on sale or at a better state later on when performance fixes will (hopefully) be released.

[b]ORIGINAL REVIEW (at 2.3 hours)[/b]

There is definitely something wrong with the first world. I had consistently max 30 fps there, lots of stuttering and fps drops, and graphics looked off even if I was on high graphics. Just started the second world and the game improved drastically; fps increased, graphics seem to look better somehow, no stuttering so far. I'll have to see how it behaves in more "busy" areas and in combat though, will update the review once I make more progress. 

I'd say if you're willing to let your eyes bleed a little you can push through the first world, it's still playable in my opinion. The game does indeed use a lot of CPU, I consistently had 50+ percentage of use throughout the whole session, and memory usage was also pretty high, but thankfully I have plenty of RAM to spare. We'll have to see if we get any optimization patches, but so far apart from these technical issues the game is awesome.

(For the record, these are my specs: 32 GB of RAM, Intel Core i7 10750H, Nvidia GeForce RTX 2070 Super with Max-Q design)

[b]TL;DR[/b] A great and true sequel to Jedi: Fallen Order.
Even though it's at times frustrating and the system requirements are steep, the overall entertaining gameplay and compelling story make more than up for it.
Play Fallen Order first if you haven't already.


To many, Jedi: Survivor may be one of the biggest disappointments of 2023. A game with much promise, yet riddled with bugs and bad performance. From my experience since release, with currently almost 100h and on my third playthrough, I can say that I haven't encountered any grave bugs, and the number of times the game crashed is still in single digits.
The performance is okay. My RX 6650 has no issues reaching 60fps with high/epic settings @1080p. Ray-Tracing is still fine with 30-40fps. I tend to automatically reduce my settings a bit when I enter certain open-space areas with nighttime shading or lots of dust. This is where performance updates could really improve upon. Speaking of which, while I didn't encounter any big issues, I also didn't experience any noticable performance uplift from the updates. The only thing that happened is that start-up of the game takes forever now (on an SSD), as there's a lot of shader-compiling going on. As always, YMMV.

After all the drama about the tech, what's left? Jedi: Survivor improves meaningfully on Fallen Order, both in story and gameplay. The presentation is top-notch, as is the acting.
The plattforming is never unfair, but at times a bit far-fetched. 
The puzzles are, if anything, too easy. Same goes for combat, unless you play on one of the harder difficulties or decide to limit yourself to only one of the five combat-styles.

Combat is, however, where frustration may rear its ugly head: getting trapped against walls, stunlocks, an evasion-range that is too small (especially in direct comparison to Fallen Order), the odd input lag now and then, and some enemy types with one-shot attacks and/or insane hitboxes on grab attacks.
In general though, Jedi: Survivor manages to get across that feeling of gracefully dancing through or around your opponents with a lightsaber.


[b]YOU SHOULD BUY IF:[/b]
- You want to experience a good Star Wars story.
- You enjoy Arkham-style games.


[b]YOU SHOULDN'T BUY IF:[/b]
- Quick camera movements and/or timed controls aren't for you.
- You're easily frustrated.
