At launch I gave this game a negative review and while it is unacceptable to release games in rushed, unfinished and buggy states they at the very least have since fixed the game

I pre-ordered this game but refunded it at release and bought it now again on a Steam sale and my review now is based on the state of the game today not how it launched

Overall the game is amazing, it has a great story, great gameplay, amazing graphics and a vast variety of locations to explore and personally I feel like Jedi Survivor is better than Fallen Order in every aspect

The biggest change is the addition of stances you can equip, this really lets you focus your combat into the style you like the most this time around there is even a blaster stance which is quite strong actually if used right but yet is still balanced and not overpowered

Personally I used single saber and dual wield throughout most of the game simply because these were my combat preferences but all the stances have their unique strengths and weaknesses and they all have very different playstyles so it adds a lot of replayability to the game. The game is also setup with the stances in mind with locations to change stances frequently where they predict players might want to use specific strategies so that is another way to play the game

The new open world structure of the game really adds a lot without making the game feel unnecessarily longwinded or empty. All parts of the game still feel handcrafted and clearly are

Jedi Survivor really innovates and pushes the boundaries upon what they did with Jedi Fallen Order and yet keeps that strong foundation they built in the previous game. They got rid of stuff that didn't work and kept stuff players liked, while changing stuff that people liked but not in the way it was implemented

For example they've really expanded on collectibles making it not just be oh this is something you need to backtrack for to instead being something that is fun and interactive to get. Many collectibles are tied to puzzles you need to solve that are fully optional but reward some useful things from cosmetic unlocks to gameplay related unlocks

They really focused on player optimisation this game by adding a lot more styles and appearances you can unlock for your saber, blaster pistol, Cal himself and for his clothes as well as for BD1

The original challenge of Jedi Fallen Order has remained even though Cal is now more powerful and you now have the new saber stances. But the challenge level has been kept more or less the same by providing challenging boss/legendary enemy fights as well as challenging bounty hunters to fight as well as just in normal encounters you are tossed more enemies now that are really challenging

Seeing the droids from prequels and Clone Wars return is such a treat and they really add so much to the game but yet Survivor still expands on the Empire enemies you will face as well as a new faction. There are also a bunch of new creature enemies to fight

I really found myself struggling to stop playing for the night and go to bed and this game did cause me to have a few sleepless nights where I just couldn't help myself but play all the way through the night. Which is always the sign of a great game when you just can't stop playing it and can't wait to continue playing when you are busy with other things

A worthy sequel. Optimization is much better with the latest updates. Hard to find a better Jedi Simulator. By no means perfect story-wise, but characters are well developed, visuals are incredible, and the gameplay is excellent.

This game is so much better than the first one in every single way except for the performance and glitches. I only experienced one glitch which was fixed by restarting the game. Performance was constantly dipping even though my computer more than exceeded the minimum requirements. I would recommend this game to anyone if they have fixed the glitches and performance issues.

So, I'm a little ways into the game, and so far I'm really liking how the story is going. The difficulty is good, the puzzles are somewhat challenging but short (not knocking that, it's nice to get through a section quickly), and the overall look of the areas I've been to have been really good. Gameplay so far has been 10/10. However... For a game that was released 7 months ago, I really thought they would have taken care of at least some of the bugs. I know, I know, almost all the negative comments are about the performance but reading a comment and seeing it for yourself is something completely different.

From a performance perspective, this game feels like it's in an alpha state. Maybe even pre-alpha. While I'm not running a cutting edge PC, I would expect that a Ryzen 5 3700X, 32GB of DDR4-3000 RAM, and a 5700XT with 8GB VRAM would be able to handle medium to high settings without A) textures being a suggestion, B) stuttering, and C) some textures (like hair) wobbling all over the place. And I'm writing this after a particularly bad crash took my entire PC down, requiring me to do a hard boot. I haven't seen that in years.

So, I'm recommending it solely on story and gameplay, I don't regret my purchase (so far), but felt I needed to add to the sea of comments about graphics and performance being a big issue.

Up there with one of the greatest gaming experiences I've ever had. The entire final act is peak Star Wars and left me with so many feels, so much to think about, and a greater appreciation for storytelling.

PROS:
- Combat. Vastly improved combat to Fallen Order. It's the same system but with so much more added on top.
- Fantastic story. While fairly self-contained, the story is gripping and real.
- Graphics, beautiful.
- Characters. This cast of characters might be my favourite in Star Wars and given so many layers and complexity.
- Music. Holy crap the soundtrack is INSANE.
- Cast. Incredible acting, particularly from Cameron Monaghan, Debra Wilson, and Noshir Dalal.
- Little tidbits. Developers embracing memes will never not be amazing. From boss fights, to cosmetics, I was smiling the entire time.

CONS:
- Stability. I'm averaging about a crash each play session. While annoying it's not *terrible*, just make sure you save often.
- Performance. I have a decent rig and it holds up mostly. There are elements of pop-in, loading graphics, and the occasional frame stutter, but it's mostly a smooth experience.
- World. Instead of several decently large worlds, you get one MASSIVE world (and I mean massive), one large, and three small ones. While I love the exploration, the lack of diversity does make the game feel smaller than Fallen Order although the actual land covered is likely larger but still just as fun.

I Understand the complaints about crashing because it was bad. However in it's current state it's very playable and if you do experience problems try adjusting your graphics. I know I have a 3060TI and the game was almost unplayable until I turned on Dlss.

  That aside... Please play this game!! I played the original about 4 times, maybe 5 and this one I have already played twice and I will definitely play it again and again. Why? The story is stellar. Like nothing I have seen from a AAA title in the better part of a decade. It sucks you in with familiar characters and you get to see them grow in an actual character arc. Also, some of the twist and turns it throws at you are really well played out and don't come off as forced or lacking in sound reason which so often seems to be the case in modern story telling. 

 The combat picks up right where you left off and it just dog piles on with great new moves and combo potential and I love the styles they added... pistol and saber being a favorite. It does a great job with the power curve, you don't feel OP'ed at any point in the game and the boss battles are very well thought out and memorable. There can be some difficulty spike but most of that comes from roaming off the beaten path.

 This would prolly be my GotY if not for AC6. But I digress, This is a must play game!!

I had thought that I'd waited long enough to purchase this game for it to be actually playable.

Apparently not.

Here's an overview of my first 5 attempts at launching this unoptimised mess:

1. Waited for the stupid EA app to install. Massive lag spike (>1 fps) in the main menu and splash screens. Then waited for it to "optimise game files..." Then it crashed during the opening cutscene...

2. Rebooted the game. Managed to get into the actual game. Froze again within the first 15 mins of gameplay (during which I was handcuffed...)

3. Disabled the EA overlay (which I didn't even realise was running...) and changed from borderless windowed to fullscreen. Froze again in the exact same spot...

4. Didn't even get into the game this time. Changed all the graphics settings to low, skipped the opening cutscene and got frozen on a black screen...

5. Turned off the Steam overlay, made sure to not touch ANY buttons during that bit that froze me the last few times, and it actually worked!! ... for about 10 mins. And then it froze again...

So I guess I'll refund it and wait a year or two...

Looks like a fun game though. Hope I'll be able to play it one day.......

Jedi Survivor is a great game that suffers heavily from poor optimization for the PC port. I was running a 3060ti and although the new patch 7.5 helped fix some of the lag spikes , the game still runs poorly. There are lag spikes from as the moment you start , and it only gets worse as you progress towards bigger enemies and groups. Jedi survivor is a great game, with amazing polished combat that is refined from the original, Its just the performance which is still a major issue for PC gamer who have a decent or even high settings setup. If you have A PS5 or another console i would recommend getting it there. In PS5 The 7.5 patch allowed players to have 60 fps and a optimization setting which removed raytracing. However if you still have it on PC removing ray tracing and putting it to performance mode can help keep you around 60 frames. but by any means if you can get it on console,  DO NOT GET IT ON PC.

Story and game mechanics wise, the game is magnificent -11/10 even!- so far in the last 10 hours i've spent. You are granted with the most of the skills in the first game -for instance, reflecting blaster bolts while sprinting and BD-1's hack abilities- from the start so you don't need to relearn the whole stuff. The game is build upon progression. Even though you find Cal stronger and wiser than in the end of the first game, you still learn new things and improve throughout the game, which doesn't bore you and still does feel original. I can virtually see no major imperfections regarding the story and the mechanics, it is absolutely perfect to say the least.

Well, the gameplay is unfortunately not so perfect as the game itself, there are some significant performance issues but it doesn't make the game unplayable by any means, for me at least. I'm using a Hp Omen laptop with i7-13700hx, RTX4080 mobile, 32GB RAM, and 2TB SSD and i' having on average 60 to 90 fps on high settings without ray tracing because ray tracing brings way less than it takes. I've tried on epic and medium settings and find high to be the midpoint for fps and quality. The least fps i get is around 30 and it is still perfectly playable. The RAM usually goes around 15 to 19GBs depending on the current workload of the pc. One thing i've noticed is that when im using the holomap on mantis the fps drops to 10-15 and it lags, yet i can still choose where to go. I think all these are as they are because the game has just been released, after some patches i hope it will run way smoother.

To conclude, the game itself is perfect and excells at being a sequel to an already succesful game. Although you may not get the best performance out of it, when these performance issues have been dealth with, which almost definately will happen, i reckon you should just go, buy and play this brilliant game.

Just remove Denuvo and optimize the game. Runs like utter garbage. I waited a while for them to fix the game, and I saw a few reviews saying they fixed the game. NOPE. Ryzen 5600x, 32GB ram, RTX 3060TI, M2 SSD. 50fps max with CONSTANT drops, stutters and freezing. 

For everyone familiar with the DMC 5 story, i strongly believe that removing DENUVO will fix all these problems, EA is just too greedy, they are willing to sacrifice their game and its performance in order to stop the few ohoi savy laddies sailing the seven seas with a black flag. FU EA.

Overall a really fun game from a really shitty publisher :)

Jedi Survivor is a perfectly made sequel. It retains what worked in Jedi Fallen Order, it adjusts that which didn't, and introduces many new and innovative concepts and features. While the options of varied playstyles keeps the game fresh. It's also challenging that gives a great payoff when you finally succeed. 

The story is on par with what you could expect from a movie and the music adds to the delightful experience - including a sparingly use of classic themes used at just the right times for the most impact.

The only part I felt held it back was the occasional glitch and problems with ray tracing leading to a few crashes. Hopefully this is to be ironed out.

The final result is a game that drags you in, keeps you invested in its characters and story throughout the game's (significantly longer than Fallen Order's) playtime.

Jedi Suvivor is truly a magnificent sequel and Star Wars story well worth the money - 10/10

i purchased this for $70 in November and it released in April. this is BS. i told myself i would never write a review for any game ever unless it is absolute garbage. ive been in the gaming sphere for 10+ years. first review ive ever written. this game was one of the most frustrating things i have ever installed on my beast of a pc.

to be able to even launch the game, you have to install some good ol' EA bloat-ware(and perhaps some spyware) thats just a pain in the ass to install. i get its not uncommon for companies to require their own launchers but im sorry its a joke and no ones laughing. so once your done with the torturous process that is the EA launcher, you are all set! oh wait. you gasp. a 128 GB download stares back. what the actual fuck is this. 128 fucking gigabyes. i feel sorry for the people who's pc can store only 128 gigabytes. the devs couldn't even bother to compress that shit. well after the 2 hour long download process,  you can finally get to the game!

This game is genuinely fantastic. An incredible upgrade from the first game, in basically every aspect. The story and character writting stronger. The level designs are incredibly well constructed, expanded, and dense. There is so much to do on each planet, with Kohbo being the standout for sure. It's so much fun. The gameplay itself is just phenomenal, all the new additions to the movement, combat, and force abilites are fun and exciting. They all add to the game and allow for incredibly fun ways to traverse the world, different ways to fight the enemies, and just a very varied gameplay experience. It looks gorgeous, has an incredible score, and a incredible presentation all around. I cannot go back to the old game after this one, it is such a vast improvement over the first in basically every aspect.
However, I played this on PC which is plauged with performance issues. I was lucky to be able to play it pretty okay for most the run but the constant stuttering, frame lag, freezes, unloaded cutscenes, and multiple crashes really hurt this game. I'm going to give it a 10/10, because I truly believe it is one, but those issues cannot be overlooked and I want to make it apparent that they have really hurt this game. Don't buy this till it's fixed, but once it is, it's worth full price.

TLDR; it is 100% worth the purchase once its performance issues are fixed and the game actually can function on PC lol

A decent successor - more content, better overall quality.
I liked wider variety of styles, though I don't understand the limitation to have only two at once (lore-wise, not gameplay-wise). I'd prefer lightsaber forms (I-VII) over most of these styles - no game adapted them except KotORs (to my knowledge), so it would be awesome to finally see it.
Maybe in the next game, perhaps.
Since I like the universe I also enjoyed hunting most collectibles, they also offered more interesting puzzles to solve, though I find Fallen Order ones more interesting as they involved some backstory, an in-depth background. Make no mistake though, there are LOTS of collectibles in Survivor.
There's a grain of salt, too. [spoiler]What's the point of garden? It literally serves no purpose at all, maybe, MAYBE except artificial prolonging a walkthrough.[/spoiler]

Overall, it's still the game worth to play at least once whether you're fan of the universe or not!

Jedi Survivor is the perfect sequel to its previous game. This game brings back all the elements that made the first game great in the first place and dials it to an eleven. Overall, if you like Cal, lightsabers, and drip - it's a must have.

Update 12/09/2023: First time playing since Patch 7 released. with crash fixes and performance fixes. The patch corrupted a file and as a result failed to install which didn't become apparent until I'd tried to update the game at least 12 times, validating files and clearing caches in between. Once it did actually update, it performed the same, and crashed within 5 minutes of loading the save. Literally was jumping across platforms and it crashed. Fantastic update there...

Specs for performance comparison:
Ryzen 7 5800x3d
ASUS TUF 4070ti
64GB DDR4 RAM @ 3200MHz
Game loading from SSD
Playing at 1440p, Adaptive Sync, Epic Preset, HDR on, Raytracing off

I preordered the game, so I had no way to know ahead of time how terrible the performance would be on launch. I tried to play it and gave up after less than an hour. I saw the response and decided to wait. Eventually forgot about it due to work and other games. 

Just came back to it yesterday and found the performance to be better, but still not brilliant, dipping to high 40s in some specific cases, which is pretty abysmal for my machine, but I can deal with it as it really only matters if there's stuttering, of which there is minimal. There is a bit of shoddy game design in two early bosses in the Rancor and Spawn of Oggdo, where they give very little time to react and their tracking is near perfect, so you need to have near perfect timing, or just do chip damage (especially Oggdo).

The issue is that it's there's more bugs than an ant hill.
- General oddness here and there regarding enemy movements
- Grabbing onto walls that you shouldn't be able to, only to not be able to let go
- Got sent flying across a room once for no reason that I could see
- Random invisible walls in the middle of open fields
- Dodging sometimes having absolutely no effect, and getting hit anyway

But this sort of stuff was kinda just the jank that I've come to expect from EA. What absolutely killed the game for me was two save game breaking bugs.

The first was that for no reason while walking around in the wilderness on the first planet, the game crashed so hard that my PC needed to be hard rebooted. When it finally came back, my save file was corrupted, with apparently no backup available, despite a backup being present in the save folder. I cannot get a clear answer on whether or not the EA app supports cloud saves, which really annoying, because when I first ran the game after having not touched it in months, it asked if I wanted to use my local save or the cloud save? Even if they do exist, there's apparently no way to force them to sync, so that save is gone. And I should point out that this is a known issue in this and one other area, but no fix yet.

The game crashed again, requiring a reboot again, triggered by buying the first skill upgrade during the tutorial so, yeah good. Started again, completed the tutorial and got to the first workbench only to find that my preorder and deluxe content was missing. Found the fix (disable, run, quit, enable, run again), and moved on to the first planet, only to find that the game reset my level ups, priorite pickups, and stims. So I lost resources because the game just decided I did.

So my options are: Continue the game in a nerfed state with who know what other random penalties I didn't notice, or start again for the 4th time in less than 24 hours and hope that the game doesn't screw me over this time, with no way to predict what might happen next.

Thanks EA, you absolute travesty of a company.

The performance is definitely a sour spot for the game. It is very embarrassing that they released the game in this state as they fumbled a great game by doing so. However the game builds on everything the first game designed itself around. There is far less backtracking and if you do need to backtrack, they've put in dozens of shortcuts to make it quicker.

The gameplay is a definite upgrade through from Fallen Order. The variety of weapon stances and enemies keeps the game interesting, as they've massively increased enemy variety and tactics. Additionally the customization is far more deep between the lightsaber configurations, your outfit, your skill point distribution, and which 2 stances you wish to run around with.

If you liked Fallen Order's story, you'll likely enjoy Survivor's story. It isn't one of the best pieces of Star Wars storytelling but it is very solid, which tracks with Respawn's track record.



An odd change was that the last game had 4 planets of fairly evenly portioned content while most of the content in Survivor is on one specific planet with brief 1-2 hour detours on 2-3 other planets. Aside from the minor 1-mission side content, the Fallen Order had the forests of Kashyyyk, the wetlands of Bogano, the rocky mountains of Zeffo, and a mixture of swamps and mountains for Dathomir. In this game, you have the scientific facility of Koboh's Shattered Moon, the desert ruins of Jedha, and Koboh. Koboh is largely rugged cliffs and valleys with a dark swamp area, desolate spires, and caves. There is some imperial bases and military bases that work as differing scenario in the game but the overwhelming majority of your time will be on Koboh, as Koboh is the main hub and several story areas connect to Koboh. So while there may be a bit more diversity in scenario, you will spend most of your time in this one area as opposed to it being paced across these other areas because Koboh has a massive amount of content compared to the rest of the game.

Overall it's a good game that you could pour dozens of hours into and relax or go sweaty, turn up the difficulty, and get demolished by double frogs.
Despite any performance issues, the story is what drives this game, and it delivers hard.

If you're looking for a real good space adventure then this is for you. If you like a little bit of a challange then this is for you. If you liked the first one then this is for you.

I played at 2K and at 165hz except for when I was on Jedha, especially when Merrin was around, in that case I had to limit fps to 60. Also turning off Ray Tracing prevented the rest of my crashes. So if you're using Nvidia, I'd recommend changing these settings and you'll most likely have a great time.

Decided to take a chance and see if I could run this game, very glad that I did. Fantastic story, great combat, fun puzzles. Just as good, if not better, than Fallen Order. Just finished the main quest line @26.5 hours. Still have plenty left to explore. Less locations than the first game (you pretty much bounce between two planets the whole story), but the areas are bigger. Enemy variety is very good. Overall, it is a more condensed version of Fallen Order, which is a good thing imo. Less focused on taking you to every planet in the galaxy and more focused on a immersive, engaging story.

Performance issues seem to be a case-by-case basis. Game ran just about perfectly for me on high (a few things set to ultra) settings without anything crazy for hardware (9900K, 2080Ti, 32gb DDR4). Graphics were beautiful, cut scenes were smooth, and even in intense fights my frame rate hardly ever dipped below 60fps. The only time I experienced lag was each time I accessed the holo-table on the Mantis, which is not a big deal at all.

Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who was a fan of Fallen Order. Another solid entry for the Jedi series. Can't say it will run perfectly on your PC given all the difficulties others are having. All I can say is that it ran really well for me and I definitely think it is worth giving a shot.

Except for launch performance, this game is in almost every way an improvement on the original. 10/10, can't wait for more.

if you enjoyed the first one, this one improves on a lot of mechanics. There is improved combat with 4 different lightsaber styles now and a lot more force moves. I do have to say that enemies still do get stale as they reuse a lot of them many times, though there are several new enemies and the repeated ones have slightly different moves

[h1] Firstly, the performance issues [/h1]
Like others I did have issues with performance initially. For me, it seemed to be Wallpaper Engine. I just had to pause the wallpaper when the game is running and now no more stuttering/sudden FPS drops.
Now I can consistently get 50-60FPS on high settings baring in mind I don't have top of the line hardware:
[list]
[*]GTX 1070
[*]i7-9700K
[/list]

[h1] The Game [/h1]
I'm around 25 hours in and so far it's a fun and interesting game.
The new stances are interesting and the fact that you don't feel like you've gone backwards and weak again (like most squeals do) is great.
And the story, for the most part, is decent. Yes, there are some bits that feel repetitive, but what game doesn't' have that?

[h1] Would I Recommend It [/h1]
Yes is would... Providing it's on a sale. After all, if you do get the performance issues then you can always try for a refund.
But if you don't have them issues then it's just generally a good game with nice lightsaber combat, powerful force abilities and cool lightsaber attacks (if upgraded enough).
You will never find the game where the grass burns better

SW Jedi: Survivor is a masterful sequel to Jedi Fallen Order. Even though this game stumbled a little at launch with a few technical issues, patience and time allowed the team to fix most if not all issues with the game. I didn't experience any real issues other than a few graphical glitches that had no impact on my ability to play the game or my enjoyment of it.

This game is beautiful, the graphics are stellar and the art style is wonderful, each location in the game has a unique yet familiar style. There is no mistaking that this is set in the Star Wars universe.

The Story is interesting and enthralling, Cal's story continues to be fun and entertaining, with a health dash of Star Wars lore added in and a few minor references to legacy characters sprinkled in to remind you when in the Star Wars timeline Cal's story is taking place. I personally found the story to be solid, intriguing and at times heartfelt and heart wrenching. To the writing team I say, Bravo!

The game play and mechanics are solid and have a good "feel" to them, if you enjoyed how Fallen Order played, this game is more of the same, tightened up with most all the kinks worked out. I played perfectly fine on mouse and keyboard.

Overall I really enjoyed Jedi Survivor, I'd highly recommend it to fans of Star Wars, especially if they played and enjoyed Fallen Order. I'd also recommend playing Fallen Order first before playing Survivor, though you could play this without having played Fallen Order, it could be a detriment to your enjoyment of this game if you hadn't already meet the cast of characters from the first game. 

TLDR: It's a great game and a must play for Star Wars fans.

I'm one of the lucky few who had basically no bugs or performance issues at the launch of the game which allowed me to experience this game to its fullest.

Survivor is a perfect sequel to Fallen Order in my eyes. The gameplay is vastly improved upon from the first game by adding new stances, gadgets, and force abilities, and it also just feels way more responsive compared to Fallen Order. There's tons of unique story and side bosses, and also, an entire bounty hunter side questline to experience.

The story is absolutely incredible. It's easily one of the best Star Wars stories ever told. The characters feel real and have genuine reactions with each other that make you care for them. Unlike the Battle Scars book which read like some weird fan fiction from someone who didn't understand the characters at all. Like Fallen Order, the voice acting is incredible, and I think Cameron deserves some kind of award for his performance as Cal in this one.

I played this game with an RTX 3080 12GB, i5 12600kf, and 32GB RAM on an SSD. I played on Epic settings with FSR on before they added DLSS, and I would get around 45-60fps at Rambler's Reach on Koboh. Everywhere else on Koboh was 70-90fps, and all the other planets averaging between 70-120fps. After several patches and the addition of DLSS, I get ~10-15fps more than before in most cases.

Overall, I highly recommend this game if you were a fan of the first game, or a fan of Star Wars in general as this is probably my favorite Star Wars game now (previously Republic Commando). Buy it on sale and hope you can run it.

Jedi Survivor is undoubtedly an exceptional game, a captivating addition to the Star Wars universe that should be celebrated for its engaging story line, well-crafted characters, and thrilling light saber combat. However, it is incredibly disheartening that the PC performance tarnishes what could have been an unforgettable experience.

Unfortunately, the PC performance issues significantly dampen the joy of playing Jedi Survivor. The game's graphics suffer from severe frame drops, stuttering, and screen tearing, robbing players of the full experience of exploring the beautifully crafted Star Wars environments. These technical shortcomings hinder immersion and can be incredibly frustrating for players who were eagerly anticipating an optimized and seamless gaming experience..

If you like Star Wars even in the slightest, it'll be worth it.

If you liked Fallen Order you‚Äôll love this game, but the performance issues are obvious and frustrating at times due to how good this game actually is.

It's clear they have listened to both the negatives and positives of Fallen Order, and improved everything again, I'm sure once they‚Äôve fixed the performance issues this game will be regarded as one of the best Star Wars games out there.

Some things of improvements:
- Planets are more fleshed out and bigger than Fallen Order.
- 2 New Forms (3 if you include Duel being an actual one this time).
- Way more customisation to Cal and not just Poncho colours (yes the Poncho is back).
- Improved Customisation of BD-1 and Cal's Lightsaber. from hundreds of colours and patterns, as well as being able to adjust the condition of the material.
- More enemy factions and variety of enemies (B1s are hilarious as always) 
- Somehow made the already great movement/climbing mechanics feel even better and more satisfying. 


Great New Features:
- The saloon is amazing, you can find people in the world to invite to it ‚Äòmore lively, one also gives you access to a new mini game, but Skoova Stev is the best.
- Fast Travel
- Perk slot system to add more variety to builds
- Various creatures you can use to traverse the wider maps.

I would 100% recommended getting this game now if you can tough out the performance issue, if not then when the patch comes through.

Jedi Survivor could be good, but it's completely let down by horrific optimisation and broken features.

When a game still has simple accessibility options which are broken (toggle hold pull), ironically making them inaccessible, on a title that's now 5 months old and has had 7 patches, it really emphasises just how little the dev's care about fixing the game...

The

TL;DR: If you liked the first game, you'll like this one too. But, wait for a sale.

[b] The Good: [/b]

- The writing has taken a step up from the previous game. It's still very "Star Wars" ("I hate sand..") but the acting performances come through much clearer and with the relationships we've already built with the characters from the first game, it's very nice to see some character development.

- It took me ~30hrs to 100% explore all planets and complete the game on Jedi Master difficulty. There's a good amount of content to explore in the three main planets, and those open worlds are huge. Much less linear than in Fallen Order. 

- The game settings are much more accessible (FOV slider lets gooooo).

- The enemy diversity is a big plus, between the Empire, Bedlam Raiders, and Fauna there's close to 30 different enemy types, excluding bosses. 

- The worlds feel much more like they exist in the star wars universe, rather than separate ideas forced to fit into the star wars mold.

- The Force Tears are a very fun mechanic, like Subsistence missions from the MGS games. [spoiler] The one where you fight two rancor at once made me pull my hair out [/spoiler]

[b] The Meh: [/b]

- The majority of the game is spent bouncing around two planets. While it makes sense for the story, I personally would have enjoyed a bit more varied locations to explore. 

- While Survivor uses the same engine as Fallen Order, Unreal 4, it does look better in the some of the lighting and animation departments. A lot of work and polish obviously went into that. However, the textures fall short. Plastic-y textures and blown out sunlight are the biggest complaints. Even with brightness at 25%, many times when standing indoors or in a cave, looking out a door, window, etc. the sunlight would completely blow out the visibility outside, which isn't normally a big deal, but makes some puzzles or locations hard to see. One type of the collectibles are only found by finding floating green particle effects, which are very tough to see in bright environments, like outdoors in direct sunlight.

- Speaking of collectibles, there are so damn many. Over 500 including Echos, lightsaber parts, cosmetics (most have a color pallet found seperately), and trade resources, makes most of the game play loop somewhat grading. That being said, if you don't care about picking up every little thing it wont affect your play experince. 

[b] The Bad: [/b]

- I personally didn't have many problems with consistent crashes, Throughout the game however I had constant visual bugs. Such as artifacts and fabric stretching. 

- The game altogether made my PC a space heater, from when I launch to probably 10 minutes after the game closes.

- Hitboxes and input timing can be wonky at times. All the way from dodging un-blockable attacks by dashing into an enemy to my block inputs being ignored. (Partially a skill issue, but worth a mention for how many times it wasn't)

- A few locations are very sparse with the save point locations, generally not an issue, but makes a couple places frustrating. 

- The EA App integration is absolute doggy doo-doo. Launching the game signs me out of EA, the "background service" does not close when the game does, EA is just generally a scummy company and it's on full display here. 

[b] The Spoilers: [/b]

- [spoiler] The Bode twist was some masterful storytelling, big plus, never saw it coming. [/spoiler]

- [spoiler] The Cal/Merrin love story would've felt forced in the first game, but their relationship development felt natural inside Survivor's (and Cal and Merrin's) story [/spoiler]

- [spoiler] The High Republic tie-ins were cool, but it still makes me wish for The Old Republic. [/spoiler]

[b] Conclusion: [/b]

Jedi Survivor, at it's bones, is a really great game. If it had a different publisher and was given more time to optimize, it would have been game of the year. But EA's money grubbing hands killed most chances of that. With time, updates, and hopefully expansions, Jedi Survivor could be a really, really great game. 

Overall, I recommend Jedi Survivor, with the exception to wait for a heavy sale before you buy..

WOW!  And simply saying 'WOW' can't even describe just how amazing this game is.

HOWEVER!!  Let me just get this out of the way: This game came out buggy and un-optimized, which means it clearly was not ready for release.  At the time of writing this review, there are STILL people having issues with this game.

C'mon game developers, seriously?  I know this is a phrase thrown around a lot for stuff like this, but we don't pay $60 - $70 to beta test your game.  We pay because we expect something to be completed when it comes out.  A lazily hashed together 'We're Sorry' notice is not going to sway the minds of your fans/followers if this is how you treat them.  Plus, this should've been fixed by now, though I suppose EA couldn't give a **** less by this point.  Please stop doing this and keep fixing this game.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now, with that out of the way, let me give you a run down of the quick Pros and Cons:

Pros:

- Extensive combat system, which is a stark improvement over the last game.
- BEAUTIFUL worlds and atmospheres (AFTER the bug and slight optimization patches).
- Incredible scores that FEEL like Star Wars.  Whoever composed this stuff must be the reincarnation of John Williams.
- More enemies, and much like before, each with their own unique mechanics that require cunning maneuvers.
- Plenty of minigames and extra activities for a single player game.
- NO MICRO-TRANSACTIONS.
- An interesting and compelling story following Cal Kestis, who really is more likable between these two games.
- Many achievements for those who want to 100% the game.
- Cool unlockables, gear, and more freedom on customization for Cal, BD-1, and the weaponry.
- The ability to mod the game on the PC version, changing the game to make it even more hilarious/fun.
- Some dismemberment, which is better than none!
- And many smaller details I'm likely missing!

Cons:

- Game required multiple patches after launch (It's still a mess now).
- Optimization is a mess on PC.  Highly recommend you play this on a console unless you have a super computer.
- Slightly awkward dodge mechanic that requires getting used to (Especially after the previous game).
- Requiring the use of EA's launcher.
- And perhaps some other things that I haven't noticed in my playthrough.

The pros do outweigh the cons, hence the thumbs-up for this review.  However, again, this does not excuse the state in which the game came out in, and the state it's in now.  If you're a Star Wars fan, like me, and are willing to bear through the issues, there really is something special to be had with this game.  If you're an average-Joe looking for something souls-like to fuel the addiction, I would suggest playing something different until this gets fixed on PC.

Despite some crashes and other performance issues that showed up as FPS drops and stutters, the game was in my own opinion, amazing. Its far and away better than Jedi Fallen Order with each world being much larger with more to discover, more to fight, and see. The combat compared to Fallen Order is also so much better and much more varied, as you would expect with more stances and the inclusion of a blaster. The increased amount of customization of basically everything, from your clothing and its colors, to hair styles, beards to the blaster and the increased amount of lightsaber parts and to top it off, BD-1 gets parts to customize as well which is a welcomed inclusion. 

I did enjoy the story, it didn't feel pointless like everything we did meant nothing in terms of achieving anything. There were parts of the story that I could see a mile away, but despite that, they still had some impact. I felt the game had good length, even if you aren't trying to find everything. New Game Plus is another welcome inclusion, and I understand certain aspects of things not carried over, as it would break the flow of the game and actually just outright break the game.

I would recommend the game for sure, but do keep in mind it does have performance issues, so if you can get past the occasional crashes and frame drops and stutters, you will find a good and enjoyable star wars game with good gameplay and a good story.

**Review of "Jedi: Survivor" by Chris**

If you're on the fence about diving into "Jedi: Survivor," let me share my experience with this stellar game. As a fellow gaming enthusiast, I believe this title offers something special for both Star Wars fans and gamers alike.

First off, the story is a standout feature. It's not just a run-of-the-mill narrative; we're talking about a well-crafted plot that showcases complex character development. As you progress through the game, you'll find yourself deeply invested in the characters' journeys. This depth adds a rich layer to the gameplay, making every decision and battle feel meaningful.

Speaking of gameplay, it's as smooth as it gets. Transitioning between combat, exploration, and story sequences feels seamless. Whether you're engaged in a lightsaber duel or navigating through intricate environments, the controls are intuitive and responsive. This polished gameplay ensures that your focus remains on the experience, not on wrestling with clunky mechanics.

"Jedi: Survivor" is a must-play. It blends a compelling narrative with fluid gameplay to create an immersive experience. Whether you're a Star Wars aficionado or just someone who appreciates well-designed games, this one's definitely worth your time. Give it a try, and may the Force be with you in your gaming adventures!

Starting this off, I want to try to give EA the benefit of the doubt, and blame it on day 1 problems, but it is very hard to just shrug it off and pretend I haven't spent a lot of money on the game. This is a very poor launch, especially for the first part of the game.

The first 2 hours you must persevere through an extremely poorly optimised planet, I have since then moved onto the second planet of the game and my framerate seems to be much more consistent and enjoyable.

Playing on a 3060ti and a Ryzen 9 5900x I assumed it would run fine. Unfortunately it does NOT for the first 2 hours. The game itself is not bad at all, it is super fun from what I've played so far and as a massive Star Wars fan I love the combat, characters and everything about the world, but with the poor framerate on a pretty good PC it is quite disappointing.

I really hope they give the game further updates but with EA being the company they are I don't know if we can trust them to fix everything. 

I knew to expect the day 1 Negative reviews, as all throughout the night of launch, the speculation of people crying and winging about not having a constant 144fps in the game was insane. If you are willing to play through the start of game at a poor framerate then move onto the rest of the game and enjoy it at a good framerate then you should purchase it.

If you are running anything below a 3060, it might be harder to justify the ¬£60 price tag, it might be better off to pick up the game when it is on sale or if the bugs get fixed in the next few weeks, however the PC version of the game isn't the only version with problems, PS5 and XBOX Series consoles have been reported to have bad stutters and frame drops. 

Try to ignore the haters, after all it is a Star Wars game and there will always be someone complaining about it, let alone the fact EA is behind this title.

Once I have played more of the game and if the framerate issues get solved I will come back to add to this review.

After finishing the game and actually getting 100% achievements, I can say that if your machine is able to run this game then I will suggest playing it as they have made performance better (however still doesn't run like it should -_-). The game has a great story that is engaging and it has twists and turns that are not predictable, it has fun lightsaber gameplay that is refreshed since the previous game with all of the new stances and the customisation is stellar compared to other games in this genre.

To address the elephant in the room, yes I did have performance issues but the first patch actually completely fixed it for me. 

Now, to actually review the game itself. I genuinely enjoy this game so much more than I even truly expected to. I have always loved Star Wars ever since I was a little kid so I was stoked to see a new game come out. I also really enjoy souls-like games, so the fact that this game combines two of my favorite genres ever is awesome to begin with. 

I think they did a fantastic job getting that signature souls-like feeling while also having the fun, suspenseful, interesting original story from a pre-existing universe. Aside from the Souls games themselves I think this game is a masterclass in what a souls-like can be. Obviously the performance issues suck and made a lot of people dislike the game, but I think looking past that to the gem of a game under it is important. The voice acting is great especially from Cameron Monaghan, and the art/vfx are stunning in almost all instances. 

I do highly recommend this game. I will say that if you don't have a middle to high end PC you are unlikely to get the best experience but it will be fun no matter what.

"Star Wars Jedi: Survivor" is one heck of a game! The gameplay is top-notch, especially the lightsaber combat and parkour moves. Exploring those open-world landscapes felt like stepping into the Star Wars universe for real.

The story's cool, but I wished it connected more with the movies and shows. Cal's character growth and his thing with Merrin added depth, though. And those nostalgic cameos and music hits? Gave me major Star Wars feels!

The combat's great, but I hoped the lightsabers would feel even more powerful, slicing through enemies like they do in the movies. (some of them)

Overall, "Survivor" is a solid Star Wars adventure. It's got room to improve, but if you're into Jedi action and exploring epic worlds, give this one a go.

Don't get me wrong, The PC release of this game was terrible. So I chose to wait for the game to be patched. Now 5 months later I bought the game on sale and played through it till the end. I experienced only 1 or 2 minor glitches my entire play-through, all of which being graphical, the game-play was flawless. I don't have insane PC specs either. 

After experiencing everything STAR WARS Jedi: Survivor has to offer, I can truly say it's a fantastic game. This game had made some fantastic improvements to it's story, mechanics, graphics, combat etc compared to it's predecessor STAR WAR JEDI: Fallen Order. I would go into to detail but honestly I think it's best you buy it and play it for yourself spoiler-free like I did. All my issues with the game itself are far to minor and nit-picky to mention.

Though I praise this game for how fun it is, Game Developers should NEVER be forced (or consider) to release an UNFINISHED GAME. I only had a good experience because I waited FIVE MONTHS AFTER RELEASE. These companies are getting way to comfortable releasing unfinished games to make a dead-line or a quick buck. Just delay it. I'd prefer a late game than an unfinished one. Take the Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom for example. That game was delayed AN ENTIRE YEAR OF IT'S INTENDED RELEASE and it turned out fantastic as a result. I preordered this game and played it at launch. I was lucky enough to only suffer some minor performance issues, up until the final bossfight, where booting the game up caused it to crash. I spent half a year waiting for the bug to eventually be fixed, and then I could finally finish the game.

Even with my bad experience, I still love this game. The soundtrack, the visuals, the gameplay, and filling up the diner with patrons (and watching them leave again) all contributed to a magical time. My game of the year for 2023, hands down.

An Emotional and Captivating Adventure

**Disclaimer: This review focuses solely on the game's content, characters, and the emotional impact it had, without addressing performance issues or bugs.**

Star Wars Jedi Survivor is a game that has touched my heart in ways I never expected. It's a breathtaking journey filled with moments of joy, excitement, and even tears. I feel compelled to share my experience with you, as it has truly been a transformative and emotional ride.

From the very first moments of the game, I was immediately captivated by its immersive storytelling. The characters came to life before my eyes, and I found myself forming deep connections with them as if they were real people. The performances were so genuine and heartfelt that I couldn't help but be moved by their struggles, their triumphs, and their unwavering determination.

The world of Survivor is a marvel to behold. The attention to detail in the environments, the rich lore, and the stunning visuals transported me to a galaxy far, far away. I felt like I was a part of this vast universe, experiencing the wonders and dangers alongside the characters I had grown to love.

But it wasn't just the grandeur of the game that moved me. It was the intimate moments, the quiet conversations, and the profound connections forged throughout the journey. The game delves deep into themes of friendship, resilience, and the power of hope, reminding me of the profound impact we can have on each other's lives.

There were moments when I laughed with pure delight, moments when I cheered with triumph, and moments when tears welled up in my eyes. The emotional depth of Survivor is unparalleled, and it resonated with me on a profound level. It made me reflect on my own life, my own relationships, and the power of perseverance in the face of adversity.

As I reached the end of the game, a bittersweet feeling washed over me. I was elated by the incredible journey I had taken, but I also felt a pang of sadness knowing that it had come to an end. Survivor had opened my eyes to the beauty of storytelling and the power of immersive gaming experiences.

In the end, Star Wars Jedi Survivor is not just a game. It's a transformative experience that has left an indelible mark on my soul. It has reminded me of the power of empathy, the strength of the human spirit, and the importance of cherishing the moments we have with the ones we love.

If you're looking for a game that will make you feel truly alive, that will immerse you in a rich and vibrant world, and that will touch your heart in ways you never thought possible, then look no further. Star Wars Jedi Survivor is a masterpiece that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

May the Force guide you on this unforgettable journey.....

An incredibly strong game that does an amazing job of realising both the world, themes, and Jedi fantasy of the Star Wars world in an interactive way, while also being a really fun game. The combat is excellent, the environments are gorgeous, the customisation options are great, and I thought Cal‚Äôs journey and narrative was easily one of the best from Star Wars I‚Äôve consumed in a long time. I also think the way the game visually, and mechanically represents [spoiler] Cal‚Äôs experience with the Dark Side/Cere‚Äôs strength as a Jedi Master [/spoiler] is inspired and are fantastically powerful gameplay-narrative moments.

But between it‚Äôs suite of technical issues, weak side-content, and bloated collectibles/open-world shenanigans, the core game is constantly fighting way harder than it needs to stay well-paced and constantly engaging.

I hope we continue to get patches and performance improvements, I‚Äôm eager to replay on NG+ to get a more streamlined experience, and I can‚Äôt wait for the sequel.

The weak launch may have damaged the overall perception of Jedi Survivor, but rest assured it IS a fantastic game (when it works). Now that it's out of public beta.... I mean been release for a while (sarcasm). The bugs and technical issues have been fixed. 

So its both cheaper and in a better overall state. 

As to my actual review.

Story is decent and while I personally liked the first games plot a bit better, that IS a personal preference and this Jedi Survivor is by no means bad.

Gameplay is (now) much better than the first game, it's a bit sharper and more responsive. In addition to this the powers, challenges and several other aspects of the game have been expanded on.

Soundtrack .... it's Star Wars... as long as they put John Williams on repeat I am happy.

Voice Acting is well done, and to a AAA standard.

Some "Pre Order" and "Deluxe Edition" BS, so it looses a point for that, but no MTX crap beyond that.
As a side note, I would skip the Deluxe Edition, the cosmetics aren't worth $2 let alone the ~$20 in my opinion and the game itself has plenty to collect, many of which are more impressive than the cash-grab ones.

Overall 8/10 (up from a 6/10 at release, now that most technical issues have been fixed)

The final proof that EA doesn't deserve the Star Wars license.

While I am normally biased in favour of any Star Wars media, this one just sucks.

I appreciate that it is a lengthy single player game, rather than multiplayer-only or best-as-multiplayer, as so many other EA games. I appreciate getting to play as a jedi and all that, BUT:

* Double-DRM. Why the **** don't they adopt a more consumer friendly approach to DRM? I bought the game on Steam, why do I also need the EA launcher to run alongside it? DRM could easily be handled server side between Valve and EA's APIs, but no.. we have to be reminded that it is an EA game. Don't worry EA - I'm more than aware that this is one of your releases, don't need the launcher to recognise that fact. It unnecessarily complicates the use of Big Picture mode for one, as well as complicating playing the game on Linux through Proton. There should be a law against this double-DRM nonsense. Imagine needing to install the EA, Epic, Ubisoft, 2K and other launchers on a Playstation or XBox... so why torture PC gamers? We bought the game on our chosen platform, we can prove it, so now leave us alone. No need for a 2nd or 3rd launcher. 

* Performance tuning is abysmal, just like the previous instalment: Jedi Fallen Order. It's just lazy software development. All the Sony Playstation PC games run flawlessly and often even look better than Jedi Survivor, yet frame rate is all over the shop with this untuned rubbish. It gets better with DLSS/FSR enabled, but this game is way too resource demanding for the fidelity it delivers.

* Graphics fidelity is a mess, textures glitch way too often - or even consistently. Example: Wearing the Tactical Outfit with Cape will see BD's legs clearly going right through the fabric. Or riding the Spamel on Jedha, the way the legs (don't properly) connect with the ground is just too distractingly ugly.

* Horrible camera automation, it almost proactively sabotages the player.

* The amount of climbing and battling of fauna. It gets really tedious, really fast. A bit of climbing, sure. A few monsters here and there, sure. Not this crap. I want to fight the empire, not the Discovery Channel.

* ...

The story isn't too bad, a bit predictable but not bad overall.

Verdict: Have other developers develop Star Wars games from now on. Keep the writers, ditch the publisher and programmers. I recommend watching the story on YouTube. The game itself is a mess at its best, and abysmal at its worst.

I have to finish this game as I paid for it, but I really don't enjoy it one bit. Tedious, messy, rubbish.

Amazing gameplay and story, dogshit EA

For story and gameplay, it is great. It is a perfect sequel that really has heart felt moments, serious and also funny moments. Cal has grown a lot since the last game and has matured in his connection to the force and as a person. His dark sides moments are really cool and I cannot wait to see where the 3rd game goes. 
However, the bugs and unoptimized nature of this game really harms this game from being a top tier game. My PC is a mid-range build that has no problem get above 90 fps on high-ultra 1440p but I can only get 50 with constant drops. The patches have been useful but it is not enough to fix the game. 
Overall 9/10 for story, 9/10 for gameplay, 8/10 for environments/exploration (wish there was more detailed planets), and 5/10 for performance. Get this game for story, if you love star wars, or if you don't mind about performance, otherwise wait for a sale or something.

I lost 27 hours of time played/progress after the game crashed and corrupted my save. Thanks EA!!

Finished the entire game with an average of about 80 FPS with a few frame drops (Koboh) and 1 crash. My performance was fine and i think the game is awesome. It does everything better than the first game.

As of writing I have about 24 hours in the game. I started playing after patch four came out and in terms of performance I have had no crashing and some stuttering, but otherwise it's remained fairly consistent. The only times I notice real frame drops are when I tried streaming on discord but I'd assume that speaks to the strength of my PC rather than the games performance. 

This game feels like it was made by people that love Star Wars. Every NPC I've come across so far has felt very lively and charismatic (looking at you Skoova). I've had lots of fun with the side objectives of the game like finding plants, helping catch fish, playing holotactics, etc.. The only NPC and side quest I think is weak is Caij and hunting the other bounty hunters because I feel it's tedious after the first four bounties to have to go to a different planet to find just one. Caij, to me is just bargain brand Cad Bane, wearing a similar style of clothing that made me excited upon seeing the hat but then sad realizing who was wearing it. 

The combination of narrative moments that unlock abilities has been done better in this game than it its predecessor. I always thought the moments where Cal remembers his training to remember his force abilities was strange in the first game but I think they hit a good combination of combining narrative and gameplay mechanics  this time around when Cal learned the air-dash ability. I thought that a flash back to a life lesson Cal didn't understand at the time works better than remembering that Cal's master taught him how to double jump. 

Overall I'm excited to continue playing the game, and with more patches to come I think this might end up being one of the best Star Wars games made!
This is current go-to game and probably will be for a long time. Its an amazing game with a great story and returning favorite characters. This might be my favorite single player Star Wars game ever.

While there is a few performance issues for sure. I'm yet to have such severe problems as some of these other reviews are stating, can run on high graphics with an old 1070TI.

Now to the actual game. The story and gameplay is just about everything I expected and wished for. Feels like a direct continuation of Fallen Order in every way. The gameplay itself is simply improved in every way, between stance options, new sabre options, customisation, etc. While the story is vastly different, their decision to do so I argue was good, it kept the story fresh and new and strayed away from just throwing the same Inquisitor based story in your face again..

Edit: Missing achievement was fixed, but too little to late. Now 100% completion. 

Waited and waited and waited for fixes for this game, barely any came. Posted on the EA forums of game breaking bugs in May, it is now August / September and nothing.

The game ran ok on my rig (passable FPS, bad drops and stutters here and there), was fun to play when working, but there are errors and in my case on screen errors that literally say error in the game in place of text!

It is scandalous that this level of incompetence is allowed to stand in PC gaming, releasing unfinished and broken games is getting tiresome. It is no wonder people wait for Steam sales as we are treated like dirt.

Respawn has lost all my trust, it may be EA who dictate releases (maybe), but I do know, I will never buy a game from Respawn early again until there are glowing reviews and a sale on.

They of course know their game is broken, they have play testers and the devs are not stupid, but the game is released anyway.

Don't buy, wait a year or two, maybe it will be fixed then.

Maybe Valve can up their own quality control and play test themselves so that studios stop releasing unfinished games.

A great improvement over the previous title, good story, engaging, fun, and challenging gameplay, as well as tons to explore.

Update for Patch 7: This crashes the game for me, now.
"Out of video memory trying to allocate a rendering resource. Make sure your video card has the minimum required memory, try lowering the resolution and/or closing other applications that are running. Exiting..."
Whatever they did broke it on a 1660 Super. Guess no chance at 100%ing this until I can afford a new 8Gb+ graphics card.
Now it goes into the "Do not buy" pile.

Update

I figured out the problem for the out of memory error.

Restart your PC, then get in game/continue your progress, then as soon as you stand up, immediately use the meditation point to re-save your progress. My guess it's something to do with the update to the saving system causing some errors.

Now there's been some UI updates for 16:10 displays, but most screens are still not updated for this, and it seems that they might not, which is a small annoyance.
Still not a perfect game, but it got close :)

=====8<========

Ryzen 7 5700G (32Gb) with an nVidia 1660 Super (6Gb). 1920x1200 resolution.
Running on medium works fine (obviously no raytracing on a 1660). Probably not hitting 60fps most of the time, but it's more than playable.
Hope it gets patched/fixed for all the other people who are having problems, so beware about buying this until it's confirmed to be fixed.

Edit: Now that I've finished it, some thoughts;
This game came out at least 3 months early. EA NEEDS to learn to not launch broken games.
Checked my frame-rates (after the first patch at the start of May) and I'm getting between 30 and 75 (caps at 75 due to monitor frequency and vsync).
The story is a little all-over-the-place at times, but is still good overall.
The character moments are pretty damn perfect.
Some of the gameplay elements are not well explained. For instance, you get the ability to pass through green barrier shields later in the game, but nowhere does it tell you that you can also go through red barrier shields at a specific location, not even in the codex or a hint.
The open world design has the usual problem of feeling a little empty, especially with how big each of the planets is, but at least they give you mounts to make travel quicker, and lets not forget FAST TRAVEL :)
New Game Plus adds some perks to make the game a little harder and to mix up the enemy selections, but these can be turned off.
16:10 screen ratio has the in-game menus cut off on the sides, which is annoying but doesn't break anything.

Final Thoughts:
Only buy this full price if you have a high tolerance for some small bugs/glitches, but also can handle frame-rate fluctuations!
Otherwise, buy on sale or once the patches fix the game properly.
i like it

UPDATE 2: There are many areas that are very laggy outside of the starting mission, but there are also a lot of areas that are working flawlessly for me. Fortunately, I have not had a single crash or freeze and have not encountered a single gameplay bug. The gameplay itself is so much better than the first one (Fallen Order). The combat is better, the enemy variety is far grander and more interesting, map design is more interesting, the world environments are much larger and there are a lot more side activities and random places to explore. The story and characters are more interesting too. The puzzles are SIGNIFICANTLY less annoying than the last game. If they can just get the performance right, this will be a very worthy successor to Fallen Order as it is better in every way.

UPDATE:  I have made it to the second map where my FPS is completely normal so far, running at a locked 72 fps with about 70% GPU utilization, so likely can go about 90+ FPS unlocked. It also seems there is something very wrong with the FSR2 "disabled" setting. When I have FSR2 disabled, the game looks like a blurry, low resolution mess, but with it turned to "Quality", the game looks much sharper and crisper, more like it should. Still overall, seems the game has pretty bad anti-aliasing no matter what setting, even with it set to Epic. I recommend leaving FSR set to Quality no matter what as it seems very bugged otherwise.

Like the other reviews, I am unable to get a stable FPS. I have a 6800 XT and 3700x and get about 57 fps at most, often dipping down to the 40-50 range. Lowering graphics, display settings or utilizing FSR2 changes nothing. The problem seems to be that our GPU's and CPU's are not being utilized fully. I am averaging 30-60 % GPU utilization, with about 10-11.5gb of VRAM being used up on the 6800 xt, and about 10-11gb of RAM as well. CPU utilization is only at 20-30%. So clearly there is a lot more hardware available to be utilized, it's just not being used. Really sad as I feel a lot of the PC community had faith in Respawn as a developer, and this is going to hurt them. 

Please devs, piece of advice: All the patching you are doing now, and doing over the next few weeks and months, needs to already be completed BEFORE you launch the game. That's how you gotta run your business. You guys are losing out on millions (MEELEEONS) of dollars because you are going to get shit on with a red page of steam reviews, and rightfully so. Literally, LITERALLY, the solution is to already be at the stage you would be at 6 months from now literally TODAY at LAUNCH.

Going into Jedi Survivor I was a little worried, the first game was absolutely an amazing experience, and I wasn't sure how well the sequel would live up to it.

Respawn really knocked it out of the park with this one. Everything about the game made me just never want to stop playing. The aesthetics, soundtrack, and gameplay were all spot on. The few gripes I'd had with the first game were almost entirely addressed which was a welcome surprise. I had a blast exploring the environments and exploring different playstyles.

The story often kept me guessing and I was well and truly invested, though I will say one character relationship in particular (if you've played you know what I'm talking about), felt a little bit abrupt and forced. I wish they would have taken their time and had more small moments leading up to the main event.

Nearly all of my problems with the game came from difficulty spikes and the endgame.

I played on the hardest difficulty, and most of the time had no issues, however a handful of boss encounters had me tearing my hair out for at least an hour each. All of the encounters leading up to the boss would feel so easy that I felt woefully unprepared for facing the boss when the required timings became much tighter. I know that this is a key piece of the soulslike genre, but I was just frustrated by the inconsistent difficulty, to the point that on my first playthrough for a few encounters I just changed the difficulty so I wouldn't be pulled out of the story and experience too much. Some boss encounters just felt like luck whether they would use an insta-kill ability on me or not, which is not how I want to win, I wanted skill to prevail, not RNG. 

There is also the issue of an encounter in the second half of the story where you play not as the main character, but a side character instead. I was extremely frustrated by not having the option to go explore side content to cool off after a half hour of failed attempts, and my inability to level up further and invest skill points into areas where the character was lacking. For a game that has you heavily invested in building up your character, throwing all of that away for a few encounters was a bit jarring to me.

When I got to the endgame I was eagerly looking to 100% the title, and moved into New Game + to do so. Several achievements were broken for me and I had to replay the game multiple times to reset some progress and try again at getting it to pop. A few of the playspaces were also a bit too sprawling without much content to fill the spaces in between after the story had been completed. Backtracking to find missed collectibles and mini-bosses got a bit frustrating as in many cases there wasn't a way to skip annoying parkour or round-about sections (though the addition of fast-travel was very welcome).

Overall Star Wars: Jedi Survivor is an incredible title that I wholeheartedly recommend everyone should play. Though not without playing Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order first of course!
I think overall I preferred the fallen order for story but this game for the gameplay.

Jedi Survivor expanded on the story line of Jedi Fallen Order almost perfectly. The game gives you the option to go between side stories and the main story line perfectly. Boss fights are perfectly set when it comes to the difficulty that has been chosen by the player. Plenty of collectibles and ways to personalize your character and his gear. The game was in my opinion a great experience.

I am writing this right after the nth crash today alone. I would write about the game, but any enjoyment I start to get is interrupted with a crash. I attempted to look past the performance issues and push forward. This game is, by far, the most unstable game I have played this year. I've played a lot of K-T games this year, so that's definitely saying something.

I am fortunate enough to have a 13900k, 4090, and 64GB of DDR5 RAM, The game still can't maintain a solid 60fps, stutters constantly, and still has stutters when changing areas. One of these areas being during a platforming section where you have to jump onto a zipline. What god awful timing for a consistent stutter. Does it ever get any better? No, it doesn't get any better. You start the game on a linear path and might wonder what everybody is complaining about. Once you get to the open world segment, all these issues explode in your face.

I'm not sure if the performance issues or crashing are worse now. Bad performance is one thing, but I cannot progress in the game because the game decided to only save a meditation points. That would be absolutely fine if the game did not crash constantly. Most of my playtime is retreading ground I have already covered. The shortcuts do not help because you have to reach them to be helpful.

This game is currently in a god awful state. If you think PC gamers are being performance snobs, then feel free to buy it. It takes over two hours to get to the point where the game starts to crash consistently. This game should not have been released in this state and I cannot recommend a game you can't play.

EDIT: The game crashes on the ending every time still even after Patch 4. Worst port of 2023 by far.

EDIT #2: Crashing has been fixed as of Patch 7 (9/5/2023) and framerate is much better. Be warned, my HW is a 13900k, 4090, and 64GB DDR5. So this review is only for people with too much money to burn.

This game takes everything that fans loved about Fallen Order and improves upon it. After going back and playing the series' first installment, it was made immediately apparent what game-play and quality of life changes were made in Survivor; from the addition of a fast travel system, to a fun list of new lightsaber stances and abilities, to a more intuitive feel to the game's overall platforming, just to name a few. 

The game allows you the freedom to explore the open-world setting, without it feeling like a chore or isolating you from the actual story. The random chance encounters with roaming AT-ST and imperial squads give the game a more dynamic feeling and really help to build an atmosphere of a galaxy-at-siege by a brutish empire. The story is incredibly captivating and some of the best canonical Star Wars content we've received in years.

While the initial launch was plagued by a number of bugs and graphical issues, Respawn Entertainment has really worked hard to address these and improve the game's overall performance. If you're a fan of the first game or just a Star Wars fan in general, I highly recommend getting this game.
